title: FARM PRICES OFF BY 3% FOR MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Prices farmers receive for raw agricultural products fell 3 per cent from Nov. 15 to Dec. 15, the first decline in three months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: WOUNDED DOCTOR KILLS ASSAILANT
description: HADDON HEIGHTS, Dec. 31 (UPI)A podiatrist who was shot five times during a holdup at his home here today shot and killed one masked man and may have wounded another, the police reported.

title: F.D.A. Seized 25 Million Birth Control Pills in Dispute Over Advertisements
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The largest seizure of a single prescription drug in the history of the Food and Drug Administration took place recently in an action against a concern at Pearl River, N. Y.

title: Hunter Among Richest Athletes
description: Although there were no announcements yesterday as to all the specifics of the contract Jim (Catfish) Hunter signed with the New York Yankees, it was reported that the total value of the complicated, multiyear deal was $3.75million.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND TO AID BURMAH OIL
description: LONDON, Dec. 31The British Government, through the Bank of England, is going to the rescue of the Burmah Oil Company, which said tonight it expected to show a big loss on its tanker operations.

title: Market Place
description: Has a corporation a reason for being other than to serve its shareholders?

title: Population at 213,203,059
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. ReutersThe United States will have a population estimated at 213,203,059 persons on New Year's day the Census Bureau said today. This is an increase of 0.7 per cent, or 1,600,000 persons, from the population at the start of 1974, the bureau said. The population also increased by 0.7 per cent in 1973.

title: Glossary of Gold Terms
description: BULLION: Gold in bar, wafer or other unworked form, valued purely for itself rather than for its decoraitve or coinage worth.

title: BREZHNEV AILING, EGYPTIANS HEAR
description: CAIRO, Dec. 31  Informed diplomats said today that the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, had told Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt that he had been forced by ill health to postpone his visit to the Middle East.

title: Snowfall in Early Evening Snarls Homebound Traffic
description: The expected rain turned to unexpected snow and sleet in parts of central and northern New Jersey last evening, giving homeward bound commuters something to contend with before they headed for any planned New Year's Eve celebration.

title: Farm Prices Decline
description: Prices farmers receive for raw agricultural products fell 3 per cent from Nov. 15 to Dec. 15, the first decline in three months, the Agriculture Department reported. Page 23.

title: 3 Arabs Killed
description: Yesterday, the Israeli military command said that three Arab guerrillas crossed the border from Lebanon tonight and were killed by a patrol.

title: Britain, in New Peace Bid, Will Free Some in Ulster
description: LONDON, Dec. 31  Britain announced today that she would release a number of political prisoners in Northern Ireland.

title: Huskers Winners In Bowl
Night Mayor's Office Falls From Favor Into Oblivion
description: Born nine years ago with fanfare and pizazz, the city's Night Mayor program officially and quietly slipped into limbo last Friday, without announcement.

title: Willimantic Tries to Carry On, Even Without a City Payroll
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 31Today, on the last day that this City received funds with which to function, Mayor David Calchera said the government would soldier on for a while, even without money if necessary.

title: Few New Yorkers Get Gold Fever
People and Business
description: Geoffrey H. Moore, an economist charged with classifying stages of the business cycle, yesterday joined the list of Americans declaring that the country is in a recession.

title: Article 2  No Title
FRANCE DISSOLVES RADIOTV AUTHORITY
description: PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 1France's centralized broadcasting system went out of existence last night, to be replaced With seven stateowned television and radio companies designed to improve programming through competition.

title: Ford Signs Bills to Spur New Jobs And Expand Unemployment Benefits
Obituary 2  No Title
description: MRS. EDWIN PETERSON

title: CALLAGHAN ARRIVES for TALKS IN ZAMBIA
description: LIVINGSTONE, Zambia, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Foreign Minister James Callaghan arrived in Zambia today for talks with Rhodesian nationalist leaders.

title: Miami Philharmonic in a Crisis As Financier Quits as President
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 Maurice Gusman, the Miami financier, resigned today as president of the Greater Miami Philharmonic Society, Inc., plunging the institution into its worst crisis since it was formed in 1926 under the aegis of the University of Miami.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A Farewell to 74 Bade With Abandon
description: In spite of freezing rains that soaked hornbiowers in Times Square and sloshed into wine in Central Park, New Yorkers bade a boisterous farewell last night to a year of inflation, recession and Watergate scandals and ushered in 1975.

title: Connors, Newcombe Gain Aussie Net Final
Nixon Foundation Drops Library Plan
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 31The Richard M. Nixon Foundation is preparing to disband and abandon its ambitious plan, introduced in 1969, to build a library and museum costing $8million to $12million as a memorial to the former President's historic achievements.

title: Soviet Jewish Doctor Gets 8 Years in a Bribery Case
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31Mikhail Shtern, a Jewish physician whose arrest and trial have attracted Western attention, was sentenced today by a Ukrainian court to eight years in a labor camp on charges of swindling and bribetaking, his elder son, Viktor, reported.

title: About New York
description: There are New Yorkers in pain today, suffering from hangovers. It is too late to prevent the hangovers, and other than making resolutions they will not keep about never getting hangovers again, there is not much the New Yorkers will do with their hangovers except to suffer them. Still, hope springs, and there are supposed to be better ways.

title: Governor Carey
description: Last night in Albany, Hugh Carey took the oath of office as Governor of the State of New York in a private ceremony held early enough for his youngest children to observe the occasion and still have time to get a good night's sleep. The sensible human instincts which led Governor Carey to shape his oathtaking as he did should stand him in good stead during the next four years, for all that can be said with certainty about the Governor's future is that it is bound to be difficult.

title: Who Was Subversive?
description: The horrors of the Nixon Administration were hardly confined to the White House, as former Attorney General John N. Mitchell would have had everyone believe. One of the Justice Department horrors of Mr. Mitchell's lawandorder years is gradually coming to light in a North Carolina courtroom.

title: And Vail Is Not Exactly an Exciting Spot for Social Life
Florida Senator Named
Colby Said to Confirm C.I.A. Role in U.S
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Central Intelligence Agency has told President Ford that its agents maintained thousands of files on American citizens and participated in a wide program of electronic surveillances, breakins and the surreptitious inspection of mail inside the United States, wellplaced Government sources said today.

title: Suit Over Haircut and Job
Italian Insurers Now Covering Ransom
description: ROME, Dec. 31Italian insurance companies are not advertising it yet, but they almost routinely write policies now covering the ransom paid to kidnappers.

title: The Dance
description: David Blair's clear and unaffected production of Giselle appeared yesterday afternoon for the first time in American Ballet Theater's current season at the City Center 55th Street Theater. It was designed for the New York State Theater and it looks a little cramped on the City Center stage. But it is no great matter, and some of the dramatic detail actually gains from this enforced closer focus.

title: Venezuela to the Fore
description: One of the more dramatic events of 1974 in the Western Hemisphere was the signing this week of an agreement to restore diplomatic relations between Cuba and Venezuela. Yet this was only one in a series of actions by the Government in Caracas to carve out a new leadership role for itselfin South and Central America as well as in the Caribbean.

title: Hearing Is Scheduled
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 31 (AP)The New Hampshire Supreme Court will hear arguments Friday seeking invalidation of the state's disputed Senatorial election. The hearing was prompted by a suit filed by Louis C. Wyman in Superior Court that alleges widespread irregularities and seeks to have a runoff election called on that ground.

title: Tillman Has Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Rusty Tillman, a Washington Redskin linebacker, underwent surgery today to repair torn knee ligaments prior to an operation for a shoulder separation next week, Dr. James Palumbo, the team physician, performed the 90minute operation at suburban Arlington Hospital.

title: L.I.R.R Posts Rise In Passenger Total; Subways Off Here
description: The Metrapolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday that the number of passengers on the Long Island Rail Road averaged 225,000 on weekdays during the first half of 1974.

title: POLICE IN HOUSTON DEFIANT ON HIRING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The police chief of Houston said today that he had no intention of hiring former convicts to serve beside his men despite demands of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Ariosto Is Hero of Poemsand Menus, Too
description: With the exuberance of the poetry they celebrated, an international gathering of scholars paid homage this week at Columbia University to Ludovico Ariosto and his most famous work, Orlando Furioso.

title: Business Briefs
description: The First Women's Bank of New York, now in formation has officially asked the Federal Deposit Insbrance Corporation to permit it to start operations with less than the $4million in capital it expected to raise, the Government agency disclosed yesterday.

title: Sniper's Classmate Says Guns Were Whole Life
More Police Authorized
description: BUENOS AIRES (UPI)The Argentine Government has authorized the federal police to hire 3,000 new policemen to keep up with the increased work load. Federal police handle most crime control in Buenos Aires and do specialized jobs throughout the country.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY JANUARY 1, 1975

title: Economy's Next 25 Years
STEINGUT TO END INSURANCE TIES
Holiday Closings Set
description: All securities, commodity and currency exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today for the New Year's holiday.

title: 2 Retarded Women Lost Since Outing
description: Two mentally retarded women in their 50's have been missing since they got lost in a crowd at Madison Square Garden Monday afternoon. They were part of a group of 35 from the Willowbrook Mental Developmental Center on Staten Island who were taken by bus for a performance of Pinocchio in the Felt Forum.

title: Beefimport Compromise Is Announced by the U.S.
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TIME TRIPPING Inside an old clocktower far off the beaten track for such institutions, art and government are handmaidens in the operation of one of the city's more unusual galleries. Its name, appropriately enough, is the Clocktower: and it, is an arm of the Institute for Art and Urban Resources, which fosters contemporary art and the viewing thereof.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Dec. 31, 1974

title: Pension Controls Ease as U.S. Law Takes Effect
Seals Bow, 43, To Wings
The World in 1974: A Pictorial Review
description: Petroleum became the overriding political and economic force last year, with effects that radiated from the Mideast around the world.

title: Ivan S. Beritashvili, 90, Soviet Physiologist, Dies
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (UPI)Ivan S. Beritashvili, a leading Soviet physiologist who once was the focus of a dispute about reconciling medicine and Marxism, has died at the age of 90, Pravda, the organ of the Communist party, reported today.

title: Scofflaws Line Up on Deadline to Prevent the Loss of Car Registration
description: There were 268 persons in long lines before the oldfashioned teller's windows in the gloomy old bank building at 51 Chambers Street yesterday, and they had to be among the unhappiest depositors in town.

title: PHONE RATE RISE PUT OFF IN JERSEY
Music: Cosmic Jam, a Mixed Program
description: The pretentiousness and the ludicrousness of late nineteensixties rockjazzclassicalethnic mixes was reborn Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall, with a program by Anthony Newman and friends called Cosmic Jam.

title: Beame Signs Bill To Protect Elderly On Rent Control
description: Mayor Beame signed a bill into law yesterday exempting elderly persons on fixed incomes from rent increases in rentcontrolled and rentstabilized apartments.

title: 1974 Is Over Not a Day Too Soon
description: Kynge Henry toke a surfet by etynge of a lamprey, & thereof dyed, according to an English chronicle of 1513, alluding to the death of Henry VII four years earlier. Just such a surfeit, albeit of not fatal proportions, was suffered by many Americans in 1974, they having either been pelted by an excess of modern eels, or obliged in one way pr another to ingest, by sight and sound, a superfluity of eely substances.

title: DERAILMENT CUTS POWER TO 30,000
28 Die in Mecca of Cholera
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 31 (UPI)Twentyeight Nigerians who went to Mecca in Saudi Arabia for the Moslem pilgrimage have died of cholera, the Saudi Arabian Health Ministry said today in a statement broadcast by Riyadh radio.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MannedBalloon Flight Across Atlantic Set
2 BLASTS DAMAGE ROCKEFELLER BANKS
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Powerful bombs blasted two branches of the Rockefellerowned Chase Manhattan Bank today in what the police said was an apparent protest against the vacation here of Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Withholding of Tax for Social Security Will Resume Today
description: WASHINGTON, Dec.31 (UPI) Middle and upperincome workers face 5.85 per cent cuts in takehome pay beginning tomorrow, when withholding for Social Security taxes resumes. For a worker earnmg $15,000 a year, that means there will be about $17 less in this week's pay envelope.

title: Extension of Revenue Sharing Urged
description: A Federal panel has recommended that President, Ford press the 94th Congress to extend the Federal general revenuesharing program to late 1982 at an additional cost of $40.7billion.

title: Yankees Sign Up Catfish Hunter In Estimated $3.75Million Deal
71 MEMO REPORTS 3 STATE OFFICIALS BACKED BERGMAN
10 Killed by Avalanche In an Austrian Resort
description: BLUDENZ, Austria, Dec. 31 (Reuters) Ten skiers were killed today when an avalanche cascaded down a mountainside in Austria's second serious winter sports accident in two weeks.

title: Pension Controls Ease as U.S. Law Takes Effect
description: Pension and welfare plans affecting millions of New Yorkers are starting off the new year with less supervision as a result of a Federal law that goes into effecte today.

title: The World in 1974:
description: Petroleum became the overriding political and economic force last year, with effects that radiated from the Mideast around the world.

title: Past and Future
description: To bid farewell to 1974 is in many ways a relief. It was a year of drama and trauma. But as the American people turn their eyes to the future while walking away from the political debris of 1974, they can hardly be cheered by the economic and political prospects of the new year.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Mills's Statement Pleases Folks Back in Arkansas
GOLD SALES FIND SCANT RESPONSE FROM U.S. BUYERS
description: America's widely heralded gold rush turned into a walk yesterday as only a scattering of investors and speculators took advantage of their new freedom to buy gold.

title: Trading Begins in Gold Futures On 4 Leading U.S. Exchanges
description: Gold futures trading opened yesterday on four leading exchanges in what experts called the largest voltune on any exchange for the opening day of a new contract.

title: People in Sports
Real Factory Pay Here in 1974 Cut 5.1% by Inflation and Taxes
description: The real spendable earnings of New York City factory workersthat is, what they have left to live on after inflation and taxes take their bitesfell 5.1 per cent in 1974, the largest drop since such computations began in 1950, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: It's Not Exactly a Winter White House'
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 30President Ford's rented home during his Christmas skiing vacation here is already being called the new Western White House, but many Vailites say It doesn't fit the image.

title: Ethiopia Announces A Full Nationalization
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Wednesday, Jan. 1 (Reuters) Ethiopia's military rulers today announced the nationalization of all land, financial institutions and insurance companies.

title: Communists Take A 6th District Town In Vietnam Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Dec. 31 (AP)North Vietnamese forces spearheaded by tanks overran a South Vietnamese district town 75 miles north of Saigon today, the military command announced.

title: S.E. C. PLANS RULE ON GOLD DEALINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a new rule today designed to maintain brokendealer financial responsibility in gold transactions and set standards for the custody and handling of the metal.

title: Bouts Halted at Forum, A Scene of Outbreaks
HALDEMAN TAPES REPLAYED BY JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The jury at the Watergate coverup trial deliberated for a second day today without reaching a verdict.

title: Withholding of Tax for Social Security Will Resume Today
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31Middle and upperincome workers face 5.85 per cent cuts in takehome pay beginning tomorrow, when withholding for Social Security taxes resumes.

title: Two Mortgage Rates Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Potential homebuyers got interest rate reductions from two key government institutions today.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BACK FROM CHINA: Helen Boehm, widow of Edward Marshall Boehm, manufacturer of porcelain bird sculptures, with a handpainted bowl presented to her on recent trip. Mrs. Boehm was invited at request of Chinese porcelain experts who admired a Boehm piece presented to Mao Tsetung by former President Nixon.

title: A. T. & T. Files for a $600Million Debt Issue
description: Trading was light in fixedincome markets yesterday, with shortterm attention fixed upon New Year's Eve and longterm thoughts dwelling more soberly on the huge financing calendar ahead for 1975.

title: Yankees Sign Up Catfish Hunter In Estimated $3.75Million Deal
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter signed a fiveyear contract estimated at $3.75million with the New York Yankees last night, ending the most celebrated bidding war in American sports history. The total value of the pact sets a record for baseball.

title: Cartier's Left Open, But Nothing Is Gone
description: A wouldbe customer walked into Cartier's at 4:35 P.M., yesterday and found nobody home.

title: Mayor Denies Slain Youth Had a Conviction for Rape
description: LONG BRANCH, Dec. 31Mayor Henry R. Cioffi tonight termed incorrect reports indicating that an unarmed 16yearold shot dead here by the police on Dec. 8 had a juvenile conviction for rape.

title: Penn State to Wear Ford WIN Buttons
REAL FACTORY PAY SHRINKS 5.1% HERE
description: The real spendable earnings of New York City factory workersthat is, what they have left to live on after inflation and taxes take their bitesfell 5.1 per cent in 1974, the largest drop since such computations began in 1950, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CAREY IS SWORN IN AS 51ST GOVERNOR
Bus Moves Careys To Albany Mansion
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31Governorelect Hugh L. Carey today did what any father would do when faced with moving 12 children, one Labrador retriever, thred hockey sticks, a basketball a case or soda and a dozen or so trunks and suitcases to a new house.

title: Rutgers Police Tell Why They Want to Be Armed
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThe Rutgers University Campus Patrol has given the University administration an inchthick report that it believes supports its contention that it be given the right to carry weapons 24 hours a day.

title: Rifleman Kills a Mailman in Cohoes, then Invades Police Station, Shooting 2
description: COHOES, N.Y., Dec. 31A mailman was shot to death on a sidewalk here today, and the police said that his alleged assailant later appeared at Police Headquarters and shot a policeman and his superior. The gunman was then captured.

title: 1,000 ATTEND RITE for SLAIN OFFICER
description: More than 1,000 policemen joined city officials and relatives yesterday at the funeral of Police Officer Kenneth A. Mahon at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Astoria, Queens, to pay their last respects to the slain policeman.

title: Britain, in New Peace Bid, Will Free Some in Ulster
description: LONDON, Dec. 31  Britain announced today that she would release a number of political prisoners in Northern Ireland.

title: Israeli Forces Raid 2 Lebanon Villages; 6 Houses Blown Up
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Jan. 1Israeli forces entered two villages approximately a mile across the Lebanese border at about midnight, blew up six houses and took six prisoners, Israeli military headquarters here announced this morning.

title: 2 in Sect Die in Plane Crash
description: FAIRCHANCE, Pa, Dec. 31 (UPI)Two members of the Society of Brothers, a religious group, were killed yesterday when their singleengine airplane crashed into a mountainous area five miles south of this Fayette County community. The victims were identified as Dwight Blough, 40 years old, of Farmington, Pa., and Jerry Kadish, of Norfolk, Conn.

title: St. John's Crew Upsets N.Y. A. C.
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Dec. 31St. John's University's eightoared crew upset the New York Athletic Club today in the annual New Year's Eve regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Orchard Beach Lagoon.

title: CODE BOARD TO MEET ON FAMILY TV FARE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31A special meeting of the Television Code Revieiv Board of the National Association of Broadcasters has been called to consider a proposal to reserve the first hour of network evening shows to programs suitable for family viewing.

title: Minnesota Mining Had $634,000 Fund for Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company acknowledged today that it had kept a $634,000 political fund, that it was facing a grand jury investigation for criminal tax exasion and that the company could be assessed $11million in back taxes and penalties.

title: Oilers Buy Kennett
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Dec. 31 (AP)The Edmonton Oilers purchased Murray Kennett, a defenseman, today from the Indianapolis Racers in a World Hockey Association transaction. Bill Hunter, the general manager, said the Oilers obtained Kennett with the provision that the Racers could buy him back in the future.

title: Falling Prey to Parodies of the Press
RETARDED WOMEN FOUND UNHARMED
description: Two mentally retarded women in their 50's who had been missing since Monday afternoon when they got lost in a crowd at Madison Square Garden were found by authorities last night, apparently none the worse for their experience.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 22yearold woman charged with helping her boyfriend kill his mother was in fair condition at Memorial General Hospital in Union after an apparent suicide attempt, the police said.

title: 2 BLASTS DAMAGE ROCKEFELLER BANKS
Bears Hire Pardee as Head Coach
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP)Jack Pardee, who coached the payless Florida Blazers into the title game of the World Football League, was named today coach of the Chicago Bears in hopes of leading the National Football League team back to respectability.

title: Sniper's Classmate Says Guns Were Whole Life
description: OLEAN, N.Y., Dec. 31Guns, that was his whole life, Jeff Lampack said today of his fellowstudent, Anthony Barbaro, the 17yearold highschool senior who was seized here yesterday as the sniper who killed three people and wounded nine.

title: 3 Bowl Games on Tap Today
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31Tomorrow's Rose Bowl game between Ohio State and Southern California is one of those contests Mil of elements (Channel 4, 5 P.M.).

title: 1974: Woes for Stock Market Mixed With Inflation and Layoffs
L.I.R.R. Posts Rise In Passenger Total; Subways Off Here
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday that the number of passengers on the Long Island Rail Road averaged 225,000 on weekdays during the first half of 1974.

title: GOLD SALES FIND SCANT RESPONSE FROM U.S. BUYERS
description: America's widely heralded gold rush turned into a walk yesterday as only a scattering of investors and speculators took advantage of their new freedom to buy gold.

title: PRICES OF GOLD SLIDE IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, Dec. 31Gold prices fell sharply today on the European bullion markets, reflecting profit taking by speculators and a newly cautious attitude about the impact of legalized gold ownership in the United States.

title: SCHOOL CLOSING SOUGHT IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31Ranking city and state police officials called today for the permanent closing of the South Boston High School complex, saying they had information that the situation there was more dangerous than ever.

title: Report Says Slow TaxBase Rise Hurts Cities School Financing
Miss Lies Gains By Default at Net
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Dec. 31  Unseeded Donna Lies of Springfield, N. J., advanced by default to the girls 16yearsoldandunder final of the Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today. Her opponent, topseeded Caroline Stoll of Livingston, N. J., had to withdraw because of a virus.

title: School Suit Plaintiffs Want State Court To Tell Legislature to Pass Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31  The plaintiffs in the successful legal attack on New Jersey's system of financing public schools said today that they would ask the State Supreme Court tomorrow to order the State Legislature to approve a state income tax, despite the fact that few legislators believe the court has that power.

title: Blazer Has Bone Surgery
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 31 (UPI)Larry Steele, Portland Trail Blazer starting guard, underwent surgery today for a fractured bone in his right cheek. The Blazers said Steele would miss four games, all at home, and would not see action until after Jan. 14.

title: One Hurt as Crane Topples
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP)A construction crane fell 25 floors to a downtown street yesterday minutes before offices emptied for lunch. Tons of steel crashed to the street when the 260foot crane broke, but the police said the only person hurt was a crane operator, Michael Hager, 46 years old, who received superficial cuts.

title: Children Out of School
description: A recent study demonstrates that profound rigidities In many of America's school systems are depriving millions of the nation's children of education and piling up future disasters for society as a whole. The study, conducted by the Children's Defense Fund, was designed to go behind the 1970 census report that nearly two million children aged 7 to 17 were out of school, to find out who those children were and why they were not in school.

title: Notes on People
description: Already plagued by repeated displays of their American debut, Valery PanolY. and his wife, Galina Ragozina, the emigre. Russian ballet dancers, must now show cause Friday in State Sumeine Court why they should not be barred from giving performancesbeyond those scheduled in Philadelphia and Los Angelesexcept under the management of Maxim Gershunoff. The impresario named the Pariovs lawyer, Ellis .I. Freedman, as defendant in his suit, charging that he had sent out letters Dec. 12 to announce that Kr. Gershunoff no longer represented the couple. The manager said he signed a twoyear contract with them july 12 in Israel and had boked a 30appearance tours but received a letter from a doctor Dec. 9 saying that Mr. Panov would be unable to dance for six weeks. He, agked the court, to appoint two doctors to examine Mr. Panov for any injury that would prevent him from dancing.

title: HOME OF BLACKS STRUCK BY BUM
Colby Said to Confirm C.I.A. Role in U.S.
Woman Is Dragged From Blazing Room By Fire Lieutenant
description: A 40yearold fire lieutenant dragged a seemingly dead Brooklyn woman from her burning apartment yesterday and, with other firemen, worked for 20 minutes before getting a response from the victim to heart massage and mouthtomouth resuscitation.

title: BREZHNEV AILING, EGYPTIANS HEAR
description: CAIRO, Dec. 31 Informed diplomats said today that the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, had told Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt that he had been forced by ill health to postpone his visit to the Middle East.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Baseball's winter freeagent draft will be held here Jan. 9, with about 250 players expected to be selected. San Diego gets the first choice, followed by California as the 24 major league teams choose in reverse order of their 1974 records. The draft is held in two phases, the first for new men, the secondary for players drafted last summer who did not sign but still are eligible to be selected. In the secondary phase, the order of selection was determined by a drawing made by the league presidents, with Philadelphia getting first pick and Kansas City last. The last meeting saw 257 selections made, but there may be more this time because of a recent rule that permits collegians to be drafted who have reached the age of 21 or who will be that old within 45 days of the draft.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: LELAND SMITH

title: ZELLERBACH BUYS S, T, CORP, ASSETS
description: The Crown Zelleerbach Corporation, one of the nation's largest paper companies, disclosed yesterday that it had exercised its option to purchase all the assets of the S. T. Corporation for about $145  million in cash and notes. The assets include 184,000 acres of prime timberland in northern Louisiana plus lumber and plywood facilities near Joyce, La. These were purchased by the S. T. Corporation, an affiliate of Lehman Brothers, Inc., investment bankers, from the Tremont Lumber Company last July. At that time Crown Zellerbach had paid $40million for an additional 33,000 acres of the timberland, a sawmill and interests in producing oil properties, which are pumping out 1,000 barrels of crude monthly. A spokesman for the paper company said this is a minor producing area and that the property had been purchased mainly for the timber on the lands.

title: India and Portugal Resume Ties After 19 Years
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 31India and Portugal today reestablished diplomatic relations after a break of nearly 20 years.

title: Eastman Kodak Is Set To Raise Its Prices
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday announced that it would raise prices on nearly all its cameras, projectors and movie cameras, an average of 7 per cent on Feb. 1. The company also increased the price of all its photo chemicals by an average of 11 per cent, effective last Friday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY JANUARY 1, 1975

title: Beame, O'Dwyer, Sutton and Leone To Contribute Part of Pay to the City
description: Mayor Beame, Council President Paul O'Dwyer and Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan announced yesterday that they would contribute a percentage of their salaries to the city to ease the present budget crisis. Each has already sent in the first installment.

title: Wilson Names Battista to Architecture Council
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31 Vito P. Battista, the outspoken RepubIican Assemblyman from Brooklyn who was defeated for reelection, Was appointed by Governor Wilson today to the State Council on Architecture.

title: HALDEMAN TAPES REPLAYED BY JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The jury at the Watergate coverup trial deliberated for a second day today without reaching verdict.

title: Simonetta Bulgarelli Wed to P. A. Meisels
description: Simonetta Bulgarelli, owner and operator of the Farm House Stables, N. Y., was married last night to Peter Alexander Meisels, a trial lawyer, who is senior counsel to the Legal Aid Society of Westchester County.

title: Minnesota Mining Had $634,000 Fund for Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company acknowledged today that it had kept a $634,000 political fund, that it was facing a grand jury investigation for criminal tax exasion and that the company could be assessed $11million in back taxes and penalties.

title: A New Yet Traditional Market Thrives in Nigeria
description: ONITSHA, Nigeria, Dec. 24In his new concrete market stall that caught the breezes this morning from the nearby Niger River, Daniel Agbaizu handground snuff from a mixture of tobacco leaves and potash.

title: Strike at Laurel
description: Labor disputes shut down one Eastern track and threatened to close another while a settlement was reached at a third yesterday as thoroughbred racing's winter merrygoround prepared to limp into the New Year.

title: Paul Griffith, Retired General, ExLegion Chief, U.S. Aide, Dies
description: Paul H. Griffith, a retired brigadier general who had served as national commander of the American Legion and as Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Truman Administration, died Sunday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 76 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Sauce for the Gander
description: PARISThe Middle East problem has become measurably more complicated during the past year. We don't know if Leonid Brezhnev will be a harbinger of trouble and further brinkmanship if he eventually goes to Cairo after deferring his trip, perhaps because of poor health.

title: PANEL WILL STUDY SENATE ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31A Senate subcommittee dominated by Democrats announced today that it would hold hearings next week to try to determine the winner of a contested New Hampshire senatorial election.

title: Quake's Toll in Pakistan Climbs to 5,200
description: PATTAN, Pakistan, Dec. 31 (AP)The death toll in northern Pakistan's earthquake was estimated at 5,200 today, up 500, with the discovery of two more mountain villages practically destroyed in the disaster Saturday.

title: Gould, Inc., Settles Suit Over Purchase of ITE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (UPI)Gould, Inc., said today it had settled a suit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission over its purchase of securities of the ITE Imperial Corporation.

title: MannedBalloon Flight Across Atlantic Set
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31The new year's first aeronautical adventure will seek to fulfill a centuryold dream of a mannedballoon flight across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
Bridge:
description: A claimant for the title of the world's biggest bridge book becomes available todayalthough some might argue its credentials. The veteran authorpublisher George Coffin of Waltham, Mass., has taken his four most significant works and created a 960page paperback volume entitled Bridge Play. ($12.95 257 Trapelo Road, Waltham, Mass. 02154).

title: Final Evidence Submitted At Hearing on Sioux Treaty
Bus Moves Careys To Albany Mansion
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31Governorelect Hugh L. Carey today did what any father would do When faced with moving. 12 children, one Labrador retriever, three hockey sticks, a basketball, a Case or soda and a dozen or so trunks and suitcases to a new house.

title: Books of The Times
description: Martin Mayer's The Bankers tries to answer every question about money we ever, thought to ask plus a good many that most most of us wouldn't know enough to phrase.

title: Hispanic Post Filled
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Community Affairs Commissioner Patricia Q. Sheehan announced the appointment today of Carlos Veguilla of Jackson Township to head the new Office of Hispanic Affairs in the Division of Human Resources. Mr. Veguilla is a native of Puerto Rico. The agency will coordinate funds for use by Spanishspeaking community groups, Mrs. Sheehan said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Korn yesterday temporarily blocked a Police Department order that would have required all police officers to begin wearing name tags on their uniforms tomorrow. He acted at the request of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which had contended that the tags were inflammable and dangerous to wear.

title: Fulbright Says U.S. May Be Facing Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31Today was his last day. He may not have his name on the door any longer, a guard said, pointing to Room 1215.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Erupts; Spews Lava in a 3Mile Rift
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 31The southeast slope of the 13,680foot Mauna Loa volcano erupted today, sending fountains of molten lava up to 300 feet in the air for almost four hours along a threemile rift in the 13,680foot volcano on the island of Hawaii.

title: Vegetarians Attack Drive To Raise Meat Consumption
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  A vegetarian group accused the Agriculture Department today of causing rather rather than stopping world starvation by promoting consumption of meat.

title: Clemson Five Routs Fla. Southern, 9273
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Dec. 31 (UPI)  Clemson's Tigers, using superior height, speed and balanced scoring, led all the way today to overwhelm Florida Southern, 9273, in the first meeting between the teams.

title: Cities and States Are Given Reprieve On WageHour Law
Miki Sees Middle Eastern Crisis And Inflation as Key 75 Issues
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 1premier Takeo Miki in his New Year message told the Japanese people today that the troubled situation in the Middle East and inflation were the greatest, Issues facing Japan and the world in 1975.

title: Article 1  No Title
Jacob Adler, Yiddish Humorist And Prolific Writer, Dies at 101
description: Jacob Adler, a Yiddish humorist whose contributions under the name of B. Kovner were a regular feature of The Jewish Daily Forward, died in a nursing home in St. Petersburg, Fla., yesterday. He was 101 years old and lived at nearby Gulfport.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Willimantic Tries to Carry On, Even Without a City Payroll
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 31Today, on the last day that this city received funds with which to function, Mayor David Calchera said the government would soldier on for a while, even without money if necessary.

title: U.S. Junior Six Loses
description: FARGO, N.D., Dec. 31 (UPI)Emil Meszaros scored four goals last night to lead the Swedish junior hockey team to a 73 victory over the United States in the world junior tournament. Dag Bredberg had two goals and four assists for the winners.

title: Millionaire Pitcher
description: America's sports fans after years of growing cynicism with their heroes, may not believe this, but Jim Hunter actually said that when his baseball career was over, I just want to be able to come back to Hertford to hunt, fish, farm and just be a country boy. The people in Hertford, N. C. (population 2,023), believe in James Augustus Hunter (they never call him Catfish, that hated nickname bestowed on Jim by Charles O. Finley).

title: PurseSnatching and Recovery Lead to a Reward for Neediest
description: A midtown pursesnatching ineident came to a happy ending when two young women retrieved the pocketbook with its contents intact and then suggested that a proposed reward of $100 be given in their names to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Farm Prices Decline
description: Prices farmers receive for raw agricultural products fell 3 per cent from Nov. 15 to Dec. 15, the first decline in three months, the Agriculture Department reported. Page 23.

title: Cartier's Left Open, But Nothing Is Gone
description: A wouldbe customer walked into Cartier's at 4:35 P.M., yesterday and found nobody home.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: CELIA WEISSBERGER

title: Racially Troubled High School In Boston Told to Remain Closed
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1William J. Leary, School Superintendent, today ordered the racially troubled South Boston High School Complex not to reopen tomorrow or Friday and said that a move was under way to seek its permanent closing.

title: Continued Health Perils for Workers Disputed at South Jersey Chemical Plant
description: DEEPWATER, N. J.Manuel Pollock, a frail, lively factory worker who has spent 40 of his 61 years working at the sprawling du Pont industrial complex here, suffers from bladder cancer. Surprisingly, so do a large number of othe factory workers here in Salem County, where the death rate for white males from this form of cancer is the highest in the country.

title: Markets Were Closed
description: All securities, commodity and currency exchanges in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday for the New Year's holiday.

title: A Washington Lawyer, 78, Slain in Apartment Garage
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1South Trimble Jr., a 78yearold Washington lawyer who headed the Senate Commerce Committee's staff invstigation of the crash of the Zeppelin Hindenburg in 1933, was fatally shot last night in an apparent robbery attempt in the garage or his northwest Washington apartment complex.

title: Unexpected Snow Lifts Catamount's Ski Spirits
description: HILLSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 1 for the last 10 days, the snowmaking crew at the Catamount ski area was kept on the ground in hopes the thermometer would drop low enough at night to enable it to produce piles of the precious white flakes.

title: Four Australian Navy Ships Are Aiding Stricken Darwin
description: DARWIN, Australia, Jan. 1 (Reuters)  Four Australian Navy ships carrying urgently needed supplies and manpower arrived today to help clean up this cyclonedevastated city.

title: LOUISIANA ADOPTS NEW CONSTITUTION
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 1 (UPI) Louisiana's new state Constitution, which sets forth a basic set of laws for the state's 3.5 million residents, took effect today at one minute past midnight.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Kenneth Wells Parkinson
description: A native of Washington, the 47yearold Mr. Parkinson was active for years in District of Columbia affairs.

title: Adventurous Method for Cooking Spaghetti: Wedding It to the Sauce
description: It was a comeon, of course, but uncommonly compelling. It was an advertisement of Alitalia airlines and stated in part, Unless you've been to the Trattoria di Ciccio in Amalfi, you don't know how spaghetti should taste. First, Ciccio makes a sauce with clams and olives. Next he boils some spaghetti. Then he puts both things into a paper bag, folds it shut and heats it in an oven. What comes out of that paper bag isn't just spaghetti with sauce on it. But spaghetti with sauce in it.

title: Trading on Detente
description: The Soviet press campaign against the emigration clauses in the new Trade Reform Act suggests an intention to repudiate the threeway compromise on this issue negotiated by Secretary Kissinger with Moscow and Senate leaders.

title: California Granted a Delay On Criminal Trial Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) California authorities won a temporary stay yesterday of a court order directing them to stop permitting judges who are not lawyers to preside over criminal trials.

title: Nixon Southern Strategist Is Subject of Bar Inquiry
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 1 (UPI)The South Carolina Bar Board of Grievances and Discipline is scheduled to meet Jan. 10 to discuss possible action against Harry Dent, the former White House Southern strategist.

title: Alpine Inquiry Clears 3 Of Causing Fatal Slide
description: BLUDENZ, Austria, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Three West Germans were cleared tonight of starting an avalanche that killed 12 skiers at an Alpine resort near here.

title: The Escorts of Debutantes Enjoy Their Role These Days
description: It has always been taken for granted that most debutantes loved the excitement of coming out and reveled in the glamour of a social whirl, magnificently centered upon themselves.

title: PAST COME BACK IN GEORGE JAMES
Jeeves's Creator, at Home, Reflects on Title
description: REMSENBURG, L. I., Jan. 1P. G. Wodehouse, the 93year old Britishborn humorist who was named a knight by the Queen today, began his morning by touching his toes.

title: Dr. Boris B. Rubenstein, Endocrinologist, 67, Dies
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP)Dr. Boris B. Rubenstein, an endocrinologist noted for research on the relationship between ovarian hormones and human behavior, died yesterday of heart disease. He was 67 years old.

title: Message in Bottle Tells Of a Mutiny at Sea
description: PAPEETE, Tahiti, Jan. 1 (UPI)French Polynesian authorities have found an SOS message in a bottle disclosing a mutiny aboard a Taiwan fishing trawler reported lost at sea since Dec. 19.

title: Stamps Fail to Reach Many of Eligible
description: From 34 million to 39 million Americans are eligible for food stamps, but fewer than half of them are benefiting from the program, according to a private study released Tuesday.

title: Meat and Potatoes Seen Supplanting Fringe Benefits in Industry
description: Meat and potatoes will seem more palatable than new fringe benefits to employes during the months ahead or as long as the costofliving index gallops ahead of the dollar.

title: Cotton Bowl Scoring
Gary, Ind., Confronts Steel Woes
description: GARY, Ind., Jan. 1 (AP)The decision of the United States Steel Corporation to close 10 airpolluting open hearth furnaces at its Gary Works threatens the socioeconomic stability of northwest Indiana, one of the most industrialized regions in the country.

title: U.S. and Soviet Submarines Are Said to Have Collided
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (Reuters)The Pentagon refused to comment today on a report that a United States nuclear submarine and a Soviet submarine had collided under the North Sea last November.

title: Wisconsin Indians Release Hostages and Enter Talks
description: GRESHAM, Wis., Jan. 1 (AP) A group of armed Menominee Indians took over the Alexian Brothers Noviciary early today, briefly held some hostages, then released them when officials of the noviciary agreed to meet with them the authorities said.

title: Some Thin Shafts of Sunlight Cut Through Britain's Holiday Gloom
description: LONDON, Jan. 1The nip in the air is ending one of London's warmest spells in more than 30 winters, the shoppers are crowding the sales, the Queen has a grant to repair two cottages, Mrs. Barlow is awash in flowers and Mr. Davies has his toolbox back.

title: Harry Robbins Haldeman
description: Next to the President, Mr. Haldeman was the most powerful man in the Nixon White House. A call from the chief of staff was feared by lower officials, who knew him as a brusque taskmaster who made efficiency his watchword.

title: Article 3  No Title
Minimum Wage Law Bringing Increases To the Lowest Paid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) New Year's Day brought higher wages for many of America's lowestpaid workers.

title: Robert Charles Mardian
description: Mr. Mardian headed the internal security division of the Justice Department from November, 1970, to May 1, 1972, when he resigned to join Mr. Mitchell on the President's reelection committee.

title: 50 Editors Are Named to Jury for Pulitzer Prizes
Pier in Village Burns
description: A twoalarm fire on a tarsoaked, abandoned Greenwich Village pier blazed out of control for a half hour yesterday. No injuries were reported. Fire authorities said the blaze, at Pier 51, near West and Horatio Streets, on the Hudson River was reported at 5:48 P.M.

title: TanaPrices Deadlock Keeps Fleets in Port
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)A deadlock over tuna prices kept the United States fishing fleet in port today, the traditional sailing day of the new season.

title: Sir Eagle, $9.60 Wins
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Jan. 1 (AP) Sir Eagle, with George Seabo aboard, ran five furlongs in 1:02 3/5 over a sloppy track today to take the feature race at Lincoln Downs before a crowd of 6,690. Sir Eagle paid $9.60, $5 and $3.80 after his onelength victory. Zeezer finished second and paid $5.20 and $3.60 and Clouds of Glory returned $6.60 to show.

title: Dance: Le Baiser de 74
description: The year 1974 ended with a bang, not a whimper, for New York dance. Tuesday more people attended a dance event than on any previous weekday in the history of the city.

title: Insurance for Alcoholics
description: The alcoholic now can buy lossofincome insurance to protect him when his weakness keeps him from working, the Health Insurance Institute told United Press International. The Institute says at least 17 major companies are writing such insurance. But to get it, the alcoholic must acknowledge his illness, register and place himself under medical care.

title: Trial Is Capstone of Prosecution Force
Market Basket Price Rose 13.8% Last Year
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in the city rose 13.8 per cent during the last year, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday. Its 38item Market Basket cost $64.57 last week, compared to $56.74 in the same week last year.

title: Who else Is Guilty?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1Four out of five guilty! shouted the man on the desk in the newsroom, as the bottom fell out of the lives of John Mitchell, Bob Haldeman, John Ehrlichman and Robert Mardian.

title: Of LongTerm Teachers
Douglas Has Stroke
description: Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court suffered a stroke in the Bahamas and was taken to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where he was reported in serious condition. Page 31.

title: Text of Carey inaugural Speech
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1Following is the inaugural address by Governor Carey:

title: Jersey Widow, 100, Dies In Fire Started by Candle
description: An invalid widow who celebrated her 100th birthday on Chirstmas Day died New Year's Eve when a fire, ignited by a toppled holiday candle, swept through her wooden farmhouse in Dennis Township, N.J., about 35 miles south of Atlantic City.

title: Big Board Profit Lagged while Amex Lost Money
description: Last year was hard for the nation's two biggest stock exchanges. The New York Stock Exchange's profits were sharply reduced while the American Stock Exchange lost money.

title: A New Strip Mining Bill Is Forthcoming, Udall Says
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 1 (UPI) Strip mining legislation similar to a bill pocketvetoed by President Ford will be introduced shortly after Congress convenes, according to Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona.

title: Many University Students Are Turning U.S. Food Stamps Into a Form of Scholarship
description: In the waiting room of the Dane County Social Services building on the outskirts of Madison, Wis., three bearded young men, dressed in ski jackets and blue jeans, sat reading magazines one day recently while a young woman sitting nearby was studying a college textbook.

title: Giscard Phones Ford With New Year Wishes
description: VAIL, Colo., Jan. 1 (Reuters)President Valry Giscard d'Estaing telephoned President Ford last night to wish him a happy New Year and to pledge that he would continue the cooperation they worked out during their Martinique meeting in midDecember.

title: Israel's Readiness to Talk Is Stressed by Allon
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 1Foreign Minister Yigal Allon, in the first related official Israeli comment since the postponement of the Cairo visit of the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, said today that there would be no need to coax Israel to negotiate if Egypt was really ready for significant talks.

title: Golda Meir Named As Most Admired; Betty Ford Second
description: Golda Mein, former Premier of Israel, is the most admired woman of 1974, according to a Gallup poll released yesterday. Betty Ford, wife of President Ford, won second place in the poll, and Patricia Nixon, the former First Lady, came in third.

title: Rangers Top Black Hawks, 62
description: Having built a modest winning streak mostly against patsies, the Rangers took on a genuinely strong hockey team last night in the Chicago Black Hawks, and beat them, 62. Now the streak is four in a row, the New Yorkers longest of the season.

title: Spain Must Begin Again
description: GLENELG, AustraliaGeneralissimo Francisco Franco's greatest achievement has been to have survived when so many equally brave and more brilliant men have died.

title: Ski Conditions
description: MAINE

title: Smoking Pleasure?
description: The alarming increase in cigarette smoking by girls barely into their teensdespite health warnings on packs and occasional health commercials on televisionshould alert Congress, state legislatures and city authorities that new approaches are essential to diminish this serious hazard to the nation's health.

title: U.S.C., Notre Dame Win
description: Southern California beat Ohio State in the Rose Bowl, 1817, yesterday, Notre Dame topped previously unbeaten Alabama, 1311, in the Orange Bowl and Penn State routed Baylor in the Cotton Bowl, 4120. Page 51.

title: '75 Resolution by Nessen Goes Up in Literal Smoke
description: VAIL, Colo., Jan. 1 (UPI) The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, made one of the New Year's shortestlived resolutions.

title: Ford Signs Bill to Avoid Misuse of Records on Citizens
description: VAIL, Colo., Jan. 1 (AP)President Ford signed a privacy act today intended to safeguard individuals from the misuse of Federal records, and announced that James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, will replace Roy L. Ash as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: $426Million in Contracts for F14A Go to Grumman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) The Navy has awarded contracts for $425.6million worth of F14A jet fighters to the Grumman Aerospace Corporation.

title: Wide Hunt Is Pressed for Mislabeled Pills
description: A nationwide hunt for anti epilepsy capsules in bottles labeled as aspirin went on hurriedly through New Year's Eve and most of New Year's Day, ending with a Happy New Year belief that the effort was not needed.

title: Penn State Victor Over Baylor, 4120
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1Coached to bide its time anticipating a big second half, Penn State tore into Baylor's defense after intermission today and rallied from a 73 deficit to beat the Southwest Conference champion football team, 4120. in the Cotton Bowl.

title: Eleanor Gardiner Has Nuptials Here
description: Eleanor Morris Collier Gardiner of New York, daughter of Mrs. Sargent Collier of Lake Bluff, Ill., and Bar Harbor, Me., and the late Mr. Collier was married yesterday afternoon to George H. P. Dwight, a partner in the New York law firm of Richards & O'Neil. State Supreme Court Justice Thomas R. Jones performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: JUSTICE DOUGLAS SUFFERS STROKE
Pathet Lao Said to Leave Town Seized by Hill Tribe
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 1 (AP)Defense Minister Sisouk na Champassak of Laos said today that Pathet Lao troops who had entered the town of Ban Houayxay to side with Royal Laotian Army soldiers who seized control had withdrawn to a ceasefire line 15 miles away.

title: John Daniel Ehrlichman
description: President Nixon's top domestic adviser was a classmate of Mr. Haldeman at the University of Southern California, and many viewed them as carbon copies both in personality and in outlook.

title: Pan Am Grants Mortgage
description: Pan American World Airways reports that it has granted a mortgage to secure payment of some $390million in outstanding senior debt. The action was in accord with a previously announced agreement with institutional holders of that debt.

title: People in Sports
description: Bart Starr, new head coach and general manager of the Green Bay Packers, asked for and received resignations yesterday from seven assistants and the scouting director who worked under Dan Devine, the former Packer mentor.

title: ARTICHOKE WINS THE MASCOT WAR
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 The great artichoke war has officially ended, but the controversy about college expenditures symbolized by the vegetable still smolders.

title: 800th Homicide in Detroit Sets Record for That City
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (UPI)Detroit recorded yesterday its 800th homicide of the year, which set a record for this city. The police said that there was little likelihood the pace of killings would slacken.

title: Tradition Key for Hennessey
description: Larry Hennessy, who knows what it means to play on a winning National Basketball Association team, still thinks it was tradition that made him a successful high school coach.

title: Arabs Impatient for Peace But Girded for a New War
description: The prospect of devastating conflict with Israel is frustrating the Arabs' vision of an economic renaissance made possible by their new oil wealth. Throughout the Arab world there is growing impatience for a resolution of the confrontation with Israel so that urgently needed development projects can 20 forward.

title: Democrats Enthusiastic, Republicans Are Wary
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1Governor Carey's inaugural address drew the expected enthusiastic response from Democrats attending the ceremony, while Republicans were generally cautious in their reaction, waiting for the Governor to detail his program in the State of the State message next week when the Legislature convenes.

title: City to Publish List Of 10 Worst Hotels In Welfare Range
description: The city's Department of Social Services is planning to issue a periodic listing of the 10 worst hotels that people receiving public assistance can afford.

title: Unease on Wall Street
description: It is not only the depressed state of the stock market that is causing anguish on Wall Street these days; it is the prospect of an imminent overhaul of the centuriesold mechanism for buying and selling stocks.

title: Chaplin and Wodehouse Are Knighted
description: LONDON, Jan. 1  Charlie Chaplin and P. G. Wodehouse were knighted by the Queen today. Both were named Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire (K.B.E.) in the New Year's Honors List.

title: Canadian Juniors Win in Hockey, 30
description: WINNIPEG, Ontario, Jan. 1 (UPI) Ed Staniowski blocked 29 shots today as Canada defeated Czechoslovakia, 30, in the World junior hockey tournament. The shutout by the goalie from the Regina Pats of the Western Canada League was the first in the sixcountry tournament and helped put Canada into first place with a 40 wonlost record. The Soviet Union. the only other team that can win the tournament, has a 30 record and will play Canada Sunday afternoon. At Bloomington, Minn., last night, the Soviet team defeated the United States, 31.

title: CANADA EXPANDS CARIBBEAN ROLE
Continued Health Perils for Workers Disputed at South Jersey Chemical Plant
description: DEEPWATER, N.J.Manuel Pollock, a frail, lively factory worker who has spent 40 of his 61 years working at the sprawling du Pont industrial complex here, suffers from bladder cancer. Surprisingly, so do a large number of other factory workers here in Salem County, where the death rate for white males from this form of cancer is the highest in the country.

title: STEINGUT ACCUSED OF BAR TO INQUIRY
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said here yesterday that Stanley Steingut, the Democratic leader of the Assembly, asked him in 1973 not to investitigate any nursing homes owned by Bernard Bergman, the central figure in allegations of fraud and political influence in the industry.

title: Douglas Has Stroke
description: Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court suffered a stroke in the Bahamas and was taken to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where he was reported in serious condition. Page 31.

title: Edwin E. A ldrin Sr.,78, Is Dead; Aviator Was Astronaut's Father
description: BRIELLE, N. J., Jan. 1 (AP)Edwin E. Aldrin Sr., a retired Air Force colonel who was a founder of the Aeronautical Engineering School, now the Air Force Institute of Technology, died Saturday while visiting a daughter in San Francisco. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: Customer Stood Guard At an Abandoned Cartier
description: I was confronted with a totally empty storeit was a little awesome, Gilbert Kerlin said yesterday, recalling how he had walked through the unlocked front door of Cartier, the Fifth Avenue jeweler, Tuesday afternoon and had found no one there.

title: Few Tears, a Bit of Anger As the Verdicts Are Read
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 1 There were few tears in the courtroom, and only one open display of anger, as four members of the Nixon Administration were found guilty today of taking part in a criminal conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Watergate scandal.

title: STUDENTS LEARNING HISTORY IN NEW WAY
description: NORTHRIDGE, Calif. (AP)Students at the California State University at Northridge are learning American history in a fun way.

title: Washington Lockup Eased
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., Jan. 1 (UPI)A 24hour lockup of Washington State Penitentiary inmates who seized 13 hostages in an uprising was eased today.

title: List of Major Donors and Lenders to Carey Campaign
description: Following is a list of the major contributors to the Carey campaign either in direct gifts, loans or loan guarantees. If not otherwise noted, the figure represents a contribution. The list was compiled from the Carey campaign reports.

title: Quake Jolts Alaska Area
description: PALMER, Alaska, Jan. 1 (AP)A moderate earthquake has jolted an area 40 miles north of Anchorage, rattling windows and shaking shelves. But authorities said there were no reports of injuries or major damage. Some trouble with the telephone service for a while was reported.

title: Rose Bowl Scoring
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ethiopia's Rulers Nationalize Banks, Insurance Firms
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 1 (Reuters)  Ethiopia moved further toward socialism today with the nationalization of all banks, mortgage corporations and insurance companies, many of them partly foreign owned.

title: TwoPoint Play Is Decisive in the Rose Bowl
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 Pat Haden has thrown hundreds of passes to John McKay, his high school and college classmate, in scores of practices and dozens of games. Their last one, which came today toward the end of the frenetic Rose Bowl game between Southern California and Ohio State, was the best of all.

title: Zenith to Discontinue Challenged Ad Claim
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation has agreed to discontinue the use of the challenged TV advertising claim that Every color TV Zenith makes is built right here in the United States by Americans like these. Which is nice, since it wasn't true in the first place.

title: Advertising
description: By the time 1975 ends, 1974 might look like a great year in adland. But right now, standing this close to it, it doesn't look all that hot.

title: Woman Heads Press Group
description: Ann V. Dulye of Walden, N.Y., yesterday became the first woman president of the 122yearold New York Press Association, a group of more than 200 weekly newspapers With headquarters in Syracuse. Mrs. Walden, copublisher of The Stewart Citizen and CitizenHerald of Walden, succeeds Michael Milmoe, publisher of The Canastota (N.Y.) Bee Journal.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT HELD NO PERIL TO PUBLIC
Israel Reports Attack On Guerrillas in House
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday, Jan. 2Israeli military headquarters here said today that an Israeli force searching for Arab guerrillas in southern Lebanon blew up a house with guerrillas inside it this morning after an exchange of fire.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Economists Ready With a Plan for U.S. Income Distribution
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 The huge Imperial Ballroom of the San Francisco Hilton Hotel was a happy place. Economists, meeting at their annual convention, were being told that they had, for a change, done something right.

title: Arms Sale to Iran Scored As Drain on U.S. Military
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1The multibillion  dollar American arms sales to Iran are beginning to impose a drain on critical military skills needed by the United States armed forces, the General Accounting Office has found.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Paul R. Screvane, president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, said that he would not press to open a new OTB branch office on East 79th Street. Mr. Screvane earlier this week had said he was determined to open more branches in an area east of Fifth Avenue from 59th to 86th Street. But when he sought community suggestions for a site on 79th Street, he ran into vigorous opposition on the ground that an OTB branch would Lower the residential quality of the area.

title: Widow, 100, Dies as a Candle Starts a Fire in Her Farmhouse
description: An invalid widow who celebrated her 100th birthday on Christmas Day died New Year's Eve when a fire, ignited by a toppled holiday candle, swept through her wooden farmhouse in Dennis Township, about 35 miles south of Atlantic City.

title: So. California Rallies to Beat Ohio State, 1817; Irish Thwart Alabama, 1311, in Orange Bowl
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1In a dramatic college coaching farewell for Ara Parseghian, Notre Dame surprised previously unbeaten Alabama, 1311, in the Orange Bowl tonight.

title: State Audit Says District Bought Unneeded Texts
description: An audit by State Controller Arthur Levitt's office has found that Community School District 1, on the Lower East Side, purchased new textbooks during 197172 and 197273 when it had more than 118,000 unused books of the same or equivalent kind worth about $160,000.

title: Newcombe Vanquishes Connors
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP)John Newcombe, saying the had been well psyched up, defeated Jimmy Connors, 75, 36, 64, 76, in the final of the Australian open tennis championships today.

title: Most Cited in Scandals Pleaded Guilty
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 1 While more than 60 individuals and corporations have been convicted or pleaded guilty to criminal charges growing out of the Watergate scandals, only a handful have gone on trial.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The person who decides he or she has a hearing loss and then goes out and buys a hearing aid is practicing medicine without a licenseand may be the victim.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The third suspect wanted in the shooting and attempted robbery of a Camden County podiatrist walked into the Haddon Heights police headquarters and gave himself up, the police said. The suspect, William J. Aydolotte, 27 years old, of Bellmawr, entered the station with his father, and was booked on charges of armed robbery and assault with intent to kill in connection with the shooting of Leo P. Bende early Tuesday. The police said he was unarmed, and had not wounded a shootout, as had been believed earlier.

title: Top Judge Recalls His Shaky Start
INDIA ENTERS '75 TORN AND UNSURE
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 1India celebrated the New Year today on a dark and uncetain note. Commentators and politicians said that the nation's mood had lifted in recent months, but that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government was in deepening trouble.

title: BARNARD PLACES A 2D TWIN HEART
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 1 (AP)The world's second human twinheart operation was performed last night by Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, and hospital officials said here today that the patient was in excellent condition.

title: Business Briefs
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 1The Algerian Government's New Year's gift to citizens is a 50 per cent rise in gasoline prices, from 98 cents to 1 dinar and 47 cents a liter. Fuel oil and diesel fuel remain at present prices.

title: F.B.I. and Police Capture Fugitive in Florida Killings
description: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1 (UPI) e Thomas Otis Knight, wanted for the murders of a Miami industrialist, Sydney Gans, and his wife, was captured in an apartment here yesterday by F.B.I. agents and the police.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Celtics Tie for Lead
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 1 (UPI)John Havlicek scored 31 points and sparked the Boston fast break tonight to a 10894 N.B.A. victory over the Portland Trail Blazers, lifting the Celtics to a firstplace tie with Buffalo in the Atlantic Division.

title: How All Over Town Got on Boards
description: If you do a play on Broadway without a half a million dollar advance, you've got a 100to1 shot, said Dustin Hoffman, director of Murray Schisgal's new comedy, All Over Town.

title: Whoopee! in Albany: Brooklyn Has Its Day
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1To most of the politicians and dignitaries crowded into the Assembly chamber, he was the new Governor. But to the delegation from Brooklyn. Hugh L. Carey was the hometown boy who made good, and they were not about to stand on ceremony.

title: Baseball Joins Sports HighRoller Leagues
John Newton Mitchell
description: Mr. Mitchell was Attorney General from Jan. 20, 1969, to March 1, 1972, when he resigned to head President Nixon's reelection committee. Three months laterand after the Watergate breakin he left the post, saying he was doing so at the insistence of his wife, Martha.

title: Critical Tests for Ford
Books of The Times
description: Western civilization, says John Murray Cuddihy, rests on secularized Christianity, and in order to be fully accepted in it, the classical Jew was obliged to euphemize himself.

title: Thrift and Integrity Promised by Carey
WATERGATE JURY CONVICTS MITCHELL, HALDEMAN, EHRLICHMAN AND MARDIAN IN COVERUP CASE; ACQUITS PARKINSON
Aloof jury Foreman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 When the jury at the Watergate coverup trial began its deliberations, defense attorneys were reportedly happy to learn that John A. Hoffar, a retired policeman with the National Park Service's local police force, had been selected as foreman. Although he gazed blankly for long periods durin the trial, his facial expressions during crucial testimony caused some of the defenders to see him as a friend.

title: Paying for the Schools
description: In the context of the city's extreme budgetary dilemma, the $2.78billion budget request by School Chancellor Irving Anker comes as a painful shock. Even against the general backdrop of inflation, an increase $518 million over the current cost of operating the schools looms large in a community in dire straits.

title: NEW QUAKES ERUPT ON HAWAII VOLCANO
description: VOLCANO, Hawaii, Jan. 1 (AP)A series of earthquakes shook the southeast slope of Mauna Loa volcano early today, but none caused damage.

title: $100,000 in Jewelry Stolen
description: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI)A car containing $100,000 in jewelry samples was reported stolen early today from a salesman's home in this suburb of Los Angeles.

title: Rev. Raymond Kennedy, Leader of Jesuit Retreats
description: The Rev. Raymond J. H. Kennedy, who had conducted 421 retreats across the country for the Society of Jesus, died yesterday at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx, after a long illness. His age was 71.

title: STEINGUT ACCUSED OF BAR TO INQUIRY
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said here Yesterday that Stanley Steingat, the Democratic leader of the Assembly, asked him in 1973 not to investitigate any nursing homes owned by Bernard Bergman, the central figure in allegations of fraud and political influence in the industry.

title: Guilty
description: The jury verdict in Federal District Court in Washington yesterday finding the four major Watergate defendants guilty of conspiracy in the coverup plot, and three of them guilty of obstruction of justice and perjury, brings to its climax the many long and agonizing months of the Watergate drama.

title: In Search of the Noxious Weed
description: The legislation we are today considering for the control of noxious weeds is particularly timely. At a time when we are suffering food shortages both in the United States and around the world, we should make every effort to increase agricultural productivity. The Weed Science Society of America has estimated that weeds cost us $5 billion each year in the United States.

title: Major Campaign Reforms Take Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The most sweeping political campaign reforms in the nation's history took effect today.

title: Arabs Impatient for Peace But Girded for a New War
description: The prospect of devastating conflict with Israel is frustrating the Arabs vision of an economic renaissance made possible by their new oil wealth.

title: Insurgent Attacks Force Thousands Into Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Communistled insurgents launched a series of attacks on the outskirts of Phnom Penh today and thousands of refugees, hundreds of them injured, streamed into the capital.

title: VIOLATIONS LISTED AT 13 FOOD OUTLETS
Reputed Mafia Figure Charged With Hitting F.B.I. Car in Chase
description: A reputed Mafia figure who allegedly tried to flee from Federal agents attempting to serve him with a subpoena has been charged with assaulting a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent by ramming his car in an attempt to escape.

title: VENEZUELA BUYS OUT U.S. STEEL CONCERNS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 1 President Carlos Andres Prez raised the Venezuelan flag over a mountain of iron ore today in the nation's ironrich Guayan district and declared that American iron mining companies operating here were now the property of the state.

title: Editors Rate Watergate Scandal As the Biggest News Event of 74
description: The Watergate scandal, culminating in Richard M. Nixon's resignation and Gerald R. Ford's succession to the Presidency, was the top news event, of 1974, accordingto a poll conducted by The Associated Press.

title: Colt Breaks Leg in Stake At Calder
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1The TropicalatCalder stakes program for 1975 began today on the same tragic note with which the 1974 schedule ended four days ago. Spot T. V., a son of T.V. Lark who won four races and $43,345 last year, broke his leg on the far turn in the $63,000 McKnight Handicap. An attempt is being made to save him for stud duty.

title: JOSEPH SCHWARTZ, JEWISH AIDE, DIES
description: Joseph J. Schwartz, who directed the relief and rescue of hundreds of thousands of Jews in Europe in World War II, died yesterday at his home, 146 Central Park West. He was 75 years old.

title: BURMAH WILL REPAY INTEREST ON LOANS
description: LONDON, Jan. 1  Burmah Oil Britain's third biggest oil company, which has been rescued by the British Government from a financial crisis, said tonight it would continue to repay principal and interest due on its big dollar loan.

title: Blacks and Women Continue Steady Education Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)On two fronts, blacks and women are closing the education gap that separates them from their white and male counterparts, the Government reports.

title: Golda Meir Named As Most Admired; Betty Ford Second
description: Golda Meir, former Premier of Israel, is the most admired woman of 1974, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday. Betty Ford, wife of President Ford, won second place in the poll, and Pat Nixon, the former First Lady, came in third.

title: Bridge:
description: Once a partnership uncovers a good fit, direct raises are usually appropriate and there is no need to show side suits.

title: Colt Breaks Leg in Stake At Calder
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1The TropicalatCalder stakes program for 1975 began today on the same tragic note with which the 1974 schedule ended four days ago. Spot T. V., a son of T.V. Lark who won four races and $43,345 last year, broke his leg on the far turn in the $63,000 McKnight Handicap. An attempt is being made to save him for stud duty.

title: The Bright Side of Smog
description: CHICAGO (UPI)Dr. Albert M. Potts of the University of Chicago says eyeirritating photochemical smog is a blessing in disguise. It is probably the single most important factor in directing attention to the air pollution problem, the eye specialist said.

title: Few Tears, a Bit of Anger As the Verdicts Are Read
The Nation in 1974: A Year of Transition and of Unrest
description: On the political scene, 1974 was a year of transition, as the Presidency changed hands. There was an energy crisis, inflation, unemployment. The busing plan brought racial unrest to Boston. In California, a kidnapped girl turned terrorist.

title: Article 2  No Title
