description: Paul Screvane, president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached with the operators of the Tropical Park meeting at the Calder Race Track in Florida to accept bets, starting on Monday.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UP AGAIN, TO 7.1%, HIGHEST SINCE 61; MONETARY POLICY IS EASED
A MISSIONARY GOAL ON JEWS IS DENIED
description: ROME, Jan. 3The Vatican strongly denied today that it had any intent of proselytizing in the fraternal talks between Roman Catholics and Jews advocated in a new church document.

title: Earth Satellite Program in Peril
description: Close studies of images sent by an earth satellite passing over remote regions of Africa, Asia and South America have enabled Bolivia to shorten a projected pipeline by 10 miles with an estimated saving of $3million. They have disclosed areas of Africa infested by river blindness and also typical diamondbearing formations.

title: Sanitation Unit Moves to Cut 132 Jobs
PENTAGON BACKED ON 11BILLION RISE IN ARMS SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Ford Administration has approved a $95billion defense budget for the coming fiscal year, an $11billion increase over military spending in the current budget, Pentagon officials said today.

title: A Portrait by Rembrandt Quietly Sold by Columbia
description: Columbia University has quietly sold a Rembrandt that has been in storage since 1968, when university officials grew fearful that student demonstrators might damage the painting.

title: Walter Eyerdam, Explorer In Solomons and Siberia
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 3 (AP)Walter J. Eyerdam, an explorer who had visited some 50 countries, died Wednesday in a hospital here at the age of 82.

title: No. 1 N.C. State Upset By Wake Forest, 8378
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 3 (AP)Skip Brown, a sophomore guard, scored 25 points as he led Wake Forest to the first of a pair of upsets tonight, handing topranked North Carolina State its first loss in 37 games, 8378, in the opener of the Big Four basketball tournament.

title: Islanders, Rangers Pack House Tonight
description: Loyalties will be on the line tonight in the standingroomonly crowd expected at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I., to watch the third meeting this season between the New York Rangers and the New York Islanders.

title: 3 UTILITIES TO AID SOUTH JERSEY GAS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 3The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners said today that three of New Jersey's largest utilities had agreed to provide 2.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas to help South Jersey Gas Company weather its current gassupply crisis caused by cutbacks by its supplier. Early last month South Jersey Gas predioted it would be 1.1 billion I V feet short of meeting the needs of its customers this winter because of a cutback in the amount of natural gas that the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation would supply.

title: Experts Expect Major OilPrice Drop in a Few Years
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3A group of American specialists on energy problems forecast today that the world market price for oil would probably fall substantially within a few years.

title: 7.2% Rise Asked on LongDistance Calls
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a proposal yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to raise longdistance rates by 7.2 per cent as of March 4.

title: Bridge:
description: The grand national team championship has become, in its third year, an event with mass appeal: it is the only opportunity for players to compete in a national championship without going further than their local club.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UP AGAIN, TO 7.1%, HIGHEST SINCE '61; MONETARY POLICY IS EASED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The nation's unemployment continued to grow rapidly in December, reaching 7.1 per cent of the labor force, or 6.5 million workers, the Labor Department reported today. This was the highest unemployment rate in more than 13 years.

title: Slain Inmate Shared Cell With a Muslim He'd Helped Convict
BERGMAN INQUIRY BEGUN BY JERSEY
description: The New Jersey State Attorney General said yesterday that his office was investigating nursing homes owned by Bernard Bergman, who is already under investigation for his nursinghome operations in New York.

title: Nets Win As Dr. J Gets 34
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 3The New York Nets defeated the St. Louis Spirits, 130113, tonight as they stopped Marvin Barnes but almost got stung by a Fly in the process.

title: Cavaliers Face Knicks Tonight
description: What could be better for the Knickerbockers last home game tonight (till Jan. 21) than to face a team they've never lost to at Madison Square Garden? Their opponents, the Cleveland Cavaliers, will be seeking their first victory here in 13 meetings with the Knicks and only their third in 22 games over all.

title: City Aide Accused of Extorting $7,500 to Approve $527,500 Bid
description: A management official in the city's Department of Correction was arrested yesterday minutes after he allegedly received $7,500 in cash to approve a $527,500 bid for a computer contract.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Coast Guard warned residents of the coastal area from Delaware to Rhode Island to beware of sealed steel barrels that may wash up along the shore. It said the 50 barrels, swept overboard from a ship during a storm Thursday, contained fumes of tetraethyl lead, the antiknock compound.

title: Willowbrook Official Testifies Hospital Conditions Are Better
Draft Evader Gets a Suspended Sentence
description: NEWARK, Jan. 3 (UPI)Vincent Kinek, the first person convicted of draft evasion in New Jersey since conditional amnesty was announced, was given a suspended sentence today with the condition that he spend two years in publicservice work.

title: Court Spokesman Says Douglas Has Improved and Is Exercising
description: Justice William O. Douglas's strokeweakened left arm and leg were reported yesterday to have shown improvement, as he began a series of exercises designed to maximize the use of the left side of his body, according of a spokesman for the Supreme Court.

title: Gimme One in Basic Black, With Four Cylinders
JUDGE ALLOWS U.S. TO ADD TO I.B.M. SUIT
description: The Justice Department received permission yesterday to amend its antitrust lawsuit against the International Business Machines Corporation as the litigation moved toward trial Feb. 18.

title: EMPLOYES FUNDS TO BUY CITY NOTES
description: New York City's employe pension funds and sinking funds plan to invest an estimated $425million during the first quarter of 1975 in a private placement of city notes.

title: Sandman Is Appointed Solicitor in Cape May
description: LOWER TOWNSHIP, N. J., Jan. 3 (AP)Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., Republican of New Jersey, who leaves office next week, has been hired as Township Solicitor in this Cape May County community, it was announced today.

title: Contract Award
description: Worthington Pump, Inc., a subsidiary of StudebakerWorthington, Inc., has been awarded a $10million contract to supply main feed and auxiliary feed pumps, fluid drive couplings and spare parts for four 600 MW fossil team power plant units in the station of Porto Tolle in northern Italy.

title: Arab Oil Wealth Puts Pressure on Israel
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaArab officials say their new oil wealth will create a framework for stability in the Middle East, but their vast income is now being used to put international pressure on Israel.

title: MINE HILL PUSHES CORRUPTION ISSUE
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 3 (UPI) Newly elected officials of Mine Hill Township said today that they would seek an early meeting with Jonathan L. Goldstein, the United States Attorney, to outline suspicions of corruption in the outgoing municipal government.

title: Federal Reserve Reduces Its Discount Rate to 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Federal Reserve Board reduced its discount rate today from 7 per cent to 7 per cent in a strong signal of an easier monetary policy to fight the nation's economic recession.

title: Families Thrive In the Bitter Cold Of U.S.'s Icebox
description: INTERNATIONAL FALLS, Minn.They call this city of 6,332 the icebox of the nation. And to the families who live here, this translates into long cold winters of parkas, ski masks, square tires, icicles, 40below temperatures and snowbanks the size of small mountains.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: In Memorian

title: JERE SULLIV AN, 79, A RETIRED BUILDER
description: Jere H. Sullivan, who retired in 1962 as a vice president of the George A. Fuller Company after having supervised major construction projects here and in other parts of the world, died Thursday in Brunswick, Ga. He was 79 years old and lived in St. Simons Island, Ga.

title: 13 Are Hurt as Ferry From Staten Island Hits Manhattan Slip
description: Twelve passengers and a deckhand were injured on a Staten Island ferry boat yesterday morning when it rammed into the vehicle ramp at the Manhattan slip.

title: Riva Ridge Sires Filly, His First Get
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 3 (AP)The first offspring of Riva Ridge, the 1972 Kentucky Derby winner, was born at Walmac Farm yesterday just five hours after Secretariat's first foal was born. Secretariat won the Triple Crown in 1973.

title: RATS FIND HOME IN CENTRAL PARK
description: Scampering past Stroller's and joggers, hundreds of large grayishbrown rats scramble each day through the fallen leaves of Central Park. They dart across walkways, rummage through trash and burrow in the dark, moist soil.

title: Two Bills to Help Jobless Signed Into Law by Byrne
description: TRENTON, Jan. 3Governor Byrne today signed into law two measures designed to create thousands of new jobs in an effort to stem rising unemployment in the state.

title: The WhiteCollar Worker Confronts Unemployment
description: WARREN, Mich., Jan. 3Ten years ago, when Paul L. Jarvis was 27 and a rising autostyling engineer, he never figured it could happen.

title: Retail Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Department of Commerce said today that total retail store figures for the week ending Dec. 28 were an estimated $10.49billion, up 7 per cent from the year earlier $9.459billion. Total department store sales were an estimated $1.706billion, up 8 per cent from the year earlier $1.275billion.

title: Rep. Mills's Illness
description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills has shown exemplary courage in publicly acknowledging that he has been a victim for some time of the illness known as alcoholism.

title: A.M.C. Deferring New Dental Plan
description: DETROIT, Jan. 3The American Motors Corporation in an effort to cut costs has notified its 7,500 salaried employes that it will defer putting into effect a dental plan, stop merit raises and freeze the cost of living increases at the level paid in the last quarter.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Francis Sheldon Hackney, who as provost of Princeton University has been its secondranking official since 1972, will become president of Tulane University in New Orleans in July. He succeeds Dr. Herbert Longenecker, who is retiring after 15 years. Dr. Hackney, a 41yearold history professor received degrees from Vanderbilt University in Nashville and Yale University and has written and edited books on the history of populism. In his 10 years at Princeton, Dr. Hackney's principal course, conducted at both graduate and undergraduate levels, has been The History of the South from 1607 to the Present. He has also done research and teaching on the South.

title: National Steel Buys Mine From Consolidated Coal
description: The National Steel Corporation said yesterday that it has purchased the Kepler mine of the Consolidation Coal Company for an undisclosed sum.

title: Antiques: Paris Enigma
PENTAGON BACKED ON 11BILION RISE IN ARMS SPENDING
REAGAN DISCUSSES MISQUOTATIONS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI)Gov Ronald Reagan insisted at a farewell news conference today that he had never said some of the most controversial things attributed to him during his eightyear tenure.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on P. G. Wodehouse in The New York Times Thursday it was reported erroneously that Mr. Wodehouse had said: I don't understand why authors receive knighthoods. Mr. Wodehouse's comment was: I don't understand why authors refuse knighthoods.

title: Britain to Guarantee Loans Of Troubled Truck Maker
Haldeman Lawyers Seek a New Trial
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: State Panel Finds Sex Discrimination At Smith Collegge
College President Named
description: AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 3 (AP) John P. Kendall, a Boston businessman, has been elected chairman of the Hampshire College board of trustees. Mr. Kendall, 46 years old, is president of Faneuil Hall Associates. He succeeds Franklin Patterson, founder of the experimental liberal arts college, who resigned.

title: Ford Signs the Trade Act; Soviet Issue Is Unresolved
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3President Ford signed a farreaching trade reform act today but left uncertain the fate of the controversial provision that allows him to grant trade benefits to Moscow in return for assurances of freer Soviet emigration policies.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOISEMAKERS Nobody connected with the event tomorrow afternoon at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine likes to use the word exorcism, but the truth Is that at least one element of the goingson draws its inspiration from the ancient practice of driving away evil spirits with loud noises.

title: Mournful Numbers
description: With the heavy layoffs in the auto industry last month, everyone realized that the unemployment picture was worsening; but the figures just released by the Labor Department are even worse than expected. The overall jobless rate has jumped from 6.5 per cent to 7.1 per centits highest level in thirteen years. The total of unemployed individuals rose from six million to six and a half millionin absolute figures, the largest number of Americans out of work since the end of the Great Depression. Total employment dropped by 550,000 and is now half a million less than it was a year ago, despite the fact that over a million and a half additional workers have entered the labor force.

title: EVERTON POINDEXTER
description: Everton G. Poindexter, who had been president of Commodity Brokers, Inc., a New Yorkbased wholesaler of flour and other food products, died Wednesday in Bridgeport (Conn,) Hospital, following a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 74 years old and lived in Easton. Conn.

title: The Multiple Sins of Human Nature
description: LONDONFor reasons with which I sympathize, one makes oneself unpopular with progressive people if one blames public evils on human nature. True, the argument that human nature is bad is often used as an excuse by interested parties who oppose social change. All the same we seem to have got to a stage in the world's history where at every point we are brought up against human nature as an impassable wall that prevents us taking obvious measures to save ourselves from destruction.

title: Cornell Six Wins, 10 to 7; Brown Bows
description: Cornell scored five goals in the first period and defeated Boston College, 107, and St. Lawrence beat favored Brown, 43, before 10,517 fans at Madison Square Garden last night in the opening round of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference Holiday Hockey Festival. The winners meet tonight in the Festival final.

title: Say, Can You Recall?
description: Remember Fred Astaire's top hat in Top Hat? Remember Boris Karloff's mummy wrappers in The Mummy?

title: FRANCE GIVES IRAN STAKE IN URANIUM
description: PARIS, Jan. 3Iran is to lend the French Atomic Energy Authority $1billion for 15 years for a 10 per cent stake in a giant uranium enrichment plant being built in the Rhone Valley, French officials said today.

title: JULES LEVEY IS DEAD; A FILM PRODUCER, 78
description: Jules Levey, an early motionpicture executive, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, on a Manhattan street. He was 78 years old and lived at 24 West 55th Street.

title: Backer of Dissident Artists In Soviet Is Held for 9 Days
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 3Aleksandr Glezer, a Moscow poet and art collector who has been active in unofficial art circles here, said today that he had returned from serving nine days in jail in Leningrad on charges of petty hooliganism.

title: People and Business
description: Three former Nixon Administration Cabinet officers are reportedly representing Iranians and Arabs who are investing in the United States or buying goods and services from American companies.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Jan. 3 (UPI)Joe Woolley, a former high school coach, failed to appear today for trial on charges of altering grade transcripts of two University of Oklahoma football recruits. The alleged incident led to the current probation of Oklahoma by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The trial was reset for Jan. 16. Woolley's attorney, John Thoma, said he didn't have his client in court because he was unaware the case had been set for trial. A codefendant, Lynn Nix, who now lives in Arkansas, also failed to appear. The trial has been delayed numerous times since the two were indicted by a grand jury in 1973.

title: Options Volume Lags
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP)The volume of trade in December on the Chicago Board Options Exchange fell about 9.4 per cent from the preceding month. The exchange reported today that there were 570,972 option contracts traded in December.

title: Sandman Is Appointed Solicitor in Cape May
description: LOWER TOWNSHIP, Jan. 3 (AP)  Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., Republican of New Jersey, who leaves office next week, has been hired as Township Solicitor in this Cape May County community, it was announced today.

title: Finley Plea to Change Hunter Ruling Denied
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 3Charles O. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, lost Round 2 today in his attempt to regain the rights to Jim (Catfish) Hunter, one of baseball's top pitchers.

title: New Highway Aid To Pocono Skiing
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 3Although only a few inches of snow have fallen since skiarea operators in the Poconos opened their liftticket windows for the season, business in this resort country has been booming. I'm convinced there's two intermingled reasons for the surge, Said Bob Uguccioni, the executive director of the Pocono Mountain Vacation Bureau, while looking at a light snowfall through his Main Street office window. The first has to be Interstate 80, which now provides express driving from the George Washington Bridge through New Jersey to our ski centers.

title: Cambodians Tell of Fighting Vietcong
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 3 (Reuters)Government forces killed 183 insurgents in fighting on three fronts today around Phnom Penh, according to a spokesman for the Cambodian command.

title: Calley Hearing Set Feb. 18
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (UPI) The United States Court of Apneals for the Fifth Circuit today set Feb. 18 to hear the Armys appeal against Lieut. william Callev whose conviction for murdering 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai was overturned by a Georgia judge. Lieut. Calley was sentenced to life in prison by a military court in 1971 but the sentence eventually was reduced to 20 years. Federal Judge J. Robert Elliott of Columbus, Ga., later threw out the courtmartial, saying massive publicity prevented a fair trial. The former Lieutenant was freed by Judge Elliott last November on a S1.000bond, pending the Army's appeal of the ruling.

title: Gas Inquiry Is Urged in South Jersey
description: BRIDGETON, Jan. 3  At the urging of Representativeelect William J. Hughes, a group of South Jersey legislators, county officials and industry and union leaders called today for a Federal Power Commission investigation of the pipeline company that supplies natural gas to South Jersey.

title: CLASHES AT BORDER REPORTED BY ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 3 (Reuters)Israeli and Arab units clashed today in the northeastern sector of the frontier, where Lebanon, Syria and Israelioccupied territory meet, an Israeli Army spokesman said.

title: BERGMAN INQUIRY BEGUN BY JERSEY
description: The New Jersey State Attorney General said yesterday that his office was investigating nursing homes owned by. Bernard Bergman, who is already under investigation for his nursinghome operations in New York.

title: Japan Plans a Sale Of Fertilizer Plant To North Vietnam
STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCES
description: Prices advanced for the second straight session on both the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday in moderately increased trading.

title: Everything Else in Louisiana Has Risen, But a Phone Call Still Costs Only a Nickel
Slayings Suspect Still Had Gun Receipt
description: An unemployed electrician charged with killing two men in Nathan's Famous Restaurant in Times Square early yesterday still had the receipt for the alleged murder weapon, a 9mm. pistol, in his pocket when apprehended minutes later, the police said.

title: Tale of a Claimer Has Happy Ending
Everything Else in Louisiana Has Risen, But a Phone Call Still Costs Only a Nickel
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3They've always called this a nickel town, a New Orleans dry cleaner said the other day.

title: Ford Signs the Trade Act; Soviet Issue Is Unresolved
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3President Ford signed a farreaching trade reform act today but left uncertain the fate of the controversial provision that allows him to grant trade benefits to Moscow in return for assurances of freer Soviet emigration policies.

title: Cairo Talks Open to Seek HusseinPalestinian Peace
Fumes Keep Labor Agency Out of $95Million Home
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Department of Labor has refused to move into its new $95million building on Constitution Avenue. Officials are worried ahout a sagging, leaky roof and automobile fumes from a freeway underneath the building.

title: Pistons Win, 11193, After Fights, Fouls
Nelson Norgren,83,Coached Football at Chicago 36 Years
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI)  Nelson H. Norgren, a former allAmerica football player and a longtime coach at the University of Chicago, died Tuesday. He was 83 years old.

title: DACCA GOVERNMENT TAKES NEW POWER
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 3 (Reuters)  The Bangladesh Government, acting under the national state of emergency declared last week, assumed virtual dictatorial powers today to fight extremists and economic offenders.

title: Benny Memorial Planned
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (Reuters)  George Burns and George Jessel, friends of the late Jack Benny, announced today plans to found a Jack Benny memorial forest on the outskirts of Jerusalem. They said friends of the comedian from all walks of life would donate trees. Mr. Benny died here last week at the age of 80.

title: Suit Accuses Pennsylvania Of Bias Against Whites
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Jan. 3 (AP)  Pennsylvania was accused of discriminating against whites in the hiring and promotion of state policemen in a lawsuit filed today in United States District Court.

title: Commodity Price index Off 1.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 207.9 from 209.8 last week.

title: Gulf and Shell End Kuwaiti Oil Pact
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group announced yesterday that they had terminated their longterm contract under which Gulf supplied Shell with crude oil from Kuwait.

title: Dodge Is Winner Of Giant Slalom
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Jan. 3 (AP)Peter Dodge of St. Johnsbury, Vt., won the men's giant slalom competition today in the first CanadianAmerican amateur ski races of 1975.

title: Weisl Fears Deterioration Of Trees in Prospect Park
description: If Betty Smith were to write her famous novel today, she might have to call it A Tree Dies in Brooklyn.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Rossini's L'Itallana In Algeri, 2; Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov, 8;30.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Regional Office of the National Labor Relations Board has declined to issue a complaint against Macmillan, Inc., which had been charged by officials of Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employes of unfair labor practices.

title: Arab Oil Wealth Puts Pressure on Israel
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaArab officials say their new oil wealth will create a framework for stability in the Middle East, but their vast income is now being used to put international pressure on Israel.

title: O Estado at 100
description: One obscure note says much about the fiercelydefended independence of Brazil's biggest newspaper, which celebrates its centennial today: the masthead of O Estado de So Paulo admits to only 95 years of independent existence, rather than 100, because it excludes from its history the period 194045 when it was seized by army troops and then operated by agents of President Getulio Vargas's dictatorship.

title: Cairo Paper Says Brezhnev Suffers From Bronchitis
Stage: Insights in The Hashish Club
U.S. Safety Board Enters Study of Bronx Rail Crash
News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 4, 1975

title: Newark's First Black Police Inspector Is Sworn Into Post by Mayor Gibson
description: NEWARK, Jan. 3Edward D. Williams, a 22year veteran of the Newark Police Department and the author of a book about his life as a policeman, today became the first black inspector in the department's history.

title: Federal Reserve Reduces Its Discount Rate to 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Federal Reserve Board reduced its discount rate today from 7 per cent to 7 per cent in a strong signal of an easier monetary policy to fight the nation's economic recession.

title: Market Place
description: Some observers believe that the stock market cannot emerge from its persistent downward course until interest rates come down and until the dimensions of the economic recession become manifest.

title: Bid for Michigan Bank Laced With Arab Tact
description: DETROIT, Jan. 3A member of a wealthy, influential family from Syria who is making a major effort to buy a controlling interest in a Michigan bank has found that making a good offer is not enough. One must also use diplomacy.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: DR. LEO PERLMAN

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: India Sets Up Film Agency To Aid Fledgling Directors
description: BOMBAY, IndiaThe Indian Government, in an effort to encourage fledgling directors and, at the same time, lessen the impact of blackmarket money on the film industry, is setting up an agency that would provide financing for feature films and promote their export.

title: DR. DAVID GRIGGS, GEOPHYSICIST, 63
description: David T. Griggs, who had been a professor of geophysics at the Institute of Geophysics of the University of California at Los Angeles since 1948, died Tuesday of a heart attack while skiing at Snowmass, Calif. He was 63 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: MILKSUPPORT BILL IS VETOED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)President Ford vetoed legislation today that would have increased retail milk prices by about 12 cents a gallon, declaring the measure was highly inflationary to consumers and unnecessary.

title: Health Chief Gives City Schools, Grade of  B to Bon Conditions
description: Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, the City Health Commissioner, yesterday gave a grade of B to B to the city's 983 public schools for their health and safety conditions.

title: GULF DROPS REQUEST for WAIVER ON DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Gulf Oil Trading Company has agreed to supply fuel to the Navy's Operation Deepfreeze in Antarctica and will comply with laws requiring the company to justify its prices, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today.

title: Market Pushes Upward; Dow Jones Climbs 2.50
description: The stock market brushed off some early adverse economic news yesterday and registered its third consecutive advance in moderate trading.

title: We've Got Plenty Of Nothing
description: PARISThe fragility of modern industrial society has been exposed to an astonishing degree by the energy crisis, which is almost certainly the harbinger of other crises involving distribution and prices of raw materials. Complex systems were hard hit by the initial Arab petroleum embargo and the subsequent series of abrupt price risers that more than quadrupled the cost of oil.

title: Prices of Gold Again Fall As Investors Remain Wary
description: Gold prices continued to drift lower yesterday as investors and speculators waited for the sale of 2 million ounces of gold by the United States Government on Monday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Customers of New Jersey's two largest utilities will receive lowered electric bills this month, benefiting from the state's fueladjustment clause, according to the Board of Public Utility Commissioners. The Jersey Central Power and Light Company and Public Service Electric and Gas said the savings had resulted from the increased use of nuclearpowered generators. The fueladjustment clause allows the utilities to pass along to consumers automatically either lower or higher fuel prices.

title: Vatican and Jews: Way Open to Dialogue on Vital Issues
Lefkowitz Challenges Memo Linking Him to Bergman
Reynolds Metals to Reduce Aluminum Output in Week
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it planned to reduce its primary aluminum production next week in Texas and Arkansas.

title: Dave Anderson
A.T.&T. Asks Rise
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a proposal with the Federal Communications Commission to raise longdistance rates by 7.2 per cent, effective March 4. Details on Page 29.

title: The WhiteCollar Worker Confronts Unemployment
Birch Society Planning A California University
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3, (Reuters)The John Birch Society plans to open a university in California by 1979, according to Charles R. Armour, the Society's western district governor.

title: MANHATTAN CABLE DROPS PROGRAMS
F.P.C. Staff Says Outlook for Natural Gas Worsens
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Federal Power Commission staff reported today that the outlook for natural gas supplies had worsened unexpectedly and recommended mandatory conservation measures that would affect all gas consumers, even private homes.

title: Prof. Kenneth Colegrove Dies; RightWing Political Scientist
description: Kenneth W. Colegrove, Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Political Science at C. W. Post College died yesterday at his home in Butler Hall. 88 Morningside Drive. He was 88 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP)The Philadelphia Electric Company today announced that four companies in the Philadelphia metropolitan area will be dealt a 27 per cent cutback in their natural gas deliveries.

title: Killing of Cabinet Minister Shocks India's Politicians
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 3The killing in a bomb explosion of Lalit Narayan Mishra, 52yearold Railway Minister and a confidant of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, sent shock waves through India's major political parties today.

title: Bombings in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 3 (UPI)Two bombs exploded today in the Egyptian and Jordanian Embassies in Damascus, causing heavy damage and slightly injuring four persons, police sources said.

title: Power Failure Halts Service By Some Penn Central Trains
FREEZE ON U.S. FUNDS for CHICAGO UPHELD
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (UPI)A United States Appeals Court denied emergency motions today filed by city attorneys to release $76million in Federal revenuesharing funds. The money was frozen because of alleged discrimination in the Chicago Police Department.

title: 3 Companies Agree to Aid South Jersey Gas Utility
description: NEWARK, Jan. 3The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners said today that three of New Jerseys largest utilities had agreed to provide 2.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas to help the South Jersey Gas Company weather its current gassupply crisis caused by cutbacks by its supplier.

title: Milton Cross Dies
description: Milton Cross, the commentator known to a nationwide broadcast audience as the voice of the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday as he was preparing for the broadcast today of L'Italiana in Algeri. He was 77 years old.

title: Leader of State Senate Democrats
description: A few minutes after his selection as the minority leader of the State Senate yesterday, Manfred Ohrenstein was giving the name of his new law firm to reporters.

title: $800MILLION PLANT IS SET FOR MALAYSIA
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 3 (AP)The chief minister of Malaysia's Negri Sembilan State outlined plans today for an $800million petrochemical complex expected to be set up with partners from the Middle East.

title: The Future of Taiwan
description: Twentyfive years ago last month the demoralized Nationalist Chinese leaders under Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek sought refuge on the offshore island of Formosa, proclaiming themselves sovereign over not only ten million residents of the island but over the whole of the mainland from which. they had just been routed. Some two million military and civilian refugees from the mainland lent strength to the claim. The anniversary passed unmarked and largely unnoticed in Taiwan.

title: U.S. Interior Department To Sell Oil and Gas Leases
description: AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 3The United States Department of the Interior has announced an auction of 551 oil and gas leases on offshore Texas Gulf of Mexico lands for Feb. 4.

title: Books of The Times
Better Days Are Here Again
London Store Loses $125,000 to Hoaxer Posing as Terrorist
description: LONDON, Jan. 3  A man posing first as a Scotland Yard inspector and then as an Irish Republican Army terrorist hoodwinked a large department store into parting with $125,000 last night.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: RICHARD C. RIPPIN

title: Israelis May Offer Incentives To Attract Foreign Companies
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 3Israel is considering offering incentives to multinational corporations that might otherwise be reluctant to invest here as a result of the Arab League boycott, Israeli finance officials said today.

title: British Foreign Secretary Plans To See Vorster in South Africa
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 3 (Reuters)  The British Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, said today that he would have talks in South Africa with Prime Minister John Vorster within the next few days.

title: 25 IN LONG BEACH LOSE CITY POSTS
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 3About 25 municipal employes worked their last day for Long Beach today as the result of a layoff announced late last year by this financially pressed city.

title: A Dissent on Who Is No. 1
description: Oklahoma, the nation's only unbeaten and untied team, is college football's national champion for 1974, the Associated Press says.

title: Feeding the Monsters
description: President Ford should find room in his capacious pockets for a veto of the highway bill that slipped through Congress in the fading days of the session. The bill, which was intensively lobbied by the trucking industry, has some good provisionsnotably one that would make permanent the 55mileanhour speed limit on Federal roads. But whatever is good in the measure is more than offset by its authorization to increase maximum truck weights on interstate highways from 73.000 pounds to 80.000, or 40 tons.

title: A.T.&T. Asks Rise
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a proposal with the Federal Communications Commission to raise longdistance rates by 7.2 per cent, effective March 4.

title: White House Declines to Add to Kissinger Remarks on Use of Force
Goldsworthy Of Stars Hurt In Club Spat
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3 (AP)  Bill Goldsworthy, a forward for the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League, was injured early today trying to break up a fight among some of his teammates. He will be out of action for at least two weeks, a club spokesman said.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on P. G. Wodehouse in The New York Times Thursday it was reported erroneously that Mr. Wodehouse had said: I don't understand why authors receive knighthoods. Mr. Wadehouse's comment was: I don't understand why authors refuse knighthoods.

title: Canadian Cabinet Clears American Investment Bid
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 3 (Reuters The Canadian Cabinet has overturned a decision of the Foreign Investment Review Agency for the first time and is allowing the partial takeover by an American concern of a small Quebec company, which previously was denied.

title: FILM UNIT TO CUT ROSTOW SEQUENCE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2Walt W. Rostow, National Security Adviser to former President Lyndon B. Johnson, has won a temporary court order barring use of an interview with him in Hearts and Minds, a movie about the United States involvement in Vietnam.

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: For periods ended Nov. 30 unless otherwise Indicated.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS name OHRENSTEIN LEADER IN SENATE
description: State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein of Manhattan, one of the early leaders in the reform Democratic movement, was chosen yesterday as the leader of the Senate Democrats.

title: Patent Office Loses Patent on Its Name
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Patent Office has been renamed the Patent and Trademark Office. The man in charge, C. Marshall Dann, is no longer known as Commissioner of Patents but as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks.

title: FordBrezhnev Convergence Impressed Giscard
description: PARIS, Jan. 3President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, chatting at a New Year's reception for the press, said today that he had found President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev to be closer in their views on a Middle East settlement than was generally supposed.

title: A Gain in Battle Is Reported by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 4The Saigon military command said yesterday that its forces had weathered a North Vietnamese attack on Phuoc Binh, a province capital 75 miles north of Saigon, and were still in control of the city.

title: BETHLEHEM TO BUILD BIG BLAST FURNACE
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UPI)The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced Friday that it had started construction of the largest blast furnace in the WeStern hemisphere at its Sparrows Point plant near this Maryland city.

title: Lottery News Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)  President Ford signed into law today a bill allowing newspapers and certain broadcasting stations to send information on their state lotteries through the United States mail and on interstate airways. The law took effect immediately.

title: Secretary to Cabinet Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) President Ford announced today that he was appointing Dr. James E. Connor, director of the Atomic Energy Commission's Office of Planning and Analysis, as secretary to the Cabinet. The post has been vacant for months and Ron Nessen, White House press secretary, said Mr. Ford has decided to fill it because he is using the cabinet more than his predecessors.

title: System Helps Aircraft to Avoid Collisions
G.M. Sets Layoffs At Buffalo Plants; Others in Cutbacks
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that 544 workrs at two Buffaloarea Chevrolet plants have been laid off for an indefinite period.

title: Endearing Indira
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi for years has been famous for biting the hands that feed India. But in her latest lecture to the world's advanced nations, she outdoes herself.

title: Coach Helps Aztecs Get New Image
description: In the first season in the North American Soccer League last year the Los Angeles Aztecs won the title but averaged only 5,600 fans at home games.

title: Editors Choice
description: General

title: Hebrew Christian Is Preaching Gospel to the Jews
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFSAs a Hebrew Christian, the Rev. Daniel Fuchs, executive director of the American Board of Missions to the Jews, has encountered prejudice on two sides.

title: MARKET'S CRITICS ACTIVE IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Jan. 4The British are entering their third year in the Common Market and critics are stepping up their campaign to make it the last.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Priorities / Title IX / HoHum
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE IRANIAN AID TO ARABS LIKELY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 4Iranian officials, discussing the Shah's forthcoming visits to Amman and Cairo, indicated this week that Iran would provide more economic aid to Arab nations and work toward a Middle East settlement.

title: Rescuing the Bankrupt Railroads Will Cost $2BillionJust for a Starter
description: This is the year Congress, the Department of Transportation, the Interestate Commerce Commission and the Federal and state taxpayer must face the facts of Northeast railroad reorganization. One fact is that the cost begins at $2billion and could go on from there with no calculable limit.

title: A Realization That Kissinger's Assurances Alone Are Not Enough
description: JERUSALEM,Although Israel continues to pedal along in tandem with Secretary of State Kissinger's peace initiatives, there is a growing realization in Israel that the Soviet Union must eventually play a more active part in the mediation process, if the IsraeliArab conflict is not to produce increasingly dangerous openended wars.

title: Sunday Observer
description: For this I need dim lights and cobwebs. It is the interior of one of those magnificent walnut  paneled clubs, but there is a sense of opulence gone to dust. The rooms are empty, except for an occasional spider nestled under the ear of a marble Minerva and, at the great oaken bar, a bartender, old and greenishgray, who has given up polishing the glasses. It is not the end of the world in here, but the end feels very near.

title: Brooklyn Cable TV Group Wins Praise From City Official for Thinking Small
description: A small video corporation has applied to the City Bureau of Franchises for permission to construct an experimental closedcircuit cable television system in a small portion of Brooklyn, and, according to Morris Tarshis, director of the bureau, it might solve the problem of developing a Workable cable system for the city.

title: Seed Catalogues Offer Bright Newcomers
Gunmen Trapped by Their Own Victim and OffDuty Policeman
Subsidies Aid Adoption of HardtoPlace Children
description: TRENTONMore than 160 hardtoplace children, who might have had to spend years in temporary foster homes or institutions, now have homes and families of their own as a result of a state  subsidized adoption program.

title: Bowl Bids Date Limit Is Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)  The National Collegiate Athletic Association set today the third weekend in November as the earliest date for contact between a school and a post season bowl game. The N.C.A.A. threatened violators with a bowl ban and financial penalties.

title: State Health Aide Sees Willowbrook Progress
description: The State Deputy Commissioner of Mental Hygiene testified yesterday that the present situation at Willowbrook was less grim than it had been three years ago when conditions at the Staten Island school for the mentally retarded first gained widespread public notice.

title: BLUE RIBBON UNIT
KOLB NAMED CHIEF OF MENTAL HEALTH
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday the official appointment of Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb, director of the New York State Institute of Psychiatry, as Commissioner of the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: A.E.C. Reveals Size of Uranium Stock
description: The Atomic Energy Commission has disclosed that it already has on hand a large supply of the raw material that could significantly reduce both the economic cost and environmental impact of introducing in the nineteennineties a nuclear power industry based on a commercialscale use of breeder plants.

title: President's Statement on C.I.A. Inquiry
At Broad And Wall No Joy At All
description: In the sidewalk in front of 30 Broad Street, fenced in by brasspipe railings, is a miserable, leafless sycamore tree, its trunk no more than 4 inches through. A plaque proclaims it the successor of that spreading buttonwood under which, so many years ago, 24 men promised to charge buyers outside their circle a little more, and pay them a little less, than they would quote on the same transactions among themselves.

title: Marriage Planned By Laura Bullitt
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Lewis 3d of Media, Pa., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Lewis's daughter, Laura Hutchinson Bullitt, to James Richard Despard, son of Mrs. Richard James Despard of Rochester and the late Mr. Despard.

title: Notre Dame Bows, 9082, To Maryland
description: By The Associated Press

title: Child to Mrs. Leibowitz
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Martin Leibowitz of New York on Dec. 31 in Beth Israel Hospital. The child, who has been named Karen Louise, is a greatgranddaughter of the late Louise Homer, the contralto. The infant's mother, the former Sarah Fryer, is known professionally as Dr. Sarah Leibowitz and is assistant professor of physiological psychology at Rockefeller University. Her father is vice president and director of investment systems at Salomon Brothers, stockbrokers.

title: An Uneasy Truce Is Seen for Labor In a Tranquil Year
Grain Farmers Prosper, but Dairymen Suffer
description: CHICAGOIn the last year most American grain farmers prospered, but livestock and dairy farmers suffered.

title: Soccer Problem in U. S.: Plenty Of Players, Scarcity of Coaches
description: The United States is an underdeveloped country as far as soccer is concerned: rich in resources, but poor in the technical skills to develop them. That is, we have an almost embarrassingly large number of boys taking up the sport, but a desperate shortage of coaches.

title: Fire Rages in Jersey City
description: A generalalarm fire in Jersey City brought out almost all of the city's firefighting apparatus yesterday to battle a blaze that raged for hours in a partly abandoned factory building at Route 440 and Danforth Avenue. The police said that clouds of smoke, visible for several miles, were probably from large rolls of paper stored in the old Kellogg factory, which had caught fire.

title: The Jay Way Finds Success in Vermont
description: NORTH TROY, Vt.Martin DeHahn, a strapping motel owner from Virginia Beach, had flown his plane into nearby Newport with his wife, two daughters and their two friends as passengers a night earlier. The following afternoon found him walking into George Stepanek's office at Jay Peak and asking for an individual lesson.

title: 2D SUSPECT SEIZED IN HOLDUP KILLING
description: A second suspect was arrested early yesterday in the bank robbery near Gramercy Park on Friday afternoon in which an offduty police officer was, killed.

title: Baker Asks New Inquiry On C.I.A.Watergate Links
Marcia Anne Stanley Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard John Stanley of Tewksbury, N.J., and Pinehurst, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Anne Stanley, to the Rev. Roger Allen Verse, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Iselin, N.J. He is the son of Herbert Fred Verse of Scotch Plains, N.J., and the late Mrs. Verse.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Every generation sees a biography of the New York Philharmonic. On the orchestra's 50th birthday, Henry E. Krelibiel wrote a memoir. On its 75th birthday, James Huneker did the honors. To celebrate the centenary there was a book by John Erskine. There should have been one in 1967, for the 125th anniversary, and there would have been had Howard Shanet been ready in time. But better late than never, and Shanet's big bookbigger by far than its three predecessors put togetheris just coming off the Doubleday presses. Its title is, simply, Philharmonic, and it is subtitled A History of New York's Orchestra.

title: Environmental Concern: Not a Passing Fad
description: It doesn't take a very large crystal ball to see that 1975 will be the most active year yet in terms of interaction between American business and the relatively new national awareness that goes under the umbrella name of environment.

title: ATOMIC REACTORS MAY HAVE TO SHUT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Some nuclear reactors producing electricity In the United States may have to close down this year because of a shortage of space to store their radioactive waste, an Atomic Energy Commission report has concluded.

title: A ROBBERY SUSPECT IS KILLED BY POLICE
description: An alleged robber who fired a wild shot at two policemen chasing him on foot was killed yesterday on the Lower East Side when the policemen fired 16 shots at him.

title: Miss Peck Fiancee Of Michael Nicoll
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Peck of Oyster Bay, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Quintard Peck, to Michael Lee Nicoll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S, Nicoll of Westbury, L. I.

title: City's Hospitals Agency Approaching Insolvency
description: Five years after the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation was created to improve the quality of care in the municipal hospitals, patients are still dying from inferior medical treatment, the corporation is virtually insolvent and, as the largest nonFederal healthdelivery system in the nation, it is struggling just to provide the basic minimums of health care.

title: PANEL TO MANAGE MIAMI ORCHESTRA
description: MIAMI, Jan. 4The effective management of the Miami Philharmonic Orchestra has been placed in the hands of a new steering committee that will try to save the financially troubled institution.

title: Year of the Rabbit, Traditionally Mild, Augurs Well for 75
description: TOKYO, Jan. 4 (UPI)Children across Asia traditionally believe there is a rabbit in the moon. If there is, he'll be in a happy mood by February when the Year of the Rabbit begins, according to the Oriental lunar calendar.

title: DOGS AND PONY DIE; NEIGHBOR IS CHARGED
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP)A man apparently unhappy about animals kept by his neighbors has been roaming through a Tampa subdivision and shooting at pets, the police said today.

title: Ford Weighs Options as Recession Deepens
description: WASHINGTON  In his second inaugural address in January. 1972, President Nixon expressed the hope that his second term would he the best four years in American history.

title: Activists in Suburbs Narrow Their Goals
Sarah A. Fergusson, A. J. Brown to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Carter Fergusson of Gladwyne, Pa, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Anne Fergusson, to Anthony Janney Brown, son of Medford Jennings Brown Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Anne Janney Brown.

title: A Major Art Collector at 24
description: FAR HILLSChristopher Forbes, son of Malcolm Forbes, the magazine publisher, has accomplished what many art collectors consider virtually impossible: He has assembled a major collection of breadth and death in just five years.

title: Point of View
description: The great Irish poet W. B. Yeats one wrote, But I was young and foolish, and now am full of tears. A good warning to forecasters; but economists, like poets, must look into the future.

title: View Fromthe Kitchen: 1975 Started Off Well
description: LYNBROOK  Several hours before midnight, the New Year's Eve rush had not yet begun at Bernie's Peppermill Pub here. But Alan Becker, the bartender there, was already busy.

title: Ruling on Assault Cases Against Indians Is Assailed
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 4A United States Court of Appeals ruling has made it difficult if not impossible to prosecute assault charges against reservation Indians, a Federal prosecutor said this week.

title: Metals Industry Speaks in an Optimistic Voice
City Urges the State to Return Control Over Nursing Homes Here
SignalClose Action!
description: Is it a naval engagement you're after, in the old days when sailors were less afraid of the enemy than of the ship's surgeon? Then ship out with Alexander Kent for another bloodsoaked voyage during the Napoleonic Wars. The screams of the wounded caught in the rigging will cure your nostalgia, me hearties. The year 1798 finds Richard Bolitho a commodore in the Royal Navy, in command of a small squadron in the Med. His mission: to winkle out what Boney's Admiral Brueys is up to. This calls for the author's full repertoire of 18thcentury naval strategy, including a daring amphibious operation against a couple of Spanish forts and a climactic sea battle with a French convoy.

title: An Engagement Book for All Seasons
description: Expected an engagement book this year and didn't get one? The oversight can be happily remedied.

title: Backing of Hunter Arbitration Decision Called Prelude to Changing Pro Sports Setup
The Logic of the Tennessee River
description: Not long ago I took a 727 from Charlotte, N. C., to Nashville, Tenn. The flight begins and ends on plains, but most of it is passed above the Smokies. The afternoon before had brought a minor storm to the high ground, and on this morning the leeward tops of the mountains were dusted with snow. In late November, all but the conifers were bare, and from 27,000 feet the browned woods and the snowed slopes interacted to suggest the hide of a piebald pony.

title: Sucide Follows Dismissal
description: CONCORD, Calif., Jan. 4 (UPI)A female sheriff who was dismissed Thursday for sounding her siren without cause shot herself to death with her service revolver in her patrol car, policemen reported yesterday. The victim was Roberta Ann Kline, 24 years old, of Martinez.

title: Iran Papers Assail Secretary
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 4 (Reuters)  Two independent evening newspapers that usually reflect Iranian foreign policies today criticized Secretary of State Kissinger's comments on the possibility of using force against oil producing countries.

title: Lisa Christensen Married to an Engineer
description: Lisa Joyce Anne Christensen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kai Svane Christensen of Somerville, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Howard E. Spencer 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer 3d, also of Somerville. The Rev. Marinus Verwey performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Mount St. John Roman Catholic Chapel in Gladstone, N. J.

title: John Spruille Young to Marry Angela C. Nugent in August
description: Angela Cecile Nugent and John Spruille Young, doctorial candidates at Brown University, plan to be married in August.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 5, 1975

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Florida United Numismatists, Inc.better known as FUNis one of the hobby's many organizations that exist primarily to sponsor and conduct major annual coin conventions. Although the FUN convention is always held at the height of the tourist season in early January, in a worldfamous fun place, Miami Beach, those who attend invariably find that play is not the convention's primary purpose.

title: Two Horse Show Units To Meet on West Coast
description: The 58th annual convention of the American Horse Shows Association will be held at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco Thursday through Saturday with some important questions up for discussion. Along with the A.H.S.A. meeting, the United States Equestrian Team will hold its annual gathering on Saturday, also at the Fairmont. The A.H.S.A. group actually winds up its business Saturday morning. The U.S.E.T. then will be host at a luncheon and Bill Steinkraus, the president, will make his annual report.

title: How fair is our justice, how fitting is execution?
Economic Oracles Finding Good News in Bad
description: The same economists who erred so grievously in predicting the traumas that unfolded in 1974 are at it again, peering into the murky future to turn out forecasts.

title: W. J. DEMOREST 84, REALTOR, IS DEAD
description: William Jennings Demorest, a leading New York realtor for many years, died Thursday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 84 years old and lived at 21 Glendale Road, Rye. N. Y.

title: Friday's Fight
description: By The Associated Press

title: Buffeted, Not Beaten, U.S. Seeks Economic Recovery
description: IT seemed appropriate, five years ago at this time, when the glow of the Soaring Sixties was diminishing and a new decade was starting with the United States in the midst of its worst inflation in 19 years, to recall the words of Thomas Paine: These are the times that try men's souls.

title: Once It Set the Pace
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  For those who have become accustomed to seeing California as a trendsetter, an unsettling trend has developed in recent years. Imperceptibly but inescapably, California and the rest of the country are merging into each other.

title: She not only argued she exemplified
description: Mary Wollstonecraft (17591797) is a heroine in the history of the emancipation of women. As publicist and ideologist she commanded for a time the attention of the Western world, until dark reaction set in and overwhelmed her cause for a century. A Vindication of the Rights of Woman (1792), which she wrote in six weeks, established her fame both then and now. It was the logical culmination of the Enlightenment's concern with humanitarianism and human rights. And inasmuch as many of the male leaders of the Enlightenment were in fact less devoted to woman's rights than one might suppose or they themselves thought, it can fairly be said that she was more realistic and consequential in her thinking than they.

title: Mary Ladwig Bride of Dwight Johnson
description: Mary Louise Ladwig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis William Ladwig of North Caldwell, N. J., was married yesterday morning to Dwight Craig Johnson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Johnson of Sioux Falls, S. D.

title: Egypt's President Appoints New Armed Forces Chief
description: CAIRO, Jan. 4 (Reuters)Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, who is the country's supreme military commander, has appointed Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Aly Fahmy as Chief of Staff of the armed forces, it was announced here today.

title: Clean Water
description: Clear, freshtasting water free of impurities, bad tastes and objectionable odors, can be insured in every home and apartment (including boats, trailers and mobile homes) by simply installing a modern water filter on the water supply line. Producing the equivalent of top quality bottled water  at a fraction of the cost of purchasing it  these filters come in a variety of different sizes and styles, but all use disposable cartridges that are replaced periodically when they become clogged or saturated.

$1Million in Prizes Is Offered in Lottery

description: LOS ANGELES. Young writer has hit play, goes off to Hollywood and is never heard from again. And if he's a black playwright? Lonna Elder 3d is watching out.

description: NEWARKThe dean of the Seton Hall University School of Law called last week for a state constitutional convention to revitalize the Legislature.

description: TOKYO, Jan. 4 (Reuters)Thousands of American mines sown around Japanese harbors in the closing months of World War II still pose a hazard to port and dredging operations nearly 30 years later.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (UPI) Three persons were killed today in an explosion and fire at a rubber plant in the city's Kensington section. The names of the victims were not immediately disclosed.

In the North Sea, the Norwegian Government owns 50 per cent of each drilling venture, and the British Government has announced a similar policy for the already proven fields.

title: SCHOOL REOPENING SLATED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON. Jan. 4  School Superintendent William J. Leary said tonight that he would reopen on Wednesday the racially troubled South Boston High School, the scene of violent clashes over busing to achieve desegregation.

title: Two Get Heart Awards
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (UPI) Rocky Bleiek, Steelers runring hack, and Viet Nam veteran, and Manny Sanguillen, Pirates catcher, have been named Pittsburgh's athletes with the most heart for 1974 by the Western Pennsylvania Heart Association. The awards will be presented at the 39th annual Dapper Dan dinner in the Pittsburgh Hilton Feb. 2.

title: The Nation Is Anxious for Leadership
description: WASHINGTONUnless he is politically hard of hearing, President Ford must be getting the message. It is coming in from the country loud and clear.

title: Coryell Coach of Year in N.F.L.
description: Don Coryell, who turned the St. Louis Cardinals from perennial losers into division champions, was named coach of the year in the National Football League yesterdy by The Associated Press. The 50yearold Coryell received 50 of a possible total of 78 votes from a national panel of sports writers, including three representatives from each of the N.F.L.'s 26 teams. Sid Gillman of the Houston Oilers finished a distant second with 12 votes. Lou Saban of Buffalo, Chuck Fairbanks of New England and John Madden of Oakland also collected votes. The winner of the award last year was Chuck Knox of the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Miss Weisberger, V. J. Anzalone Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Weisberger of Kingston, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Weisberger, to Vincent J. Anzalone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anzalone of Pittston, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: Garment District Is Alive but Ailing
description: The familiar sound of garment racks clattering along the sidewalks of Manhattan's Seventh Avenue has subsided a bit. Manufacturers of women's clothing, it seems, are facing difficult times. The apparel industry in New York may even have to change its ways, perhaps by expanding into a different part of town.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: President Ford is being urged to set up a threemember White House council on science and technology as a means of reestablishing productive communications with scientists.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Investigations initiated by the State Welfare Inspector General's office last year saved the state nearly $9.2million, the office said in its annual report. The report, issued by inspector General William F. Meyers, said the watchdog agency continued to find chaotic and incomplete records, and the persistence of error and fraud on the welfare rolls.

title: Indiana Court Curbs Suits Over Libel in News Media
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 4 (UPI) An Indiana Court of Appeals decision has redefined state libel standards for individuals and First Amendment coverage in light of several recent Supreme Court decisions.

title: Utah U. Plans Observatory
description: Special to the New York Times

title: The pact of two Henrys
Rosie
description: Unlike most love stories, this one begins with an ending and ends with a beginning  a hopeful gambit. The ending is the death of Rosie Pepperell's young husband, which pitches his widow into the slough of a depression. M. M. Constantin is very good at reconstituting the workaday world of a college teacher of dramatic lit (which Rosie is), seen through a film of grief. A raw sense of love decreases the heroine's patience with the asininity that is a corollary of her profession. The author follows the teacher through a sabbatical in Los Angeles, where she tries to sort herself out with the aid of a psychiatrist and tries also to pursue a research project. This involves a famous leftwing playwright, whose private papers are interred at U.C.L.A. along with a sad secret or two. As work, time and maybe the shrink begin to clear Rosie's head, she sees more clearly the two lovers who bless her singleness. She responds to this surfeit of riches after passing through a couple of emotional decompression chambers that Mrs. Constantin depicts beautifully.

title: Public Art Should Be Art for the Public
Article 1  No Title

Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, John Mitchell and Robert Mardian, whose names once made strong men tremble, stood convicted of Federal crimes. Unless the verdict was upset on appeal they would probably go to prison.

McDivitt, executive vice president for corporate affairs of the Consumers Power Company, asked in a recent interview here.

title: The kidvid monitor
description: ACT is endorsed by a va riety of national organizations, including the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Friends Service Committee, the American Public Health Association, the National Education As sociation, and the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Membership in ACT, including the quarterly newsletter and various mailings throughout the year, costs $15. A oneyear subscription to the newsletter alone costs $5. Other materials available from ACT include The Family Guide to Children's Talevision: What to Watch. What to Miss What to Change and How to Do It (Pantheon; $2.95); the film But First This Message, $25 to rent or $100 to buy; and a television game, Switch, ($1.50). in which the object is to reach SIGN OFF without acquiring commercial cards for such products as Boredom Berry, Sugar Sloughs, and Robot the Ripoff.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 5Fierce fighting was reported yesterday from the besieged province capital of Phuoc Binh, 75 miles north of Saigon, and there were unconfirmed reports that the Communists had captured the town.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK  An unusual program that got its start at Douglass College is gaining widespread acceptance at universities across the nation.

St. John's Upset by Georgetown

title: Rising Prices and Joblessness Expected Abroad, Poll Shows
description: People in nine foreign countries as well as the United States expect 1975 to be a year of rising prices and rising unemployment, according to a Gallup Poll made public today.

title: Phnom Penh Weathering New Assault in Long War
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 4  The hospitals are full of casualties and there is more noise and windowrattling from bomb and artillery explosions here than at any time since the summer of 1973, when the insurgents pushed cicise to Phnom Penh despite massive American bombing.

title: Rita Gardner Fiancee Of Vincent P. Murray
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Gardner. Jr., of Neponsit, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Rita Gardner, to Vincent P. Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Murray of New York.

title: Canada's GoldMining Industry Stays Calm
description: TORONTO  The men whose mining companies have made Canada the world's third largest gold producer (after South Africa and the Soviet Union) scrupulously avoid too blatant a posture of delight in the world's problems. But they do concede that their situation was aptly expressed by a recent headline in The Northern Miner, a Canadian trade newspaper, which proclaimed: New Round of Crises Augur Well for Gold.

The downturn in real gross national product will continue, at least, until next summerthat is, for six quarters in a row. If left to itself, the recession could easily roll on for another year.

title: Former Aide of Mrs. Gandhi To Direct Planning in India
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 4  Parmeshwar Narain Haksar, former principal secretary of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was named head of the Planning Commission today.

title: The Slightest Distance
description: A delicate nostalgia is the predominant mood of this collection of spare family miniatures, nine stories (eight previously published in The New Yorker, one in The Atlantic) about the various generations and branches of the Richardson family, all of whom share a common malaisecumphilosophy: all are slightly out of register with the present moment so that they are almost always either longing or remembering. The single quivering instant of love in which one is fully alive is brief and rare. All the Richardsons are, in their various ways, aware of this mystifying human predicament, which has to do with the enigmatic nature of time and the way the heart works. Eachdiplomat father Sam, his reflective wife Laura, his disappointed brother Ken, his sons Scobie (the writer), Matthew and Quentinvoices an explicit variation on this theme. The father bending over his infant son and seeing a marble clutched in his fist: I know nothing, Sam thought, suddenly straightening and staring around the room Nothing. Scobie on his girl friend: I look at Susan's face in the silver light and feel suddenly empty, horrified at the strangeness of what I see. Mother Laura: There is no getting at the truth of things. Each of the stories laconically delineates the almost eventless surface of a moment in family life in counterpoint with these moments of numb reflection, or of memory, so seductive and elusive. There seems no real connection between event and event, or event and triggered memory.

title: Boating Groups Accused of Discrimination
description: Awaiting public hearing by the New York State Division of Human Rights is Charlotte P. Arutt's complaint charging the United States Power Squadrons and the Hempstead Bay power squad ron with unlawful sex discrimination in refusing to admit women members.

title: The Good Word: Cyril Connolly
Whooping Cranes to Get Island From Air Force
Hockey: The Shooting Gallery
description: Money and glamour have introduced the prima donna to the National Hockey League. No one is now content to be a spearcarrier on ice. You make more money by scoring goals, and to heck with defense.

title: Art Rooney's Super Bowl
