Or putting on a sergeant's blue uniform for a reunion of retired cops. Except that Art Rooney is a millionaire, probably the most admired millionaire around.

title: Longest Season Closes With 36.250 at Aqueduct
description: A crowd of 36,250 went out to Aqueduct yesterday to play the horses and, in keeping with the law of averages, there were more losers than winners. However, there was one big winner.

title: How to Hit in Platform Tennis
description: When winter comes, some tennis players stash their racquets away in the attic alongside their baseball gloves and beach umbrellas. Some hustle to sign up for court time at one of the burgeoning number of indoor tennis centers. And some try to keep in shape and put a glow on their cheeks by switching for the season to platform tennis, the only racquet sport that can be played in cold, wet weather.

title: Alison Roosa Is Bride Of David Cluff in Rye
description: In the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon Alison Ruth Roosa, an alumna of the University of Michigan, became the bride of David Warren Cluff, who graduated from Ohio University. The Rev. Joseph Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: The Glenn Gould Contrapuntal Radio Show
description: Glenn Gould is rehearsing. Bundled in a heavy darkgray overcoat, muffler and cap, seated in his cluttered, stuffy, overheated office there's a draft. in here, he complains), Gould conducts two large KLH 5 speakers: at yellow Bic pen in his left hand marks the upbeat, signaling the entry of the double basses and cellos that opens Mahler's Resurrection Symphony. He glances at the stop watch cradled in his right hand, and while guiding the orchestra toward a crescendo with a giant sweep of his arm, he suddenly lunges forward off his chair, scattering papers, imploring his engineer: De La Grange in at six with the EQ out! Gould now begins to conduct the verbal inflections of author HenryLouis de la Grange, whose words are coming from the left speaker, while still conducting Mahler's music from the right speaker.

title: Tax Cut Seems Surer Than Reform
description: WASHINGTON  The unemployment rate in January may have more to do with what kind of tax legislation is written this year than either the political demise of Representative Wilbur D. Mills or the election of last November.

title: ExHead of PepsiCola Apparent Suicide
description: James Bentley Somerall, the former president and board chairman of the PepsiCola Company, was found shot to death yesterday afternoon in the bathroom of his home at 30 Sutton Place. Detectives termed the death an apparent suicide.

title: Heather C. Chalmers Is Affianced
description: Prof. and Mrs. Bruce Chalmers of Quissett, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Heather Clare Chalmers, to Steven Johnson Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley H. Green of Greenwich, Conn.

title: FUNDS STILL SHORT for SUBWAY PLAN
Swiss Skier Is Victor in Cup Slalom
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 4 (AP)LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland twisted down a tough special slalom course today to win a World Cup event marked by numerous spills and disqualifications.

title: New teacher, old church, new house
description: Marcy Lewis is 13, and she narrates this novel in a snappy, contemporary voicelike a junior New York magazine writer: All my life I've thought that I looked like a baby blimp with wireframe glasses and mousy brown hair. Everyone always said that I'd grow out of it, but I was convinced that I'd become an adolescent blimp with wireframe glasses, mousy brown hair, and acne Sometimes I feel guilty being so miserable, but middleclass kids have problems, too. Marcy has a lovable, neurotic little brother, a tranquilizerpopping mom ripe for feminist liberation and a father who sets some kind of a record for psychological childabuse.

title: Auto Insurance Rise Backed
description: BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP)State Insurance Commissioner John G. Ryan approved this week$79.7million automobile insurance rate increase for 1975 and said it would cost most drivers at least $30 more a year than they pay now.

title: Rhodesians Dismiss Trip
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 4 (Reuters)Elliott Gabellah, acting president of the Rhodesian African National Council, today dismissed speculation that a delegation from his group would travel to Zambia, to meet Mr. Callaghan.

title: And the First Is: Whose Inquiry Should Take Precedence?
description: WASHINGTONThe four committees of Congress that have announced they will investigate allegations of illegal domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency will first have to confront these questions: How will Congressional inquiries affect the special investigation announced by President Ford? And are four Congressional inquiries three too many?

title: Miss Oakley Plans Bridal
description: Katherine W. Oakley of New York, an officer in the investment division of the United States Trust Company of New York, and Anthony C. Leonard of Chatham, N. J., a vice president of the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation of Whippany, N. J., plan to be married in March.

title: Democratic Coalition Declines To Oppose Steingut's Election
STAGE VIEW
description: Hold everything. We've got to begin to make some sense of what we're doing around here. Of course we are in the throes of a passion for elderly musicalsas indeed I think we should be, given the quality of the scores in our composers safe deposit boxesand we've already made our ways through No, No, Nanette, Irene and Where's Charley? With the holidays playing host. Good News has added itself to the treasuretrove.

title: Indians in Queens Reviving Heritage
description: Seated crosslegged in the living room of a modern highrise apartment building in Lefrak City, Queens, women in bright silk saris and men in cotton outfits filled the air with melodious tunes of devotional music from exotic instruments.

title: Nancy E. Leighton to Be Wed to Harold O. Koenig
description: The Right Rev. David Keller Leighton, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland, and Mrs. Leighton of Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Leighton, to Harold Otto Koenig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Purington Koenig of Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: How Recession's Pincers Grip Vulnerable Groups
Vanishing Frontier
description: The century that began with Theodore Roosevelt's accession to the Presidency and his dramatic leadership of the nascent conservation movement is now threequarters gone. During this time, Americans have made important progress in conserving their natural resources. But, as recent actions by President Ford and the mixed record of the recently adjourned Congress both demonstrate, Americans have yet to unlearn all the heedless habits of mind acquired in the past when this was an empty continent, a virgin land.

title: Janet R. Tracy Plans Nuptials
description: Janet Ruth Tracy and Rodd McCormick Reynolds plan to be married in the early spring.

title: Show Goes On at Opera With New Voice on Radio
description: For millions of fans of the Metropolitan Opera's Saturday afternoon radio broadcasts, the familiar mellifluous voice of Milton Cross was missing yesterday. For many, it was like an opera performance without recitative.

title: Women Immigrants Find Growth Here, Despite Problems
U.S. Attorney's Office in Newark Leads Nation in Special Awards 2d Year in Row
description: NEWARK  Jonathan L. Goldstein, United States Attorney for New Jersey, has announced that Attorney General William B. Saxbe has presented 11 special Department of Justice awards to assistants on his staff.

title: Carey to Print State Guide To Offset Campaign Debts
description: In an unusual political fundraising venture, Governor Carey hopes to raise nearly $1million through the Publication of a political and governmental guide to New York.

title: Carola Phelan Has Nuptials
description: Carola Mary Theresa Phelan, daughter of Mrs. Lewis Joseph Phelan of Keene, N. H., and the late Mr. Phelan, was married in Keene yesterday afternoon to Michael Kane Sandoe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Sandoe of Weston, Mass., and Acworth, N. H. The Rev. David L. Hyman performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church.

title: 10 Blacks at Michigan State Suspended in Rift With Coach
Aerospace Outlook Brightens
description: WASHINGTONThe aerospace and defense industries are not exactly booming, but their prospects are far brighter than for most industries in the coming year.

title: Rand and Sundgaard Ski Jumping Victors
The Critical List
description: Having written by reliable count the ten thousandth scholarly work on Kafka, Quagmeyer had been assured by the publisher to whom he had submitted it that he would be given the treatment he deserved. Then why had he been kept waiting already a day and a half in the outer office, to see this elusive editor in chief, Mr. Ruebottom? But now the receptionist rose and said, Mr. Ruebottom will see you now. Follow me, please.

title: Music: Delbarton Group
Chris Evert More Alert to Lifestyle Shifts:
description: FORT LAUDERDALE. Fla., Jan. 4Chris Evert was depressed on her 20th birthday two weeks ago, but not because of her suddendeath tiebreaker with Jimmy Connors or the thought of relinquishing her role as a teenager.

title: Profits Expected to Fall
description: Corporate profits, which pyramided to new peaks last year fueled by phantom inventory profits, will deteriorate in 1975, in the view of most economists.

title: Pennsylvania
Point of View
As if she had been invited into the world
description: Spencer Curtis Brown, Elizabeth Bowen's literary agent and friend of many years, writes in his affecting and helpfully informative foreword to this collection about the circumstances surrounding the appearance of Pictures and Conversations. Miss Bowen, who died on Feb. 22, 1973, had talked over this book with him, and he prints here some notes she made for her publishers before she began it.

title: Beth Israel Shuts Passaic Birth Unit
description: PASSAICBeth Israel Hospital has closed its obstetrics unit because of lower birth rates in this city of 55,000 people and higher costs.

title: Why can't a man be more like a woman?
description: It's a pity these three books couldn't have been oneand it would have saved a lot of nice trees. All three say the same thing and say it so piously and turgidly that one becomes tired of hearing the message before one has even heard all of it once. Their views on the current state of masculinity are so uniform it's regrettable someone didn't think to send the three manuscripts to that sly master of the cutup, Mr. William Burroughs. It is my opinion that, given a free hand to slice and splice, Mr. Burroughs could have reduced their 41 extremely selfrepetitious chapters to a more modest 15 without doing the slightest violence to the authors' insights.

title: Farmhouse in Paramus Restored to Its Former Glory
MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market made an impressive advance last week as bargainhunting, especially in the depressed blue chips and glamour issues, buoyed the list.

title: Consumer Groups Expect New Gains
description: WASHINGTON  Deteriorating economic conditions may bring about some important shifts in priorities among consumer groups in 1975, but no one can expect any overall weakening of the movement.

title: Brokers Prepare for the Day of Reckoning on Rates
description: One day soon, perhaps this month, the Securities and Exchange Commission will lift the veil of antitrust immunity now hanging precariously over Wall Street and, in one historic moment, sweep away 183 years of history on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Healthy Pro Tour Shuffles Schedule for Warm Start
How a Man Decides He'll Run for the Presidency
description: ATLANTAHow does a Presidential candidacy get born? Mysterious forces that Russell Baker embodied in The Great Mentioner used to draw up a handicapped list of contenders for any nomination. Nowadays candidates are their own mentioners.

title: ANOTHER ELECTION DUE IN LOUISIANA
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 4Southeast Louisiana voters will fill on Tuesday the last remaining seat in the House of Representatives, which has been undecided and disputed in the courts since the rest of the nation chose new Congressmen on Nov. 5.

title: Laura Lapid us Engaged To Martin P. Kaufman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lapidus of Port Washington, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laura Susan Lapidus, to Martin Philip Kaufman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kaufman of Rochester. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Minorities and Women Fearing Trauma
Affirmative Action Plan Scored as Inadequate
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne's affirmative action plan has drawn both praise as a step in the right direction and criticism as an inadequate and unrealistic program.

title: Angolans Extend Talks
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, Jan. 4 (Reuters)Leaders of Angola's three liberation movements unexpectedly extended their discussions today aimed at reaching a common front.

title: Cornell, Larries in Hockey Final Today
description: The Eastern College Athletic Conference holiday hockey festival ends at Madison Square Garden today with the championship and consolation games. Cornell meets St. Lawrence in the final at 1:30 P.M. The consolation match between Boston College and Brown starts at 11 A.M.

title: H.L. Hunt, Horseplayer
description: A cavalry troop made its leisurely way through the gloom of South Ozone Park yesterday, the 2,421st such force to complete its appointed round at Aqueduct, Belmont or Saratoga since Feb. 25, and suddenly the lives of New York horseplayers were as empty as their pockets. These are the worst of times, the 50 dark days before thoroughbred racing returns to the metropolitan scene on Feb. 24. But stay. Into the breach steps Phil Bieber, of the inexhaustible memory: If I had a rich father, perhaps I would do the same, said John D. Rockefeller Sr. when told that John Jr. was an extravagant spender. This came to mind when the fine filly Dahlia was winning the Man o War at Belmont. Dahlia is owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt, whose father, Haroldson Lafayette Hunt, was one of the world's richest men when he died about a month ago.

title: TaxExempt Bonds Are Tempting Investors After Adversities of 1974
description: The tax  exempt bond market, thanks to the adversities of late 1974, now presents investors with some very tempting yields.

title: Lag in Storm Alert Angers Shore Area
Liddy Calls Dean a Judas, Magruder Liar and Nixon Insufficiently Ruthless
The People's Verdict
description: On July 30, 1973, John Ehrlichman concluded his testimony before the Senate Watergate committee with the truculent statement that he had intended to raise a voice for the President, who is unrepresented here.

title: $603000 IN IVORY STOLEN IN BRONX
description: Burgiers ransacked a home in the Fieldston section of Riverdale in the Bronx while the owners were away on vacation and escaped with ivory objects valued at more than $60,000, the police reported yesterday.

title: Greene and Noll Win Pro Awards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI)Joe Greene, Pittsburgh Steeler defensive tackle, today was named pro football player of the year by the Washington Touchdown Club and his coach, Chuck Noll, was selected as National Football League coach of the year.

title: Has hockey turned into a snow job?
Nets Put Squires To Rout
Across From the Floral Park
description: For sale: odd mansion with conservatory, crazy old lady, resident young woman and mysterious prowler. Last Year In Marienbad style dcor. Fully furnished.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Brian Tilton Bristol Marries Susan Lowry
description: Susan Lowry and Brian Tilton Bristol were married yesterday afternoon in the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn., by the Rev. J. Greeory Tweed.

title: Tema Vyner Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Vyner of Rochester have announced the engagement oftheir daughter, Tema Ann Vyner, to Mitchell Brian Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Shapiro of Brooklyn. Miss Vyner is a senior at Buffalo State College, from which her fianc was graduated.

title: The prospect of death
description: Most healthy people are afraid of dying, and it is hard not to be awed by the magnitude and mystery of death. Despite the several recent books about dying, death remains a taboo topic in our culture. Children may hold long scary conversations to explore what it will feel like to die, but we adults tend to carpet over our emotions with intellectual acceptance, or practicalities. Moreover, vast numbers of people have little choice about experiencing their own dying, since they die in hospitals, too drugged to participate in their own final moments. Our culture encourages us to hide our own fear, curiosity, anger, grief, helplessness or excitement at the prospect of death, as if these normal feelings were somehow shameful.

title: MRS. ISAAC HARBY
description: Isabel Solomons Harby, widow of Isaac Harby, a civil engineer and a supervising engineer for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, died Thursday at her home in Scarsdale, N. Y. Her age was 83.

title: STAMPS
description: Happy New Year of the Hare In the Chinese lunar calendar, as in much of Asia, years have their animal symbols, and 1975 is the year of the Hare; 1974 was the year of the Tiger.

title: U.S. Plans to Prohibit Joint Bidding for Offshore Oil Leases by 8 Big Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4The Interior Department is drafting new regulations that would, if made final, prohibit joint bidding for offshore oil leases by the eight largest United States oil companies and also expand significantly public disclosure of drilling results, senior officials have disclosed.

title: 10Day Bicentennial Fete Is Planned
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne has announced a statewide bicentennial observance in 1976 and 1977 of what he called the 10 crucial days of the Revolution in New Jersey.

title: Mrs. Grasso Faces Connecticut Budget $180Million Short
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 4 Faced, with a $180million gap between the projected expenses of government in Connecticut and the revenues she expects, Governorelect Ella T. Grasso is weighing proposals to increase the state sales tax, the corporation business tax and possibly the state tax on gasoline.

title: Fed, Under Burns, to Move Cautiously on Monetary Growth
description: WASHINGTON  As the Federal Reserve Board faces the inflationrecession dilemma of 1975, its policies are likely to be more cautious than those of the President and Congress in trying to restimulate the economy.

title: Rescue Cost $77,000
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 4 (AP)The Coast Guard says its efforts to help two disabled freighters in the North Atlantic cost taxpayers at least $77,000. The bill covered operating costs of three Coast Guard cutters and a rescue plane sent to aid the Pacific Logger and the Corina for about 12 days, a spokesman said this week.

title: Business Is Uncier the Heaviest Fire in Many Years
description: The nineteenseventies, the business establishment in the United States fears, could be as wrenching for business as such other watershed times as those of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal or the trustbusting assault of the turn of the century.

title: Children's Unit Names Head
description: Hortense R. Landau has been named executive director of the New York Society for the Preevntion of Cruelty to Children. Miss Landau, a member of the society's staff since 1948, is a lawyer and a certified social worker and for the last year has been assistant executive director. She succeeds Thomas T. Becker, executive director for more than 20 years, who will remain with the society as assistant to the president, Elbridge T. Gerry Jr.

title: Hong Kong Brandy Fans Are Outdrinking French
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 4if an educated guess had to be made whether the per capita consumption of cognac is higher in the Cognac district or in this small British colony, the answer would almost certainly be Hong Kongespecially if the contest was limited to V.S.O.P. grades.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Wards Construction Company plans to build a 26story apartment tower on the west blockfront on Second Avenue between 26th and 27th Streets.

title: Sharp Tremor Jolts Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 4 (AP)A sharp earth tremor jolted central Chile today rocking buildings, rattling windows and frightening Chileans who live under the constant threat of earthquakes.

title: Arms and the Man in Europe
description: NICE, FranceOne major step in the improvement of FrancoAmerican relationships has been the defusing of what promised to be an angry argument over rivalry for new markets between the latest United States and French jet fighters.

title: Alicia du Pont MacGregor, Social Leader in Florida
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP)Alicia du Pont MacGregor, a member of the du Pont family of Delaware and a social and civic leader here for more than 25 years, died yesterday at the age of 67.

title: Letters
description: Terminology

title: The Attraction to the Mob Is Clear: It Can Clean Up
description: The State Attorney General began a series of court actions yesterday to drive racketeers and hoodlums from the private garbage collection industry in the metropolitan area.

title: The National Food Basket
description: (Third quarter) Retail prices are U.S. averages. Net farm value is based on the quantity of the commodity at the farm level required to make one retail unit.

title: A Quiet Town Clinging to Its Old Ways
description: HALEDONThe residents of this Passaic County borough like to talk about the past when they discuss what has happened here. They enjoy recalling visits by Dennis James, the television host, and Lou Costello, the late comedian, who used to come to Haledon to dine and lounge in the old Cedar Cliff Hotel on Belmont Avenue, a place where the atmosphere was similar to any oldtime mecca for vaudevillians.

title: Best Housing Hope Is for Slow Pickup
description: Mired in the worst slump since World War II, the United States housing industry faces an uncertain future in 1975.

title: Miss Rachelson Engaged
description: Marjorie Rachelson and Lawrence Samuels, seniors at Brandeis University, have become engaged and plan to marry in August. Dr. and Mrs. Morton H. Rachelson of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Samuels of Miami.

title: Miss Buchsbaum To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Buchsbaum of Rumson, N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Heyser Buchsbaum, to Edward Eric Holmgren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric O. Holmgren of New Shrewsbury, N.J.

title: Martha V. Hall Plans Wedding This Summer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Perry Hall of Newton Centre and Nahant, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Martha Vickery Hall, to William Harry Kehlenbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Edmund Kehlenbeck of Rockaway, N. J.

title: Tairow Is Destroyed at Calder; 3d Accident in 8 Days at Track
description: MIAMI, Jan. 4One week ago, in the Miss Florida Handicap, La Prevoyante suffered a ruptured lung and died. Last Wednesday, in the McKnight Handicap, Spot T.V. broke his leg and is fighting for his life. Today, when 14 threeyearolds ran in the $64,000 Dade turf classic at Calder, the victim was Tairow a son of Speak John, who cost $31,000 as yearling. Tairow, who had won two of his last three starts, broke his right leg going to the stretch turn and had to be destroyed on the track.

title: Is It News? Is It Show Biz? It's AM America!
description: Tomorrow morning, the Amerdcan Broadcasting Company enters the earlymorning TV. stakes. AM America, described as an entertainment  information newsmagazine, will premiere in the 7 to 9 A.M. slot, representing the network's first attempt to draw viewers from NBC's Today and the CBS Morning News. The show's hosts, in New York City, will be Bill Beutel and Stephanie Edwards, with Peter Jennings anchoring newscasts from Washington.

title: West's Coal Rush: A Chilly Welcome
description: While the Government continues debating how to solve the nation's energy problems, the energy industry is marching west to the Rocky Mountain states.

title: Reducing the A Variety of
description: WASHINGTON  President Ford is committed to cutting American oil imports one million barrels a day (from 7.4 million) by the end of this year. But how is he going to do it? And even if he succeeded, would it be enough and would it be worthwhile? In its original form, the idea was straightforward and even popular among those in Congress and elsewhere who felt the Administration had not done enough to cope with the energy crisis. But like so many ideas in the energy field, the closer one looks at it, the morecomplex it turns out to be.

title: Women as Travelling Salesmen
Americans Planning Major Grand Prix Effort
Economy Council Predicts Dismal '75 As Jobs, Profits and Revenues Decline
Surprise Exit From Plane
description: DENVER, Jan. 4 (UPI)About 15 persons on a United Airlines DC10 slid down emergency exit chutes that mistakenly opened last night when the plane's crew opened the front door for unloading. A United spokesman said that the plane, flight 282 from San Francisco to Chicago with an intermediate stop in Denver, carried 119 persons. The door opening set off an alarm that caused use of the chutes.

title: Dallas Mayor's Car Is Sold at Auction
description: DALLAS, Jan. 4The embarrassing financial situation of Mayor Wes Wise of Dallas, whose car was impounded and auctioned off this week, has triggered some grassroots efforts to help him pay off his debts.

title: Rangers Rally, Top Islanders
A Very Shaggy Dog Story
description: SOME 90 miles northeast of Munich there lies a sleepy Lower Bavarian village whose name rarely appears on a map, whose two spanking clean and incredibly inexpensive country inns are rarely fulland whose citizens are embroiled in as unlikely an international enibroglio as can be imagined.

title: Gen. Westmoreland Is Treated on Coast for a Heart Attack
description: DESERT Calif., Jan. 4 (AP) Gen. Williarn C. Westmoreland is being treated at the Eisenhower Medical Center after suffering an apparently mild heart attack, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: TV VIEW
description: Television's second season begins next week. I look forward to it, in the immortal words of Tom Lehrer, like a Christian Scientist with appendicitis. Whatever happened to the first season? All right, you don't care what happened to the first season. But since today is one of the few days in the past six months during which a professional football game will not be committed, you might as well pay attention. I am musclebound with disappointments.

title: Penny Gumball in Trouble
description: DETROIT, Jan, 4 (UPI)Inflation is ravaging the gumball business. Dealers who supply Detroitarea vending machines with gumballs say that, with costs rising, the product has been shrinking.

title: HearthFire
description: It used to be said that a fireplace was a wasteful thing, an inefficient way to produce heat. That was before the price of fuel oil headed for the moon, soon followed by the price of coal and natural gas. Now, particularly in the outer suburbs and beyond, many a family is learning the basic facts about a wood fire on the open hearth.

title: 2 Friendly Housewives at Hall of Fame
description: Sue Shea and Kay Delaney, two Scarsdale, N.Y., housewives who make spending money interviewing and videotaping ordinary country club athletes for playback fees, found themselves competing against major television networks and some of the nation's top broadcasters and sportswriters recently. Mrs. Shea, a mother of three and the camerawoman, and Mrs. Delaney, mother of three who does the interviews, were hired by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame to tape some events for its archives at the annual awards dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. They were the only housewives among the 1,300 guests, who included President Ford, Bob Hope and national football stars past and present.

title: Three novels
description: A friend once said to me that certain Europeans we know have absolutely no selfknowledge. Without really thinking I answered that Americans have lots of knowledge, but no self. This is a first novel about young New York creative types embarked on the Search for Self whichwhen you realize it's going on in millions of apartmentstakes on the mass character of a rush of lemmings. The young couple at the center of this story, Leonard and Jane, have not read How To Be Your Own Best Friend or any of those other tripguides; it happens to them spontaneously in the form of a certain discontent with their contentment and the selfsufficiency of their marriage, which has grown not so much stale as unchallenging.

title: Retailers Shift To Defensive Line
Rights Group's Hopes for '75
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 4At the weekly Saturday morning meeting of People United to Save Humanity, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson still leads the chant, I am somebody. He still raises a clenched fist and demands, What time is it? and his faithful followers still respond enthusiastically, It's nation time.

title: SEVENTH AVE.
description: Wool as a textile fiber has been largely overshadowed by the manmade fibers, but some astute operators of woolen and worsted machinery have succeeded not only in staying alive but leading in the production of styled fabrics that are much in demand.

title: 2 Women Winners In Stakes
The AvantGarde Discovers Chekhov
description: Something odd is happening to New York's theatrical avantgarde. Three of its most vociferous exponents and practitioners  Andre Gregory, Joseph Chaikin and JeanClaude van Itallie have fixed on none other than Anton Chekhov as their playwright of the moment. Not only have these three innovators opted for Chekhov but all have gone back to the Russian master's 1896 play The Sea Gull for their avant  garde entries of 1975. Andre Gregory's group, The Manhattan Project, will open its version of The Sea Gull at the Public Theater on Wednesday. Joseph Chaikin's staging of the play, in a new adaptation by JeanClaude van Itallie, opens Jan. 29 at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Recital
description: Between 1954 and 1959, David Davis gave at least four recitals here. The violinist then appears to have turned his back on the New York solo scene, not returning until last Friday night for a concert in Alice Tully Hall. With him at the piano, as before, was the estimable David Garvey.

title: Zoning Rules Sought for Air Over Streets
description: Foreseeing an increase in construction plans that utilize the air space above the streets, the City Planning Department is working out zoning proposals that will put this form of construction under its control.

title: Carlo Levi Dies in Rome at 72; Wrote Christ Stopped at Eboli
description: ROME, Jan. 4Carlo Levi, the writer and painter, died of pneumonia in a hospital here today. He was 72 years old, and had been taken ill on Christmas Day.

title: MRS. JOHN D. SMALL
description: Gwendolyn Davies Small, widow of Rear Adm. John D. retired, who had served as chairman of the Munitions Board in the Defense Department, died Friday in Jersey City, where she lived. Her age was 84.

title: Texas
description: DALLAS  A Tennessee woman brought reluctantly to Dallas by her husband 125 years ago, took one look at the placethe buffalo, the Indians, the mud and the heat and demanded to go home.

title: Tourism Down Worldwide But Up in Africa and Asia
description: GENEVA, Jan. 4 (Reuters) International tourism developed steadily in Africa and Asia including the Middle East in 1974, the World Tourism Organization said this week. But overall, tourism declined by 3 per cent, with Europe most affected.

title: City's CableTV Outlook Dim
description: The developers and regulators of cable television have a dour message for residents of Brooklyn and Queens: Don't expect it soon.

title: A Dream Of Skiing At Taos
description: THE other day, I met a New York couple who confessed to having the almost identical recurrent dream. Both husband and wife dream of endless slopes of dry, dry powder  blue skies, brilliant sun nary a lift line in sight. But there they literallypart company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Confidence in President Ford

title: The Central Questions Of Philosophy
description: A. J. Ayer is not a man to be pushed and pulled about by every fashionable current, Almost 40 years ago, in his positivist manifesto Language, Truth and Logic, he put the case for a radical empiricism and dismissed the claims of traditional metaphysics as meaningless because they are not even in principle verifiable. In the next three decades positivism lost its popularity, and the verifiability criterion of meaning was discredited. Philosophers were attracted instead to Wittgenstein's view of philosophy as a kind of intellectual therapy; then they were charmed by J. L. Austin's wit and subtle linguistic distinctions. Completing the circle, metaphysics eventually came back into fashion.

title: Nessen Says President Backs Kissinger Warning on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)President Ford's chief spokesman acknowledged today that Secretary of State Kissinger did reflect the President's views when he said the United States would consider using military force in the Middle East in the gravest emergency.

title: Sister Mary Benigna, 85, Blind Nun, Taught the Blind
description: Sister Mary Benigna, a teacher for 65 years at the Lavelle School for the Blind, the Bronx, died yesterday at the Mother House of the Sisters of St. Dominic of Blauvelt, N. Y. Her age was 85.

title: $4.5Billion Fund to Aid Jobless Approved by Ford
Oregon: a Testing Ground
description: SALEM, Ore.,Tom McCall has wound up the two consecutive terms as Republican Governor of Oregon, that green and rainy corner of the great Northwest. On Jan. 1 he bequeathed to a Democratic successor a state thatenvironmentally speaking, at leastis in far better shape than he found it.

title: Knicks Win by 103102 On LastSecond Shot
description: Walt Frazier, alias Clyde, alias Mr. Cool, scored on a 20foot turnaround jump shot at the final buzzer last night that enabled the Knicks to beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 103102, at Madison Square Garden.

title: FM Station on Air At Montclair State
description: MONTCLAIR  WMSCFM, Montclair State College's new radio station went on the air last week.

title: 8 Drown in Peru Mishap
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 4 (UPI)A launch carrying merchants selling goods to small towns along the Apurimas River in the central Peruvian Andes, overturned and eight persons drowned, according to reports reaching here today. The remaining 24 aboard were able to swim to the riverbanks, according to the reports.

title: LETTERS
description: Utility Reform

title: Nation's Dual Harvest: Abundance and Inflation
description: Food prices will remain high through 1975, but the costs of industrial goods should not rise appreciably until late in the second quarter. This economic assessment comes easily to commodity traders, the people who deal in the raw materials for the nation's future meals and manufactured goods.

title: STUDENTS' RIGHTS ON FILES DEFINED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) College students have been told that their right to see most of the information kept by schools in the students' personal files included the right to obtain copies of the records.

title: Bowie Turns to Trainees
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 4 (AP)Bowie Race Course began training replacements for striking workers today, but without announcing any definite plans to begin racing Monday.

title: On a Time Machine Called the Agony Line
description: ON a Friday morning in July, a small Greek steamer called the Evangelistria glides out of her berth and down the main channel of Piraeus Harbor toward the open Aegean. The Piraeus Town Hall clock says 11, but already the temperature is nearly 100 degrees Fahrenheit, and the worst of the day's heat is still ahead.

title: Venice Communists Begin Cooperation With City
description: ROME, Jan. 4The City Council of Venice attracted nationwide attention this week as it approved a longdisputed urban renewal project with Communist members voting in favor.

title: NEW COMMENTARY ON TORAH ISSUED
description: The first volume of a new commentary on the Torah, or the five books of Moses, will be published Jan. 15 by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which represents Reform Judaism.

title: The life and times of Multivac
Ellen Berezin Wed to Lewis A. Shenard
description: Ellen Ruth Berezin, assistant curator of education at the Worcester (Mass.) Art Museum, and Lewis A. Shepard, curator of the Mead Art Building at Amherst College, plan to be married in June.

title: Robert Kniffin to Wed Leta Pyne
description: The engagement of Leta Wright Pyne to Robert Swan Kniffin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Grafton H. Pyne of New York and Southport, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of the late Ogden Kniffin of New York and the late Catherine Swan Castles of Stamford, Conn.

title: Hunter Mows Ditches and Wife Sews As Life Hardly Changes in Hertford, N.C.
description: HERTFORD, N. C., Jan. 4He's out mowing the ditches.

title: Peking's Oil Strategy
description: The following is excerpted from China's Minerals and Metals, an article in U.S.China Business Review. The article was written by Peter D. Weintraub, an assistant editor of the review.

title: EUROPEARAB BID STALLED ON P.L.O.
description: BONN, Jan. 4Disagreement between France and its eight European Common Market partners over the status of the Palestine Liberation Organization has led to a long delay in a EuropeanArab dialogue on economic, technical and cultural cooperation.

title: SOME OR NATIONS ADJUSTING PRICES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4Crude oil prices at Mediterranean terminals have been reduced to meet the competition of exports from the Persian Gulf, and Libya is reported to have lifted her ban on oil sales to the United States.

title: Energy Decisions: America at the Crossroads
description: WASHINGTON  Stewart Udall, who says that as Secretary of Interior in the nineteensixties he was taken in by the braggadocio of America's oil industry, cites this passage from the late columnist to convey his sense of the new energypolicy road that he believes the United States must begin to follow.

title: Little Guy Plays It Safe
description: A small, informal survey of individuals once active in the stock market discloses a feeling of resignation over losses of recent years.

title: ALBANY BODY ASKS NOFAULT CHANGE
description: Changes in New York State's nofault automobile insurance and in medical malpractice insurance were recommended in a report yesterday by the Select Committee on Insurance.

title: Pakistan Quake victims Fight for Survival
description: PATTAN, Pakistan, Jan. 4 The icy villages in this valley of northern Pakistan are shattered. Huts of stone and mud have been wrecked by boulders. The bazaar in Pattan is a mound of rubble, and wooden planks are tossed in the fierce winds.

title: Two Titles Are Taken By Hunter
Sports News Briefs
Stars Down Pacers
Beginnings
description: Barely out of the playpen herself, Susanna Juliusburger is in a splendid position to diagram the very latest in discords between parents and childrenwhich she does in a refreshing novel whose polish is all the more surprising in the light of its author's tender years (17). We are presented here with the firstperson account of a summer spent in London by 14yearold Sana with her parents and two younger brothers. Mother and father are young university teachersgrasssmoking. beautiful people who swing a little in a controlled environment. They are tolerant of almost everything except one another.

title: New Trade Law to Admit Many DutyFree Goods From Poor Nations
description: WASHINGTONThe passage by Congress late last year of the manysided tradereform bill will enable negotiations to start this year on numerous international trade issues, but it will have little immediate effect on the flow of goods into and out of the United States.

title: J. D. Siegfried, Kathie Yoswein Plan Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Yoswein of Brooklyn, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kathie Irving Yoswein, to Jonathan Dick Siegfried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Siegfried of New York. The wedding will take place next summer.

title: Gas Utility Rescue Plan Cost Is High
Rider Graduates To Hear Governor
description: TRENTONGovernor Byrne will be the principal speaker at Rider College's 110th commencement on Feb. 9. He also will receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

title: Critics of Seoul Regime Get Warning on Stirring Unrest
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan, 4 (UPI)Premier Kim Jong Pil said today that the Government could not indefinitely tolerate the stirring of social confusion through irresponsible and academic demands for restoration of democracy in South Korea.

title: A Kind of Liberation vs. the Undermining of Basic Skills
description: In the late 17th century Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz designed a machine to mechanize the calculation of trigonometric and astronomical tables. It is unworthy of excellent men, he explained, to lose hours like slaves in the labor of calculations.

title: CHESS
description: Upsets are frequent enough in chess to justify regarding them as a permanent facet of the tournament scene. They occur even in games between players of widely disparate skill, because, although it may take 40 good moves to build up a winning position, it takes only one rotten blunder to wreck it.

title: New Man In The Chair
description: WASHINGTONAsk Senator William Proxmire what his top priority will be as the new chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and the answer comes out plural.

title: Miss Alderman Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Alderman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Alderman, to Dr. Harold M. Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rosenthal. Both families are of Brooklyn. The future bride is an educational consultant on early childhood at the University of Virginia Hospital. Her fianc is an interne at the Georgetown University Medical Center.

title: Notes: That as The Year That Was
description: NINETEEN seventyfour opened with a fuel crisis and ended with inflation raging amid recession. It was a year in which traditional travel patterns in the United States showed dramatic change, including a decline in automotive travel and increased use of common carriers for longdistance trips.

title: The Anticipated American Gold Rush of 1975 Opened More Like a Crawl
description: America moved into its new golden era last month in slow motion. Investors and speculators who had been widely expected to flock to the nation's banks and brokerage houses to buy gold decided instead to sit back and watch.

title: ADVERTISING
description: In his letter to Santa in behalf of his agency Stanley I. Tannenbaum, chairman of Kenyon & Eckhardt, asked for a number of goodies inincluding a cheap but effective set of worry beads for himself.

title: SCIENTOLOGY CHURCH GIVES EDICT TO C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) The controversial Church of Scientology said today that it had delivered to the Central Intelligence Agency a court order forbidding the agency to destroy any files it has on the church.

title: Planners Approve 3 Landmark Sites
Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Pragmatic Immorality
description: Today's issue of The New York Times Magazine carries a description of one of the most pessimistic and morally threadbare intellectual positions to be advanced since the demise of the Third Reich. The position, called Triage, is based on a military medical practicenecessitated by scarcityof separating the wounded into three categories: those who would get well without treatment, those who would die no matter what, and those who might be saved if given care. Only the wounded in the last category were treated.

title: Austrians Debate Whether Skiers or Resorts Are at Fault in Fatal Snowslides
description: VIENNA, Jan. 4Avalanches in Austrian ski areas that killed 21 persons in the last two weeks of 1974 have set off a nationwide debate here on the responsibility for such disasters.

title: NAGRIN JAZZ DANCES A RELAXED PROGRAM
description: Jazz dance rose from its slave origins to master Broadway, Hollywood and, in part, concert dance. Daniel Nagrin, whose own solos and group pieces have formed a coherent body of jazzorinted work discussed and performed a lovely blend of dance Friday evening at his studio theater, 550 Broadway.

title: Brazilian Government Lifts Censorship on Leading Newspaper
description: BRASILIA, Jan. 4 Brazil lifted censorship today from the country's leading daily newspaper and defender of press freedom, O Estado de Sao Paulo, which is celebrating its hundredth anniversary.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A Canadian writer with the euphonious name of Reymoure Keith Isely now has a first crime novel to his creditA STRANGE CODE OF JUSTICE (BobbsMerrill, $6.50). It is a promising piece of work, though it is notable more for its deft writing than any originality in plotting. But good writing is always a precious commodity, and the world of the crime novel is full of construction engineers. Isely turns out to be an architect rather than an engineer.

title: Euclid M. Covington, a Founder Of This Week Magazine, Dies
description: Euclid M. Covington, a retired publishing executive and a principal founder of This Week magazine, died Thursday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Sharon.

title: Miss Burke Fiancee of Robert McGowan
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Moy Burke of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Dow Burke of Takoma Park, Md., to Robert Paul McGowan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pennell McGowan of Adelphi, Md.

title: Gulf Coast Oil Negotiations
description: HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 4 (AP)  Major oil companies along the Gulf Coast and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union began negotiations today in an effort to avoid a strike on Tuesday The union is seeking pay rises of $1.50 an hour each year for the next three years. The companies have generally offered 60 cents an hour for the first year of a two year contract and about 50 cents the second year. The 7,500 Members now are paid an average $5.95 per hour.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 7New Jersey Association of Corvair Enthusiasts meeting at Dodley Chevrolet, 685 U.S. Highway 202206 North, Somerville, N. J., 7:30 P.M.

title: L.I.R.R. Union Selects Raymond Mills as Head
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 4Raymond J. Mills of Jamaica, Queens, has been elected chairman of the United Transportation Union of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: CAMERA VIEW
Future Social Events
description: Jan. 9The genus rosa is generally prickly stemmed but the 22d annual Ball of Roses at the Plaza, is a thornless variety. The ball aids Roosevelt Hospital's free medical care fund for patients not covered by health insurance or public assistance. The Grand Ballroom will be a bower of roses, with bouquets centering tables and others threading their way through abundant treillage. Lester Lanin, who has conducted the music for the 21 balls so far, will again augment the glow of dancers. Mrs. Norman L. Hope is chairman. Tickets, $75; for juniors, $35. By invitation only.

title: Ranger Fans Heat Islander Ice
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 4 At 8:09 tonight in Nassau Coliseum the New York Rangers scored a goal against the New York Islanders, and the cheers came loud and strong.. Once again Ranger fans had permeated the home ice of Long Island's only majorleague hockey team and made their presence heard in what is rapidly becoming the N.H.L.'s hottest rivalry.

title: Hearings to Begin On Kickback Suit
description: MINEOLAHearings on a suit naming Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive; Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, chairman of the county Republican Committee, and the County and State Civil Service Commission on allegations of kickbacks to the Republican party by county employes are to begin Wednesday.

title: CARDINAL COOKE HELPS NEEDIEST
description: A personal check for $250 has been received from Cardinal Cooke for the 63d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with a messageThank you so much for continuing to remind us of the persontoperson response.

title: Pamela McLean Married to Nelson Ehly
description: Pamela Ann McLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Douglas McLean of Mount Kisco, N. Y., was martried yesterday afternoon to Nelson Richard Ehly, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Wileman Ehly of East Berlin, Pa. Canon Wendell W. Philips performed the ceremony in Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, assisted by the Rev. Gerald Leon Ehly, a Congregational minister and uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Evelyne Handy Fiancee Of Stephen D. Ryan 3d
description: Evelyne Romaine Handy, a sophomore at Kirkland College in Clinton, N.Y., who is attending Oxford University in a yearabroad program, and Stephen David Ryan 3d, a Keasbey Scholar at Oxford, where he is completing his final year of graduate study in history, plan to marry late summer.

title: Egyptians Inform U.S. That Brezhnev Has Pneumonia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Egyptian officials have told the United States that Leonid I. Brezhnev was suffering from pneumonia but that EgyptianSoviet policy differences also had contributed to the Soviet leader's decision to postpone his trip to the Middle East.

title: Office Stairs Take Novel Twists
description: Private staircases, increasingly recognized as apt solutions to officedesign problems, are coming into their own in the city's skyscrapers.

title: Secret Service to Observe 110th Anniversary in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) The Secret Service will celebrate its 110th anniversary in 1975, its director, H. S. Knight, says.

title: BRITISH MINISTER MEETS VORSTER
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 4 (Reuters)  Britain's Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, arrived in Zambia tonight after holding what he called a frank exchange of views with South Africa's Prime Minister, John Vorster, concentrating on Rhodesia's constitutional dispute with Britain.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Pro Basketball

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GOVERNMENT economists are urging President Ford to cut taxes to pull the economy out of recession. Mr. Ford is said to have cooled on his proposal for an incometax surcharge.A lack of interest in gold by Americans brought a sharp drop in gold prices in European and domestic markets. Gold closed in London Friday at $174 an ounce, down from $195 an ounce a week earlier. The First National City Bank raised its prime rate from 10 per cent to 10 per cent.

title: A Gala Birthday for a Glittering Company
description: When the late Richard Pleasant founded Ballet Theater in 1939, he envisioned a company that would be a lively and glamorous museum of dance. The museum that he had in mind was to have many wings  one to display the ballet classics, scrupulously remounted and polished until they glowed; another to collect and exhibit the most interesting and valuable contemporary works from Europe and America; another to discover new and controversial art. As American Ballet Theater begins its 35th anniversary season at City Centera season to be climaxed by a gala celebration next Saturday nightthe company is displaying the same lavish talent, diversity and optimism with which it began. (The American was added to the name for the company's second State Department tour abroad in .1956.)

title: UTLITY EXEMPTED ON WATER TOWERS
description: The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection has exempted Northeast Utilities, the state's largest producer of electricity, from a regulation that would have required it to build a $150million series of cooling towers for its nuclear power plants at Millstone Point in Waterford, Conn.

title: Ideas & Trands
description: Police are turning increasingly from shooting to talking in situations in which hostages have been taken. The following report describes the operation of one special negotiating team.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Training OntheJob for Arab Financiers

description: Alfred Letourner, who won scores of bicycle races in the nineteentwenties and thirties, when such endurance tests were in their heydey, died yesterday at his home, 19 West 85th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: How Much Is Enough?
description: President Ford apparently returned home from his ski trip to find his economic advisers generally agreed upon the necessity for some degree of tax reduction as a stimulus to the economy. If any of them, or Mr. Ford himself, was skeptical about it, his doubts must have been removed by the disastrous unemployment figures just in for December.

title: Patricia Whitney To Marry in June

Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Raymond Lawrence Whitney of New Brunswick, N. J., and Blue Hill, Me., mother of the bridetobe.

description: HARTFORDA draft of the final report of the Governor's Task Force on Oil Refineries scheduled to be delivered to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill tomorrow finds that it would be unwise for Connecticut to proceed with refinery development at this time.

title: Princeton Five U psets Penn,5049
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 4After taking a 4024 lead early in the second half, Princeton survived a furious Penn comeback bid to upset the Quakers 5049, today before 4,000 at Jadwin Gymnasium.

description: Campbells Court Queen, a fourthgeneration red and white homebred cocker spaniel came up from Dade City, Fla., yesterday and won the futurity stake at the American Spaniel Club specialty at the StatlerHilton.

title: Mary Robinson Fiancee Of Kent Carter Jewett
description: The Right Rev. Harold Barrett Robinson, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western New York, and Mrs. Robinson of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Robinson, to Kent Carter Jewett, son of Mr. and Mrs. N. Holland Jewett, also of Buffalo.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The Schoenberg centennial year is over and, predictably, the celebrations have been muted performances of the major orchestral works here and there, some chamber concerts, a few seminars and magazine articles seem rather meager tributes to a composer who is generally conceded to have shaped the destiny of 20thcentury music.

title: From Idea Into House
description: Anyone who has watched the process of a house in the making will never forget it. The open meadow or mossy woodland that we fell in love with in the first place is transformed into a barren gravel heap surrounding an open pit. The earth is scarred with tire tracks and pot holes from trucks, trailers and timbers piled around the site. For months the place is the scene of violent noise and activitythe whirr of cement mixers, dump trucks, hammers and buzz sawsuntil slowly order finds its way out of the chaos and the skeleton of the house appears.

title: LEADERS OF INDIA IRATE AT KILLING
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 4Prime Minister Indira Gandhi flew today to the village of her Railway Minister, Lalit Narayan Mishra, a victim of a bomb explosion Thursday, to attend his funeral.

title: Food
description: If there was ever such a thing as a classic American dessert, it must be Indian puddingmuch more valid than apple pie, which has a European heritage. We know of one recipe for Indian pudding, a variation of which is said to have been served in a New England family for nearly 200 years. It is that of Kathleen and Sam Scranton of Minneapolis. Their forebears started the custom of serving Indian pudding during the cold winter days in Connecticut. Originally, Sam Scranton says, it was served with hard sauce. Then Delmonico sauce became the family favorite. Delmonico sauce is an English custard flavored with vanilla. orange. Slice the orange thinly, then cut each sliceflesh, skin, juice and allinto very small cubes. Add the orange to the cornmeal mixture.

title: The Auto Industry's Price Gamble
description: DETROITWhen will the automobile industry cut prices?

New Orleans Goes Into HillBuilding Business to Pacify Its Citizens
RUSSIAN WARNS U.S. ON LOSING BUSINESS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (AP)A Soviet commentator suggested today that Russia's business could go to other capitalist countries if Washington persisted in limiting trade credits to the Soviet Union.

title: A Teacher Takes Time Off to Play
description: When a noted music teacher does not perform in public regularly, it is something of an event when one leaves the studio and heads for the concert platform. This will happen on Monday night, when Adele Marcus plays a recital at Alice Tully Hall, her first in this city since 1963.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Mordecai Richler, a Canadian, is author of Saint Urbain's Horseman and other novels.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: ** The Swiss Chalet, Route 17, Ramsey. (201) 3270800.The Swiss Chalet has grown from a small wayside stop serving Swiss food, which opened in 1918, into a large, showy, catering and dining place offering a steak and seafood menu with continental specialties. Floyd Aramino has been the owner since 1968.

title: Wealth Migration Is Global Challenge
description: Before the world can lighten the burdens of inflation and recession, it must first solve the problems of energy, many economists agree.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Some people affect to see a similarity between audiences for the performing artsespecially classic dance, with its emphasis on bodily skillsand the audiences for sport. Well, that pretense might be more credible if people kept score at the theater or the opera houseand every performance ended in a definitive result. Yet what such arts do have in common with sports Is a certain, occasionally intense rivalry between the participants, and a frequently marked partisanship among the audience. This partnership is often all the more intense in the arts because of that missing objective result. It cannot be proved that one tenor is better than another, but if at the end of a boxing match George Foreman is on the canvas and Muhammad Ali is standing up, there is strong presumptive evidence that the latter is the better.

title: What They Are Saying
INVESTING
description: If you're fairly young, selfemployed and reasonably successful, you can save on taxes and retire a millionaire, a savings bank exclaimed recently in an advertisement aimed at attracting deposits.

title: TAX BITE IN STATE IS LARGEST IN U.S., SURVEY DISCLOSES

Robin Boucher Bride of Alexander Benet
description: Robin Elisabeth Boucher of New York and Alexander Victor Bent of Key Biscayne, Fla., were married yesterday afternoon in Palm Beach, Fla., where the Rev. Hunsdon Cary Jr. performed the ceremony in the Bethesdabythe Sea Episcopal Church.

title: So You Want to Be A Judge?
description: BOSTONBeing a judge is not a bad job. There's comparatively little heavy lifting, the robe keeps your regular clothes from getting shiny on the seat, and you don't have to take any back talk, on duty.

title: Boy
description: This novel is said to have headed the French bestseller list for several months. Here, it's destined for rather special tastes. It's an atmospheric period piece, a sort of French Summer of 42 except it's summer of 37 and very aristocratic, languid and sunny on the Basque coast, with little rumblings of external trouble (the Spanish Civil War) and internal decay (the gradually revealed alcoholism and gambling of dashing young Uncle Boy) sensed behind the pretty painted scenes. In other words, a novel of the last innocent summer. It's told from the alternating points of view of a precocious girlchildd and a sensual Basque servant girl, both of whom are, in their very different ways, smitten with Boy. Twelve  year  old Hildegarde, the daughter of the Malgasse family, regards Boyher mother's younger brotheras a special ally, playmate and gallant; Suzon the maid has been at his sexual beck and call every summer for years. But this is the summer when Boy reveals his decadent is not quite the right worddissolute qualities; Hildegarde must eventually see her hero falling down drunk and gambling  broke, and Suzon gradually turns toward a man of her own kind, strong and clean and simple and healthy. The denouement is tragic and fixes Boy in nostalgia forever, the incarnation of innocence lost.

title: U.S. Seeks Court Order In Sex Bias at Symphony
National Health Insurance Debated
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout this decade liberals on Capitol Hill have been arguing that national health insurance is an issue whose time has come.

title: Ballet: Two Sylphides
description: Ballet Theater's production of La Sylphide may not be the best in the worldthe current Royal Danish Ballet version and the now sadly lost ElsaMarianne Von Rosen productions for Ballet Rambert and the National Ballet of Washington spring to mindbut it is still lovely. Erick Bruhn has staged it with authority and affection.

title: TwoDay Air Defense Test Planned Over Many States
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 4 (AP)Military aircraft will fly over towns and cities from the Midwest to the Atlantic when the North American Air Defense Command and the Strategic Air Command hold a joint air defense training exercise Tuesday and Wednesday, a spokesman at command headQuarters here said.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, asked the Federal Aviation Administration today to require airlines to accept disabled passengers.

description: The operation of the $40million Suffolk State School for the mentally retarded, In Melville, L.I., has been broadly criticized in an audit report from the State Controller's office.

title: INDIANS EXCHANGE SHOTS WITH POLICE
description: GRESHAM, Wis., Jan. 4 (UPI) Law enforcement officers and Menominee Indians occupying a monastery exchanged gunfire late today for the first time since the Menominees seized the building New Year's Day and demanded that the monastery and its lands be turned over to them under Federal law for a medical center.

title: Closing of Last Steel Furnaces Alarms Gary, Ind.
description: GARY, Ind., Jan. 2Since 1909, three years after this working man's city was established by the steel industry, the United States Steel Corporation's Open Hearth No. 4 had been producing 80,000 tons of steel a month.

description: In the salt bays of the Northeast and among the black rocks of Connecticut's Thimble Islands, rafts of hardy bluebills ride the cold, gray water.

description: An excellent talk on canine nutrition was delivered by Dr. James E. Creed at a recent dog health seminar at Colorado State University. The event was sponsored by the Morris Animal Foundation, Colorado Purebred Dog Fanciers Association, and the university's veterinary college. The speech, in part, follows:

title: Helen W. Metz Wed in Israel
description: Helen Winchester Metz, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Ronald Irwin Metz, was married in Jerusalem yesterday to Ibrahim Samaan Ashrawi, son of Salwa Ashrawi of Nazareth and Jerusalem and the late Samaan Ashrawi. The bride's father, executive assistant to the Anglican Vicar General in Jerusalem performed the ceremony in the Cathedral Church of St. George the Martyr.

title: She Helps Americans in Israel
description: When Sima Altman moved into her new apartment in Ramat Aviv, Israel, recently, she met with a huge mass of resistance from everyone involvedthe tile layer, a Yemenite; the person handling her dutyfree goods, who was from South Africa; the building's construction engineer from the Soviet Union; and the carpenter, a sabra, or nativeborn Israeli, who built her kitchen cabinets without leaving enough space for the refrigerator.

title: JORDAN AND P.L.O. TO HOLD PARLEYS

description: Jane Elizabeth Osgood, a recent graduate of Bard College, was married yesterday noon to Andre Marino Vagliano, a classics student at Bard who will continue his studies in Athens. The Rev. Robert West performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Windsor, Vt.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ECONOMIC commentators at the turn of the year have had their fun proclaiming the onset of the fourth quarter of the 20th century and theorizing on what its particular characteristics might be. But historians of the future might find it more convenient to date the new age, not from 1975 or even, for calendar purists, from 1976, but from 1974 or the closing months of 1973.

title: Judith Asher Engaged To Edward M. Lane
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Asher of Kings Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Sadie Asher, to Edward Michael Lane, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Ellison Lane of Plandome Manor, L. I.

description: MARLBORO, Mass., Jan. 4 (AP)A threemonthold baby, Jessica Gamache, was rescued uninjured when three men lifted a mediumsized car that had landed on top of her baby carriage. A man in a service station, who declined to give his name, said that he and two others lifted the front bumper of the car so the baby could be removed from the carriage in which it was trapped.

title: In the Land Of Plenty
description: An air of emergency has now overtaken the careful stepatatime approach to the economy President Ford has advocated for the last several months, and with dramatic reason. The Government's latest unemployment figures show that 7.1 per cent of the nation's workers were without jobs in December, an extraordinary increase of .6 per cent in a single month and of 1.1 per cent in just two months.

title: State Holds Firm on Closing Flemington Police Barracks
description: FLEMINGTONA spokesman for State Attorney General William F. Hyland warned last week that the decision to keep open the state police barracks here past New Year's Day was a reprieve, not a cancellation, of Mans to shut it down.

title: Erie Lackawanna Calls Aid for New Cars Skimpy
description: A Federal grant providing funds for 160 new airconditioned passenger cars on the Erie Lackawanna's electrified lines falls short of the system's needs, according to the railroad.
