description: Jim Hunter is about the size of a large millionaire. Like most of the men who played with him for the Oakland Ns, he is fairly hairy, with a coiffure that overhangs his ears like a thatched roof and an upper lip likely to attract a pair of indigo buntines at nesting time. Now in hic 2th year, he moves and talks with the quiet assurance of a man who has pitched successfully in the American League since he was 19, has thrown many shutouts and one perfect game, is undefeated in three World Series and has been

title: WOMAN SHOT DEAD BY 3 MEN IN BRONX
description: Three armed men forced their way into an apartment in the East Bronx shortly after midnight today and shot a 27yearold woman to death, the police reported.

title: New Postal Chief
description: When Benjamin F. Bailar echoes the rallying cry of his predecessor as Postmaster General, Elmer T. Klassen, that there is no better bargain in the country than the mail service, he does so from the vantage point of a Harvardtrained financial mana ger.

title: F.P.C. Starts Study Of Cutbacks in Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Federal Power Commission has begun an investigation of massive natural gas cutbacks to industrial users by the TTanscontinental Gas Pipeline Company, a pipeline operating in states from Texas to New Ynrk

title: Federal Judge Sworn In
description: CAMDEN, Jan, 9 (AP)John F. Gerry was sworn in as a Federal judge today. replacing Judge James A. Coolshan, who went on senior status in 1974. Judge Gerry was appointed to the Camden County Court in 1972 and promoted in the State Superior Court in 1973. He is a 1950 graduate of Princeton University and a 1963 graduate of the Harvard Law School.

title: Thai Flood Toll at 122
description: BINGROK, Thailand, Jan. 9 (AP)  The death toll from floods in southern Thailand rose to 122 dead today with the finding of 28 more bodies, the Ministry of Interior announced. Heavy, unseasonal rains continued for the See. end, day, but the flood waters were beginning to subside in some areas, the ministry reported. Rubber and rice crops were expected to be seriously lamaged,

title: Legislators React Warily To Jordan's Fiscal Plans
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 9Mayor Paul T. Jordan got a guarded reaction today from Hudson County's Assembly delegation on some of the legislative proposals he had offered in the hope of making up projected 915.7million shortfall between income and outgo in Jersey City's 1975 budget.

description: In Billions

description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1975

title: Feelin Mighty Low
description: Depression and the start of winter have long been associated with each other. The mythology of all except tropical countries is filled with great concern that the sun will continue to grow weaker, the days shorter, and the earth will fail to renew itself. Elaborate ceremonies are performed to encourage the return of light and warmth. Sympathetic magic is usedthe lighting of candles and firesto attempt to manipulate or persuade the powers that be.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, January 9, 1975

title: 65th National Boat Show Will Set Sail Tomorrow
description: The National Boat Show, a midwinter fixture in New York for almost seven decades, opens at the Coliseum tomorrow with about 450 craft assembled on four floors in 360 exhibits. Furtherrnore, Mayor Beame has declared the coming week to be National Boat Show week.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Alleged Crime Chief Freed On Parole After Six Years
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Jan. 9 (UPI)Raymond L. S. Patriarca, alleged New England crime overlord, left prison today on parole after six years behind bars.

title: Louisville Stays Unbeaten, 5351
description: CANYON, Tex., Jan, 9 (AP) Philip Bond scored on a breakaway layup as time ran out to give unbeaten Louisville a 5351 victory over West Texas State in a Missouri Valley Conference game tonight.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Saudi Arabia has entered into a $750million contract with the United States for the purchase of 60 F5 jet fighters and the training of pilots.

title: Oiland Gold Help Soviet, but Hurt Comecon
description: PARIS, Jan. 9Oil and gold price increases, which have rocked the Western world's monetary and economic structures over the last 15 months, are producing windfall profits for the Soviet Union, according to analysts.

title: PIERRE FRESNAY, ACTOR, 77, DEAD
description: PARIS, Jan. 9Pierre Fresnay, the stage and film actor, died tonight at the American Hospital in NeuillysarSeine, near Paris. He was 77 years old.

title: Ballet: Episodes Debuts
description: There are many sides to the New York City Ballet, but it is ballets such as George Balan chi n e's Episodes, created in 1959 to the music of Anton Webern, that typify the company's revolutionary, even avantgarde aspect.

title: Problem Is Reported In Replacing a Plug Of Chevrolet Monza,
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP)General Motors said today that the entire engine sometimes has to be lifted to change the spark plugs in tuneups on its Chevrolet Monza 2plus2 V8.

title: Nureyev Awes Growing Audience
description: The appearance of Rudolf Nureyev and his nimblefooted friends, on Broadway, a world away from their usual haunts and admirers, is drawing new andiences, many of whom had seem modern dance or ballet only on television or in stage musicals.

description: The Department of Transportation, in an action endorsed by major Ford Administration economic advisers, proposed yesterday an immediate 10 per Cent cut in domestic aircoach fares.

title: Mrs. Grasso Defines Extent of Deficit To 1.50 in Administration on First Day
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 9On her first full day in office, Gov. Ella T. Grasso disclosed some bad news about the extent of the deficits Connecticut faces, and then went home early to catch some much needed rest.

title: SACCHARIN ROLE IS STILL NOT CLEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9After a study that began two and a half years ago, a panel of experts reported today that it still could not determine whether the artificial sweetener saccharin caused cancer when fed to animals.

description: The City Health Commis. sioner, Lowell E. Bellin, announced yesterday that the city would resume the inspection or nursing homes, a function taken away from it in September, 1973, and given to the state.

description: Continuing our discussion of the peculiar tribal mores at rock concerts, we come to the question of encores.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Secrecary of State KissInger has asked one of his top aides, Robert J. McCloskey, to assume! Julies as top liaison official; with Congress. President Ford is expected to announce the appointment soon.

description: A profitmeasuring and profitreporting regulation that implements a requirement of its nofault automobile insurance law has been issued by the New York State Insurance Department.

description: By ROBERT E. BEDINGFIELD

title: About Real Estate
description: At Ruppert Towers, the community room will be a tenant lounge, with furnishings, a coffee bar and a player piano. The halls will be found to be carpeted, the kitchens, colored, the rooms, 50 per cent larger than standard MitchellLama size.

description: Television News, Inc., a syndicated news service for television stations, which has been in operation for two years, yesterday disclosed plans to distribute its video news materials nationally by Westar, the domestic communications satellite operated by Western Union.

description: ARCADE, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP)Motorola, Inc., the largest employer in Wyomiag County, plans to lay of 375 administrative and production workers here later this month.

title: Post at Columbia Filled
description: Ward H. Dennis, associate dean of Columbia University's School of General Studies, has been named director of Columbia's Institute of Latin American Studies. He will continue in his posts as associate dean and assistant professor of Spanish.

title: N.C. State Romps; 32 for Thompson
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 9 (AP)North Carolina State's David Thompson scored 32 points and grabbed 10 rebounds tonight while leading the fourthranked Wolfpack to a 11961 rout of Western Carolina.

title: Chrysler to Idle 14,800, Closing 4 Plants for Week
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation said today that three of its six assemOly plants and one of two truck plants would be closed next week because of the slump in new car and truck sales.

title: The Laws of the White Man Have Hurt the Menominee
description: KESHENA, Wis., Jan 9Nearly 14 years ago, the Federal Government dissolved the Menominee Indian Reservation, and the beautiful 235000acre wooded tract that is the ancestral homeland of the tribe became Wisconsin's smallest and poorest county.

title: Vehicles All Over Nigeria Are Out of Gas in Strike
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 8Thousands of vehicles have been stranded throughout Nigeria for lack of fuel because of an illegal work stoppage by truck drivers who transport petroleum products to the nation's 12 states.

title: New City Law Course Planned To Revise Standard Curriculum
description: City College and New York Law School have completed plans for what their officials believe will be the first program in the country to integrate undergraduatae studies and legal education, allowing students to get law degrees six years afte,fentering college.

description: An income tax reduction for individuals totaling $20billion to help spur an attack on both inflation and recession was urged yesterday by Philip M. Klutznick, chairman of the research and policy committee of the Committee for Economic Development.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 9The president of B'nai B'rith today attacked a statement by 14 representatives of religious groups who had appraised the record of the recent General Assembly and found much that was positive.

title: Music: Siegel, Pianist
description: Jeffrey Siegel is no newcorner to the music world, and his performances during the last few years have made it clear that he is a pianist of more than ordinary attainments. Neveretheless, this listener was not quite prepared for the. superb musicmaking and uncommonly sensitive playing that the 32yearold virtuoso provided Wednesday night in his recital at Alice Tully Hall.

title: U.S. TO BAR FUNDS TO NURSING HOMES THAT IGNORE CODE
description: The Federal Government, in what it described as a major change of policy, announced here yesterday that it would stop paying its 50 per cent share of Medicaid to nursing homes that violate its lifesafety code. Officials began by giving 45 days notice to. New York State regarding nine noncomplying facilities.

title: ROLAND D'ALBIS
description: Roland d'Albis, who retired Jan. 1 as director of French Expositions in the United States, Inc., a division here of the French Embassy, died Wednesday in Paris. His age was 66.

title: Power Cut Off on IRT Line
description: Power on all four IRT Seventh Avenue line between Houston Street and Times Square was cut oft between 2:34 and 2:44 P.M. by the police who were pursuing a man who grabbed $61 from a supermarket cash register and fled along the tracks. No arrest was reported.

description: Dr. Carl Hartley Greene, a retired New York internist and gastroenterologist, died Tuesday at his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: Philadelphia Girl Stabbed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (UPI) A teenaged baby sitter whol was stabbed 25 times with an ice pick yesterday morning was listed in guarded condition today at Chestnut Hill Hospital. The authorities said they believed that the girl, identified as Marilyn Streeter, 13 years old, was stabbed by the same assailants who killed a man who was taking her home,

title: Nixon, on 62d BiTthclav Called Physically Troubled
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 9Richard M. Nixon is very thin, tires easily, has a poor appetite and trouble sleeping but is gradually, gradually recovering from surgery on his phlebitisdamaged left leg, Rabbi Baruch M. Korff said today on the former President's 62d birthday.

title: TV: View of Gerald Ford's America
description: TVTV (formerly Top Value Television), the videotape group that brought you Lord of the Universe, is returning to public television with a series of four weekly halfhours about Gerald Ford's America. On screen, the title is projected in the shape of a football, providing a pointed clue to the tone and style of the series. It begins on Channel 13 this evening at 10:30.

title: People and Business
description: Richard M. Burdge, who joined the American Stock Exchange as senior vice president in 1968, has submitted his resignation as president. Paul Kolton, the Amex's chairman, said it was being reluctantly accepted by the board.

description: A precise, practical man, he sat at his paperlittered desk, pressed his fingertips togeth, er and shyly admitted it was not easy to keep creating champions.

title: Before You Buy Your Dream Boat, Find a Place to Keep
description: Anyone living In a metropolitan area who is contemplating the purchase of a sizable boat, sail or power, should first find a home for it. A home means a slip or mooring for the season and a storage yard for the off season. All are in short supply, and one Connecticut dealer termed the situation critical.

description: (Resorts are smiled by resort owners. Not all lifts operating.)

title: France, Facing Oil Bills, Revalues Gold to $170.40
description: PARIS, Jan. 9France, in a move designed primarily to increase its international borrowing power in order to finance imports following the quintupling of the price of oil, quadrupled the valuation of her gold reserves today, to $170.40 an ounce.

title: SENATORS ASK DATA ON LA FORCE ENGINE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Senate Commerce Committee has asked the Environmental Protection Agency to turn over its files and documents pertaining to the agency's testing of the experimental LaForce automobile engine.

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 9 (AP)Johnny Miller, exhibiting the quiet confidence and crisp shotmaking that won him playeroftheyear honors last season, opened the 1975 pro golf tour today with a fourunderpar 67. However, he had to share the firstround lead in the $150,000 Phoenix open with John Mahaffey and Leonard Thompson.

description: Residents of about a third of the nations 50 states face possible tax increases this year as legislators and Governors try to balance budgets at a time when revenues are not keeping pace with inflation.

Marchi, chairman of the Finance Committee of the Republicancontrolled Senate, today, criticized Governor Carey's proposal for tax increases and budget cuts as an apparent bargaining point that was likely to be the subject during the legislative session of compromises more favorable for localities.

title: Money and Sex Called Motives Of Widow for Slaying Husband
description: PATERSON, Jan. 9  Rose Costanza, the widow of a wealthy Clifton pavin contractor who was shot to death three years ago, was accused at a civil trial today of slaying him because he could not satisfy her exorbitant demands in money and sex. the charge was made in opening remarks by William 0. Barnes Jr., a lawyer for present and former members of the Costanza family who are seeking to deprive her of six parcels of land she stands to inherit and $52,000 in insurance money. Mrs. Costanza has not been charged with any crime.

title: Car Parkers Sign Pact
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (UPI)San Francisco's parking attendants have reached tentative agreement on a twoyear contract under which they will earn $4.60 an hour in the first year and $5.06 an hour in the second year. Benefits include tour weeics vacation after 20 years on the job, and dental and visual coverage in their medical insurance.

title: Man Outwits Computer
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)A resident here recently received his monthly bill from a utility company for $0.000. He sent in a check for that amount. Apparently it was accepted by the computer, He received no further bill.

title: BILLS TO MEDICAID DIFFER UP TO 600%
description: For virtually identical services, bills submitted by a sample of nursing Home here for medicaid reinbursement in 1973 varied by as much as 600 per cent, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Business Briefs

title: People in Sports
description: Ken Stabler, the lefthanded quarterback whose 26 touchdown passes helped the Oakland Raiders to compile a 122 wonlost record during the regular season, was named the National Football League's most valuable player yesterday by the Associated Press. Receiving 36 of 78 votes cast, he easily outdistanced his nearest competitorsTerry Metcalf, a St. Louisrunning back, who drew 10 votes and Chuck Foreman, a power runner from Minnesota, who garnered five votes.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials fell slightly to 207.8 from 207.9 last week.

title: Jersey and U.S. Clash on Jobless Rate
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9State and Federal officials continue to argue over the true impact of unemployment in New Jersey,, with $10million to $15million In aid at stake, while city and county official scramble to meet tomorrow's filing deadline, for aid under a special public, employment program.

title: 14 DEAD ON COAST AS PLANES COLLIDE
description: WHITTIER, Calif., Jan. 9 Fourteen persons died today as two planes collided and fell into a school area filled with children, but none of the children were hurt.

title: Military Men Challenge Mideast  Force Strate
description: Senior American and Westem European military officers consider the seizure of selected Middle East oil fields militarily feasible but politically disastrous.

title: Notes on People
description: A rare personal statement by President Ford accompanied his official announcement yesterday that with special pleasure he had chosen Elliot L. Richardson to be Ambassador to Britain. Senate confirmation is considered a certainty.

title: Namath's Price Taff
description: While Joe Namath's laWyer was reportedly putting a $1million price tag on his fragile quarterback, the owner of the New York Jets, Phil7Iselin, was preparing to fly to New Orleans from New'York today, confident Of keeping his star at a lesser figure.

title: Islanders Finally Beat Flyers on the Road, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9The New York Islanders aren't waiting for the Bicentennial here to celebrate. The firecrackers and sparklers were exploding in the form of bedlam in the Islanders locker room tonight after New York defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 31. It was the first time that New York has beaten the Flyers in the intimidating Spectrum. They had tried seven times before. The Flyers were not themselves tonight, many of them playing as if they, too, had the flu that forced their captain, Bobby Clarke, to exit after the second period. The Flyers showed none of the second effort that is their trademark and did break through the barrier of Billy Smith in the Islander net until 12 minutes 39 seconds of the final period.

title: Toxic Carelessness
description: In dealing,with a substance as deadly as plutonium, is not enough merely to minimize the risks. The Atomic Energy Commission and its successor agency, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, have the urgent task of tightening controls over the use and disposition of this toxic byproduct in the nation's nuclear installations.

title: Steelers Expect White to Start
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9The opportunity to play in a Super Bowl does not come to everyone. When the chance arrives the player had better be ready. That is how it goes with Dwight White of the Pittsburgh Steelers, a starting defensive end, and Charles Goodrum of the Minnesota Vikings, a regular offensive tackle.

title: Bridgeport Strike Ends
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 9 (AP)Public works employes frustrated over contract negotiations agreed to return to work today after a short wildcat strike here.

title: Small Boat Sailing Continues Growth
description: The past few years have seen an explosion in the boating world, one that has attracted tens of thousands of new fans to small boat sailing and expanded the number of all pleasure boats afloat by over half a million.

title: ExRep. Virginia E. Jenckes, 97, Indiana AntiCommunist, Dead
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind.. Jan. 9 (UPI)Virginia E. Jenckes, the first woman to represent Indiana in Congress, died today at the age of 97.

description: The stock market brushed off some eaFly weakness yesterday and finished with a broad advance in moderate trading.

title: Eileen Heckart to Play at Princeton
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9Eileen Heckart, the Academy Awardwinning actress who will begin rehearsal next week for her lead role in Berthold Brecht's Mother Courage at Princeton's McCarter Theater, came to Princeton today and lost no time in letting it be known she was just as happy to be in Princeton as on Broadway.

title: Cramped Galley Needn't Reduce Your Spouse to Tears
description: Cookery, anyone will cheerfully admit, can be a high art, and in the pocket packet or the weekending cruiser, whether it be power or sail, the cramped dimensions of the gallery generate in the chef either a total frustration culminating in a diet of soggy sandwiches or an unconquerable will to succeed.

title: EARNINGS UP 33.1% Al CHEMICAL BANK
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, parent of the Chemical Bank, reported yesterday fourthquarter operating earnings of $27.1million, an increase of 33.1 per cent from the yearearlier level. A spokesman said the earnings were the highest for any quarter in the company's history.

description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 9 Five dissident directors of the First National Bank of San Jose are attempting to upset plans of Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian businessman, to buy a controlling interest in the bank for S14million.

Counterintelligence Division unsuccessfully sought authority last fall to destroy illegal domestic files on nearly 10,000 American citizens because they feared the newly liberalized Freedom of Information Act, wellplaced sources said today.

description: The San Diego Padres and California Angels, the two teams needing the most help, reached clear across the country yesterday to make college teammates, Gene Richards and Willie Mays Aikens, the top two selections in baseball's annual winter freeagent draft.

title: PODELL IS GIVEN 6 MONTHS IN JAIL
description: Former Representative Bertram L. Podell was sentenced last night to six months in prison and fined $5,000 for conspiracy and conflict of interest in accepting $41,350 to help a small Florida airline.

title: Officer on Pueblo Refuses a Medal From U. S. Navy
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP)The former executive officer of the captured United States spy ship Pueblo refused to accept the Navy Commendation Medal at a ceremony today.

title: West German Jobless Rate Climbing
description: NUREMBERG, West Germany, Jan. 9 (Reuters)The number of unemployed in West Germany rose in December to just under 950,000 from 799,300 in November, the Federal Labor Office said today.

description: PITTSBURGH, Pa. Jan. 9 (AP) The United Steel Cdrporation said today that thi6 Federal Government had reiected a proposal that could have spared 2,500 jobsat its Gary, Ind., works that were eliminated because of a dispute over air pollution.

title: Beame Will Press Carey Anew for Aid Despite Grim State Budgetary Forecast
description: Mayor Beanie said yesterday that despite the grim budgetary forecasts made in Albany by Governor Carey on Wednesday he intended to meet soon with Mr. Carey to ask again for enough state money to reduce the deficit in the city's current $11.1billion budget.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDEREdith Lally, of Garden City, on Jan. 8, 1975, beloved mother of Elizabeth A. Robertson and Alexander Alexander, also survived be three grandchildren. Service and interment private. In lieu of flowers those who wish may make contributions a charity of their choice.

title: Miss Proell Triumphs In Cup Giant Slalom
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (AP)Annemarie Proell, seeking her fifth straight World Cup ski crown, swooped to victory today in the giant slalom of the Grindelwald Series.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP)Steve West scored at 4:40 of overtime tonight to give the Michigan Stags a 54 World Hockey Association victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: The Theme Was Ties, the Opening Slightly Mad
description: It wasn't blacktie, it wasn't whitetie. If anything, the opening of the new but temporary Lajeski Gallery at SO1 Madison Avenue was sort of a burnttie affair that tried to rekindle the art happenings of the sixties.

title: Oil Union Chief Bars A Nationwide Walkout
description: DENVER, Jan. 9 (UPI)Representatives of the 60,000member Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union sought today to win a new contract agreement and avert selective strikes tomorrow against some of the nation's major oil companies.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Ariny has awarded the Hughes Aircraft Company, Canoga Park, Calif., a $108.4million contract to begin development of a new air defense system, based on a FrenchGerman missile, the Roland II. A total of $10.8million being obligated immediately under the contract.

title: Codd Keeps Force Taut, if Not Wholly Happy
description: Last Jan. 12 when Michael Joseph Codd ended a brief retirement to become New York City's Police Commissioner, he brought along a reputation of being a traditionalist and a conservatve. But during his first year as head of the largest municipal police force in the country, Commissioner Codd has been a tough surprse to many police officers.

title: Broad Rule Changes Voted By Assembly Democrats
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The new Democratic majority in the Assembly today adopted a sweeping series of rules changes designed to make the Assembly's proceedings more public, reduce the unilateral power of the Speaker and strengthen the Assembly in its dealings with the Governor.

title: The Health Priority
description: In outlining the objectives of his new administration his State of the State Message, Governor Carey said he had no higher priority than the more effective, equitable and humane delivery of health services. That is large and commendable order, especially in view of recent revelations of gross mismanagement and misconduct the care of the physically and mentally ill and of the aged here and elsewhere in the state.

title: Senators Hear NeW Hampshire Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  A threeman Senate subcommittee heard testimony today from both claimants to the disputed New Hampshire Senate seat, but made no decision on how to resolve the closest Senate election in history.

title: Envoy of P.L.O New Delhi Is Given Full Diplomatic Status
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9India granted full diplomatic status to the Palestine Liberation Organization official representative in New Delhi l0day

title: U.S. Opens New Base for Scientific Study at South Pole at Cost of $6Millior]
description: The United States formally opened a S6million, domecovered scientific base at the South Pole late Tuesday, replacing its first station on the Antarctic site, which had been occupied continously since 1956.

title: Boad Rule Changes Voted By Assembly Democrats
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The new Democratic majority in the Assembly today adopted a sweeping series of rules changes designed to make the Assembly's proceedings more public, reduce the unilateral power of the Speaker and strengthen the AsSembly in its dealings with the Governor.

title: Shah and Sadat Open Mideast Talks
description: CAIRO, Jan. 9 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat and Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran spent more than two and a half hours today discussing Middle East issues, international problems and relations between their two countries.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE FOR 6TH SESSION
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the sixth consecutive session. The overthecounter market, which had closed mixed on Wednesday, also rose yesterday.

title: Hospital Unit Votes to Shut Morrisania to Save Funds
description: The board of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to close Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx as early as next year and approved the construction of a new Fordham Hospital.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Bus to Be Tested for Use in City

title: IMPORT SUBSIDIES UNDER U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The new Trade Act of 1974 had its first concrete result today as the Treasury announced new procedures under the 77yearold countervailing duty law.

title: Advertising
description: Because it is worried about copycat competition, the Chrysler Corporation is is being a bit hushhush about the details of its plan to promote the fiveweek national clearance sale announced this week.

title: Manhattan Beaten By De Paul, 9075
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP)Greg Boyd and Bill Robinzine combined for 41 points to lead De Paul to a 9075 victory over Manhattan College tonight. Boyd went over 1,000 points for his career as he hit for 20 points, 16 in the second half. Robinzine fin ished with 21 and Manhattan's George Bucci led all scorers with 23.

title: Indonesia Protests Oil Slick
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 8 (UPI)Indonesia today issued a call for a threenation conference to discuss antipollution measures as oil slicks from a grounded Japanese supertanker moved lint() the Straits of Malacca. The Indonesian Embassy in Singapore called for a meeting of Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore.

title: Hunt Pressed for Slayers Of Young Nurse in Leonia
description: More than 50 detectives from the local, county and New Jersey police forces were assigned yesterday to hunt for a 40yearold man and a 12yearold boy sought in the brutal slaying of a 21yearold practical nurse who was stabbed to death Wednesday after being held hostage, at the home of a friend in Leonia, N.J.

title: Ford's Economic Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  It will probably not achieve the immortality of Herbert Hoover's prosperity is just around the corner, but a statement made by President Ford less than a month ago about; his economic policy plans may soon rank among the most quickly eaten Presidential words of recent history.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Art Carney has agreed to star in a revival of Eugene O'Neill's comedy Ah, Wilderness! it was disclosed yesterday by Robert Whitehead, producer. Although no contracts have been signed, Jose Quintero has agreed to direct the play. Rehearsals have been tentatively scheduled for late March, before an engagement at the Kennedy Center in Washington. A Broadway opening early next fall is planned.

title: KUWAIT WILL MCK PIPELINE VENTURE

title: Carey's Budget Plan Seen By Marchi as a Stratagem
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9SenatorJohn J. Marchi, chairman of the Finance Committee of the Republicancontrolled Senate, today criticized Governor Carey's proposal for tax increases and budget cuts as an apparent bargaining point that was likely to be the subject during the legislative session of compromises more favorable for localities.

A youngster wearing a westernstyle football shirt with the number 99, made in Thailand, runs giggling from a stranger. At one side of the compound, a group of young men. preparing supper with gusto, chop up a 50pound fish just caught in the Mekong River, which flows past this grove. And close to the river, with friends leaning on a fence kibitzing, two men play a match of boulea Frenchstyle bowling game played with metal balls.

title: INJUNCTION SOUGHT BY AMERICAN BEEF
description: OMAHA, Jan. 9 (UPI)American Beef Packers, Inc., has filed a request for an injunction in Federal Court to prevent creditors from filing any suits for payment of bills, which could run into millions of dollars. The company is one of the nation's largest meat processors.

title: PRICE CUTS SET BY SUGAR REFINER
description: The industrial division of CPC International, Inc., started another round of sugar price cuts Yesterday.

title: Banks to Tell Investors Of Strength of the City
description: Mayor Beame reported yesterday that the city's major commercial banks had agreed to act as ambassadors of goodwill and inform investors of the strength of the city.

description: In ordering the release from prison of three major participants in the Watergate scandals, Judge John Slrica has wisely exercised his right to temper justice with mercy.

title: How Much Stimulus?
description: As the economy slides deeper into recession and unemployment, already at its highest level in fourteen years, keeps rising, the Administration's economic policy swinging from restraint to stimulus. Although just month ago President Ford said he did not intend make any 180degree turn in policy, his press secretary now says, Well, it could be 179 degrees.

title: Exhibition Returns Franklin and Jefferson to Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 9America's first bicentennial show was open for preview here today a year earlyan exhibition as lively, thoughtful and bumptiously innovative as the American leaders it celebrates  Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson.

title: Columbus Talks Reopened

The de vision came after Democratic leaders in the state Legislature had proposed an additional allocation of $90million to inflationpressed districts, or about $40 a pupil.

title: John Slater, British Actor Of Stage and TV, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP)John Slater, a leading actor on the British stage for 30 years, died today of a heart attack at the National Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: STATE ALLOWS LILCO TO INCREASE RATES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The Public Service Commission authorized the Long Island Lighting Company today to increase its electric rates by $35.6million a year above interim rates in effect since June,. for a total increase of $64.3million.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 President Ford signed an execufive order today creating a najtional commission to promote land coordinate United States participation in International Women's Year.

title: Javelin Trading Ban Of S.E.C. Ends Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was lifting its suspension of tradine in Canadian Javelin stock.

title: Subway Token Booths Now Accept $10 Bills
description: The Transit Authority announced yesterday tha effective immediately all subway token booths will accept $10 bills. Under the nrevious nnlicy, token clerks were not required to accept bills larger than $5. If they accepted a $10 bill that turned out to be counterfeit, they were held responsible for it.

title: Heavy Fighting Is Reported From Vietnam Coastal Plain
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (AP)Heavy fighting erupted today in the Bong Son area of the ricerich central coastal plain, according to reports from the field.

description: Its not easy to find a boatyard today where dories are being built, but one such place is the W. Lawrence Allen Dory Builders, Ltd. P.O. Box 1057, Lunenburg, Nova Scotia.

title: Iran Said to Offer Israel Oil to Offset a Sinai Loss
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9Two Lebanese publications reported from Cairo today that Shah Mohammed Riza. Pahlevi of Iran had offered to supply Israel with enough oil to compensate for oil that Israel would lose in a return of the Abu Rudeis oilfields to Egypt.

title: BILLS TO MEDICAID DIFFER UP TO 600%
description: For virtually identical services, bills submitted by a sample of nursing homes here for Medicaid reinbursement in 1973 varied by as much as 600 per cent, according to a study released yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 9 (AP)New Democrats in Congress questioned powerful House committee chairmen in unusual fashion today, like college freshmen trying to haze upperclassmen.

title: Chinese Said to Drive III Cattle Into Mongolia
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (Reuters) The President of Mongolia, Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal, in an article printed in a Soviet journal, accused Chinese border troops of herding infected animals into Mongolia and intruding into the country.

title: New Law Course to Change Curriculum
description: City College and New York Law School have completed plans for what their officials believe will be the first program in the country to integrate undergraduate studies and legal education, allowing students to get law degrees six years after entering college.

title: GOVERNING PARTY GAINS IN DENMARK
description: COPENHAGEN. Denmark, Friday, Jan. 10The governing Liberal party of Premier Poul Hartling scored big gains in Danish parliamentary elections yesterday but retained only a shaky hold on power.

title: Eagles Dismiss Stratton
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 9 (UPI)The board of directors of the Syracuse Eagles, currently mired in the basement of the American Hockey League's Southern Di vision, dismissed Coach Art Stratton today. Taking over on an interim basis is Carl Swenson, the team captain. The Eagles are affiliated with the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) The White House said today that President Ford might press Congress for more military aid to help South Vietnam and Cambodia resist current Communist offensives.

description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The State Department of Agriculture and Markets has refused to renew the New York milk dealers license of Kraftco, one of the nation's largest handlers of milk, following a determination that the corporation had violated state law over a 15year period.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said in an interview published here today that Arab countries would blow up their oil wells before allowing them to fall under the control of invading forces from the United States or elsewhere.

description: Four hundred sand hogs and other construction men, out of work for nearly five weeks in a money dispute between the city and contractor digging the Third Water Tunnel from Yonkers to Queens, held an angry confrontation with members of the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday.

description: Barnett Freedman, director of meat purchasing for the Waldbaum supermarket chain, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here yesterday to one count of incometax evasion for 1471.

title: Eritrean Marxists Study Ethiopians Offer of Truce
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 9 (Reuters)The Marxistoriented Popular Liberation Front today promised a reply by next Tuesday to a Government proposal for a truce in its guerrilla campaign for the secession of the northern province of Eritrea.

description: A 14yearold boy who was reportedly defacing a subway car with graffiti was killed yesterday when he apparently) slipped and fell between the cars of a moving subway train in Brooklyn as he and another youth were being chased by the police.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who like new versions of old riddles might consider the question, when is a New Yorker set a New Yorker? The answer, not very subtle, is when he tot lows the sun in the winter and becomes a Floridian. This accounts for the fact that Mark Conn of Bene Harbor Queens, was in Pompano Beach, Fla., when he won the recent continentwide Charity Game.

title: City to Again Check Nursing Facilities

title: The Chilean Struggle
description: MEXICO CITYMore than a year after the fascist coup d'etat in Chile, the junta finds itself isolated internationally. The resolution voted recently, 90 to 8 with 26 abstentions, by the United Nations General Assembly, urging Chile to restore human rights and free political prisoners, demonstrated to the world that only seven other countries, in Latin America, are willing to support the military junta.

title: SELECTION BEGINS FOR MORIARTY JURY
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 9The task of picking a jury for the trial of Joseph (Newsboy) Morlinty, the wellknown gambler who was born, reared and has lived all of his 63 years in this city, got under way in Hudson County Court here today.

title: Laotian Troops HaltStudents Marching to Province Capital
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 9 (UPI)Hundreds of students marched to the provincial capital of Thakhek today but were stopped by Laotian soldiers, who sealed off the town after students took over two Government buildings.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Bosphorus East, a new Turkish reskaurant at 121 Lexington Avenue (near 28th Street), turns out to be the pleasantest kind of surprise. Opening notices made much of its being operated by a former belly dancer, a rather ambiguous gastronomical allure, but when a Turkish foreign correspondent recommended it last week we went there quickly.

title: WALLACE SELECTS BLACK ALABAMIAN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 9 Gov. George C. Wallace will have a black in a toppaying state position in his new administration, which begins on Jan. 20.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Dollar Up Slightly In Trading Abroad; Gold Also Climbs
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 9 (UPI) The dollar improved marginally in value on several European exchanges today. The price of gold rose to $181.50 in London early in the day, up from yesterday's close of $178 an ounce, but it later fell to close at $179. In Zurich, Switzerland, it rose from $178 overnight to close at $179.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1975

title: Tortures of Junta Era Still Haunting Greeks
description: ATHENS, Jan. 9The military government that ruled Greece for more than seven years regularly inflicted physical and mental torture on its political prisoners, according to numerous accounts now being made public. Three army offi cers and 13 policemen have been accused of mistreating prisoners and are now awaiting trial.

title: Phnom Penh Strikes Back At Besiegers of Village
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 9 (Reuters)  Government helicopter gunships and gunboats have carried out strikes against rebel positions on an island in the Mekong River near the besieged ferry Town of Phum Prek Neak Luong, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Richard J. Caron, 60, Dies; Provided Aid for Alcoholics
description: Richard J. Caron, who had been honored many times for his work in the field of alcoholism, died Wednesday of emphysema at a hospital in Reading, Pa. He was 60 years old and lived in Wernersville, Pa.

title: Bell Telephone Will Lay Off 335 Reducing Construction in State
description: The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, the state's largest employer, announced last night that it was laying off 335 employes and reducing its 1975 construction program by $45million because of the general widespread decline in the economic situation in New Jersey.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The board of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted to close Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx as early as next year and approved the construction of a new Fordharn hospital.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 (AP)A Federal appeals court threw out today a suit by five Centenary College basketball players challenging the National Collegiate Athletic Association's socalled 1.6 rule. The decision by the Fifth United States Circuit Court of Appeals leaves Centenary and the players on indefinite probation, which bars them from participating in televised games or postseason tournaments. The decision came just hours before Centenary met the University of Hawaii in a game described as a meeting of giantswith the 7footlinch Robert Parish matched against Hawaii's 7foot Tommy Barker.

title: MUSCOVITE FACES DEATH IN BRIBERY
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9A major newspaper published a detailed account today of the economic crimes allegedly committed by Mikhail Y. Leviyev, a Soviet Jew who was sentenced to death last month after being convicted of bribetaking.

title: France, Facing Oil Bills, Revalues Gold to $170.40
description: PARIS, Jan. 9France, in a move designed primarily to increase its international borrowing power in order to finance imports following the quintupling of the price of oil, quadrupled the valuation of her gold reserves today, to $170.40 an ounce.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Government announced today that it had exhausted the first part of the money earmarked for home buyers and the crippled housing industry under a special loansupport program initiated in November.

title: John Grejson, Film Actor In Genevieve, Dies at 55
description: PORLOCK WEIR, England, Jan. 9 (AP)John Gregson, an actor who appeared in many British movies, died yesterday, He was 55 years old and had been vacationing here.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 9If the New York Knicks are going to beat the Golden State Warriors this season, it will have to be Feb. 18 at Madison Square Garden.

title: U. S. TO BAR FUNDS TO NURSING HOMES THAT IGNORE CODE
description: The Federal Government, In what it described as a major change of policy, announced here yesterday that it would stop paying its 50 per cent share of Medicaid to nursing homes that violate its lifesafety code. Officials began by giving 45 days notice to New York State regarding nine noncomplying facilities.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9Barbara Salomon of Hempstead, LI., took the lead today in the senior women's event as the Eastern figure skating championships entered their second day at the Philadelphia Skating Club and Humane Society.

description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)A resident here recently received his monthly bill from a utility company for $0.000. He sent in check for that amount. Apparently it was accepted by the computer, lie received no further bill.

title: Christmas Sales Up 6%; Employment Off Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Christmas sales, while not sensational, were good enough to produce a small increase in seasonally adjusted retail sales in December. the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary figures.

title: W.H.A. Outlook Brighter Despite Stags Collapse
description: The World Hockey Association took over yesterday the Michigan Stags, who play in a dying city, and probably will shift the team to Baltimore. But on other fronts the 3yearold league appears to be in better shape than the other new creations in sport.

title: ROSS GOLDEN, 85, RADIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Ross Golden, internationally known radiologist, died yesterday in Santa Ana, Calif. He was 85 years old and lived in Laguna Hills, Calif.

title: STATION DELAYS TERKEL PROGRAM
description: Studs Terkel's opening program in the new Assignment America series on the Public Broadcasting Service was entitled A Mesiage to Pittsburgh, but the message failed to get through. WQEDTV, the Pittsburgh public station, declined the telecast, after having scheduled it for Wednesday night. (The series is carried here Tuesdays.)

title: Mrs. Grasso Calls T ax Rise Unavoidable
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 10Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut said today that she had no plans to ask for increased taxes to see her administration through the rest of this fiscal year but that she would almost certainly ask for hYgher taxes for the year beginning in July.

title: GRAND UNION CO. RAISES NET 52%
description: The Grand Union Company, a major food retailer operating a chain of 562 stores, realized a 52 per cent increase in earnings or the third fiscal quarter and 17 per cent for the nine months ended Nov. 30. Sales were up only 5 and 6 per cent, respectively, James Wood, president, eported yesterday.

title: Players Wives Facing Lockout
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 (AP)Bud Grant and Chuck Noll, respective coaches of the Minnesota Vikings and Pittsburgh Steelers, found a common around today in solving a vexing problem at the Super Bowl: They said that wives of players will be shut out of the bedrooms on Saturday night, the eve of the pro football title game.

title: Three Women Who've Been Assaulted
description: A sophomore at the University of California's Berkley campus, majoring in social welfare, was half a block from her dormitory when she was raped at knifepoint.

title: Pope Paul Names 9 Prelates To Church Posts in Hungary
description: ROME, Jan. 10Pope Paul VI promoted four Hungarian titular bishops and another prelate today, appointing them as heads of the Roman Catholic residential dioceses of Csanad, Vac, Veszprem, Szombathely and Hajdudorog. He also named, four titular bishops for posts in Hungary.

title: Art Seeing an Emotion's Shape
description: There have always been flashier and more fashionable talents on the British art seene than William Scott's, and it is these, alas, that we usually get to see in any abundance or regularity iR New York. The exhibition of Mr, Scott's paintings that came here two years ago was his first New York show in 10 years, and it was therefore a revelation to the kind of public that is more interested in the art of painting than in the beguilements of personality or celebrity.

title: Greystone Case Is Ruled a Class Action
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 10A Superior Court judge today granted a motion by the State Public Advocate's office making a classaction case of its lawsuit seeking to end alleged physical assaults and menial almse of patients by employes at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital. The suit, filed on behalf of seven patients, also demands the elimination of unhealthy and unsanitary conditions at the hospital, the state's largest psychiatric facility, ands a reevaluation of all patients records and case histories.

title: Sonia Horowitz, Daughter Of Pianist, Is Dead at 40
description: Sonia Horowitz, daughter of Vladimir Horowitz, the pianist, and Mrs. Horowitz, died yesterday in Geneva, where she had been living for some months. Her age was 40.

title: Bowl GameToday Super for Scouts
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 In Mobile Ala., 150 miles east of this Super Bowl site, there are 62 young athletes being piked, prodded, measured and matched by the talent scouts of the National Football League, whose job is to select the players who will be the actors in the Super Bowls of the future. The 62 athletes, divided into North and South squads, will play in the Senior Bowl contest here tomorrow (Channel 4, 1 P.M. in New York).

title: The House Revolution
description: The effects of the quiet revolution that occurred on the Democratic side of the House of Representatives last month are only now becoming apparent. Having transferred to its full party caucus the light to make Democratic committee assignments, including election of committee chairmen, the majority party in the House has effectively reduced the extraordinary power that for lo long made those chairmen the barons of Capitol Hill.

title: Music: Crumb's Vision
description: In the. last 10 years George Crumb has composed a body of music that for concentrated poetry, sheer craftsmanship and allusive power is difficult to match in this country's history. His latest astonishing score, Music for a summer Evening (1974), received its first New York performance Thursday night at the Whitney Museum, in an allCrumb concert presented by Composers Showcase in conjunction with the Fromm Music Foundation.

title: Samuel Chamberlain Dies at 79; Author, Photographer, Etcher
description: Samuel Chamberlain, photographer, etcher and author, died yesterday at a hospital in Marblehead, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: MAJORITY IN SURVEY CRITICAL OF FORD
description: President Ford has been given a negative job rating by a majority of those questioned in a Harris poll for thefirst time since he assumed office, Louis Harris said yesterday.

title: Dance Jeune Homme
description: Memories, memories On Thursday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, Agnerican Ballet Theater revived Roland Pctit's Le Jenne Homme et la Mort. which has not been seen locally since 1951. The leading role in this ballet, conceived by Jean Cocteau, was then danced by the man who created it in 1946 for Les Billets des ChampsElysees, Jean Babilee, one of the great male dancers of his day. Certainly the most temperamental.

title: Florida Citizens Reject Service of Draft Evader
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP)Swamped by a flood of public protest, Palm Beach County officials have dismissed a Vietnam war draft evader four days after he began his alternative service under President Ford's amnesty program.

title: L.I. Businessman Is Killed In Connecticut Plane Crash
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 (UPI)The police identified a New York businessman as the pilot killed when a twinengine plane crashed in a wooded area on the north side of Stratford early today.

description: LONDON, Jan. 10Although difficulties have clouded the progress made suddenly last month toward a solution of the Rhodesian problem, British offiDials still think that chances of success have not been better for years.

title: Funeral Is Held For Wilson, Son
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP)Funeral services were held today for Don Wilson, the Houston Astros pitcher, and his 5yearold son, Alex. Wilson, 29, died last Sunday when.carbon monoxide fumes filled his Houston home.

title: French ABomber Crashes
description: BORDEAUX, France, Jan. 10 (Reuters)  A French Mirage nuclear bomber crashed during a training flight near here last night, defense officials said today. The two crewmen are believed dead, they said The aircraft was not carrying any nuclear weapons, they added.

title: Steelers White Is Hospitalized Again

description: UNIONDALE, L. T., Jan. 10 The New York Nets slowed down Travis Grant in the fourth quarter and bottled up Dwight Lamar for most of the game and defeated the San Diego Conquistadors, 11298, tonight at.the Nassau Coliseum.

title: 3,000 SEEK JOBS IN ATLANTA MELEE
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 10Several persons were bruised and cut here early today when 3,000 unemployed men and women, most of them young blacks, surged into the Atlanta Civic Center to apply for 225 newly created public service jobs.

description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 Mickey Steuerer. a junior guard, scored a career high of 24 points tonight to lead Princeton to an 82.68 basketball victory over Dartmouth at Jadwyn Gymnasium.

description: Fred 0. Sink Jr., publisher of The Lexington (N.C.) Dispatch, died yesterday at his home in Lexington after a long illness. His age was 51.

title: LaidOff Foreman on Is Saved by U.S. Job Act

title: Ethics Board Limits Lindsay's Practice In CityClient Cases
description: The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that former Mayor John V. Lindsay might not engage for the next two years an any litigation covering any matter that was before any city agency during his eight years in office.

title: Policeman Saved by Badge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Steve Peterson, a police officer, says he is going to frame his badge. Someone took a shot at him last night when he stopped to help a fellow policeman aid a motorist with icedover windows. The bullet lodged in Mr. Peterson's badge and knocked him to the ground, but he was not even scratched.

WoodCock, the Bergen County Prosecutor, said today.

title: City U. to Ctit Its Budget By Equivalent of 300 Jobs.

The cuts; could be either teachers jobs or money and programs equal to. them, Mr. Giardino said.

title: Antiques: Care of Quilts
description: Museum conservators and textile experts have not been idle over the last five years as the revival of interest in period quilts moved into high gear.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS SELECT CHAIRMEN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10  The Democrats in the Assembly this week parceled out committee chairmanships, among the most valued prizes of political victory, and paid attention not only to seniority, but also to the upstate and suburban areas of new Democratic strength.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Giorgio di Sant'Angelo's favorites are what he calls no jewelry. They're thin, delicate goldcolored chains imbedded with tiny diamonds  fake ones  that hardly look prepossessing enough to tempt a mugger. Besides the chains, there are bar pins, stick pins, rings and earrings and they mark Mr. Sant'Angelo's return to jewelrythe field of design in which he first made his name six years ago.

title: Brezhnev and Rumors
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10The official reappearance of Leonid Li arezhnev this week after a 10day absence and an angry denial by the Soviet press agency Tass of any Kremlin power struggle have quieted speculation here that the Soviet leader is in political trouble. Yet sus picions are bound to linger that his program of accommodation with the West, which is ultimately linked to his own fortunes, could cause him problems within the ruling Politburo.

title: WINE TALK
description: Recently, a New Rochelle reader wrote to say that he and his wife were planning a trip to France this spring. Would it be possible, he asked, to get the names of some reasonably priced wines  three red and three white to be exactto bring along with the passports and health cards? Or would it be better, he wondered further, to stick to the vin ordinaire?

title: EXAIDE OF DAIRYLEA GIVES UP IN ALBANY
description: The former director of operations for the Dairylea milk cooperative, who was believed to be a central figure in Dairylea's adulteration of millions of quarts of milk between 1967 and 1973, surrendered to the Albany office of the State Attorney General yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BARGAIN TOWN New Vork, lest we forget, is still the best place on earth for movie shoppers. Aside from lit the new fare, nowhere else a treasure trove of varied films stretching hick into cinema history available so easily and so many hours a day. Admission prices for the revivals are reasonable to low. Library showings of some fine classics, with the merest public. ity, are usually free.

title: Tornado Kills 7 and Injures 100 in Mississippi Town
description: MCCOMB, Miss., Jan. 10 (AP) A tornado ripped a twomile swath through McComb today, leveling businesses and homes, shredding trees and injuring, mnre than 100 persons. Officials said four persons died in McComb and three others in a nearby rural area.

title: Art: Noland's Early Circles, Genuine Contributions
description: A major retrospective exhibition in a major museum is a great honor, of course. But it also has something of the character of a state funeral. It comes alone and it goes off more or less well as the case may be, and then something peculiar happens. The hero of the hour sinks out of sight. The catalogue remains and the reviews remain for those who want to go and look them up; but the mere fact that it will be a long time before we see so much of the work again has a deflationary effect. The artist is not dead, but people somehow begrudge his being alive; idleness makes itself felt, and the prospect of having to make up their minds about him all over again is unwelcome.

title: Stock Prices Climb
description: The stock market made a sharp advance yesterday as turnover soared to 25.89 million shares, the seventh largest in the New York Stock Exchange's history, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 13.53 points to 658.79. The market's advance was attributed to reports of a planned Federal tax cut and the declining interest rates announced by many banks. Page 35.

title: City Given Ruling On Use of U.S. Aid In Rehiring Plan,
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said today that New York City could not use Federal funds to rehire laidoff provisional employes without first ottering those jobs to. the most severely disadvantaged in terms of the length of time they have been unemployed.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Justice Department has recommended that Congress renew the Voting Rights Act of 1965 without expanding it to cover more Northern cities.

Gerald Culver Kott, 49 years old of Mill Valley, Calif., was to be arraigned Monday on Federal narcotics charges including conspiracy to distribute cocaine and smuggling.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 11A Columbia University student, Richard Nicholaysen, won the Franklin D. Roosevelt ski jumping tournament here today. The 25yearold Ossining resident soared 150 feet in the second jumpoff to beat Dave Harris of Brattleboro, Vt., and Thorbjorn Ryen of Staten Island. The trio tied in the first jumpoff with leaps of 146 feet. In the second jumpoff Harris jumped 148 feet and Ryen 146. Also reaching the finals were Chuck Berghorn of Lake Placid, N. Y.; Arthur Tokle of Lake Telemark, N. J., and Michael Voboril of Glen Cove, L. I. Nicholaysen won the Class A division of the Norway Ski Club tournament as he soared 143 feet twice for 195.3 points. Harris, a 27yearold in his 15th year of competition bete, took Class B with two flights of 138 feet for 179.4 points.

title: Rooney
description: What the Kennedys have been in politics, the Barrymores in the theatre and the Rockefellers in finance that's what the Rooneys of Pittsburgh have become in sports. And today, when their Pittsburgh Steelers meet the Minnesota Vikings in the Super Bowl game, sitting in the eye of the hurricane in New Orleans will be the patriarch of the clan: Art Rooney Sr. At 73, he is surrounded by his five sons and 34 grandchildren and all the trappings of success. From Green Mountain in Vermont to Palm Beach in Florida, Rooney & Sons control race tracks, harness tracks and dog tracks in addition to the football team that could carry the dynasty to a new dimension today.

title: Thank You, Fog
description: Thank You, Fog contains Auden's last poems. The book is posthumous and, as his literary executor explains in a short preface, half the ghost of what it might have been. Writers, being human, are not in a position to choose their monuments. This one is more Audenesque than Auden, hardly fitting as the final words, the summing up of a man who set his mark on an age. As he developed into a superb writer, he became something more: an intellectual and moral touchstone for three generations of Englishmen and Americans. None of the obvious sources, as a leftist of the thirties, as a High Church Anglican of the sixties or even the work itselfquite account for it. History and genius worked in magical combination: Auden was in Spain in 1937, in China in 1938, in Germany in 1945. He was, after Pound and Eliot, the only international poet of the English language. (One can write poetry and be an international figure without being an international poet.)

title: Who Is That Knocking at My Door?; FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEOne of Europe's most fascinating political questions is simply this: For thirty years Italy has had the West's largest, most brilliantly led Communist party and it has been continually edging toward the seats of power. During those same thirty years the nonCommunist parties running this country have increasingly messed up the job. Yet the Communists have not made it. Why?

title: In the direct line of W hitman,the indirect line of Eliot
description: In the old days, when T. S. Eliot was an American poet, he saw the point of English humor; Humor is distinctively English. No one can be so aware of the environment of Stupidity as the Englishman. Wit is public, it is in the object; humor (I am speaking only of real humor) is the instinctive attempt of a sensitive mind to protect beauty against ugliness; and to protect itself against stupidity (1918). Yet American humor has burgeoned since then. (Did America get helpfully stupider?) In films, plays, novels, poems, songs, the visual arts, jokes, and in the daily giveandtake, American humor has been a glory. And, of course, a challenge. The American artist who cuts himself off from humor, or is no good at it, may be cut off, not just from some valuable ways of looking at life but from a national source of energy, the hidingplaces of the best American power.

A schisgalperhaps I'd better start calling it a Murray Schisgalis a breeze of equally violent proportions, warm and dry as it wafts over from Brooklyn to pass 125th Street and then settle in and around the upper 70's. Along the way, it not only stirs everything up, it stirs everything together.

title: S. F.
description: The Mote in God's Eye by Larry Niven and Jerry Pournelle (Simon and Schuster, $9.95) comes wrapped in words of high praise from big science fiction names. Like Robert Heinlein  Possibly the finest science fiction novel I have ever read. It is a big book537 pageswith a theme that has intrigued writers and readers since the days of H. G. Wells: The first contact between the human race and a race of intelligent aliens. The two authors have impressive credentials: Niven won a Hugo Award in 1970 for his novel Ringworld, and Poumelle worked in the U. S. space program and, according to the book jacket, holds degrees in engineering, psychology, and political science. Yet 20 pages into their novel, I found myself asking, with the congenital uneasiness of all reviewers, Could this be a puton? Five hundred pages later, I reluctantly concluded that it was not. What Niven and Pournelle have done is to graft a serious firstcontact novel onto a laughably bad space opera.

The membership of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which includes all member firms as well as dealers in overthecounter securities, dropped from 3,885 in June, 1973, to 3,318 in June, 1974. The figures in both cases were incorrectly reported in the National Economic Survey on Jan. 5.

title: Noreen Falk Wed To M. G. Wienges

title: Headliners
description: Irish police say they have captured the man responsible for the preChristmas bombings in London and other British cities. He is identified as Kevin Mallon, the Irish Republican Army's top explosives expert, and thought by officials to behind many of the assassinations of British soldiers Northern Ireland. Though his arrest climaxed an intensive investigation, it may not be all for the good: An spokesman has threatened to end the temporary truce Northern Ireland because bf it. Mr. Mallon has twice escaped from maximum security prisons, once during a spectacular helicopter airlift in October of 1973, and again last August, when he and 18 other I.R.A. prisoners were freed by an I.R.A.planned raid.

title: Teaching a New Dog the Old Tricks

description: One way to describe the contents of this superb expose of the mobile home industry is to chronicle my own experience as a mobile home owner. In 1970, short on both cash and credit and unable to purchase a conventionally built home, I settled on a 12 by 60 feet mobile home. The dealer was only too pleased to make all the financial arrangements and secure me a space in a mobile home park (about half of all mobile home owners live in such parks; the other half live on their own land). Within three days I was the proud owner of my first home, albeit a home with

title: Poems as concentrated as heart surgery
description: Philip Larkin is the other English Poet Laureate, even more loved and needed than the official one, John Betjeman. To the literary English now, with their thinned, overwatched sensibility, Larkin is grateful proof that at least one plangent English string can still be sounded, thrill through them. Ted Hughes is like an ephebe of Shakespeare run wild in the woods; Charles Tomlinson like a staid valley tree, with philosophical murmurings. Where in these is that grand sweetened pathos most readily recognizable as English poetry? But Larkin's small infrequent volumesonce a decaderead like prudent petitions to a National Anthology Committee. With wellbehaved orderhere are the stanzas, there the

title: Proposals for the U.S.S.R.
description: For almost five years Valery Chalidze actively worked inside the democratic movement in the Soviet Union. At first he wrote articles for unofficial journals, including an essay on class discrimination in Soviet law. Later he prepared and signed 15 issues of the sumizdat journal Social Problems, which made him a principal opponentwith Andrei Sakharov and Alexander EseninVolpinof judicial practices and Psychiatric abuses in the Soviet Union. In November, 1970 Chalidze, Sakharov and Andrei Tverdokhlebov founded the Moscow Human Rights Committee, determined to defend, in particular, the right of accused persons to due process of law. Chalidze, however, was soon removed from direct involvement in the Committee. In 1972 the authorities permitted him to deliver a series of lectures in America, but upon his arrival in New York he was deprived of his passport by Soviet officials and refused reentry into the Soviet Union. Even so, Chalidze has not diminished his efforts, for in America he established A Chronicle of Human Rights in the U.S.S.R., a bimonthly journal which reports on the struggle for human rights in the Soviet Union.

title: The Wiz Misses
description: The unfailingly appealing Clarice Taylor plays one of the two trustworthy witches,in the allblack version of The Wizard of Oz (the third remains wicked and. must be melted down as always) and it is she who gives Dorothy the pair of silver slippers that will see her safely through anything provided she never, never parts with them. Once Dorothy has gone through, virtually everythingincluding an assault by flying monkeys and a timely rescue by the Mice Squadshe wants to know just what it was about those slippers that made them so helpful. Witch Taylor compresses her rubbery face into a mashedup grin and gives her an honest answer. Oh, I could have, told you the secret of the slippers right off, she cackles, but it just didn't deem good theater. A candid creature, Miss Taylor, and sassy about the kind of work she's employed in.

It is the enemy against which valiant heroes like Alfred Stieglitz, Paul Strand and Edward Weston fought the good fight, and won. If it has been consigned to the rubbish heap of history, isn't that exactly where it belongs?

title: Anthony Retains Bowling Touch
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 11 (UPI)Earl Anthony of Tacoma, Wash., who won six tournaments and a record $99,000 last season, took first place in the $60,000 Greater Los Angeles bowling tournament today. In taking his 14th title in five years on the pro tour, the 36yearold lefthander earned $7,000 after he defeated three men in the final round. He finished with six strikes in his final seven frames to dispose of Jim Frazier of Spokane, Wash., 247216. Anthony's first victim was Larry Laub of San Francisco, by 236186, with Anthony posting seven strikes. In his second triumph, Anthony beat Ed Bourdase of San Jose, Calif., 238213.

title: A City God Meant To Be Invincible
description: ASHEER ciange, It lieknobbed cliff erupts from the shimmering crust of the sea and bursts 600 feet into the sky. The Turks called it the Fortress of Flowers, and long after Monemvasia had passed its prime, it was known to 19thcentury Englishmen as the Gibraltar of Greece. Located just off the coast of southeastern Pelt). ponnesus, the fortress city was once the greatest stronghold in the Aegean, renowned for the sophistication of its citizens and powerful enough to bring even the Emperor of Byzantium to his knees. title: GUEST VIEW

Even then, he was appearing with his own Ridiculous Theatrical Company, under his own direction, in plays of his own authorship. His madscientist opus, Bluebeard, displayed a fascination with ambiguous sexuality and an equal fascination, expressed through affectionate,parody, with oldfashioned, highly artificial, highly conventionalized histrionic modes (i.e., madscientist movies).

title: Pipestone, a Treasure That Belongs to the Indians
description: IN the uniformity of the rolling farmland of southwestern Minnesota, the Pipestone National Monument comes as a surprising break. Within this wooded oasis are a waterfall, high quartzite cliffs, historic sites and virgin. prairie. Above all, the 283acre Monumentit is 45 miles northeast of Sioux Falls, S.D.contains quarries of soft red stone, called pipestone, lying between layers of hard quartzite, that have been worked by the Indians for than three centuries. Indians still carve and polish the pipestone, as their forefathers did, to produce calumets, or ceremonial pipes, Indeed, the Monument protects the stone for the Indians sole use, and although some of the pits were abandoned long ago there are about 30 that are still active.

title: 2 SAIGON Al1RCRAFT REPORTED DOWNED1
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (UPI)Communist gunners shot down two South Vietnamese warplanes today, the fifth day of heavy air raids launched in retaliation for the capture of Phuoc Long province.

title: Tennis, Yes
description: ctiicely a month passes without someone discovering a new threat to our health, or even our survival. If it isn% mercury in our tuna salad, it is carcinogens in our drinking water, or Godonlyknowswhat in the air we breathe. The newest menace is aerosol spray; it may be destroying a layer of the atmosphere which is all that keeps the, sun from cooking us to cinders. And there are all those radioactive wastes. and chemical warfare agents, just sitting around somewhere, probably in leaky containers, waiting for an accident which will trigger the final disaster.

The lone exception has been the rising stock market, a traditional barometer that lately has been acting quite contrary to most other leading economic indicators.

The ingredients are there for overnighting, weekending, short cruises, a full vacation or a whole summer of harborhopping.

title: Food: TV cooks
description: Franco and Margaret Romagnoli have been cooking together for 22 years, ever since they were married in Rome where Margaret was working for the Marshall plan and Franco was making movies. When they moved to the United States, they wanted the same kind of simple family food they had been used toso simple that few cookbooks concerned themselves with it. They set to work, experimenting with dish after remembered dish until each one met their nostalgic standards. The results of their experiments have been causing the same kind of stir in Boston and its suburbs that Julia Child caused when her French cooking first splashed all over the television screen. The difference is that there are two of themand it's pizza they drop on the floor. Their cookbook, The Romagnolis Table, will be published in the spring by Atlantic, LittleBrown. Starting next Tuesday evening, the Romagnolis will be cooking on Channel 13 at seven o'clock.

title: Baseball Reserve Rule on Trial
description: With the thought growing that someday the World Series and the Super Bowl will be decided in a court. room instead of a stadium, baseball officials have girded themselves, for their next legal battle, one that could make the Jim (Catfish) Hunter case an insignificant skirmish.

title: A Youpg Maestro At the Met
description: For 33yearold John Nelson', the bright new hope of the. Metropolitan Opera's musical staff, there was no taking the easy way. Almost every opera he has conducted over the past two years has been a major, assignment that has thrust him into the spotlight of the New York musical press. He made his New York opera debut at Carnegie. Hall in 1973; conducting an uncut performance of Berlioz's epic Les Troyens, and his Met, debut last season, with the same opera, occurred on a day's notice when he was called upon to substitute for the, ailing Rafael Kubelik. Fain Berlioz's classicromaotic grand opera, Nelson went, on this season to lead that masterpiece of Czech national opera, Janacek's Jenufa, and those perehnials of Italian verismo,. Cavalleria. Rusticana and Pagliacci all to general critical acclaim.

title: How to Endure Though Playing Modern Music

In a field where such organizations usually have the life span of a fruit fly, Weisberg's has endured and endured without losing its sense of purpose. The fact that it is giving a concert tonight solely of premieres is taken almost as a matter of course.

title: After 4 Years of nua le neasy Coexistence In the Senate, Davits and'Buckley quare Off for a Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 They are the odd couple of New York Republican politics. In their four years together in the Senate, the liberal Jacob K. Javits and the conservative James L. Buckley have treated each other amicably and with bemused tolerance, although they have rarely agreed on major issues.

title: SCORES VIEW BODY OF SLAIN NURSE
description: PALISADES PARK, N.J., Jan. 12Scores of friends and relatives streamed into the Volk funeral home here this afternoon to view the open coffin of Maria Fasching, as Bergen County investigators reported no good solid leads to the whereabouts of her assailants. The practical nurse was stabbed to death in Leonia last Wednesday.

title: Simbera Takes Crown
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 12 (AP) Jan Simbera of Czechoslovakia and Ellen Grindvold of Norway won the singles titles today in the Scandinavian open tennis championships. Simbera surprised the former champion, Ove Bengtson of Sweden, 61, 36, 63 for the men's crown. Miss Grinvold topped Helena Anlict of Sweden, 06, 76, 6.2.

description: Garvey to Be Cited; PUILADELpHIA, Jan. 12 (AP)Steve Garvey, Los Angeles Dodgers first baseman and the National League's most valuable playet of 1974 willlie honored Jan. 27 as sportsman of the, year by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association at their annual dinner.

title: Soyuz Crew on Strenuous Schedule After Salyut 4 LinkUp

title: Equality and Scarcity
description: Among the disasters tucked away in the unemployment statistics released by the Department of Labor a few days ago was evidence of the erosion of the progress women and minorities have made in the labor market the last decade and a half. The raw statistics tell the story. The jobless rate for adult men is 5.1 per cent, for women 7.2 per cent. For whites the overall rate is 6.4 per cent; for blacks it is exactly twice that, 12.8 per cent.

description: SHAWANO, Wis., Jan. 12 Residents of this northeastern Wisconsin town jammed into community hall today, criticizing the National Guard for not acting against armed Indians holding a Roman Catholic abbey.

title: Jobless but Happy
description: My friends call, asking how I am. A little edgy, I say. Bored, eh? they answer, I know how it is. Back in 68 when I was unemployed.  And they launch into horror tales of boredom driving them up the wall, and the socalled work ethic making most things exercises in guilt.

title: S. JOHN MARONE
description: WALDEN, N. Y., Jan. 12 (UPI)S. John Marone, a running guard on the New York Giants football team in the nineteenforties, died today, apparently of a heart attack, as he was preparing to watch the Super Bowl IX game on television. He was 57 years old.

title: Michael Denard Dances as Franz With Miss Gregory in Coppelia
description: Saturday afternoon, clowning almost overtook good sense as Michael Denard and Cynthia Gregory larked through American Ballet Theater's Coppelia. The first act had a rowdiness more appropriate to farce than to the humorous remnant of the Romantic ballet, though it subsequently settled down.

title: PUERTO RICO BOMB KILLS 2, INJURES 11
description: MAYAGUEZ, P.R. Jan. 12 (UPI)A bomb exploded yesterday in a restaurant frequented by Puerto Rican nationalists, killing two men and injuring 11 other persons, the Police reported today.
