Scott Fitzgerald's last and unfinished novel, The Last Tycoon. title: Marquette Wins, 69.60
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 14 (AP) Bo.Ellis scored 14 of his 21 points in the second half tonight, leading Marquette to a 6960 victory over South Carolina.

title: Air Canada Cuts 145 Flights From Its Weekly Schedule
description: TORONTO, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Air Canada will cut out about 145 weekly flight effective today, and airline spokesman said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report by United Press International in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly stated the earnings of the First National Boston Corporation and the bank holding company's net loan losses. First National Boston's pershare earnings for the fourth quarter of 1974 fell to $1.01 from $1.22 in 1973 and for the full year ros to $4.60 from $4.28. Net loan losses for 1974 fell to $25.1million from $29.6million for 1973.

title: Pending Legislation
description: HIGHER EDUCATION The basic Federal law comes up for renewal. Conflicts could arise on the proper mix of student grant and loan programs. Direct help to institutions appears to have virtually no support in, Congress. Efforts may be made to restrict the affirmative action obligation of institutions to hire and promote women and minorities.

title: Postal Official Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Clyde S. duPont was designated by President Ford today to be acting chairman of the Postal Rate Commission, He succeeds Fred Rhodes, who resigned Dec. 30.

title: FORD ACTS TO FILL 2 CABINET POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 President Ford moved today to fill. two of three Cabinet openings by announcing his inten: tion to nominate Edward H. Levi, president of the University of Chicago, to be Attorney General and William T.. Coleman Jr., a lawyer from Philadelphia, to be Secretary of Transporta

title: The Newest Innovation: Back to Basics
description: Prince George's County, Md., will open a special, innovative alternative educa. tion program next fall. A new school will stress the three R's, plus a big D for discipline and a P for patriotism.

title: 2,599 Found Collecting Welfare Funds Illegally,
description: The city has found 2,599 persons who have illegally received welfare payments while working for the city or state or obtaining unemployment benefits, the Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: `Diamond Studs, a Saloon Musical, Is Sheer Delight
description: Yes, yes, a thousand times yes! Diamond Studs, which is something called a saloon  usical, turned up last night at the Chelsea Theater Center's Westside Theater, and it turned up trumps with five aces and a full house of jokers. It is unadulterated delight, which, together with adulterated delight was the way the West was run.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS A CURB ON DIVORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14States can require A year of residence to qualify for a divorce in their courts, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Goociyear,Switches to LIFO
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber company said yesterday that it bad switched to the lastin, firstout inventory accounting method. Earnings for 1974 under 1,170 will approximate $15.53nillion, Charles J. Pilliod Jr., chairman of the nation's largest rubber company, said. In 1973, the company earned $184.8million, or $2.53 a share, on sales of $4.68billion.

title: Monday's Fight
description: London  Bunny Johnson, 186 pounds. Jamaica, knocked out Danny McAlinden, 193, Ireland, 9 rounds; Johnson won British and Commonwealth heavyweight titles.

title: SOVIET PURCHASE BLOCKED BY U. S.
description: PARIS, Jan. 14The United States, with British support, is blocking West German efforts to sell nuclear power stations to the Soviet Union. The move is generating tensions between Bonn and Washington.

title: Dr. King's Holiday
description: When Martin Luther King Jr. accepted the Nobel Prize for Peace, he did so with an abiding faith in America and an audacious faith in mankind. As a man of vision, he never allowed his dreams to impede the need for hard, pragmatic effort. As a man of courage, he never feared that his creed of nonviolence might make him appear weak. Nonviolence, he maintained, seeks no victory over anyone. It seeks to liberate American society and to share in the selfliberation of all the people.

title: For Top Legal Post
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 14It was February, 1968, and the campus of the University of Chicago was seething with student. unrest that finally erupted into, a. long sitin by radical students in the university's administration building.

title: Aide Explains Ford's Adoption of New Economic Policy. His Options Were Limited
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The President's options were limited.

title: Few Lessons From the Past
description: Formal education has up till recently been a growth industry in the United States. Though the growth was not always steady, and the rates shifted, the pattern was consistent. But the situation is changing.

title: Suffolk G.O.P. Picks Republican To Fill Vacant Legislature Seat
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Jan. 14In a session that was marked by loud and sarcastic exchanges Suffolk County Republicans voted today to install a Republican in a County Legislature seat to which Governor Carey had already appointed a Democrat.

title: Loan Is Ordered Paid
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (UPI)A Federal judge has ordered William H. Rentschler, comanager of Mr. Nixon's Illinois 1968 presidential campaign, to pay $335,475 as the guarantor of a loan made in 1971 by a Maryland hank

title: African Mine Toll Now 10
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 14 (Reuters)  The death toll in the riots last week at the Vaal Reefs gold mine has risen to 10, it was announced today. The trouble in the world's blgest gold mine was touched off by a law in neighboring Lesotho requiring her nationals to deposit 60 per cent of their earnings as miners in her banks until they return home.

title: COURT ISSUES A WRIT TO NIAGARA GAZETTE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 14 A Niagara County judge has begun contempt proceedings againts. The Niagara Gazette for publishing a grandjury repart he had ordered sealed forever.

title: 2 More Campisis Admit Guilt As Plea Bargaining Continues
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Jan. 14Two more members of the North Jersey Campisi crime family reportedly pleaded guilty in closed court today in a multiplemurder, armed robbery and racketeering case.

title: $1Billion in Daimler Stock Acquired By German Bank to Bar Sale Abroad
description: BONN, Jan. 14,Nearly $1 billion of stock in DaimlerBenz, the large West German automotive giant has been acquired by the Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest commercial bank, to prevent it from being sold abroad.

title: Ball to Head Board Of International House
description: George W. Ball, former Under Secretary of State in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, was elected chairman of the board of trustees of International House yesterday, the organization's president, Howard A. Cook, announced.

title: FORD STILL BACKS VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14President Ford said yesterday that he continued to favor the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and would send draft legislation to Congress this week to extend it.

title: Opportunity
description: America feels itself to be humanity in miniature. When in this crucial time the international leadership passes to America, the great reason for hope is that this country has a national experience of uniting racial and cultural diversities and a national theory, if not a consistent practice, of freedom and equality for all. What America is constantly reaching for is democracy at home and abroad. The main trend in its history is the gradual realization of the American Creed.

title: Dean Says He Heard That Nixon Was Confident on Tapes Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14John W. Dean 3d.,said today that he had heard that former President Richard M. Nixon had been confident, after conversations with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, that the courts would not force him to surrender the Watergate tapes.

title: State G.O.P. Now Needs A Slogan for Row B
description: The Repubican party, which captured Row A on the state's voting machines in 1938 and ever since has urged New Yorkers to Vote Row A All the Wdy, is searching for a new slogan. Voting Row A now means voting for Democrats.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Article 6  No Title
Kings. Beat Capitols, 6.2
description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 14 (UPI)Dan Maloney had two goals and. two assists and Terry Harper collected his first score of the year to lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 62 victory tonight over the Washington Capitals in a Nfational Hockey League tame.

title: 2 Cypriote Factions RenewTheir Talks; Prospect Is Hopeful
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 14Representatives of the Greek and Turkish communities announced that they had had a useful exchange of views on the Substance of the Cyprus problem today. The talks resumed after a sixweek break.

title: NIXON'S MORTGAGE IS BEING PAID OFF
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon's $523,000 mortgage on his beachfront estate is being paid off but associates declined to say who came up with the money.

title: National Health Needs And New Physicians
description: WASHINGTON Medical schools, those invaluable institutions, may be becoming in effect a public utility, a prospect that is causing a philospohical debate in education.

title: Article 7  No Title
HOW TO AID Tilt FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Reach Energy Plan Mixed
description: President Ford's energy, Mr. gram as disclosesinhis television address Monday night reCeived mixed reviews fronljo, dustry executiliii and economists yesterday, withhpraise ge. neralized and guarded and criticism specific and sometimes harsh.

title: Owner of a Nursing Home In Indicted in Jersey in Fraud
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14The former president of the New Jersey Nursing HomeAssociation was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of filing false Medicare claims from 1968 to 1971 for al nursing home he owns.

title: Germany to Use Curbs On Sales of Industries
description: BONN, Jan. 15 (Reuters)West Germany intends to impose legal controls on sale to other countries of major shareholdings in the country's industry, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today on television here.

title: Text of Report by Colby in Response to Charges of Domestic Spying by C. I. A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Following the text of a report by William E. Colby; director of Cehtral Intelligence, responding to charges of illegal domestic surveillance by the agency, which he submitted to the Senate Appropriations Committee today:

title: Drop in Quarter First Since 69 Revenue Up
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday a 4.7 per cent decline in fourthquarter earnings, the first drop since the last quarter of 1969.

title: Goldwater Recruits Aid for Buckley's 76 Campaign;
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Senator Barry Goldwater, Arizona Republican and a leading conservative, has enlisted support for the 1976 reelection campaign of Senator James L. Buckley, New York ConservativeRepublican.

title: Dollar Shows Drop
description: The dollar faltered yesterday on European money markets after the shortlived rise afforded by President Ford's economic package. Meanwhile the price of gold edged up. Details on Page 65.

title: Soviet Jews See Their Hopes Set Back, but Pledge New Emigration Efforts
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15Soviet Jews who want to emigrate were described, today as disappointed by the Soviet Union's renunciation of the 1972 trade agreement with the United State.

title: Yonkers Raceway Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions.

title: Unemployment, Growing Daily, Takes Spotlight in Longest Recession Since the Depression
description: From a barely perceptible beginning about 14 months ago the longest recession since the end of the Great Depression is biting deeper into the nation's economy with widespread unemployment and plant closings.

title: Butz Backs Private System To Guard Grain Reserves
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 15(UP1) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. tutz said today the Government sold its reserves of grain too quickly,two years, ago because of political pressure.

title: SUIT ALLEGES FRAUD BY AMERICAN BEEF
description: OMAHA, Jan. 15 (UP1)A $25million class action suit was filed today in United States District Court alleging that the president of American Beef Packers, Inc., of Omaha embarked on a fraudulent scheme to cheat and defraud hog and cattle producers.

title: The Dance: Sheer Ballet
description: For an evening of sheer dancing, there is the New York City Ballet. This truth was brought home again Tuesday night at the State Theater In that quintessential Balanchine ballet, Symphony in C, and the season's first performance of Jerome Robbins's Dances at a Gathering.

title: For Independent Angola A Great Threat of Strife
description: ALVOR, Portugal, Jan. 15With formal recognition by Portugal of Angola's independence, one of Africa's biggest and wealthiest nations will be born in November. It will also be a country with one of the greatest potentials for internal strife.

title: 9 EMPLOYES OF I.T.T. LEAVE BOARD OF AVIS
description: Avis, Inc., announced yesterday that nine members resigned from its board, according to The Associated Press. All of the former directors are employes of the International Telephone and Telegraph Cornoratirm.

title: Brooklyn Tech Hurdlers Set Relay Meet Mark
description: The Public Schools Athletic League honored the memory of Martin Luther King yesterday with a track meet for its member schools at the 102d Engineers Armory. It was the fifth annual indoor memorial event.

title: Fire Hits Flooded Thai City
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 15 (AP)Fire broke out today in Trang, a southern provincial capital, causing extensive damage, Government sources said. The city, hard hit last week as the worst floods in decades swept a nineprovince area lacked sufficient firefighting equipment, the reports said.

title: Attack on Jersey Woman Called Hoax
description: After a daylong search for a man and a boy who reportedly attacked a 46yearold Margate N. J., woman in her $100,000 bayfront home Tuesday morning, the Margate police said last night that the woman had flabricatedrthe story and that the entire incident was a hoax.

title: Ford Weighs Shift of Telecommunications Office
description: As part of the reorganization of the executive office, the White House is seriously considering transferring the Office of Telecommunications Policy to the Department of Commerce.

title: COMMON MARKET PLANS AID FUND
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 15 (UP1)The nine European Common Market nations agreed today to set up a $4billion fund for five years of development assistance to 46 developing countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific Ocean regions.

title: U.S. Backs Treatment as a Right of Mental Patients
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The Department of Justice gave its support today to the contention that involuntary patients in mental hospitals had a constitutional right to treatment.

title: Sylvia Tauber Kraemer Married To Mordecai Rochlin, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Sylvia Tauber Kraemer, widow of Walter Kraemer, to Mordecai Rochlin, a senior member of the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison, took place here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: Quebec To Step In On Strike
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 15 (AP)The Quebec Government will intervene tomorrow and impose a settlement of a strike of 1,200 ironworkers that has jeopardized the suture of the 1976 Summer Olympic Games in Montreal, Premier Robert Bourassa announced tonight.

title: SALYUT 4 CREW SETS UP TELETYPE
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (UP1)Two Soviet astronauts aboard the orbiting Salyut 4 space station carried out complex navigational experiments and set up a teletype link to earth today.

title: Book's of The Times
description: EASY AND HARD WAYS OUT. By Robert

title: FORD NOMINATIONS RESENT TO SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) President Ford today resubmitted 10 nominations that were not acted on by the Senate last year, including the controversial choice of the former Governor ofConnecticut. Thomas J. Meskill, to be a judge of the Second Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. Mr. Meskill's nomination met opposition by several. Senators and by the American Bar Association.

title: Patients Laud Imperiled Home
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. Jan 15The fact I'm here means it's a nice home, said 89  year  old Catherine M. Joyce today, about the private nursing home where she lives.

title: State Pressing Its Efforts to Close 62 Nursing Homes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15An outraged Governor will be joined by an outraged Health Commissioner, Dr. Robert P. Whalen said today, announcing on the eve of taking command of the State Health Department that he wanted to close 62 of New York State's 599 nursing homes because of uncorrectable fire hazards.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Stock Average Gains 4.69; Computer Off 21 Minutes
description: The stock market moved in a narrow price range yesterday but managed to finish with moderate gains in active trading.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Concerto Grosso in G Handel; Suite No. 6 in F, Fischer; Apotheose de Luny, Couperin.

title: 2 Killed in Boston Shootout
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP)Two persons were shot to death toflight and two others were wounded in a shootout involving a narcotics investigation, by the police in Boston's South End. A police spokesman said none of the dead or wounded, who were not imtnediately identified, were policemen. Some heroin and two handguns were found at the scene, the police said.

title: CONGRESS BLAMED FOR MOSCOW RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15President Ford blamed Congress today for the breakdown in efforts to exchange American trade benefits for liberalized Soviet emigration practices. But key Senators and American Jewish groups blamed the Soviet Union.

title: Arrests Confirmed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP1) The State Department confirmed today that nine West Germans had been arrested in Karlsruhe on charges of espionage. One suspect was identified as an employee of I.B.M.

title: New Markets Are Sought for Miniaturized Computers
description: SANTA CLARA, Caif., Jan. 15The United States electronic industry has developed circuitry so miniaturized that it is pushing to install many computer functions in such things as automobiles, gasoline pumps, traffic signals and supermarket cash registers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: LISBON SIGNS PACT FREEING ANGOLA
description: ALVOR, Portugal, Jan. 10Portugal agreed today to grant independence to her African territory of Angola on Nov. 11. The accord virtually liquidated the world's last colonial empire.

title: Killebrew Accepts Pact With Royals
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 15 (AP)The Kansas City Royals said today they had signed Harmon Killebrew. He is expected to join Kansas City after getting his unconditional releas from the Minnesota Twins.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Jan 15, 1975

title: Radio Emissions From Saturn Detected by Satellite
description: On 12 occasions, a satellite in earth orbit has detected strong bursts of radio emission from the direction of Saturn. The emissions are believed to be similar in origin to those from Jupiter, indicating the presence of a strong magnetic field and encircling radiation belts.

title: LI FUCHUN DIES; LEADER IN PEKING
description: Li FuChug, a Vice Premier and top political figure. lib Chinki economy, has died at the Wage of 75, the official ChinesePiess Agency reported yesterday.

title: Ford's Energy Plan
description: Despite the continuing plunge in economic activity, the Ford (Administration still seems unconvincedas it was last Octoberthat recession is the worst evil facing the United States. Nor does

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Victor M. Rivera, New York district director of the Federal Small Business Administration, urged operators small, businesses in this area who had suffered substantial economic losses as a result of the energy crisis to apply soon as possible for loans from his agency to help compensate for their losses. Under a new program ire this field by the Small Business Administration, the agency can grant lowinterest loans up to $500,000 and guarantee up to 90 per cent of loans from banks. Mr. Rivera said applications would be handled on a firstcomefirstserved basis. Further information may be obtained by calling Philip Stuart of the S.B.A. office here (2643486) or the city's Department of Commerce and Industry (5938660).

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Funds for Rail Link to Be Sought

title: Armstrong Cork Price Cuts
description: The Armstrong Cork Company, Lancaster, Pa., announced yesterday that it was cutting mill prices on its Sundial cushioned nowax floors 20 per cent on 6foot rolls and 13 per cent on 12foot rolls. The company said that the reductions were the direct result of manufacturing efficiencies achievable from the substantial volume of Sundial sales.

title: Bowie kesults
description: BOWIE, MD.

title: Edda Moser Sings Lieder Superbly
description: Edda Moser is a living denial of the myth that good voice is a handicap for a lieder singer. The Berlinborn soprano, whose versatility has been displayed at the Metropolitan Opera in roles as diverse as Donrta Anna and the Queen of the Night gave a song recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night that continually refuted that dangerous old halftruth of music commentary.

title: LISBON SIGNS PACT FREEING ANGOLA
description: ALVOR, Portugal, Jan. 10Portugal agreed today to grant independence to her African territory of Angola on Nov. 11. The accord virtually liquidated the world's last colonial emAre.

title: Yugoslavia Jails 4 Ethnic Albanians
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 15Four Yugoslays of Albaniaq origin have been tried and imprisoned on charges of plotting against the state and the Communist party.

title: COMMUNIST CHIEF IN PARIS STRICKEN
description: PARIS, Jan. 15The French Communist leader, Georges Marchais, who has been leading his party's increasing denunciation of its Socialist allies in recent months, entered a hospital last night after suffering a heart attack.

title: Texans Dedicate L.R.J. Bust
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 15 (UP1)Texas legislators today dedicated a bronze bust of the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. Lady Bird Johnson unpinned a blue cloth draping the bust, unveiling it before the lawmakers and friends of the Johnson family. The bust, done by Jimilou Mason of Arlington Va., will be placed permanently in the halls of the state Capitol.

title: Miss Wade Victor
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 115 (AP)Virginia Wade, disputing line calls most of the match, posted a secondround victory over Betty Stove of the Netherlands tonight in a $75,000 women's tennis tournament.

title: 5 Freight Cars Jump Track
description: PEQUEA, Pa., Jan. 15 (AP)Five freight cars left the tracks near this Lancaster County community this morning, blocking a Penn Central shipping link between Pennsylvania and Maryland. The railroad said that the derailment occurred at 2:30 A.M. on the main line between Harrisburg, Pa., and Perryville, Md.

title: EHRLICHMAN GAINS IN PLUMBERS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP1) The special Watergate prosecutor said today he would not pursue the appeal of a chargedismissed by a Federal district judgethat John D. Ehrlichman lied to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the plumbers case.

title: FORD'S OIL PLAN CRITICIZED HERE
description: The city's top housing official and leaders of the local realestate industry expressed dismay yesterday at President Ford's proposals for added fees and taxes on oil and other petroleum products.

title: Miss Makarova Mugs Way Through Role
description: kassy was a delight as Cerito but Eleanor D'Antuono and Karena Block seemed a little jokily conventional as Grisi and Grahn respectively. Do you ever wonder what would happen if these dancers jumped up from their graves and reviewed these machinemade, computer  operated successors?

title: Greek ExDictator Refuses To Answer Treason Charge
description: ATHENS, Jan. 15 (UP1)George Papadopoulos, the former Greek dictator, refused to defend himself today against charges of high treason and insurrection before an investigating magistrate.

title: Madness in Great Ones
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15There has hardly been a time when problems so numerous and so profound confronted us at once. The American economy is in deep trouble. The price of oil is shaking the international financial structure. Future world supplies of energy and food are in doubt. War threatens the Middle East. Relations between the United States and the Soviet Union are deteriorating.

title: House in Connecticut Approves Opening of Committee Meetings
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 15The Connecticut House of Representatives voted unanimously today to open committee meetings to the public, except for security reasons or on personal matters. They also voted, 144 to 0, that votes of the members be recorded and that no votes by proxy be allowed.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GEM BOX You never know what quite to expect in the revival cavalcade of classics staged by the West Side Community Repertory (874.9400; 6663521), performing Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at 252 West 81st Street. Admission is $2.50. It is just beyond a barber pole southwest of Broadway (one flight down into a redyellowandglass front), seats only about 40 people and is invariably a bargain.

title: Magruder Says Prisoners Might Try to Kill Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP1)  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell's life might be in danger if he were sent to prison and other inmates were allowed access to him, Jeb Stuart Magruder said today.

title: Passengers Come to Aid Of IRT Robbery Victim
description: A pursesnatching suspect was held prisoner by a group of subway passengers at a Manhattan IRT station yesterday morning until the police arrived to arrest him according to the Transit Authority.

title: Today's Entries at Bowie
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter desginates OTB listing

title: U.S. Soviet Trade Has Been Soaring Despite Absence of a Ratified Accord
description: Under the impetus of the detente initiated by. Richard M. Nixon, trade between the Soviet Union and the United States has risen more than fivefold in the last few years even without formal ratification of the 1972 commercial agreement.

title: Ford to Visit Yugoslavia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reu ters)The White House said today that President Ford had accepted an invitation to visit Yugoslavia but said no date had been set. President Tito sent an invitation recently.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners. Not all lifts operating).

title: Neediest Cases Get a `Windfall From Erratic Vending Machine
description: An inoperative vending machine in Philadelphia, which failed to deliver a daily copy of this newspaper and then disgorged 50 cents in coins to the surprised purchaser, brought a small windfall to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Status Report on Layoffs
description: In the first round of city layoffs, on Nov. 22, a total of 510 civil servants and 1,000 provisionals were targeted for dismissal. On Dec. 11, in the second round, 2,200 civil servants and 1,525 provisionals were to be dismissed, and 2,700 Civil Service employes over the age of 65 were not to have employment extensions granted. Also, 875 substitute teachers were to be discharged.

title: PHILIPPINE REBELS REPORTED IN RAIDS
description: MANILA, Jan. 15 (UP1)Moslem rebels armed with mortars and grenade launchers killed all the members of a 41man army patrol and attacked Government installations in renewed fighting in the southern Philippines, military sources reported today.

title: Kerner Is Denied Parole; He Can Ask Again in 76
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP1) The Federal Parole Board today denied parole for Otto Kerner Jr., the former Illinois Governor and Federal judge who is serving a threeyear sentence on charges of bribery mail fraud, tax evasion, perjury and conspiracy.

title: SUSPECT IN DEATH OF L.I. GM SEIZED
description: NORTH BELLPORT, LI., Jan. 15A 17yearold youth has been charged with stabbing and strangling a 14yearold girl last weekend following a party in this small South Shore community.

title: New Clash Reported in South Lebanon; Israelis Deny Account of Major Attack
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday, Jan. 16 Four Arabs described as terrorists were killed and two Israeli soldiers wounded in a clash in southern Lebanon last night, the military headquarters announced today.

title: Colin Davis Leads Bostonians in Elgar and Sibelius
description: Colin Davis is one of the eminent Berlioz conductors of the day, but last night in Carnegie Hall, as guest with the Boston Symphony, he was content to use his favorite composer merely as a curtainraiser. The Waverley Overture is an immature work Berlioz in utero as it were but it is nice to hear once in a while.

title: Personal Finance: A Compendium For ConsumerComplaint Outlets
description: Never before have there been so many organizations government or industrysponsored groupsto help consumers with complaints about businesses or government agencies.

title: Continental Oil Extends LIFO
description: The Continental Oil Company has extended the lastin, firstout (1IFO) method of valuation to inventories of its Eastern Hemisphere petroleum division which will reduce 1974 consolidated net income by an estimated $65million or $1.28 a share, Howard, W. Blauvelt chairman, said Sresterday. LIFO has been in use for the company's United States petroleum and chemical inventories.

title: Beaunit Corporation Acquires Subsidiary of Indian Head, Inc.
description: Indian Head, Inc., and the Bgaunit Corporation announced jointly yesterday that Indian Head's subsidiary, Joseph Bancroft & Sons, Inc., owner of the BanLon trademark had been sold to Beaunit. The trademark

title: Market Place
description: The insurance companies that issue policies to help pay for damages from fire, automobile accidents or other casualties have just come through a poor year. Underwriting losses increased while their capital resources eroded with the stock market's slump; meanwhile the bond market fell steeply as interest rates rose.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Twelve junior business executives, graduate students of business at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. were required to become consumer advocates, specializing in fighting deceptive advertising.

title: Colts Name Marchibroda Coach
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 15 (AP)  Ted Marchibroda, a former National Football League quarterback who has been an assistant coach of George Allen for the last nine years was named today asthe fifth head coach of the Baltimore Colts in 27 months. He received a threeyear contract.

title: Economic Recovery the Key to Ford's Chances in 76
description: Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, a leader of the conservative Republicans, was quoted as having said that tax cuts would not save the economy and that the nation's economic ills resulted from Federal proErams.

title: In a Besieged Cambodian City, Hunger Death and theWhimpering of Children
description: NEAK LUONG, Cambodia Jan. 14Every 15 minutes or so a shell screams down and explodes in this besieged town and another halfdozen people are killed or wounded. It goes on day and night.

title: HartSchaffner Dividend Cut
description: Hart Schaffner & Marx said yesterday that it was cutting its regular quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share of common stock from 22 cents a share. The dividend is payable Feb 19 to shareholders of record Feb. 3.

title: Money
description: Wednesday, Jan. 15, 1975

title: A Laser Sheds New Light on Music
description: The big dome of the Hayden Planetarium, usually given over to kibitzing the course of galaxies, is being taken over these weekend nights by the laser beam.

title: Gerdy Stars on Court
description: The basketball shooting talent of John Gerdy of Passaic Valley High was evident to coach Carmen DiSimoni two years before the youngster became a freshman. So, it was not a total surprise to DiSimoni that in his first year at the Little Falls school, Gerdy scored 648 points for the varsity and developed a reputation as one of the better shooters in the state.

title: A HIGH ETHIOPIAN IS SAID TO DEFECT
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia, Jan. 15 The commander of, police forces in the north Ethiopian province of Eritrea has disappeared, according to unofficial and unconfirmed reports, and may people here believe he has defected to Eritrean guerrillas seeking independence from Ethiopia.

title: Keepers of the Bees Who Love to Cook With Honey Too
description: CORTLAND, III. In the Middle Ages, Sidney Gross told us over a glass of homemade beesting liqueur, honeybees were used as agents of warfare. The combatants would catapult the hives over castle walls to rout the enemy.

title: U.S. BUSINESSMEN UPSET OVER PACT
description: American businessmen, who had just begun to profit from hardwon business with the Soviet Union, were chagrined yesterday by the annulment of the United StatesSoviet trade agreement.

title: Solzhenitsyn Says Soviet Acts to Isolate Dissidents
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 15 (AP)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn charged today that Soviet authorities had begun neoStalinist strategy aimed at cutting the links of all dissidents with the outside world.

description: PARIS, Thursday Jan. 16The Constitutional Council ruled today that the abortion bill passed Dec. 4 by the French National Assembly is constitutional.

title: Dr. King Is Honored on 46th Birthday
description: The 46th birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was marked throughout the nation yesterday by ceremonies demonstration,s memorial servces and a range of programs that recalled the legacy of the slain civilrights leader and focused on both old and new problems confronting blacks and the poor.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: COAST UNIT BLOCKS 53 OFFSHORE WELLS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 15 1(UN)The drilling of 53 offshore oil wells in the Santa Barbara. Channel and construction of a controversial oil pipeline have been halted, at least temporarily, by the new State. Lands Commission.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the obituary of former State Senator Alexander A. Falk in The New York Times on Tuesday, the name of his widow, the former Edith Flavelle, was given incorrectly.

title: Australian Kelpie Gains Breed Recognition in U.S.
description: The Australian kelpie, one of the great sheepdogs of the world, has been officially recognized by the United States Department of Agriculture and now is eligible for dutyfree import into this country. U.S.D.A. breed recognition is required before pedigreed animals may be granted free entry under an Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service certificate of pure breeding.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: No Title

title: Contract Awards
description: Ingalls Shipbuilding division, of Litton Systems, Inc. Washington, has received a $252.6million increase under Navy contract to complete financing of the last seven destroyers in a 30ship program.

title: Pierre DavidWeill Dies at 74; Lazard Freres Partner in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 15Pierre DavidWeill, an art patron and a I,partner of Lazard Freres & Co. here and in New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 74 years old.

title: Beame Expects Dismissals To Cut Deficit $15Million
description: In the third and most severe round of budgetreducing cutbacks so far, Mayor Beanie announced yesterday that 4,050 additional city employees, including policemen, firemen, sanitationmen and teachers would be dismissed next month.

title: Records Sought From 3 In Subpoena by Bergman
description: Lawyers for Bernard Bergman served subpoenas yesterday on two state officials and a reporter for The New York Times, demanding that they appear with all notes and records of recent investigations of Mr. Bergman and the nursinghome industry.

title: Gene Mayer Upset Victor Over Taylor
description: FREEPORT, Bahamas, Jan. 15 (AP)Gene Mayer, 18yearold amateur from New Jersey, pulled a stunning upset today by beating Roger Taylor of Britain, 76, 62, in the second round of the $50000 Bahamas open tennis tournament today.

title: State Reporters Elect Slate
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15 (UP1)Dick Zander of Newsday today was elected president of the Legislative Correspondents Association, the organization of reporters covering state government from the Capitol. He succeeds Joseph Pichi of The Albany TimesUnion. Jerry Allan of The Buffalo Evening News was chosen first vice president; Thomas W. Poster of The New York Daily News, second vice president, and Patrick J. Brasley of Newsday, third vice president. John Considine of American Banker was reelected treasurer, and Robert Fusco of Bond Buyer was reelected secretary.

title: Beirut to Seek Arab Talks
description: BEIRUT, Jan. 15The. Lebanese Cabinet, meeting under President Suleiman Franjieh, decided today to call for a meeting of the Arab League's DeForeign Minister Philip Takla described as deterioration of the situation on the border with Israel.

title: Bridge
description: The first major tournament of 1975 accessible to New York enthusiasts, the Tristate Regional championships, begins today at Grossinger, N. Y. The schedule is as follows:

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Top Soccer Pick Is Star At Oneonta
description: The North American Soccer League conducted its annual college draft yesterday without its two Canadian teams Toronto and Vancouver. They said they wanted to develop only Canadian players for the benefit of the national team.

title: Jerseyan Slain in Florida
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)A Maplewood, N. J. man on a fishing vacation was shot dead near here by a hitchhiker according to the police. The victim; Stanley Brower; 70 years old, was shot in the head Monday rnd pushed cut of a rented car, a Monroe County Sheriff's officer said yesterday. The police said he apparently had resisted a hitchhiker's attempt to rob him.

title: PRICE INDEX DOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The nation gots its most encouraging report on the inflation front in more than two years today but there was also further confirmation of the deepening recession.

title: E.P.A. Chief Supports Ford Proposal Of 5Year Delay in CarFume Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Russell E. Train, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agericy, said today that he thought Priiident Ford's propaiat for a fiveyear moratorium on the final automobile emission limitations was quite reasonable.

title: States and Cities Seeking to Ban Police Use of Dumdum Bullets
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (UP1)Hollownosed, or dumdum bul lets, are outlawed as instruments of war. Now a move is afoot to ban their use by police departments in the United States.

title: Insko Suffers Fractured Skull
description: YONKERS, Jan. 15  Del In,sko was placed on the intensivecare list at St. John's Hospital here today. The 43yearold harness race driver, one of the best in the nation, was unseated during a race at the Yonkers Raceway last night, was hit by another horse and was taken unconscious to the hospital with a fractured skull.

title: on the Economy
description: President Ford has recognized the necessity of reversing the course of his policy as a means of changing the disastrous course of the economy. But the critical question is whether he has selected the best method of checking the decline, increasing real income and output, getting the unemployed back to work, curbing inflation and reducing United States dependence on foreign oil.

title: Bergman Denies All on Nursing Homes
description: Bernard Bergman, the central figure in a spate of inquiries into nursinghome abuses, has denied in an interview with a Yiddish weekly all accusations against him and says he is determined to clear his name.

title: Rangers Win From North Stars, 53
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 15The land of 10,000 lakes appeared like the land of 10,000 missed opportunities tonight for the Minnesota North Stars and the Rangers. What appeared like an easy victory for New York turned into a hangon, sweatitout 53 cliffhanger.

title: The Dance: In the Footsteps of 1845
description: There is pastiche, parody recreation, reconstruction and frank burlesqueand presumably they all have a part in ballet. Many years ago, in 1935 to be precise an English choreographer and teacher, Keith Lester, had the idea to recreate, for the MarkovaDolin Ballet in London a new version of one of dance's greatest confrontations. It was The Pas de Quatre, a romantic divertissement first presented by the impresario Benjamin Lumley at Her Majesty's Theater in London in 1845.

title: Canadiens Win, 53; String Now at 21
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (UP1) Yvan Cournoyer scored twice tonight as the Montreal Canadiens extended their undefeated string to 21 gamestwo short of the Natinnal Hobkey League record  by beating the Boston Bruins. 53.

title: City's New Corporation Counsel
description: I first met Mayor Beame when he joined city government, W. Bernard Richland said yesterday. I came across him at that time when he was assistant budget director. He was

title: Ford's New Direction
description: We. have a slogan. On his television teaser Monday night, President Ford spoke of his new direction; he repeated it twice in his State of the Union address yesterday; in his transmittal messages for the budget and economic reports in coming weeks, the new direction will flutter like a banner over the fine print.

title: NEW PRESSURE PUT ON SEOUL NEWSPAPER
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15 South Korea's most outspoken national daily came under new Government pressure todayias three members of its advertising staff were taken into custody for questioning.

title: Arab Oil Experts Express No Alarm Over Ford's Plans
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 15Arab oil expertsexpressed no surprise or alarm today over president Ford's proposed oil tax and conservation measures, which they characterized as a predictable reaction to higher world oil prices.

title: Satellite Liftoff Delayed
description: VANDENBERG Air Force Base, Calif., Jan. 15 (UP1)The launching of Landsat 2, the second earth resources survey satellite, has been rescheduled for Jan. 22, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N; Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Waldheim to Let Vietcong Open Geneva Office to Deal With U N
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Jan. 15Secretary General Waldheim has agreed to let the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionaiy Government of South Vietnam open an office at the United Nations4 Geneva headquarters to deal with humanitarian matters.

title: Leader of Rabbis Rues NursingHome Abuses
description: Rabbi Sol Roth, reelected yesterday as president of the New York Board of Rabbis said that the organization of some 1,000 Orthodox, Conservative and Reform rabbis in the metropolitan area and beyond was deeply distressed over alleged abuses in the nursinghome industry.

title: 1974 Trade Deficit Was $12.2Billion
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  The Government announced today that Britain ran a deficit in her exportimport trade equivalent to $12.2billion in 1974, the largest in British history and perhaps the largest in the world for the year.

title: and Energy
description: The ringing rhetoric for energy conservation with which President Ford began his series of policy statements this week had grown a little muffled by the time he got to the State of the Union Message yesterday. Now the initiative has passed to Congress to fashion a meaningful and equitable energy tax program, seizing upon the positive aspects in what the President has proposed but realigning his emphasis better to achieve the goal of conserving otherwise wasted energy.

title: Israelis See Immigration Loss. In Voiding of U.S. Soviet Pact
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 15 (AP)Israeli officials expressed dismay today over the collapse of the United StatesSoviet trade agreement because of Moscow's objections to American legislation linking trade benefits to freer emigration for Jews.

title: Natural Gas Emergencies To Be Asked in Six States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) A Federal Power Commission judge says that he will ask six states to declare natural gas emergencies, The proclamations would call on residents and businesses to use less gas for heating by lowering thermoitats to 68 degrees.

title: Lebanese Canip Shelled
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 (AP)The Palestinian guerrilla command here said Israeli naval vessels shelled a refugee camp and other targets in southern Lebanon today hours after an Israeli troop attack on a Southern Lebanese village. No casualties in the naval attack were immediately reported. [Eight Israelis were wounded in the ground attack on the vilrage, he Israeli command said.]

description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's State of the Union Message delivered to Congress yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The York Times:

title: Driver Seized In Times Sq. Area After Chase Through Midtown
description: A 27yearold motorist was seized near Times Square last night after he allegedly brandished a pistol at East Side pedestrians and then led the police on a wild midtown chase in which his car struck and seriously injured a man crossing the street.

title: King Day Crowds Give Skiing a Lift
description: Martin Luther King Day a holiday in Massachusetts helped send sales of ski lift tickets soaring in bordering southern New Hampshire yesterday. By noon, such ski re

title: Today's Entries at Calder
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Six in Jersey Family Killed as Fire Sweeps Home
description: BOONTON, N.J., Jan. 15Six members of a family died here late last night as a fire swept through their twostory home. Officials called it The worst disaster we ever had here.

title: Montaup to Burn Coal
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP)Montaup Electric Company has been granted permission to burn coal in one of its two units in Somerset, the Environmental Protection Agency said. The agency said yesterday that the company would begin burning coal about Feb. 1.

title: Advertising
description: The latest blowup in the bubbling field of syndicated magazine research came yesterday as Time Inc. filed a breachofcontract suit against W. It Simmons & Associates the major company in the field. Longtime observers of the field believe this suit, filed yesterday in New York State Supreme Court, is the first of its kind.

title: S. Carolina Names Aide
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15 (UP1)Larry New of the University of Arkansas has joined the football coaching staff at the University of South Carolina as offensive assistant and recruiter.

title: Release of Prisoners In Northern Ireland Denounced by I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Jan. 15 (UP1)Britain released another group of Irish Republican Army and Protestant loyalist prisoners today but the I.R.A.'s political front denounced the peace gesture.

title: PADDLING INQUIRY ORDERED BY ANKER
description: Dissatisfied with an earlier local investigation into allegations of corporal punishment in some Bronx schools, Chancellor Irving Anker has directed his special trustee in Community School District 9 to personally conduct a new investigation into the charges.

title: Last Four Plead Guilty in Campisi Case
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 15 The Campisi murder and racketeering trial ended today bpefore it formally began, with the last four of the nine defendants changing their pleas to guilty.

title: They Came to the. House Party and They Brought Their Money
description: You know how everybody's bored with charity balls. An theater parties have their limitations. So when the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, which runs the settlement house at 331 East 70th Street, planned a fundraising event, they decided to run it at home. The nursery and day care rooms on the second floor were filled with grownup size tables and turned into dining rooms. The gym in the basement was filled with chairs and became an auction room, basketball hoops still hanging from the sides. The auditorium on the main floor was transformed into a series of boutiques with merchandise contributed and cajoled by the likes of Bill Blass and Sister Parish.

title: Kissinger and Allon Open Talks on New Mideast Round
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 ecretary of  State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel opened a crucial series of discussions today on bow to make progress in the next round of IsraeliEgyptian negotiations.

title: A.T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its earnings had taken a sharp drop in December and for the first time the giant utility issued a preliminary unaudited earnings statement.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Survey Finds Shift in Views on Religion
description: While most Americans still believe Jeligion is losing its impact on society, the majority holding that view has dwindled sharply since 1970.

title: GEORGE SLAUGHTER UROLOGIST, 70, DIES
description: Dr. George W. Slaughter, a urologist, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home. He was 70 years old and lived at 111 East 48th Street.

title: Energy Plan to Raise Consumer Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15President Ford submitted to Congress today a manysided energy independence plan that would mean higher energy prices for all consumets.

title: Swiss Wins In Ski Race For Women
description: SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 15 (UP1)  Bernadette Zurbriggen of Switzerland took advantage of a rare lapse by Annemarie Proell today and won a world cup downhill race.

title: Nets Beaten By Pacers Drop to 2d
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 15The Indiana Pacers continued their mastery, over the New York Nets tonight by defeating the defending champions of the American Basketball Association, 111106.

title: Union Carbide Spending
description: The Union Carbide Corpbtadon said yesterday it would spend about $2.8billion onits construction program in the next three years with $800million allotted this year and $1billion each in 1976 and 1977

title: S. Carolina Names Aide
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15 (UP1)Larry New of the University of Arkansas has joined the football coaching staff at the University of South Carolina as offensive assistant and recruiter.

title: SovietAustralian Pact
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (Reuters) Australia and the Soviet Union signed their first scientific and cultural agreements today after talks between Australia's Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, and Aleksei N. Kosygin the Soviet Premier. Mr. Whitten arrived in the Soviet Union on Sunday and flies to West Germany tomorrow.

title: PRESIDENTS PLAN DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Influential Senators and House members were sharply critical today of many of President Ford's proposals to conserve energy and invigorate the economy, and there appeared to be little chance that the proposals would be approved intact.

title: Britain Sets Plans for the Nationalization of the Aircraft Industry
description: LONDON; Jan. 15The Government announced plans today for the nationalization of the British aircraft industry and the formation of a stateowned corporation to take over the business and assets of three major aircraft producers.

title: Detente and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15For official Washington, the sting of yesterday's announcement that Moscow had rejected the 1972 trade accord will be felt more in the arena of American domestic politics than in that of Soviet  American dtente itself. The general reaction is that dtente will survive, but that someone will have to be,blamed anyway.

title: CONGRESS BLAMED FOR MOSCOW RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15President Ford blamed Congress today for the breakdown in efforts to exchange American trade benefits for liberalized Soviet emigration practices. But key Senators and American Jewish groups blamed the Soviet Union.

title: Cutting Food Budgets for the Elderly
description: No one was younger than 62, some were in. their 80's and about 90 per cent of them were women and they were all in the Lower East Side supermarket one morning this week to hear about a shopping experiment.

title: Pulling Back From the Mideast Precipice
description: CAIROThe most probable option facing all parties in the Middle East is another war between the Arabs and the Israelis. But another war will be different from the previous ones.

title: Alexians Suspend Talks With Indians Over Home
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (UP1)The Alexian Brothers said today they planned no more meetings with Indians occupying their monastery at Gresham, Wis., until the Indians supplied visible proof of a wellorganized program for using the 64room mansion.

title: Cloud From a Rocket Seen Off the East Coast
description: A huge bluegreen fluorescent cloud created by powdered aluminum discharged by a rocket fired from Wallop's Island, Va., startled residents along much of the Eastern Seaboard early last night. Hundreds of calls to police stations and news organizations resulted.

title: Chess
description: In his new book 200 Open Games, the Russian grandmaster David Bronstein says You can have what views you like, but there is no such thing as a competitive player that's plain fiction. As is habitual with him, Bronstein neglects to provide any defense for his assertion. The style of his writing is that of his conversation: what might be termed off the cuff, excathedra delivery.

title: Administrations Expects Budget Deficits of on $47 Billion in
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The Ford Administration disclosed today that it expected the budget deficit to go as high as $344billion this fiscal year and $47billion in the fiscal year 1976, assuming Congress enacts the entire Ford economic program.

title: Last 4 Defendants Plead Guilty Ending Campisi Murder Trial
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Jan. 15The Campisi murder and racketeering trial ended today before it formally began, with the last four of the nine defendants changing their pleas to guilty.

title: Hebert to Weigh Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP1)  Representative F. Edwar Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said today that he would be willing to consider President Ford's proposal to tap the Elk Hills Naval Petroleum Reserve in California.

title: Britain Inherits an Ancient Castle With American Connections
description: LONDON, Jan. 15Leeds Castle, an ancient fortress once belonging to a family that helped colonize Virginia has been bequeathed to the British nation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Teacher Decision Delayed
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 15 (AP)The New Hampshire Board of Education postponed today any action on a regulation that would suspend the credentials of striking teachers. The board, on a 5to1 vote decided to seek further advice from the state attorney general's office.

title: DR. JULIAN HERRMANN
description: Dr. Julian B. Herrmann, a cancer surgeon, died Tuesday at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 78 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15Some Arab commentators expressed gratification today at the cancellation of the Ameri

title: Boy, 15, Murders His Parents With Ax And Leaps to Death Off a Water Tower
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, Jan. 15A 15  year  old private school student killed his mother and father with an axe yesterday evening, the police said and then committed suicide by jumping from a water tower a half mile from his home here.

title: SCHICCHP ROLE SUNG BY MISS DI FRANCO
description: Lauretta, the young heroine of Gianni Schicchi, was sung by a soprano who was almost a namesake in the performance of the Puccini work at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night. She was Loretta Di Franco, whose work with the company in shorter roles has occasionally been rewarded by a larger part. Although Miss Di Franco looks more matronly than she used to, her voice still has a pretty, fresh clarity that made her singing of Puccini's sensuous melodies appealing.

title: Saxbe Says He Refused Aid for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that he had been repeatedly urged by White House aides to President Nixon to interfere in the prosecution of the Watergate case.

title: Boy, 6,.Drowns in Nassau
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Jan. 15 (UP1)  A 6yearold boy drowned this afternoon when he fell through the thin ice of a small stream that runs parallel to Meadowbrook Parkway near his home. A Nassau County police officer, Frank White, reached under the ice and pulled out the boy, Timothy Fowler of 122 Mitchell Avenue but the boy was pronounced dead on arrival at the Nassau County Medical Center here.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Justin S. Colin, president of Ballet Theater Foundation and the executive committee of the foundation board which sponsors American Ballet Theater, announced yesterday that Sherwin M. Goldman has declined to accept a further term as a governing trustee in order to give attention to his other activities.

title: Fordham Subdues Lafayette
description: Although it took Darryl Brown nearly half of the gaMe to get his first 5 points in Fordha.m's 7472 overtime victory over Lafayette last night, he scored a point a minute the rest of the way.

title: Blanche Dworsky Ratner Aided Jewish Aged Here
description: Blanche Dworsky Ratner, a pioneer in programs for the Jewish aged here, died Tuesday in Southport, Conn., at the age of 79.

title: Accord Is Reached On I.M.F. Oil Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Finance Ministers representing both rich and poor countries agreed today on a $6billion oil facility within the International Monetary Fund to help nations pay their oil bills in 1975. The ministers also reportedly agreed on a new feature for the facilityinterest rate subsidies on loans to about 30 of the very poorest nations.

title: W. D. M'MILLAN 3D, 77 ENGLISH PROFESSOR
description: William Dougald MacMillan 3d, Kenan Professor Emeritus of English at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill died Friday. He was 77 years old.

title: Jersey Bell to Reconsider Layoffs of 334
description: NEWARK, Jan. 15 The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company agreed today to review its decision to lay off 334 workers on Feb. 1.

title: Computers, Collection Agencies and City Police Act to Ferret Violators Out, but Still Fall Behind
description: The elderly woman on the telephone was indignant. A young neighbor in her building got parking tickets in wholesale lots but simply tore them up because he had arranged to get his license plates from a distant state. Besides, she said; he lives in a filthy room with a dozen cats, and he runs around the halls naked.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the obituary of former State Senator Alexander A. Falk in The New York Times on Tuesday, the name of his widow, the former Edith Flavelle, was given incorrectly.

title: Patman and Hays Rebuffed In Vote on Chairmanships
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The 24member Democratic Steering and Policy Committee voted today to unseat two. veteran Representatives from their committee chairmanships in a victory for Congressional reformers over the House seniority system.

title: RECORD RISE SEEN IN CITY REALTY TAX
description: A record increase of $1.09 in the city's basic realestate tax over the current level of $7.35 was predicted by Controller Harrison J. Goldin after he estimated the cost of debt service to the city for the fiscal year beginning July 1 at $2.01billion, the highest in history.

title: A Debate for Israelis: What Path to Peace?
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 15A farreaching public debate is under way here among Cabinet ministers, leading intellectuals and commentators over the best way for Israel to proceed with negotiations, with her Arab neighbors.

title: LEVER ETT F. HOOPER
description: Leverett F. Hooper, a retired banker, died Tuesday at his home. He was 81 years old and lived at 29 Gordon Road, Essex Fells. N. J.

title: Dr. Joseph A. Tamerin, 66 Plastic Surgeon Here, Dies
description: Dr. Joseph A. Tamerin plastic surgeon and medical archivist, died Tuesday at his home at 876 Park Avenue. He was 66 years old.

title: Voters in Willimantic Approve 4th Budget
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Jan. 15 (AP)  A crowd of 900 taxpayers overwhelmingly approved a fourth budget proposal tonight, bailing the city government out of a temporary crisis.

title: People in Sports
description: While Henry Boucha of the Minnesota North Stars recovers from surgery to correct double vision in his right eye the player who struck him with the butt end of a hockey stick Jan. 4 will sit out his team's next mine games plus a contest Feb. 6 with the North Stars.

title: Syracuse Man Sentenced In Death of Young Cyclist
description: SYRACUSE, Jan, 15 (UP)A Syracuse man was sentenced today to up to four years in prison in the traffic death of a 10yearold boy last year.

title: A Changing Iran Wonders Whether the Gain Will Exceed the Loss
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 15Haji Mahmud Barzegar, a seller of songbirds, scowled at the new cars that streamed unceasingly along the avenue past his neglected shop.

title: ARAB FILES LAWSUIT IN COAST BANK DEAL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15IThe controversy surrounding the plans of Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian businessman, to buy a onethird interest in the First National Bank of San Jose, Calif., intensified today when Mr. Khashoggi filed suit in Federal District Court here.

title: Republican Analysis Predicts State Budget Surplus for 74'75
description: ALBANY, 15The Republican staff of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee concluding from a computer study that the effects of inflation on state finance are stronger than the effect of recession, predicted today that the state would end its current fiscal year with a surplus of $150million or more.

description: Members of a task force on the problems of the aged appointed by Governor Hugh L. Carey agreed, after their first meeting yesterday, that the two worst crises facing the elderly were unfit nursing homes and inadequate Social Security incomes.

title: Ireland Sharply Raises Tax On Alcohol and Cigarettes
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Ireland's Finance Minister today announced heavy tax increases on beer, spirits, wine and cigarettes in a budget statement that also granted improvements in social assistance and a small reduction in income tax.

title: Ford Fuel Proposal Called Threat to Nation's Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP1)  Airline pilots and engineers fear that President Ford's program to drive up fuel costs as an energy saving measure would have a disastrous effect on the nation's carriers.

title: Pairleigh Is Beaten
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 15 The University of WisconsinMilwaukee scored 7 straight points to break a 5959 tie tonight and went on to defeat Fairleigh Dickinsop University, 7766. Rich Conrad had 23 points for F.D.U. which has a 5.6 record.

title: NO CUT IN OIL OUTPUT PLANNED BY KUWAIT
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 15Kuwait will sell as much oil as customers will buy at price levels set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries and no mandatory reduction in output has been imposed for this year, according to highly placed oil officials here.

title: CHRYSLER IS FACING AUDIT ON TANK PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reuters)The Army plans to audit Chrysler records to determine whether an increase of more than 39 per cent in this year's purchase price of M60 tanks is iustified.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 15 (UP1)Arnold Palmer, the old king who claims he isn't dead yet, will make his 1975 debut tomorrow against Johnny Miller and most of last year's top 15 moneywinners in the first round of the $200,000 Dean MartinTucson open golf tournament. The 45yearold Palmer, who was dominating the tour a dozen years ago the way Miller is now, has been practicing in Florida for three weeks. He thinks his game is in reasonably good shape.

title: MESSAGE GLOOMY

title: 'Broken Treaty at Battle Mountain'
description: "Broken Treaty at Battle Mountain," the documentary being shown through Tuesday in the New American Filmmakers Series at the Whitney Museum of American Art, generates a narrative excitement that is not often found in nonfiction films given to exploration of issues.This is the story of a small group of Western Shoshone Indians who live in Nevada's Battle Mountain Indian Colony. Unlike most of their neighboring fellow Indians, they are traditionalists, people who want to retain their culture and their lands. The land in question consists of 24 million acres, about one third of Nevada, and they contend that the treaty they concluded with the United States in 1863 did not make any concessions to the nation that had come upon them.They have refused compensation and are threatened by Government policy, which permits thousands of trees on the land to be torn down, trees that the tribe's religion regards as sacred and that also provide food.Joel L. Freedman, producer and director of this 70-minute color film, spent two years making it. He has told it as a story of a small, menaced people, depicting their way of life, their problems, their humor, their aspirations, much of it in their own words, although Robert Redford narrates the script by Tom Schachtman.Chuck Levey's photography dramatically focuses on faces and foliage, following the Indians from the quiet of their colony to a dramatic climax in the Indians' confrontation with the Indian Claims Commission and depicting the relentless uprooting of the trees by a huge chain pulled between two tractors."Broken Treaty at Battle Mountain" has much to say to anyone who is concerned with big against small, with preservation against "progress" and it says it well. The story does not end with the film. These Western Shoshones are still in litigation and seeking public support; the film should go a long way toward finding it. After the Whitney run, it goes to Quad Cinema next Wednesday.

title: Screen: 'Macon County Line' Arrives
description: When a movie like "Macon County Line" comes into town nine months after it has opened elsewhere in the country, having already earned more than $8-million, the primary impulse is to ask why. What does it mean?"Macon County Line," which arrived at neighborhood theaters yesterday, apparently means that rural melodramathe kind that realizes our worst nightmaresis still sure-fire box office if it is vivid and violent enough and if it's pitched at a mentality that finds road-sign reading an intellectual labor.Like Phil Karlson's "Walking Tall," another national phenomenon, "Macon County Line" is set in the back-country American South, a region that is becoming as essential to a certain kind of pop American melodrama as Transylvania is to the vampire movie.In these melodramas, the rural South is a place of unrelieved bigotry, cruelty and violence. Travelers from other parts of the country either are crooks who teach the natives new ways to misbehave or they are innocents, like those in "Easy Rider," who wander too close to the edge of the civilized world and fall off it. It was one of the few credits to "Billy Jack," set in the Southwest, that it showed the South to have no corner on evil.Also like "Walking Tall," based on the life of Buford Pusser, the late Tennessee sheriff, "Macon County Line" is said to be a fictionalized account of something that actually happened. There, however, the similarity ends. Mr. Karlson is a talented, canny director who knows his medium. Richard Compton, who directed "Macon County Line," has studied the medium but he doesn't seem to trust it. After the first 30 minutes, there isn't a scene or a revelation that the director (and co-author) hasn't so laboriously set up that a bright 10-year-old couldn't predict all the subsequent events.That, of course, could be one reason why the movie has proved so popular. It affirms our belief in our own witless superiority.The screenplay was written by Mr. Compton and Max Baer (late of "The Beverly Hillbillies"), who also produced the film and very creditably acts a leading role. As Deputy Reed Morgan, Mr. Baer plays a beefy, bigoted sheriff whose Confederate sympathies (he wears a small rebel flag on his sleeve) are somehow made to seem responsible for the griefstricken rampage that highlights the film.The story, placed in the mid-nineteen-fifties, concerns two young men from Chicago, brothers about to be inducted in the Army who, in the course of a final spree across the country, are mistaken for a pair of murderous psychotics. That's all there is: vagrant viciousness and coincidence. It's about nothing more than casual error.Yet the film is not without its moments of primitive fascination, which result, I suspect, from the spectacle of watching innocent people hopelessly if arbitrarily trapped."Macon County Line" also benefits from its performances by the professionals who play the leads, including Mr. Baer, and by the nonpros who play the supporting roles, random country folk, characters like waitresses and filling-station attendants whose awkwardnesses carry peculiar conviction.Alan Vint and Jesse Vint, brothers in real life, display an easy, intelligent self-assurance as the ill-fated tourists from Chicago, and Cheryl Waters is surprisingly affecting as the good-hearted bar girl who has the misfortune to be picked up by the brothers. The written roles seem merely outlines for characters, but these three young performers gives them individual and identifiable substance.

title: The Screen:Nicholas Ray Subject of 'Stranger Myself'
description: Jean-Luc Godard called him the camera. An admiring student describes him as a con artist. He himself says that when he read the laudatory analyses of his work by French film critics he didn't know who they were talking about. He is Nicholas Ray, the fine, often troubled film director who is the subject of the feature-length documentary "I'm a Stranger Here Myself," which will be shown at the First Avenue Screening Room at noon and midnight today and tomorrow.The film is a fascinating footnote to contemporary motion picture history. It's too affectionate to be critically definitive, but it captures a lot of the contradictions in the life and career of this man who manages to seem most elegant and ascetic when he most needs a shave and a fresh cigarette, who is simultaneously old and young, totally sincere and just occasionally full of bananas.Mr. Ray may well be his own most complex, riveting hero. He's a romantic with a fiercely realistic view of things.After a solid apprenticeship in the New York theater, Mr. Ray moved to Hollywood in the nineteen-forties, managing to make several classics ("In a Lonely Place," "Rebel Without a Cause" and "Johnny Guitar") while playing the role of one of the town's most dependable contract directors. He then more or less disappeared in the sixties, his fortunes declining and falling with a couple of big-budget made-in-Spain blockbusters ("King of Kings," "55 Days at Peking")."I'm a Stranger Here Myself," which he describes as the working title of every project he's ever worked on, examines Mr. Ray and his career from the vantage point of the two-year hitch (1972-1973) he put in teaching at Harpur College at the State University of New York at Binghamton. Intercut with sequences showing Mr. Ray directing his students in the production of an ambitious experimental feature are interviews with John Houseman (identified by the director as one of the two most important influences on his career, the other being Elia Kazan), Natalie Wood (who co-starred in "Rebel Without a Cause") and Franois Truffaut, who eloquently describes his admiration for "Johnny Guitar."The film also makes use of clips from various Ray films "Johnny Guitar," "Rebel without a Cause," "In a Lonely Place," "They Live by Night") to back up these points, and though the clips are fairly extensive, they have a way of undercutting the things said. Snippets from movies, even good ones, are seldom substantial enough to carry the weight of this sort of analysis.Most fascinating and moving are the Binghamton sequences:the director badgering his leading lady for being late to a wintry midnight location (she has a round, pretty unfinished face and an unfinished star's temper), theorizing about acting, recalling some of the great names he has worked with, pausing in a frozen half-crouch as he studies the set-up for a shot, pretending with all his heart to be making the next great Ray film. That's not meant to be pejorative. Pretense, illusion and monumental self-assurance are part of the drive of genius.Howard da Silva provides the mostly straightforward narration for the film, which was made by two talented young men named David Helpern Jr. (director) and James C. Gutman (producer). Auston de Besche was director of photography. They are up to the demands of their subject who, at 63 years old, is still one of the most irascible, original men making movies.

description: HOUSTON, Jan. 16 (AP)Randy White, a detenswe tackle from Maryland, was named winner of the fifth annual Vince Lombardi Award as the nation's outstanding lineman tonight. White, who accepted the award at a $100aplate dinner, beat out three other finalistsLouis Keleher of Southern Methodist, Pete Cusick of Ohio State and Rod Shoate of Oklahoma.

title: Baker Reports C.I.A. Compiled Dossiers on a Former Senate Aide and a Private New York Investigator
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. said today that his investigation into any Central Intelligence Agency involvement in Watergate had disclosed that the agency had compiled dossiers on a former Senate aide and a New York private investigator.

title: GIRL, 4, IS PULLED FROM TRAIN'S PATH
description: Two men risked their lives last night to rescue. a 4yearold girl who had fallen to the tracks in front of a subway train, according to a Transit Authority official,

title: State Lists 92 Nursing Homes With Operating Deficiencies
description: Following is a State Health Department list, broken down. by Health Department regions and released yesterday, of 92 nursing homes cited for one or more operational deficiencies:

title: Revolt in the House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Ever,since Woodrow Wilson wrote his masterful study of Congressional Government in 1913, thoughtful men and women here have been complaining about the divine right of the committee chairmen in the House and callingfor modification of the seniority system. Now finally, something is actually being done about it.

title: W. T. Grant Cutbacks
description: The W. T. Grant Company which expects to report a net loss of about $175million for the fiscal year, is involved in a heavy retrenchment in which it will discharge 12,600 employes by April 1 and close. 126 stores during the year. The expected loss is probably the largest retailing, deficit on record. Page 45.

title: 3 BIG BANKS POST HIGHER EARNINGS
description: Three big New York bankholding companiesthe Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the Charter New York Corporation reported higher earnings yesterday for the fourth quarter and 1974.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In some editions of The New York Times yesterday, the text of a report by William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, to a Senate subcommittee contained an erroneous not that distorted the meaning of one of his statements. A corrective article appears on Page 10.

title: BANKS ASSAILED BY HEAD OF U.D.C.
description: Edward Logue, head of the financially troubled State Urban Development Corporation charged yesterday that his agency's inability to raise money to complete its projects resulted from its refusal to knuckle under to a demand by large banks that it not undertake any new housing consuction.

title: Notes on People
description: Jack T. Conway, since 1970 the $45,000ayear press ident of Common Cause, the Washington  based citizens lobby; has been named exec utive director of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employes, with headquarters in Washington.

description: News documentaries and cultural programs have traditionally been television's weak fare. Yet, in recent weeks, the following have been noted from the A. C. Nielsen rating reports:

title: An UnAmerican Thing
description: The new winds blowing through the House have finally swept away that ailing relic of an ugly past, the House Internal Security Committee. Established in 1930 as the Select Committee to Investigate Communist Propaganda, it reached its heyday in the forties and fifties as the House UnAmerican Affairi.,Committee, serving as a platform for such proponents of an American orthodoxy as Martin Dies Richard M. Nixon, and J. Parnell Thomas. Between 1945 and 1969 it received more than $6.5 million In funds and managed to produce Only one Major piece of legislation.

title: Maryland Trounces N.C.State
description: COLLEGE PARK. Md., Jan. 16 (AP)Fifthranked Maryland picked apart the zone defense of fourthranked North Carolina State in the second half and defeated the. Wolfoack, 10385, tonight.

title: About New York
description: Spies are in the news again. William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence has said that at least 22 C.I.A. agents passed into the ranks of American dissidents and investigated them. Mr. Colby did not say how many agents operated in New York, but it may be assumed that a good many did. The city is a fertile place for the intelligence community.

description: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANNHAUPT

title: Mood in Cairo: War or Peace by Spring
description: CAIRO, Jan. 16The Middle East has entered a crucial period of a few months during which there will be either. new and much more devastating war or a breakthrough in the form a major Israeli withdrawal in the Sinai Peninsula and Israeli commitments to make withdrawals in the Golan Heights and the West Bank of the Jordan River.
