description: (Millions of dollars)

title: Bishop and Rector Protest Trinity's Suit on Housing
description: The Episcopal Bishop of New York, the Rt. Rev. Paul Moore Jr., and the rector of Trinity Parish, the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Parks, yesterday publicly protested a decision of the board of directors of Trinity School to continue efforts to block construction of lowincome housing across the street from the school.

title: Safety Board Says Rates of Accidents and Fatalities of U.S. Airlines Rose Sharply in 1974
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that United States airlines in 1974 recorded their worst safety record in almost a decade.

The Times Acquires StarNews Papers Of Wilmington,N.C.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had purchased the StarNews newspapers of Wilmington, N. C. the only newspapers published in Wilmington, which has a Population of 46,000.

title: ABORTION INQUIRY ASKED BY SENATOR
description: BERLIN, Jan. 16State Senator Joseph A. Maressa today called for a new hearing by the New Jersey Health Planning Council on the state's abortion policies, saying that statistics from an Atlantic City abortion clinic indicate an appalling disregard for the morts of girls and single women.

title: Suspect in Bronx Slaying Of a Stewardess Gives Up
description: One of three men wanted in the murder of a Bronx airline stewardess last week after robbers bound her husband to a chair in another room surrendered to the police yesterday.

title: A.C.L.U. Wins $ 12Million Suit. For War Protesters at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The American Civil Liberties Union won a $12million damage suit against the District of Columbia today.for what a jury said was the false arrest and infringement of rights of 1,200 antiwar demonstrators on the steps of the Capitol in 1971.

title: 27 Blacks Seize the Dining Hall At Minot, S.D., Air Force Base
description: MINOT, N. D., Jan. 16 (AP)Twentyseven black servicemen and women locked themselves in the dining hall of Minot Air Force Base for six hours today to protest what was described as racial discrimination in the community.

title: Article 2  No Title
$1,660 Corona Bank Holdup
description: The East New York Savings Bank at 5814 99th Street in Corona, Queens, was robbed yesterday of $1,660 by a man his late teens who handed a teller a threatening note.

title: GIFTS TO NEWSMEN UPHELD AS WAGES
description: For many years after the first press agent sat down to lunch with a reporter for the first time, the problem of how to handle the free tickets, free trips and other gifts proffered by news sources to reporters and editors hasplagued the media.

title: Oklahoma Governor Is Charged With Seeking Bribe of $50,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Gov. David Hall of Oklahoma was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of seeking a $50,000 bribe to influence the investment of $10million in state retirement funds in a private company.

title: Refugees From Darwin Are Growing Anxious
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 16 Theo Ginis, a Greek immigrant with a wife and two children, does not know whether he will go back to Darwin, where he worked as a laborer on a construction site before most of the city was destroyed by a cyclone on Christmas Day.

title: Date Set for Rule to Speed AutoCollision Settlements
description: State Insurance Superintend. ent Benjamin R. Schenck gave official notice yesterday that a new department regulation would go into effect April 1 to speed payments by insurers in automobile crashdamage cases.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS MOVE NARROWLY
description: Stock prices moved in a narrow range yesterday for the second straight session but ended higher as trading accelerated.

title: FOP BROS TALKS IN BID FOR SUPPORT OF ECONOMIC PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16President Ford, insisting that immediate action to implement his economic and energy proposals is urgently required; began today a concerted effort to sell his new policies to the nation.

title: ExAttorney for Hoffa Bidsto Acq uire Casino
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 16 No one blinked today when the Nevada Gaming Control Board came eyeball to eyeball with Morris Shenker, the 68yearold St. Louis lawyer who has helped arrange loans of far more than $100million from the Teamsters Union Central State Pension Funds.

title: India Wins Doubles in Cup Tennis
description: LUCKNOW, India, Jan. 16 (AP)The Amrltraj brothers who lost to New Zealand in the opening singles matches, came back for a doubles victory today that kept India in contention for the Davis Cup. New Zealand led, 21 with the final two singles matches of the East Zone series scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Beanie Seeks Fuel Parley Of Mayors in the Northeast
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he planned to organize a conference of Northeast mayors as the first step in a mobilization of the leaders of government business and consumers to insure that this sector of the country will not bear any greater burden than the rest of the nation in terms of fuel costs or its availability.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Commerce Department reported today that the nation's total output in the last three months of 1974 declined at the fastest rate for any threemonth period. in 16 years, giving evidence that the country was in its most precipitous recession since World War II.

description: W. Lloyd George, who retired as a senior official of the Central Intelligence Agency in 1967 died Thursday in Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital, Arlington. He was 74 years old. Mr. George, who lived in Washington, had lived in Merrick, L.I. and had been Long Island editor of The Brooklyn Eagle.

title: People in Sports
description: Jose Napoles, the world welterweight champion, recognized by all international boxing organizations, breezed into a midtown Spanish restaurant yesterday to announce he probably would make his 12th title defense against Angel Espada, the Puerto Rican welter champion in San Juan on March 22.

description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 17 (Reuters)The army and navy were standing by to man India's ports today as all shipping operations were halted on the second day of a dock workers strike.

title: Bergman Agrees to Appear at Inquiry By Senate Panel Into Nursing Homes
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome owner and operator has accepted a subpoena to testify here Tuesday before a United States Senate subcommittee investigating the nursinghome business, a legislative aide said yesterday.

title: Beame Knew That His New Deputy Was Named in a TicketFixing Inquiry
description: When Mayor Beame appointed Stanley M. Friedman as a Peputy Mayor last month, he Was aware that Mr. Friedman had been sternly criticized in a confidential Investigation Department report three years ago for his involvement in a scandal over parkingticket fixing.

title: Dollar Closes Lower
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 17 (UP1)The dollar closed generally lower today, ending the third full week it has been in one of its worst slumps.

title: Ranuccio Bianchi Bandinelli Italian Archeologist,74, Dies
description: ROME, Jan. 17  Ranuccio Bianchi Bandinelli, an internationally known classical archeologist who played a prominent role in the Communist party, died here today of a liver ailment. He was 74 years old.

title: Death of a Cypriote Mars Opening of Political Talks
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 17Political talks began today on the future of Cyprus, but a violent protest that resulted in the death of an 18year old Greek Cypriote showed that the issues dividing the communities of this island remained intricate and explosive.

title: EXGOV. HOMER HOLT OF WEST VIRGINIA
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 17 (UP1)  Homer A. (Rocky) Holt, Governor of West Virginia from 1937 to 1941, died yesterday in a hospital where he was being treated for pneumonia. He was 76 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Directors of a number of narcotics treatment and prevention programs in uptown Manhattan charged that the city's Addiction Services Agency, which supervises them, was inept and bungling, but Jerome Hornblass head of the agency, vigorously defended it.

title: Lawyer Says Colson Is Uncertain Whether Nixon Spoke to Burger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP1) Charles W. Colson's attorney says the former White House aide does not know whether President Nixon spoke with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger about a suit. to obtain his Watergate tapes.

title: Winter's Wool
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J.It Is probably due to inflation more than anything else, but you may (or may not) have noticed that few people nowadays are much concerned with the question, Is God dead?

title: Smithtown Nursing Home on L.I. Is Under Scrutiny by Grand Jury

Which it has been, most handsomely by Peter J. Hall. And, while the Metropolitan Opera was on the subject, it was also decided to restage it. John Dexter and Patrick Tavernia took care of that.

title: Ruth P. Collins, 84, Dies; Author of Children's Books
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (UP1)Ruth Philpott Collins, author of children's books and a freelance magazine writer died Friday in Daconess Hospital. She was 84 years old.

title: Art: Sampling of Asian Delights

The museum will permanently house the Asian art collection of, Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, and will thus provide the city with a sort of Asian counterpart to the Frick Collection six blocks to the north.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Four former highranking mem bers of the Johnson Administration said today that they knew of no Presidential directive ordering the Central Intelligence Agency to set up a special office in 1967 to handle domestic intelligence about radical and antiwar groups.

title: Notes on People
description: Muhammad All is going to step into the ring next Tunsday night with Mayor Mayhard Jackson of Atlanta who is said to be down a bit from his inauguration weight of 300 pounds and stands 6 foot 3 inches. The threeround exhibition match is part of the This Is Black Atlanta exposition to stimulate interest in the city's black business enterprises, which have been particularly hard hit by the currant recession.

title: Larger Cities See Little Effect On Them From Byrne Cutback
description: The Mayors of most of New Jersey's larger cities indicated yesterday that the state's cutback of $66million in unappropriated money as a means of shaving its own projected $100million budget deficit this year would have only marginal impact on the financially pressed cities.

title: Constitutional Bite
description: The Bill of Rights got a boost in the United States District Court in Washington this week when a jury returned a $12million verdict in favor of approximately 1,200 persons arrested during a May Day peace demonstration in Washington in 1971. The size of the verdict is less significant than the fact that the jury took violations of plaintiffs First and Eighth Amendment rights seriously and that it awarded damages on claims based directly on violations of the Constitution.

title: FILES DESCRIBE AID GIVEN TO BERGMAR
description: Detail How Aides of Wilson and Rockefeller Helped on Staten Island Venture

title: Japan's Foreign Minister Leaves Moscow After Talks
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (AP)Japan's Foreign Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, ended his meetings with Soviet leaders today, and there were no indications of progress on key issues blocking a SovietJapanese peace treaty.

title: New Hampshire TossUp
description: It is a quaint American custom to have active partisans the people most directly interested in influencing the outcomecount the ballots. When an election is closely fought, as was the New Hampshire Senatorial contest last November, this procedure can produce bizarre conseauences.

title: Texaco Abandoning OilSands Project
description: TORONTO, Jan. 17 (UP1)Texaco Canada, Ltd., a subsidiary of Texaco, Inc., announced toddy it would not take part in a massive oilsands development project in northern Alberta, further endangering efforts to save the scheme.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Times Fills Ad Post
description: Ron Moss has been named resort and travel advertising manager of The New York Times. Previously he was man ager of special advertising projects.

title: ARMY SAYS DRUG USE DECLINES IN EUROPE
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany Jan. 17 (UP1)United States Army headquarters here said today that harddrug abuse by soldiers in Europe had been falling over the last two years as a result of expanding control measures.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Sheeran Presses for Malpractice Law

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TONES Two distinct colorful samplings of the European musical heritage will hold sway over the weekend. At the Brooklyn

title: F.B.I. Aide Says Minority Hiring Lags
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) A twoyear minority recruitment program has added 19 black agents to. the Federa1) Bureau of Investigation, but blacks still account for little more than 1 per cent of the total force of 8,500 agents.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly listed the percentage decline in the fourthquarter earnings of the OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation. The company's earnings fell 44.4 per cent from the fourth quarter of 1973.

title: Market Place
description: Probably never before have so many economic and political developments concentrated in one week with so little impact on the stock market. In the good old days of the 1960's when investors still got excited over the stock market stock prices. probably would have been buffeted this way and that but this week Wall Street merely dawdled quietly, with the knowledge that it knew all along that things were going to be this bad.

title: Canadian Oil Industry: Hazy Future
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Jan. 17 Although its profits have never been higher and its product never more avidly sought, the Canadian oil industry is depressed these days and uncertain about its future.

title: Ballet: Miss Farrell Returns in Triumph
description: Yes, she can. Nearly six years after leaving the New York City Ballet, Suzanne Farrell returned to the company on Thursday night at the New York State Theater to prove that she could still dance like Suzanne Farrell.

title: Phyllis Cerf: Doer Tiger, BridetoBe
description: I love my life, really enjoy it. Wouldu't you?. said Phyllis Cerf, bridetobe of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner; widow of Bennett Cerf, the publisher and, inher own right, actress, advertising executive, author, editor, publisher cryptogrammer, columnist, benefit thrower, partygoer and committee woman par excellente.

title: 3 Senators For Arms Pact; Kissinger Welcomes Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Three influential Senatprs asked for Congressional support today for the Vladivostok nucleararms accord with the Soviet Union and urged the Ford Adminisiration to go further and negotiate a reduction'in nuclear weapons.

title: Volume Rise Below 41% Climb in 73
description: Trading volume on the nation's commodity exchanges continued to expand last year but at a far slower rate than the feverish pace in 1973.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: DRIVE TO REFORM RULES IN CONGRESS SHIFTSTOSENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The focus of the drive to alter Congressional rules and procedures shifted today to the Senate where Democrats voted to se: lect committee chairmen in the future by secret ballot of the Democratic Caucus.

title: Bijur, Howe Gain In Court Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17Jerry Bijur, a Philadelphia amateur, moved into the semifinals of the United States open court tennis championship by beating.Torn Greevy, a New York professional, 3.8, 84, 81, today at the Racquet Club.

title: ExLawyer Convicted Of Life Insurance Plot
description: Louis R. Wolfish, a disbarred lawyer who later served as a rabbi, was convicted yesterday on charges that.he had falsified his own death certificate to collect $200,000 in life insurance.

title: The Imbalance Of Error
description: GENEVA  In the days of John Foster Dulles, the original brinksman a certain stability was granted to frightened world by implicit acceptance of that new geopolitical concept a balance of terror.

title: Forbes Is Indicted On Assault Charge
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 17 (AP)Gary Flakne, Hennepin County, attorney, made public today an indictment against a Boston Bruins hockey player, Dave Forbes charging him with aggravated assault. Forbes faces a minimum of three years in prison if convicted of the charge, stemming from an incident involving Henry Boucha of the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Dance:
description: American Ballet Theater is dancing almost indecently well this season; few people find riches an embarrassment, but those few could well be embarrassed.

title: Portuguese Split on Bill Leading To Communist Control of Labor
description: LISBON, Jan. 17The Portuguese Government, deeply split over how labor should be organized, began debate today on a bill that would in effect assure the Communist party control over the nation's trade union movement.

title: Israelis Wary on Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 17 (Reuters) Three out of four Israelis oppose any further Sinai withdrawal without a peace agreement, according to a Public Opinion Research Institute poll published today.

title: U.S. Bows in Soccer
description: ATHENS, Jan. 17 (AP)The United States national amateur soccer teams was defeated, 10, by the Greek team today in an exhibition.

title: Some Sport In the White House
description: I went to the White House for game of Economics with President Ford.

title: Islanders Bad Old Days Fading
description: It was only Jude Drouin's first game as a New York Islander, a 31 victory over Philadelphia, so it was probably too soon for the center to be speaking for the Islander organization when he said.

title: A Leader of I.R.A. Provisionals Is Arrested in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 17The Irish Government announced today that it had arrested one of the top leaders of the I.R.A. Provisionals.

title: Ford to Go on Trips to Explain Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) President Ford will make a series of speaking trips around the country in behalf of his economicenergy program perhaps starting later this month, Ron Nessen, his press secretary said today.

title: GREYSTONE SCORES CUTBACK IN FUNDS
description: MORRIS PLAINS, Jan. 17The administrator of Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital today warned that there is a human price to be paid for Governor Byrne's order Yesterday impounding more than $1.1million in state funds designated for steuctural improvements to the hospital's Marcus Curry Building.

title: No Light in the Tunnel
description: When the contract for the first stage of the city's mammoth new water tunnel was let five years ago, the timetable called for its completion by this month at total cost of $222.5 million. Instead, the job is less than halffinished and the contractors have gone on strike against the city to force it to agree to a price that could run twice as higha halfbillion dollars.

title: MARY P. GREVE
description: Mary Peirce Greve, president of the William and Mary Greve Foundation and a trustee of Research to Prevent Blindness Inc., died of leukemia yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 660 Park Avenue and in Southampton, L.I.

title: Austerity Missing in Use of City Cars
description: When the Sanitation Department announced two weeks ago that it would deprive 50 of its superintendents of their chauffeurs, it became the first municcipal agency, to tighten anything other than seat belts in the use of official automobiles.

title: Teachers Urged to Aid Abused Child
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17The situation was a familiarone to teachers atschool and daycare centers: a 3yearold. boy is listless and unresponsive. He talks little often trips or bumps against things. Sometimes he arrives with bruises on his arms and legs. Efforts by the teacher to reach the mother are rebuffed repeatedly. What should the teacher do?

title: Bus Tour Promotes. City Bonds
description: The sightseeing bus wound its way through lower Manhattan and along East Side strgets yesterday, and the two dozen men and women aboard squinted through the windows into the sunlight as the guide pointed out various buildings. But instead of the oohs and aahs frequently heard on a bus tour of Manhattan, the talk on this ride was of construction capitalization, tax equivalency payments and debt rollovers.

title: ,LaidOff City Employe Sets Self Afire
description: A 33yearold city employe who was said to have been distressed over dismissal from his job, doused his clothing with gasoline last night and set himself afire outside a freight office near John F. Kennedy International Airports the police said.

title: PEKING PREPARES NEW CONSTITUTION
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 17The Central. Committee of the Chinese Communist paity announced tonight that it had approved a new slate of Government ministers and a new state constitution at a plenary meeting held last week.

title: Ribicoff Is Optimistic On Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP1)  Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, proposed again today legislation to give consumers a strong voice before courts and Government agencies.

title: Books of The Times
description: The dedication and vigor with which black freemen in the North strove for both their own liberation and that of blacks held in bondage in the South before the Civil War has only recently been receiving the serious attention it has long merited. Northern blacks struaeled under seTHEY WHO WOULD BE FREE: Blacks Search for Freedom, 183061. By Jane H. Pease and William H. Pease. 331 pages. Atheneum. $10.

title: OIL UNION IN ACCORD ON 2 NEW CONTRACTS
description: DENVER, Jan. 17 (UP1)The refiners union reached agrreement today on new contracts providing 28.6 per cent pay increases for Tenneco and British Petroleum workers and extended talks past a strike deadline with five other major petroleum companies.

title: Gierek Visits Portugal
description: LISBON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) Edward Gierek, the Polish Communist leader, paid a fly ing visit to Portugal todaythe first hv the head of a rnlino

title: BRITISH SEEN READY TO CANCEL TUNNEL
description: LONDON, Jan. 17Press re ports tonight said that the British Government had decided to abandon plans for a tunnel under the English Channel, a project shared with the French Government.

title: PROFIT MARK SET FOR CATERPILLAR
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter, but a decline in 1974 profits despite the $4billion sales mark reached for the first time in its history.

title: DRIVE TOREFORM RULES IN CONGRESS SHIFTSTOSENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The focus of the drive to alter Congressional rules and procedures shifted today to the Senate where Democrats voted to select committee chairmen in the future by secret ballot of the Democratic Caucus.

title: Bonn Confident of Its Detente With East
description: BONN, Jan. 17The cancellation of. the SovietAmerican trade agreement caused some alarm this week in West Germany, but officials voiced confidence that the Bonn Government's relations with Moscow would remain on a solid basis.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Health Center Puts U.S. Flu Outbreaks At Epidemic Stage
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 17 (UP1) The National Center for Disease Control reported today that influenza had spread throughout most of the United States.

title: Nets Regain Top Spot; Kings Trounce Knicks
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 17Eyeryone agreed that: the Knicks missee the injured Phil Jackson tonight when the Kansas CityOmaha Kings rolled to a 10790 victory by leading all the ways.

title: A NEW U.S. COURT BACKED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Creation of a national court of appeals to increase the capacity of the Federal court system to resolve important disputes was endorsed today by a Government commission of judges [lawyers and members of Congress.

title: SKITCH HENDERSON GIVEN SIX MONTHS
description: Skitch Henderson was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and fined $10,000 for filing false incometax returns that reported be had donated a $350,000 music library to a university in 1969.

title: New Clash Reported
description: TEL AVIV, Saturday, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Three Arab guerrillas were killed and two Israeli soldiers wounded in a clash on the Lebanese border today, an Israeli military spokesman said.

title: ISRAELI BELIEVES SADAT IS NOW SET FOR SINAI TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Foreign Minister Yigal Alton of Israel said today that after three days of talks with American leaders he had a notion that President Anwar elSadat of Egyp, was now ready to negotiate a new Sinai withdrawal agreement with Israel.

title: High Jump Mark Falls
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Jan. 17 (UP1)  Dwight Stones jumped 7 feet 5 inches tonight to better a world indoor highjump mark in the Meet of Champions.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday. Jan. 17, 1975

title: Corn, Soybeans and Silver Down Limit
description: Amid talk of collapsing grain prices and what analysts called panic selling in the cattle and hog markets, prices for most commodity futures showed sharp declines yesterday, including gold and silver.

title: Decay and Vandalism Besieging Belvedere Castle in Central Park
description: Decay and Vandalism Besieging Belvedere Castle in Central Park

title: Faisal Grants Damascus $150Million
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 17 (Reuters)King Faisal of. Saudi Arabia ended a fourday visit here today with an announcement of an immediate grant of $150million to Syria to meet some pressing needs.

title: Counteroffensive Launched By 2.000Man Saigon Force
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (AP)A 2,000man South Vietnamese force spearheaded by more than 50 armored vehicles was reported to have launched a counteroffensive along the Cambodian border today.

title: Israeli and Lebanese Artillery In Border Dueling for 7th Day
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17Artillery exchanges were reported along Lebanon's southern border today from early morning to nightfall as Israeli guns shelled villages where guerrillas have been active.

title: Tentative Pact Reached Between Pilots and United
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP1) A tentative agreement was reached early today between negotiators for the 5,000members Air Lines Pilot Association and the nation's largest air carrier, United Airlines, an official of the association said.

title: Park Service Seeks End to Protection Of the Western Sector of Fire Island
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The National Park Service has proposal that the western end of Fire Island, where many people have summer homes, lose its Federal protection against commercial development.

title: Terry Gibbs, Vibraharpist On Stand at Michael's Pub
description: Terry Gibbs, the busybusy Ivibraharpist of the Woody Herman Band in the late nineteenforties and with various groups of his own since then, is making his first New York appearance in 10 years at Michael's Pub, still as busybusy as, ever and spreading an aura of Las Vegas hip.

title: Main Iranian Party Seeks to Put Public in Touch With Leadership
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 15Some were provincial elders in white turbans. Some were jet; setters in Parismade business suits. And some were dowagers whose Turkoman origin showed in their almond eyes.

title: People and Business
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian businessman who is seeking to buy a controlling interest in the First National Bank of San Jose Calif blames individual fanatics for mounting campaign to block the purchase. Reached in Paris by the Associated Press, Mr. Khashoggi said yesterday he viewed the purchase attempt as a test case for the investment of Arab capital in United States banking property and nondefense defense industries.

title: EXAIDE TO NIXON PUT ON PROBATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP1) Jack A. Gleason, a former White House aide, was placed on unsupervised probation for one month today for his part in a $2.8million fundraising campaign by associates of Richand M. Nixon in 1970.

title: Laos Bars Meetings
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos today banned public meetings and demonstrations in this capital city, the Covernment news agency reported. It said the Premier or tiered the ban to forestall political troubles and allow the coalition Government to implement the peace agreement signed last year.

title: 55YEAR BAN ENDS ON MEAT PACKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan., 17 (Reuters)  Capacity use in manufacturing industries declined to 75.9 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974 from 79.4 per cent in the previous threemonth period, the Federal

title: Industrial Capacity Use Shows Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The number of new housing units started last month dropped to the lowest level in eight years, closing out a year in which activity in the industry plunged 35 per cent, the Government reported today.

title: Uniroyal Tire Plans to Furlough 1,142
description: The Xerox Corporation headed a long list of companies yesterday that announced layoffs of employes. The manufacturer of copiers said it would lay off about 1.200 workers.

title: Business Briefs
description: The United States Railway Association approved yesterday $144.1thillion in Governmentguaranteed loabs for the Penn Central Railroad and $2.5million for the Central Railroad of New Jersey. These loans, including one of $3.4million provided previously for the Lehigh Valley Railroad amounting to $150million, are being made available under Section 215 of the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973.

title: NEW YORK LIFESTYLE
description: Good times. Bad times. That's the story of Gloria Jean Betker's lifeor at least of her bank account. She's one of the hundreds of pedple in New York who are in the fashion business for themselves.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Jan. 17, 1975.

title: City's Infant Mortality Rate Reached a Low Point in 74
description: New York City experienced during 1974 the lowest infant mortality rate ever recorded here, the Health Department Said yesterday.

title: Fuel Price Up, Bills Unpaid, Heat Cut Off
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 14Last weekend, when temperatures here dropped below zero, Christine Robinson was forced out of her small flat by the cold and spent the night with friends.

title: Managua Opposition Editor Called Before Military Court
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 17 (UP1)Pedro J. Chamorro editor of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, has been ordered to go before a military court on charges of having signed a document demanding an immediate end to martial law, the Government announced today.

title: GEORGE F. BROWN
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP1)George F. Brown, senior editor of Jet magazine, died yesterday; apparently of natural causes, while working at the magazine's offices here. He was 58 years old.

title: Rockefeller Is Praised For Stint of Four Days
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)Vice President Rockefeller was congratulated today by the Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, for presiding over the Senate for four consecutive days. Al. though the ConstitutiOn says the Vice President is president of the Senate, most Vice Presidents are rarely present. Mr. Rockefeller's string of presiding days is the highest for a Vice President in at least seven years, Senate officials said. Hubert H. Humphrey presided three times in a row in 1967.

title: U.S. AGENCY CUTS FOOD STAMP AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP1) Rejecting protests from antipoverty groups and many members of Congress, the Agriculture Department announced, today its final approval of a plan to cut food stamp benefits for the needy by about $645mi1lion a year.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: No Title

title: The Bargain With Detroit
description: President Ford's proposal for lowering automobile emission standards set under the Clean Air Act offers the car manufacturers a big quid for an insignificant quo. Detroit would get a fiveyear freeze of standards fixed at a somewhat tougher level than that required for 1975 model cars but less demanding than those prescribed for 1977. In return, the auto industry would voluntarily undertake to increase average gasoline mileage 40 per cent by the year 1980that is, from 15.9 miles gallon to 19.6 miles.

title: C.A.B. Approves a Cut In Some Fares of 2025%
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board approved the first significant reduction in domestic air fares in more than two years yesterdaya new excursion plan reducing ticket prices on many routes by 20 to 25 per cent on Feb. 1.

title: A New Bonn Program Offers Nazis Victims $240Millions
description: BONN, Jan. 17 (AP)  Impoverished Jews and foreign victims of Nazi persecution would receive paymepts totaling $240million under a proposed restitution plan, the West. German Government announced today.

title: 3 Firemen on T ruck After a Fire Shot By Occupant of Car
description: An occupant of an automobile fired at a moving fire engine in. the Bronx last night possibly with a shotgun, and wounded three firemen.

title: Marcos Drops Assembly Issue From Martial Law Referendum
description: MANILA, Jan. 17President Ferdinand E. Marcos today amended the issues to be raised in the referendum Feb. 27 on his martial law Government dropping the direct question of whether the people want an interim national assembly to convene at once.

title: Faisal Grants Damascus $150Million
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 17 (Reuters)King Faisal of Saudi Arabia ended a fourday visit here today with an announcement of an immediate grant of $150million to Syria to meet some pressing needs.

title: Refusal of Visa to Rep. Diggs Is Explained by South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters)The South African Embassy today defended a refusal to grant a visa to a black member of Congress, accusing him of intervention in South Africa's internal affairs on two previous visits.

title: Bridge:
description: In the last 50 years France has produced many talented bridge players, but they have seldom proved themselves to be effective at world level. Since 1960 France has captured several European titles, but its representatives have always proved disappointing when they reached for the final prize of the world title.

title: Firm Explains Flights For U.S. in Cambodia
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP)Crews flying unmarked American planes over Cambodia for the United States Air Force perform only freight chores and airdrops and they don't even carry a 45 pistol, says the man who hires them.

title: Stanford. Topples U.C.LA
description: PALO. ALTO, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP)Rich Kelly, Stanford's 7foot center, scored 22 points and had 13 rebounds tonight, leading the Cardinals to a 6460 basketball victory over previously undefeated U.C.L.A. Ed Schweitzer also scored 22 points for the winners,

title: Hundreds Phone to See If They'll Get Award
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP1)Hundreds of Americans telephoned Washington today to determine whether they were entitled to any of the $12million awarded by the United States District Court yesterday in damages to, those illegally arrested during the 1971 Mayday protests.

title: Antiques: 275 Years of Metal Designs on Display
description: There are many ways to view the historical half of Forms in Metal, d twopart exhibition covering 275 years of American silver, pewter tin, iron and brass wares on view here in two museums through March 2. The period selections are at the Finch College Museum of Art, 62 East 78th Street, and the modern works are at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53d Street.

title: RHODESIA LEADER ASKS PARLEY NOW
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 17 (Agence FrancePresse) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said in a newspaper interview published here today that a proposed constitutional conference of blacks and whites would have to be held in Rhodesia and that it should take place as soon as possible.

title: NursingHome Hearings
description: Television station WNET and radio station WNYCAM will broadcast live the Senate subcommittee hearings on abuses in the nursinghome industry beginning next Tuesday at 10 A.M. and for as long as the hearings last. WNET (Channel 13) will rebroadcast highlights from 11 P.M. to 1 A.M. each day.

title: hvestia Sees Alarm In U.S. Over Lost Pact
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (UP1)The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that American public opinion is alarmed about the trade breakdown with the Soviet Union.

title: 2 Offer to Go to Prison In Place of Soviet Jew
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (UP1)Two young Jews, one American and one British, surrendered to the Interior Ministry today in hopes of exchanging themselves for the imprisoned Dr. Mikhail Shtern.

title: Italians Finish 1, 2 In a Giant Slalom
description: ALTAUSSEE, Austria, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Arnold Senorer and Helmut Schmalzl of Italy took the first two places today in an International Ski Federation giant slalom today.

title: LAMAR M. FEARING;. LED PAPER COMPANY
description: Lamar M. Fearing, who retired in 1966 as president and vice chairman of the board of the International Paper Company, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He would have been 72 years old tomorrow.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Index Falls 11 Points As Trading Volume Drops
description: The stock market finished lower yesterday in slower trading as investors concern over the widening recession depressed prices.

title: Out, Out, Brief Everything!
description: WASHINGTONBusybodies want to throw away things. They are always cleaning up. It makes it very hard to live with them. Take The Christian Science Monitor office, for instance. At toofrequent intervalssay every five or ten yearssomebody (invariably woman) thinks that the place should be tidied up and the bookcases eased of their load.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL AS VOLUME DROPS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell yesterday as volume also declined. Prices in the overthecounter market closed mixed as volume also dropped slightly.

title: Little Silver Mother Kills Herself, Daughter in Aut'o
description: A Little Silver woman and her 9yearold daughter were found late Thursday nightvictims of murder and suicidein the garage of their home. The bodies were discovered by the woman's estranged husband, the local police said yesterday.

description: FICTION

title: Dock Company President Is Guilty of Civil Contempt
description: NEWARK, Jan. 17  John Wert, president of Interport Maintenance Company, Inc., of Newark was found guilty of a civil contempt charge today for failing to provide corporate records to the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. He was ordered to turn over the records by next Wednesday.

title: ADM BRAKLEY DIES; LED PACIFIC FLEET
description: Vice Adm. Wallace M, Beakley, retired, a former commander of the Pacific Fleet, was found dead of a. gunshot wound, apparently a suicide, at his home in Alexandria, Va., on Thursday. He would have been 72 years old on Monday. His wife, Martha, died of a heart attack late Wednesday.

title: McCarthy, Running Again, Calls Issues Unfinished Business of 68
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17No one really knows when Eugene J. McCarthy's new campaign for the Presidency began or the old one ended.

title: A NEW U.S. COURT BACKED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Creation of a national court of appeals to increase the capacity of the Federal court system to resolve important disputes was endorsed today by a Government commission of judges lawyers and members of Congress.

title: Fledglings Find DeSalvio a Jolly Sage
description: ALBANYHis father the district leader processed Louis DeSalvio through the formality of official election in a Lower East Side district that had been nothing but Democratic within the memory of man and sent him off to the Assembly 35 years ago with some sagacious advice.

title: Lawyer Says Colson Is Uncertain Whether Nixon Spoke to Burger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP1) Charles W. Colson's attorney says the former White House aide does not know whether President Nixon spoke with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger about a suit to obtain his Watergate tapes.

title: India's Hopes Are Raised by Discovery of a Third Offshore Oil Well
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 17Drillers have struck a third well in the offshore area known as the Bombay High: 115 miles northwest of Bombay.

title: Golden Seals Rally to Tie Rangers, 44
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 17 The sound that lulled the New York Kangers into their pregame nap this afternoon was that of a power lawn mower beside the swimming pool of their motel. It was hardly hocicey weather, but this is California, and the hardy visitors made the best of it as they faced the California Golden Seals in Oaklazd Arena in quest of their 10th victory in 11 games.

title: U.S. Confirms Sale to Lebanon Of Modern Antitank Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The United States is supplying Lebanon with a small number of new TOW antitank missiles under an agreement entered into last May, Defense Department officials said today.

title: BYRNE CONSIDERS CUTS IN MEDICAID
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Governor Byrne, pressed by what is regarded as the worst financial crisis in New Jersey's history today ordered the State Treas. urer to investigate means of reducing costs in the state's $200million Medicaid appropriation.

title: 260 Rookie Policemen Get the News: No Job
description: Deputy Inspector John Lowe a veteran of 26 years on the police force, stood before a group of rookies yesterday, his face tense, his voice breaking as he delivered the bad news.

title: Gold Falls Sharply After I.M.F. Accord On Official Price
description: LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP)Gold prices dropped fairly sharply in Europe today following the consensus among monetary officials meeting in Washington this week to eventually abolish the official gold price.

title: India Dock Strike in 2d Day
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 17 (Reuters)The army and navy were standing by to man India's ports today as all shipping operations were halted on the second day of a dock workers strike.

title: Oil Lands Aid Poor Ones; $5Billion Allotted in 74

title: Music: Boulez Leads Belated Premiere
description: There wore peculiarities to be found at every turn in Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert. Pierre Boulez, who conducted, began by offering Gluck's Overture to Iphigenie en Aulide in a concert version made by Wagner, who peeled up the orchestration and added an ending of his own. The strange thing here was that Mr. Boulez, whom one might imagine to be a bluenose in such textual matters, seemed to be sanctioning the idea that the composer does not always know best.

title: A Novel Suggestion for TV
description: As everyone knows who watches talk shows on national television, there are three living American novelists. One has a high voice, one is very urbane and lives in Rome except when he comes here every 18 months or so to promote his latest novel, and the other wears a threepiece suit and is angry at everyone, especially the other two living American novelists.

title: The Real Reverse Of Racism
Shenandoah Finds Beauty In Old Truths
description: Why am I so deeply moved by Shenandoah, a musical that strikes me as singularly beautiful in its spareness? Surely each of its Civil War folk gestures is a gesture we have seen made before, fifty or a hundred times to boot. A Virginia family finds itself torn between fighting and not fighting. A rugged planter, proud tender of 500 acres, stands firm in his conviction that God didn't create war. Two boys, one black, one white, share a fishinghole, share a song about the mysterious color of their skins. A father must surrender his only daughter when courting time comes. A wedding is interrupted by a drumroll to arms. A little boy lost is found again. Clichs, the lot of them. But clichs are not born. They are made. No familiar situation, no swiftly recognizable speech pattern, was oldhat to begin with. It was onceon some odd day, out of some sudden impulsea fresh, blunt perception of the way things were, a seeing that might later be sewn into a farmhouse sampler or duplicated by lithograph until it took on folkicon and then cheap commercial status but that was just now simple, direct, revealing.

title: How to Improve Wife's Golfing:

title: Rangers Win, 32, In Last 35 Seconds
CHARTER CHANGES CONSIDERED HERE
Gazing Into the abyss
description: E. M. Cioran fled Rasinari, Rumania, to settle in Paris. France, in 1937. He was then in his twenties, just out of the university, and exilethe necessary condition of sympathy for a prophetseems to have been his first and final calling. Alone and unfettered, he dwells in a desert of his own making: in this barren place of reflection his nerves are entirely at peace.

title: Betrayed
description: It is 1862, and the U.S. Government appears too preoccupied with the War Between the States to react decisively to a secondary challenge by disaffected Indians. The time is ripe for a belated uprising against the white settlers of Dakota Territory in retaliation for the Government's ruinous manipulation of the terms of the 1851 Traverse des Sioux Treaty. Betrayed has its genesis in an obscure historical episode of that uprising.

title: Succulents for the Cactus Garden

The tubular flowers droop from long stems in shades of red, white, yellow, pink, and orange. Sometimes the stems are as colorful as the foliage.

He is also, as he has been for decades, one of our foremost artist  intellectuals, a kind or American philosophe articulate and active in many fields. With a distinct personal style of passion and gravity, he has built a career as painter, thinker and scholar that by now is rather awesome in its authority.

title: Recession Deepens
description: Progress against inflation, however, has been achieved at a high cost to the nation's output, income and employment Data released this week show that industrial production, which had stagnated during most of 1974, plunged by 2.5 per cent in November and by a further 2.8 per cent in December. The overall output of goods and servicesso called real G.N.P.fell at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 9.1 per cent in the final quarter of 1974. The unemployment rate jumped from 5.5 Per cent in the third quarter to 6.5 per cent in the fourth, and now threatens to average 7.5 per cent in the first quarter of 1975with worse to come.

title: Masters & Johnson pop
description: It is difficult to understand why Masters and Johnson have gone public. Their laboratory and clinical studies were among the most innovative and sound researches ever done in the mineladen field of human sexuality. As a result of their findings, entire canons of medical and psychological dogma have begun to be rewritten. Their books, Human Sexual Response and Human Sexual Inadequacy, albeit scholarly and dense, show signs of becoming two of the lasting books, two of the books that change both thinking and behavior for all time to come. Whether or not the authors are popularly read seems somehow well beside the point.

title: Saying It With Sand An Ancient Art Reborn
description: The American Indian art of sandpaintingcreating scenes and figures with colored sandsappears to be enjoying a revival, with miniature painted deserts materializing in living rooms across the United States. The growth in popularity of this art is easy to understand: a transparent container with a sandpainting on the inside can be attractive by itself, or as a base for a fern or cactus garden; the materials are inexpensive and widely available; and anyone can learn to sandpaint at home in a short time.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A suit filed in State Supreme Court by two board members of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals charged the society and its directors with financial mismanagement and neglect. Citing a $1,980,000 loss in capital investments, wasteful expenditures by the general director and unsatisfactory conditions in the society's animal shelters, Gretchen Wyler and Linda L. Meyer called for the removal of the society's 20 officers and managers and an audit of its finances.

title: The British Poetries
description: British poetry today is, sometimes amusingly, threatening to get out of hand. The spasms that have convulsed Western art in the wake of modern history are affecting British poetry too. A postBlack Mountain school now exists, represented most recently in the books put out by Stuart Montgomery's Fulcrum Press and in the avantgarde magazine Poetry Review, edited by Eric Mottrarm. A list of germinative names sent me in 1972 by Mottram suggests the Americanoriented, postmodernist nature of his interests: Cage, Cunningham, Olson, Duncan, Zukofsky, Ginsberg, Jones (Berate), a number of black poets, Ashbery, Elliott Carter, M. C. Richards, Fuller, the Gestalt therapists, Brakhage, McClure, Pynchon, Burroughs, Mailer, Goodman, Halprin, Chomsky, and so on. Of course, the new movements are not merely derivative. For instance, though Montgomery and Mottram have encouraged the young poet Tom Pickard, it is in part because he brings Northumbrian workingclass attitudes and speech into his poetry so freshly and originally. And a poet like Jeff Nuttall thrives in the new atmosphere because of his wild imagination and satirical joy and hectic realism. At the same time, among England's most accomplished poets, certain individual voices such as Peter Redgrove's and Ted Hughes's can be heard to have a vigor beyond that of the prevailing tone of quietly controlled feeling still dominating English verse.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18  Secretary General Waldheim has confirmed that his decision last week to allow the Vietcong to open an office in Geneva was made over the objections of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: If You Go
description: to Davos in the second half of March or in April, you'll find that hotel prices are down from highseason rates and that many packages, including hotels, meals, lift tickets and lessons, are from 20 to 30 per cent cheaper. Remember, though, that the Easter weekend (at the end of March this year) is a busy time, and reduced rates won't apply then. Like the mountains themselves, the accommodations offer a wide choice. They range from firstclass hotels, with three full meals in the highest Swiss tradition, for $50$60 a day to pensions where a room and petit djeuner (bathrooms are shared) Cost about $8 a day. There are 126 hotels, inns and pensions in Davos with prices varying between these figures. Skiers who plan really early can snatch a furnished apartment, which offers the most economical arrangement. The rents range from $15$20 a night for a one or twobedroom place to $30$40 for three or four bedrooms. Locations and facilities vary, and you have to do your own cooking and cleaning, but the savings are good. But apartments are difficult to get, especially at this late stage. You may be lucky and find a cancellation if you write to the Davos Tourist Office, Promenade 67, 7270, Davos Platz, Switzerland. The office circulates lists of apartment seekers, and the owners write directly to applicants. For further information on Davos skiing, write to the Swiss National Tourist Office, 608 Fifth Avenue, New York 10020 (tel: 212 7575944) or Swissair, 608 Fifth Avenue, New York 10020 (2129958400)R.W.

title: R. V. Guglielmi Weds Linda Doeringer
description: Linda Louise Doeringer and Ralph V. Guglielmi were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N.J., by the Rev. Dr. Charles Mead.

title: Will Washington Help Keep Lights On?
description: DETROIT  Last week Consumers Power Company chairman A. H. (Al) Aymond shocked longtime observers of his company by calling for direct Federal aid to Consumers and to other stockholderowned utilities.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Frann Stein and Tullah Kellman haven't had any inventory problems since they opened the Hired Hand at Lexington Avenue and 90th Street last spring. Now they have even less.

title: Confronting Three Economic Crises
Dave Anderson
description: In the confusion over Joe Namath's futures the quarterback of the New York Jets, the thrust of the negotiations has been obscured. Joe Namath really wants to be a club owner.

title: The Secret Committee Called 40
description: WASHINGTONWhen It was disclosed last September that the Central Intelligence Agency had spent $8million to destabilize the Government Chile under Salvador Allende, President Ford confirmed at a press conference that the United States does take certain actions in the intelligence field. Mr. Ford added: The 40 Committee reviews every covert operation undertaken by our Government.

title: GREEK CYPRIOTES BURN ONE WING OF U.S. EMBASSY
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 18 About 5,000 Greek Cypriote youths ransacked British offices here and burned a wing of the United States Embassy today in protest against London's decision to allow 10,000 Turkish Cypriote refugees to leave a British military base for Turkey.

title: WORLD OF RETAILING
description: The success of the commemoration of the nation's first two centuries will be judged on the number of players, not the number of spectators.American Revolution Bicentennial Administration.

title: Henry James Letters
description: The story of Henry James's early years has been told many times, most brilliantly by James himself and by Leon Edel. In James's own version, the stirrings of youth are seen through the magisterial elaborations of old age. His two volumes, A Small Boy and Others and Notes of a Son and Brother, are classics of American autobiography: autumnal, exquisitely arranged, rich with memories warmed by passion and imagination. Leon Edel's account has different virtues: intimate, affectionate, jammed with detail, it is also a detached, critical biography valuable both as a portrait and as an argument. Now, almost as if to remind us that the house of biography has many windows, comes James himself, speaking in the eager voice of adolescence and early manhood, not knowing how the great story is going to come out, but fresh with the sense of what life has so splendidly to offer him.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Joan Wiggins, R. W. Hooker Jr. Have Nuptials
description: Joan Folinsbee Wiggins was married in New Hope, Pa., yesterday to Roger W. Hooker Jr., Vice President Rockefeller's assistant for Congressional affairs. The ceremony was performed in St. Philip's Episcopal Chapel by the Rev. John A. Smart. He was assisted by the Rev. Lawrence J. Seyler.

title: Leagues Add Security Patrol To Avert Renewal of Fixes
description: From the Black Sox scandal to the Super Bowl, the most worrisome phantom hovering over sports gambling is the norisk result called the fix. And as the pressure of betting has grown in recent years, so has the patrol organized by the major sports to prevent cheating.

title: In This Issue
description: Dan Wakefield is the author of Going All the Way and Starting Over.

title: Red Smith
description: Luis Tiant, the best pitcher on the Boston Red Sox team, visited the office of his attorney, Robert Woolf, this weekend to say he had sent back his 1975 contract unsigned and to ask Woolf's advice.

Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Susanne Low Married To Eliot Clarke on L.I.
description: Susanne Murray Low, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hine Low of Meadow Farm in East Islip, L.I., and Boca Grande, Fla., and Eliot Channing Clarke of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Russell Bechtel performed the ceremony in Emanuel Episcopal Church in Great River, L.I. A reception was held at Meadow Farm.

title: Snow Sports Ending the Winter Hibernation of National Parks
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., Jan. 16The back country wilderness is reduced to frfozen whispers in the winter. It is cold, quiet and erie. Steam geysers, streams, snow sifting through the pine boughs, and even crosscountry skis sliding over a trail make one basic sound: Shhhhh.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Review Priorities
description: MINEOLA  The fiscal crunch that is affecting most of the nation is taking different forms in Nassau and Suffolk Countless

title: Music: An Encounter
description: Since Pierre Boulez's Prospective Encounters in Greenwich Village have figured among the most stimulating music events the New York Philharnionic (or any other organization) has offered in recent years, the opening of the current season on Friday night was awaited with joyful anticipation. It is understood, of course, that the number of programs this time around had been reduced to two from four, and the Cooper Union Great Hall was to be the new location for them.

title: Wood
description: BOSTON  For centuries, Atlantic salmon journeyed southwest thousands of miles from the Northwest Atlantic probably the Davis Strait off Greenlandand each year surged up New England rivers to spawn.

title: A Breakthrough Accord on Kashmir Is Reported in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 18Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, the Kashmir Moslem leader, will reportedly take control of most of his state after a lapse of 22 years under an agreement that he and representatives of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India have worked out.

title: Miss Poor, Yount Give Recital Here As the Beloit Duo
description: Mary Louise Nigro Poor, a flutist, and Max Yount, a harpsichordist, have appeared separately in recitals here. Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, however, was their first formal appearance together under the name of the Beloit College Concert Duo. Beloit College in Wistonsin is where they both teach.

title: 27 on Train in Egypt Die
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18 (UPI) A speeding train, so overcrowded that some passengers rode on the locomotive, was derailed north of Cairo today, killing 27 persons and injuring 52 others, the police said.

title: STAMPS
description: Minkus II

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: Martha W. Griffiths, a specialist in public welfare programs, has just retired from politics following 20 years as Representative of Michigan's 17th District. A Democrat, Mrs. Griffiths headed the Joint Economic Committee's subcommittee on fiscal policy, which undertook a threeyear study of the welfare system. The Times asked her what advice she would give her successors in the House.

title: The Booming Market for Used Machines
description: The combination of inflation and recession has doubled sales of used tools and machinery over the last two years. And the bull market in five to 10yearold industrial equipment promises to keep auctioneer's portable podiums rolling ever faster through plants across the nation this year as liquidations, cutbacks and bankruptcies loom in a score of industries.

title: What has posterity ever done for me?
description: Will mankind survive? Who knows? The question I want to put is more searching: Who cares? It is clear that most of us today do not careor at least do not care enough. How many of us would be willing to give up some minor conveniencesay, the use of aerosolsin the hope that this might extend the life of man on earth by a hundred years? Suppose we also knew with a high degree of certainty that humankind could not survive a thousand years unless we gave up our wasteful diet of meat, abandoned all pleasure driving, cut hack on every use of energy that was not essential to the maintenance of a bare minimum. Would we care enough for posterity to pay the price of its survival?

title: Center Is Opened By Cerebral Palsy
description: A $4million rehabilitation center of United Cerebral Palsy of Queens, which will provide vocational training for more than 600 people, was dedicated last week.

title: DETENTE STILL ON, MOSCOW ASSERTS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18The Soviet Government asserted today that the collapse of the trade agreement had damaged SovietAmerican relations, but added that Moscow is still interested in improved relations in all spheres between this country and the United States.

title: AROUND THE Garden
BEEF SUPPLY IN 75 CALLED PLENTIFUL
Appeals Court Lets in Attica Trial Get Extra Challenges
description: The State Court of Appeals has granted defense lawyers additional challenges of prospective jurors in the trial of two former inmates accused of murdering a prison guard in the Attica prison uprising of September, 1971.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Shortly after emerging from a swimming pool at the home of their stepaunt in Dix Hills, L.I., last Fourth of July, 7yearold Angelina Logue and her sister, Debora, 4, complained of a tired feeling. Not long after that both went into a coma. Angelina died that evening. Debora lingered for nearly nine days before succumbing. The cause of their deaths remains unknown.

title: Court Is Expected to Limit Local Zoning Power
description: TRENTONA decision that could limit homerule zoning powers is expected to be handed down soon by the State Supreme Court, perhaps before the end of the month.

title: Newsletter Tips
description: Tenants interested in starting newsletters can look to several sources for guidance.

title: The Poor Mouth
description: The recurring case of Flann O'Brien alias Brian Nolan, a civil servant, alias Myles na Gopaleen, a newspaper columnist, seems to end up with the same verdictquite possibly a major comic writer. But a forgettable one, apparently, who has to be rediscovered every, time a book of his swims into our ken. He died in 1966 at 55, not as a writer at the height of his powers, but as a somewhat comic Dublin character himself, fond of the jar and patronized by his inferiors. This present hilarious book was written in Gaelic in 1941 for an Irish audience about a local situation. You read with a hypothetical American kibitzing over your shoulder and he seems to laugh at the wrong places. The reasons are cultural and amplify a chronic minor ache of Irish lit.how American (and English) readers misinterpret the writing of a small rural country in ways that suppress its truest voice, its rootedness in a culture as alien as Aztec or Senufo, to which the Irish language gives immediate access.

title: The Region
description: The condition of the national economy continues to force difficult budgetary decisions on government officials at all levels in the metropolitan region. These were the major developments last week:

title: 400 at Meeting Are Angered Over a Predicted Sharp Rise in School Taxes
description: MERRICKMore than 400 residents, concerned over the prospect of a sharp increase in school taxes, jammed the Chatterton School here last Thursday to hear local legislators and school board officials explain the effects of a state aid package that was passed by Albany more than a year ago, but will not have an impact on taxes until next July.

title: EIGHT IN FAMILY DIE IN BALTIMORE FIRE
description: BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 18 (AP)Eight members of a family were killed before dawn today when a fire swept through their threestory brick row house. The authorities said that a cigarette on a sofa had started the blaze.

title: Things happen, seem to mean something, then disappear into memory
description: During the past 15 years Maureen Howard has written three novels, each for a different publisher. I gather from that fact that there has been no sustained managerial enthusiasm for her work, or that the enthusiasm for the first two books must have disappeared after each publication when sales failed to materialize. I have not checked the reception for the first two, Not a Word About Nightingales (1960) and Bridgeport Bus (1965).

title: North Jersey Is Fighting Disparate Electric Rates
description: TRENTONDifferences in electricity rates in neighboring Bergen County towns, and even within some of the same communities, have moved public officials to press for an amalgamation of competing utility companies serving the North Jersey area.

title: The honesty of a suburban superstar
description: LONDON. Having just completed The Romantic Englishwoman, a film she agreed to do mainly because she wanted to work with director Joseph Losey, Glenda Jackson has plunged into rehearsals for her next venture in the theaterIbsen's Hedda Gabler, for which the Royal Shakespeare Company will pay her one of the highest salaries it has ever paid an actor. A brief 10 years ago, the same Miss Jackson was employee by the same organization at a salary of 12 a week in a curious experimental season called Theatre of Cruelty in which, if she was noted for anything at all, it was for the fact that she portrayed the notorious call girl Christine Keeler, and was the first serious actress since the removal of stage censorship in Great Britain to doff all her clothes for the sake of art. Between that historical burst of nudity and Hedda Gabler, quite a lot of history has been made by Miss Jackson and although, like so much history, it is easy to chronicle, it is more difficult to explain.

title: Ford's Fingers Are in the Dike, So Congress Has A Free Hand
Quake Shakes Kashmir
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 18 (AP)  An earthquake shook northern Kashmir early today, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. Scientists said the center of the quake was near Kargil.

title: In Newsletters, the Talk Is of Security and Dogs
MEXICAN LEFTISTS FEAR REPRESSION
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18The mysterious death in jail of a longtime Communist party member has led to accusations by Mexican opposition groups that the Government is preparing a wave of repression against the left.

description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 19, 1975

title: HalfRebellion
Miss McLoughlin Wed to J. J. Pierson 3d
description: Michele Jane McLoughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. McLoughlin Jr. of West Trenton, N. J., and John Ewing Pierson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierson Jr. of Hamilton Township, N. J., were married yesterday afternoon at the McLoughlin home by Mercer County Court Judge Daniel A. O'Donnell Jr.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The country's news media gave top story coverage to the drop in the price of gold when the ban on U.S. citizen ownership of gold bullion was lifted on Dec. 31. Headlines also noted the weak response of investors and speculators to the Treasury Department's Jan. 6 auction of 2,000,000 ounces of bullion. Gold prices subsequently rose slightly and then fluctuated, a pattern that most experts say will continue indefinitely.

title: EXDALTON HEAD JOINING HACKLEY
description: COLEBROOK, Conn., Jan. 17 Donald Barr, the former headmaster of the Dalton School, interrupted work on a new book today to speak of the post that he will assume next July as headmaster of the Hackley School in Tarrytown.

title: Betting Inquiry
description: Federal agents using wiretaps are investigating gambling by certain players in the National Football League, while a national debate is taking shape on the growing issue of betting in sports.

title: This Week in Sports
description: A field of 350 is expected to compete for $12,000 in prize money in the United States Darting Association's national open championships Saturday and Sunday. Competition will be in three events singles, two person and four person Play will begin at noon each day at the Marc Ballroom, 27 Union Square, with the finals at 3:30 P.M. next Sunday.

title: Sports Betting: States Act to Legalize It But U. S. Opens Inquiry
TV VIEW
description: A couple of Saturdays ago, ABC opened its entire primetime schedule, from 8 to 11 P.M., to a Royal Shakespeare Company production of Antony and Cleopatra. It was a marvelously imaginative interpretation, beautifully performed with a cast headed by Richard Johnson, Janet Suzman and Corin Redgrave. It was also a disaster in the very practical terms of audience ratings, managing to snare a measly 6 per cent of the sets in use across the country. That same evening, All in the Family had a 51 per cent share.

title: Has Grumman Pulled Out of Its Tailspin?
description: BETHPAGE, L. I.The recent resumption of commercial credit through a $200million loan from American banks and a stateowned Iranian bank appears to have pulled the Grumman Corporation out of the fiveyear financial tailspin involving its controversial developing ofthe F14 Tomcat fighter plane.

title: Public Access to Beaches Faces a Battle in Trenton
description: TRENTONThe highly controversial question involving public access to New Jersey's ocean beaches promises to become a major issue in the new legislative session that convened last week.

description: Alice Shirley Elizabeth Ann Chase, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Harry E. Chase of Tenafly, N. J., was married last night in the Presbyterian Church there to Donald Wayne Howes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Roebuck Howes of Chatham, Mass. Mr. Chase, senior pastor of the church escorted his daughter and performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John Adam Fischer.

title: 3 Rescued From Cruiser
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 18 (AP) Three Florida residents were rescued from their cabin cruiser, which began taking water in high seas west of here, the Coast Guard said today. A spokesman said Howard Lawson of Mantama, Fla., his wife and an unidentified crewman were rescued.

title: Sense of Unity Marks State's New Congressional Delegation
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Congressional delegation has seldom distinguished Itself as a major power to be reckoned with, despite the fact that it constitutes the eighth largest voting bloc in Congress.

title: Bicentennial Chief Warmed in North Dakota
