description: The engagement of Rene Cosmy Hulitar to Barry Nisbit Rowe has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hulitar of Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Rowe of Sag Harbor, L. I., aid Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: What Every Coop Buyer Should Know
description: Does the cooperative have working capital, and if so how much? More than 90 per cent of the coop apartments on the market in the city today are resales. The number of new units for sale will continue to decrease, even after construction picks up, because of the time required to complete new buildings.

title: BREZHNEV REPORT STIRS SKEPTICISM
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18Usually knowledgeable Western and Asian diplomats said today that they had no evidence to confirm a news report from New Delhi that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, had relinquished his duties because of ill health.

title: ART VIEW
description: For those of us who found the celebrated Civilization series an unendurable Niagara of solemn clichs and simpleminded fictionswere we, I wonder, as much of a minority as we seemed, at the time?the prospect of another 15 weeks of Kenneth Clark on public television is not something that fills the heart with joy. Yet here we, are, like it or not, with another of Lord Clark's cultural spectacularsthis one called The Romantic Rebellionalready in progress. An hourlong Introductory Special initiated the new series on WNET last Monday evening; and beginning tomorrow evening, with a 30minute program devoted to the career of the French painter of the Revolutionary period, JacquesLouis David, The Romantic Rebellion will be shown at weekly intervals (except for Feb. 24) through April 28, and will no doubt be repeated many times in many places long thereafter.

title: Winter Is Quiet at the Animal Parks
description: WEST MILFORDAfrican animals, which attracted more than 3.5 million visitors to New Jersey's two drivethrough zoological parks last year, are wintering just like domestic farm stock  in heated barns.

title: City Removes 79 Cars In an Austerity Measure
description: Mayor Beame ordered the removal and eventual sale of 79 official city automobiles yesterday as a way of cutting costs and countering criticism that too many commissioners and deputy commissioners have cars and chaufeurs.

title: CHINESE REBUILD SILTRUINED DAM
HAROLD K. SUMMERS, LABOR LAW JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Harold K. Summers, administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board, died yesterday of a malignant brain tumor. His age was 62.

title: The Logical Direction at Justice Department Is Up
description: WASHINGTONThe news release from the White House was understated. It began, The President today announced his intention to nominate Edward H. Levi of Chicago, Ill, to be Attorney General.

title: Why Did Mr. Kissinger Say That?
Leonia: The Horror of a Brutal Murder Still Lingers
description: LEONIAMore lights are burning at night in the big houses on Park Avenue and Nordhoff Drive and in the smaller ones on Palmer Place and High Street. The dogwalkers who made Glenwood Avenue a busy midnight promenade are fewer and a bit more hurried.

title: Builders Are Calm Over Slow Growth
description: Builders and developers in the metropolitan area are reacting with equanimity to a recent report that the region's population has, for the first time in 300 years, stopped growing.

title: Disputes Bring New Navy Inquiry on Pueblo
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 18After six years of increasingly bitter controversy growing, out of North Korea's capture of the American spy ship Pueblo, the Navy is preparing to open a new inquiry into the behavior of the vessel's crew during nearly a year of captivity.

title: Dock Strikers in India Agree To New Talks on Pay Rises
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 18 (Reuters)India's striking dock workers agreed to new talks tonight as the Government called in the navy and the national guard to unload essential supplies at paralyzed ports.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1 No Title

title: Unhistorical novel
description: No epicsung, printed or filmedequals the sweeping turbulence of the 1,000year history of the Empire: its legendary beginnings in the rivalry between Onessa and The City; renewal of its dynasty by Arsaphes the barbarian and proud Heloise, last of the effete Porphyries; Emperor Basil's treacherous massacre of the powerful priests; the tumultuous reign of Emperor, then Blessed, finally Saint, Alexis (the only nonChristian ever canonized by the Catholic Church); his bloodless defeat of Balamir and the barbarian hordes; extension of the Empire to Ireland and Korea; and finally, with the Pax Imperil, Alexis's voluntary abdication. This has to be one of the most engrossing histories ever writtenyet not a word of it is true.

title: Rutgers Five Is Defeated By Lafayette
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 18Rutgers became another of the top 20 basketball teams to suffer the shock of an upset when a surpfising Lafayette team beat the Scarlet Knights, 7266. tonight.

title: State's Welfare Rolls Rise
description: TRENTONThe number of New Jersey residents receiving welfare, oldage and disability payments has risen substantially since last summer, and they now total more than 530.000.

title: Correction
description: The seventhranking title on the mass market paperback best seller list printed in last week's Book Review was misidentified. The entry should have described it as the 1974 edition of the Guinness Book of World Records, by Norris and Ross McWhirter (Bantam, $1.75).

title: Kenya Cholera Toll Rises
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Three more cholera victims have died in Kisumu in western Kenya, raising the cholera death toll in hospitals to 41, according to local health authorities. Earlier this week a Ministry of Health official said 133 persons had died in their homes, presumably of cholera.

title: Bistate College Hockey
description: Northern Division

title: R. L. Schweitzer to Wed Miss McKinney
description: Dr. and Mrs. George W. McKinney Jr. of Glen Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Christine McKinney, to Robert Lee Schweitzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Schweitzer of Baltimore. They plan to marry March 8 in the Sarah P. Duke Garden at Duke University.

title: New &Novel
description: For Love Or Money is hinged on the idea of death, but it is in reality full of lifethe salty, funny, sometimes nasty tumult of the old Broadway crowd. It is also a lightfingered commentary on the ties that bind parents and offspring. All of this wit and wisdom is wrapped up in a richly funny parable that moves swiftly from heaven (which is run like Tammany Hall) to Bankers.

title: Students Feel Shortage of Veterinary Schools in United States
description: Stressing there really was only one medicine, Dr. Edward C. Melby Jr., new dean of New York State Veterinary College at Cornell, said it was important to build the interrelationship between the medical professions. Speaking before the Veterinary Medical Association of New York City last week, Melby said, With animals or humans, we are dealing with the same problems, except with a different species of life. We cannot solve problems of human health, without turning to animals or studying on a comparative basis.

title: PENTAGON REACHES AN OIL PRICE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) A conflict between the Pentagon and the oil industry has apparently been resolved and contracts will be signed to meet Defense Department fuel needs, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Grand Prix A la Monaco Set for '76
description: The United States, being approximately 6,287,170 times as large as Monaco, does not necessarily deserve 6,287,170 times as many Grand Prix as does Princess Grace's CastleSurMer.

title: L.I.R.R. Terminal Delayed by M.T.A.
description: The project to provide the Long Island Rail Road access to a terminal on the East Side of Manhattan is being delayed, apparently for at least six years.

title: The Nation
description: A roundrobin of Congressional inquiries into allegations of illegal domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency, and an extraordinary admission emerged with clarity from the confusion of overlapping investigations. William E. Colby, now the head of the C.I.A., said the agencyforbidden by law from purely domestic activitieshad compiled its own dossiers on 10,000 American citizens and engaged in a variety of black, or secret, actions against some of them.

title: Detroit May Be Crumbling, But Saab Isn't
description: While automobile manufacturers elsewhere in the world seem to be going from bad to worse, Sweden's Saab enterprise is planning a 3 per cent production increase for 1975. Volvo, the other (and larger) Swedish car manufacturer, is undergoing a moderate slowdown.

title: Spencer, 26, Driver, Dies In Auto Race
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 18 Auto racing had its first fatality of the year when Bill Spencer, a 26yearold driver from nearby Buena Park, died from injuries suffered today in an accident at the Permatex 200 for late model sportsman cars.

title: New Aids for Traffic Safety
description: TRENTON  New state farms designed for the computerized reporting of motorvehicle accidents, made mandatory last Wednesday, are expected by safety officials to reduce crashes, injuries and road hazards.

title: Fears of Leonia Residents Persist Despite Arrest
Now for the Last Quarter
description: WASHINGTONThese are hard days for prophets, but despite the price of gas and other nuisances, the world is moving into the last quarter of the twentieth century anyway. Whether you regard 1975 as the last year of the third quarter or the first year of the last quarter, the temptation to look to the future is irresistible, if only to get some perspective on the gloomy present.

title: Four More House Leaders Reportedly Facing Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 New Democratic members of the House of Representatives, who stirred the sudden revolt against key committee chairmen, reportedly will try to purge as many as four chairmen of important appropriations subcommittees next week.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayEmpire Miniature Pinscher Club of Greater New York specialty match, Prospect Hall, 263 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn, entries from noon; judging 1 P.M.

title: A Merger Of Alcohol, Drug Units Stirs Fight
description: TRENTON  An administrative move that merged the state's alcohol and drugabuse programs into one unit in the Health Department last week has produced an angry confrontation between the two factions.

title: Cleveland B. Chase, Writer, Management Film Maker
description: NYACK, N. Y., Jan. 18  Cleveland Bruce Chase, a writer and book reviewer in the nineteentwenties who turned to producing management films in the thirties, died last night in Nyack Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived here on Schuyler Road.

title: Courses in Nursing Reflect Changes
description: STONY BROOK Attending meetings of welfare rights organizations and accompanying the elderly down aisles of supermarkets will play significant roles in the education of 260 student nurses at the State University here as its School of Nursing implements a new, socially oriented curriculum.

title: FARM EXPANSION PLANNED IN IRAQ
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 Iraq, a country with a large potential for food production, has announced a $10billion agricultural development program over the next five years.

title: This Week's Most Wanted Composer: Carman Moore
description: Every composer probably has his Walter Mitty fantasy, which goes something like this. Just as he is putting the final touches to a piece that Seiji Ozawa asked him to write for the San Francisco Symphony, Pierre Boulez calls and offers a $10,000 commission from the New York Philharmonic. As the dream of glory expands, both scores are ready for their world premieres, just a day apart, and composer Mitty must fly the width of the continent overnight so that he may be on hand to accept the intoxicating applause of both great cities.

title: Boy's Case Reflects Problems of Alcoholism Among Indians of Canadian North
description: PICTURE BUTTE, Alberta, Jan. 11Early on a clear, cold Sunday rooming a few weeks ago a 12yearold Indian boy broke into the liquor store of this tidy little village and went on a rampage that touched nerves all across Canada.

title: Louis and Antoinette
description: The mildest monarch who ever filled the French throne, in Gouverneur Morris's indulgent epithet, Louis XVI had the misfortune not only to be deposed but also to be decapitated, a fate shared by his Austrianborn Antoinette, the Queen who did not say, Let them eat cake. The drama of their lives has had persistent fascination for 200 years almost solely because it was a symbol of the more cataclysmic bourgeoisdemocratic upheaval that we conveniently encapsulate as the French Revolution. Thus, since the royal pair and the Revolution cannot be separated. Vincent Cronin, the stylistically graceful British writer, faced inherent difficulties in his double biography; and he has surmounted them only in part by making the Revolution the backdrop against which Louis and Antoinette played out their lives.

title: Who  Will Get Clout in Congress?
Schweitzer Unit in Gabon Begins $6Million Hospital on Founder's Centennial
description: LAMBARENE, Gabon, Jan. 14 On the side of a hill overlooking the wide, jungleshrouded Ogoou River, the cornerstone was laid today for the $6million Albert Schweitzer Hospital on the 100th anniversary of Dr. Schweitzer's birth.

title: Morgan Day Hodgson, Lawyer, Wed to William Truman Lake
description: Morgan Day Hodgson, a trial lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, was married in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday afternoon to William Truman Lake, a lawyer with the Washington firm of Wilmer Cutler & Pickering.

title: Aide's Death Focuses Attention on Hefner Empire
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17The multimilliondollar Playboy empire was the subject this week of accusations and denials revolving around the apparent suicide of an aide to Hugh M. Hefner, the man who parlayed Playboy magazine into a fortune.

title: BILLY THE KID DONE BY BALLET THEATER
description: As quick as ever on the emotional trigger, Billy The Kid made its first appearance of the American Ballet Theater season Friday evening. Terry Orr was the twitchy young Billy and William Carter his relentless pursuer, Pat Garrett, along with a full cast that looks like the inhabitants of the entire West.

title: Nancy Candib Affianced to a Count
description: Nancy Candib, buyer of junior sportswear in the New York offices of King's Department Stores, Inc., and Count John Michael Forgach, assistant treasurer in the international corporate finance division of the Chase Manhattan Bank here with responsibility for the Iberian Peninsula, plan to marry May 17.

title: Laura Burnett Wed to James Kaye
description: Laura Candace Burnett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Gilbert Burnett of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and James Lloyd Kaye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lloyd Kaye of Acton, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon. Trevor Thomas, the Archdeacon of Essex, performed the ceremony at Holy Innocents Episcopal Church in West Orange.

title: Tax Advice
description: Taxpayers who seek advice from the Internal Revenue Service's 1,900 public representatives should beware: A recent ruling by the Tax Court holds that wrong information from the I.R.S. is no defense against liability for incorrectly completed tax returns.

title: Variegated Leaves To Grow in Pots
description: House plants with marks, stripes or blotches of color are perfect choices for those bored with just green foliage. Known as variegated plants, they are a refreshing change from ordinary kinds.these plants are becoming popular, some may be a bit difficult to find. Travels from greenhouse to plant store in search of elusive species can be fascinating. Here are some plants to select, a few are readily available while others are not. Happy hunting:

title: Floating Is More Work
description: When American Express cardholders received notices recently that the rate of currency conversion for their foreign purchases would double (to 1 per cent above the wholesale exchange rate) the accompanying explanation cited continued fluctuations on exchange rates.

description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 18 (AP)  An earthquake shook northern Kashmir early today, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. Scientists said the center of the quake was near Kargil.

description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18Alvaro Pineda, one of America's top jockeys, was killed today at Santa Anita when his mount reared and hurled him against the top of the starting gate before the fourth race.

description: KANSAS CITY. We all know that air travel and electronic communication have cut our planet dawn to a size where oceans are no longer dividers and continents shoulder one another. But somehow it still comes as a surprise to find a center of Asian art smackdab in the middle of Tom Benton country. There it stands in Kansas City, the NelsonAtkins Gallery of Art, only 40 years old but with oriental collections assembled from scratch that make Kansas City's River Kaw look like a tributary of the YangtzeKiang.

description: The typical unemployed person, surprising as it may seem, is not someone who has lost a job. Such individuals have been less than a majority among the unemployed in every year since 1967, when figures on reasons for unemployment first became available. Of the 6 million unemployed in December, 1974, not quite 3.2 million had a job immediately before becoming unemployed.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Former highlevel members of the CentralIntelligence Agency have said in interviews that, to their knowledge, the agency's supersecret Counterintelligence Division never made written reports on its sensitive activities to Richard Helms or other top agency officials.

description: Wilson Mizner is one of those characters, like A. J. Liebling's Colonel Stingo, whose lives seem designed to fit into one variant of The New Yorker Profilethe nostalgic but knowing return to a more rambunctious America in which high and low life joined hands to exclude the pedestrian middle.

title: Ambro Successor Sets His Priorities
description: HUNTINGTON  Kenneth C. Butterfield, who was chosen by the Town Board recently as Huntington Town Supervisor, to his and nearly everyone else's surprise, said last week that his first priorities would be the local economy and the shaping of growth in this increasingly Populous town.

description: One recent Sunday, wearied by my efforts to determine whether Dr. Dolittle's duck was named Dabbab, Dabnab or Dabrab, I fell into a doze and crashed through the paper into Crosswordland.

title: 7 Dead at Sea off Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18 (UPI)Seven seamen were killed and 12 others were reported missing following two separate ship accidents in stormy seas today, the Maritime Safety Agency said. An agency spokesman said the 945ton freighter Goyo Maru No. 21 had sunk in the Japan Sea off western Japan and the 575ton coal carrier Fuyo Maru was missing and apparently had sunk south of Hokkaido.

title: A Governor Indicted
description: David Hall has been indicted on bribery charges only three days after leaving office as Governor of Oklahoma. Gov. Hall's finances have long been the subject of investigations by United States Attorney William R. Burkett. No previous charges had been brought against him, though news of the investiga tions were thought to be instrumental in his defeat in the August Democratic gubernatorial primary. The bribery charges involve an alleged scheme to influence the Oklahoma retirement fund board to invest $10million in a private company, the Guaranteed Investors Corporation. Two of the company's officials were also named in the indictment. In return for influencing the board,, the indictment alleges, Gov. Hall was to receive $50,000. Gov. Hall has denied the charges, and repeated his contention that Mr. Burkett has been harassing him.

title: Chester Kallman, Poet, Is Dead; Writer of Librettos With Auden

description: Article 3 No Title

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Jan. 18 (UPI)Bob Latchford, Britain's most highly paid soccer star, celebrated his 24th birthday by shooting Everton back to the top of the English League's First Division. Latchford, who signed with Everton for $840,000, slammed in two goals against his former club, Birmingham, whose goalie is his brother, Dave, in a 30 victory. The match was a family affair, with Birmingham's Archie Styles, Latchford's cousin, accidentally sending the ball into his own net to complete the scoring. Everton holds a 1point lead over Ipswich Town, which lost to Carlisle Town, 21.

title: A Guide to the Language and Customs of Sports Betting
description: ACTIONThe betting. BEARDAgent who moves action (i.e., who wagers) for another person to conceal rant bettor's identity.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: NBC television devoted three hours of primetime viewing a week ago last Thursday evening to a celebration of what coanchor persons Tom Snyder and Barbara Walters described as perhaps the most important revolution since 1776  the radical change in the relations between the sexes in America. The most revolutionary aspect of the evening, however, turned out to be the willingness of a major network to exhibit three hours of slickly produced but ineptly researched propaganda for a sexual revolution that has yet to take place, and in all likelihood never will.

title: Hans Brenninkmeyer Marries Susan Sweetser, a Researcher
description: Susan Julie Sweetser, an art researcher with Reader's Digest, was married yesterday afternoon to Johannes A. P. Brenninkmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad E. Brenninkmeyer of Brasschaat, Belgium.

title: SquareRigger to Fill South Street Void
description: Shaking off me shroud or obsolesence, the fourmasted barque Peking is being readied for sea3,100 tons of steel powered by an acre of sail. The South Street Seaport Museum's most recent acquisition is expected to fill the void at Pier 16 in the East River where another tourmasted sailing ship, Moshulu, rested until late last year.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It's an awkward title, but it does capture the meaning of the book: FACE ME WHEN YOU WALK AWAY by Brian Freemantle (Putnam's, $6.95). Freemantle has set his book in the high echelons of the Soviet bureaucracy, right to the Presidium itself. On those levels, there is an eternal power struggle, with ideological and personal roots that go back to Stalin's day. So we are assured by the Kremlinologists, and so Freemantle assures us.

Both County Executives expressed concern over the tariff's impact on their autodependent counties, and the Long Island Lighting Company said that the tariff would result in an increase of 13 per cent in the monthly bills of an average homeowner.

title: India's Image

It is not surprising, therefore, that Harry Wilhelm, who has headed the Ford Foundation's extensive activities in India for the past four years, has expressed concern about what he contends is India's current zero or minus ten image in this country.

She has worked in a variety of musical idioms, including singing for commercials, but most recently her main work has been with experimental composersabove all Steve Reich and Phil Glass, but also Robert Ashley, David Behrman, Jim Burton, Alvin Curran, Garrett List, Alvin Lucier, Charles Morrow and Stanley Silverman. description: Henry Dumas was 34 when he was killed by a white policeman in 1968. Fortunately, his creative potential had matured enough so that his poetry can be read without one's judgments being influenced by the reverberating echoes of the bullets that ended his life.

title: Oil Spill Volume Down
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP)The volume of oil spills along the Massachusetts coastline dropped by 75 per cent in 1974, the Massachusetts Petroleum Council says. The council said that the decline was from 87,495 gallons in 1973 to 21,806 gallons last year.

title: Temple Picks Quedenfeld
description: Theodore (Ted) Quedenfeld, the coordinator of training activities for Temple University sports teams, has been named associate director of the university's Center for Sports Medicine and Science. He will be in charge of the daily administration of the center and will teach and direct rehabilitation programs.

description: We're hoping for a couple of percentage points of gain in sales this spring, says Richard Roth, a retailer from La Porte, Ind. But we're gearing our business for a 10 per cent decline and cutting our inventories to suit.

She is unemployed. Unless she finds work soon, she will be forced to end her 12year career as a sprinter. And she must find a job that will allow her time to work out.

Mr. Casey is president of the McCord Corporation, manufacturers of automotive supplies in Detroit.

title: Inflation Slows Down
description: Under the battering of the worst recession since World War II, inflation is stowing down. Last month the key index of Industrial prices showed no increase at all, and the wholesale price index dropped by onehalf of 1 per cent. While this does not mean that the inflation is over, there is reason to believe that doubledigit rates of price increases which he nation suffered in the past year, are behind usunless the Administration succeeds in getting Congress to go along with its inflationary energy program.

title: Notes:

description: The City Planning Commission has proposed the designation of a substantial portion of the Riverdale section of the Bronx as a Special Natural Area District, placing it in a protected category that would prevent any development from interfering with natural features of the landscape.

description: Photography buffs often discover that they need and want to know more about their favorite pastime, and the past year has seen the publication of many new books that should prove helpful in this respect. Here is a roundup of some of the more recent ones:

title: Kathy Whitworth, on 71, Leads Triple Crown Golf
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP)Kathy Whitworth sank some clutch putts today at the Doral Country Club's 6,229yard Blue Monster course and shot a oneunder par 71 for a onestroke lead at the halfway point of the 36hole triple crown golf tournament.

title: REV. WILLIAM NOON, LEMOYNE PROFESSOR
description: The Rev. William T. Noon, an emeritus professor of English at LeMoyne College, Syracuse, died on Friday in Misericordia Hospital. He was 62 years old land lived at MurrayWeigel Hall of Fordham University.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The United States registered grave concern to the Cyprus Government today over the attack on the American Embassy in Nicosia, the State Department said.

title: Black Tulip Runs First At Keystone
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 18Black Tulip, owned by Al Wozneski and trained by his brother, John, won the $32,750 Tuscarora Handicap for fillies and mares today by a neck at Keystone Race Track where 7,457 patrons wagered $798,066.

title: Hopes for New CeaseFire Rise in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 18Hopes of restoring a ceasefire in Northern Ireland rose today with strong speculation in political circles that talks had been arranged between representatives of the I.R.A. Provisionals and British Government officials in Belfast.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market gave President Ford's new economic and energy proposals a lukewarm reception last week as prices finished lower in active trading.

title: John Miller to Marry Laura Mosko in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joel Mosko of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Michele Mosko, to John Stevenson Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour W. Miller of New York.

title: Campus for Baruch Supported At Hearing
description: The construction of a new campus for Baruch College in the Atlantic Terminal renewal area in downtown Brooklyn was enthusiastically supported at a City Planning Commission hearing last week by representatives of the City University, various community groups and city and state officials.

title: New Cookbook Spiced With Anecdotes of The Store
description: From the spare and refreshing elegance of The Store, Amagansett's famous finefood emporium, we now have a cookbook. The Store Cookbook, by Bert Greene and Denis Vaughan (H. Regnery, $7.95), shares the unusual and excellent salads, the gossamer mousses, the rich pts, hams and croustades which, for the last seven years, have been delighting partygoers and partygivers summering in the Hamptons. The book is liberally spiced with opinions, anecdotes and pungent wit to enjoy while the ratatouille bakes.

title: END TO CONCERTS AT RINK OPPOSED
description: The city's Parks Department has met with opposition in its efforts to oust the popular 10week Schaefer Music Festival from the Wollman Rink in Central Park, where the concerts have been held for nine years.

title: The Choosing
description: This is the time of year when the pioneers, those who lived out at the edge of the settled areas, went to the cabin loft and chose among the herbs and other plant materials stored there. First they chose the medicines, to treat the coughs, the colds, the winter weaknesses from whatever cause.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Holland of Miami Beach and Monticello, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Bonnie Holland, to Jeffrey Sheldon Schweitzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schweitzer of Palm Beach, Fla., and Bethesda, Md. The couple are students at the University of Miami.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Nobody has done much work on the early history of opera in the United States, and it is a subject screaming for attention from musicologists and historians. It is generally believed that the first staged opera composed by a nativeborn American was Leonora by William Henry Fry, in 1845but a group named The Old American Company had 50 operas in its repertory by 1770, and it is not impossible that research might dig out native works that predate Leonora by many years. It has been stated that the Manuel Garcia company brought Italian opera to America in 1825, but long before that the opera house in New Orleans was a flourishing institution that staged French and Italian opera well prior to the work of Garcia and his talented family (Maria Malibran and Pauline Viardot were his daughters).

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: United Press International

title: He Was Mr. Opera for Millions
description: When the Metropolitan Opera curtain came down on Christmas afternoon, 1931, an aural window had been opened. The first nonexperimental radio broadcast from the stage of the opera house a performance of Hansel and Gretelreached a receptive and enthusiastic audience.

title: Princess Caroline at 18: A Serious Student, Casual Partygoer
description: PARIS, Jan. 18 (UPI) Princess Caroline of Monaco hurried home to the elegant apartment of the Grimaldis on one of the most fashionable streets in Paris an hour late with the improbable story that the hairdresser had put her under the dryer and then had somehow busied himself elsewhere.

title: STANDARD TO END ROLE AT ELK HILLS
HAND CHOICE TIED TO ENVIRONMENT
description: Experiments with mice have led a geneticist to conclude that left  or right  handedness, or pawedness, is not inherited but is instead determined by environmental influences. Although the conclusion applies chiefly to mice, the scientist said he strongly suspected the same was true of human beings.

description: The sister of the New Jersey boy who committed suicide after killing his parents last Tuesday night said yesterday that she felt that her brother had slain his mother and father to spare their pain over his suicide.

title: WELFARE INSPECTOR DROPPED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey has abolished the Office of Welfare Inspector General and has let go, as of Feb. 1, Inspector General William F. Meyers.

description: TOMS RIVERThe first elderly persons to benefit from an experimental fee plan adopted by Ocean County College will attend classes beginning with the spring semester.

title: Stagflation in the Big Industrial Nations
description: The United States is not alone in undergoing the abnormal economic condition for which a name was only recently created: stagflation; simultaneous inflation and economic stagnation. The charts below describe conditions in six other nonCommunist industrial nations, and the accompanying text explains what is not apparent in the. charts.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Clash Anew Near Lebanon's Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18New clashes between Israeli troops and Palestinian guerrillas were reported today along a sector of Lebanon's southern border to the west of the Arkub, where fighting has been concentrated for a week.

title: Museum to Recall State's Film Role
description: FORT LEEFrom about 1912 to 1920, Fort Lee was the Hollywood of America, for it served as the site of many of the leading motionpicture studios. And even before then, New Jersey inventors and scientists played a key role in the development of the movie camera.

description: The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association has subleased from the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation the 19th floor at 299 Park Avenue.

description: Princess Grace of Monaco joined Governor Byrne of New Jersey yesterday in honoring Irish Americans who participated in the Revolutionary War.

title: CLIMATE CHANGES CALLED OMINOUS
How Those With Money Are Trying to Hang On to It
Life's possibilities are those very things once felt as dangers
description: These are six stories (a few are short novels) to do with lives often driven or hopeless, but what they are ultimately about is what might have been. They bring together the, possibilities and the impossibilities of human relationships. They happen in Australia, Egypt, Sicily, Greece, where they go off like cannons fired over some popular, scenic riverdepth charges to bring up the drowned bodies. Accidentally set free by some catastrophe, general or personalwar, starvation, or nothing more than a husband's toothachePatrick White's characters come to a point of discovery. It might be, for instance, that in overcoming repugnancies they are actually yielding to some far deeper attraction; the possibilities of a life have been those very things once felt as its dangers. Or they may learn, in confronting moral weakness in others, some flaw in themselves they've never suspected, still more terrifying.

title: Mary Frank Explores Women's Erotic Fantasies
Chief Suffolk Planner to Veto Further Fire Island Development
description: ISLIP, L. I., Jan. 15  Although the National Park Service has proposed ending its protection against commercial development of part of Fire Island, local authorities will not permit further growth in that resort area, Long Island's chief planner said today.

title: Workers Calm as Layoffs Rise in West Germany
description: WOLFSBURG, West GermanyThe vast parking lots around the Volkswagen factory in this onecompany town stand empty except for a few with undelivered Beetles, Rabbits and Squarebacks. Cars that jam the spaces when the factory is operating are crowded instead into the parking lots and at the curbs around the neat development houses where most of the 50,000 workers live.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at a Major Story
description: The House Internal Security Committee, formerly the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities, passed away last week. The immediate cause of death was a decisive vote by the liberally inclined House Democratic Caucus to transfer its functions and its famous files to the Judiciary Committee, but in fact the creature had been languishing for more than a decade. Despite a substantial budget and staff$725,000 and 39 people in 1974the committee found itself in recent years with no issues to inspire it, few names to feed upon.

description: MONTREAL, Jan. 19 (UPI) Bob Nevin recorded the fifth threegoal performance of his career tonight and led the Los Angeles Kings to a 63 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

description: VULCAN, AlbertaR. C. Munro, the affable editor of The Vulcan Advocate, felt frustrated.

description: The Symphony of the New World's concert presentation of Eugene Onegin yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall had much to recommend it. There were flaws, of course. But at least the performance succeeded in giving us the sweep and passion of Tchaikovsky's opera.

title: Stein Links Some Suppliers To Owners of Nursing Homes
Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP)It will be the last hurrah for Willie Lanier and perhaps the last National Football League appearance of a half dozen other stars tomorrow night in the 25th Pro Bowl. The game, the finale of the sixmonth season, matches allstar teams of the American and National Conferences in the Orange Bowl at 9 P.M. Eastern Standard Time (Channel 7 in New York). Lanier, a 29yearold Kansas City Chiefs linebacker, is quitting after the game to take an executive position with a tobacco company.

title: Gen. Paul Ely, 77, Dies in Paris; Led French Forces in Indochina
description: PARIS, Jan. 19General Paul Ely, former army chief of staff and commander in chief of French forces in Indochina, died Thursday at Val de Grace military hospital here. He was 77 years old.

description: There was a lot of news for New Jersey consumersmost of it badin the annual messages of President Ford and Governor Byrne last week and in the brief announcement by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey.

description: A vast dust cloud thrown Into the stratosphere by a volcanic eruption in Guatemala last October, is spreading northward over the earth, causing spectacular, multicolored sunsets and, in many areas, a prolongation of twilight.

As the most persistently visible figure in the investigations, however, the 30yearold East Side Democrat has seen a dramatic change in his political fortunes.

title: Death in the Starting Gate
description: The freak accident that killed Alvaro Pineda at Santa Anita Saturday was a painful reminder that every time jockey gathers the reins on a thoroughbred he is taking his life in his hands. He knows it, and it is a fact that ought be remembered oftener, perhaps, by horseplayers who risk only their money and do not hesitate to blackguard the kid who is putting his life on the line. At 29, Pineda had spent half his life in the saddle and there must have been many times he got off a loser and heard himself reviled as a crook or a coward or both by some sportsman who had dropped $2 on his mount. Chances are when he rode into the starting gate for Saturday's fourth race there were clients prepared to give him the treatment if his horse didn't win. He was getting off a green colt when it reared in the gate and smashed his head against a crossbar. Taken to a hospital just across the road from the track, he was dead on arrival.

title: The Screen:'Paperback Hero,' Tale of Living a Fantasy
description: "Paperback Hero," the new film at the Festival Theater, is about a swashbuckling young Walter Mitty who is actually living out his fantasy and making a botch of it. It is a pictorially vivid, often engrossing motion picture that sets you ruminating on what it is really all about after you've seen it rather than while you are looking on.In a small town in Saskatchewan, the kind of place where the local beer hall functions as the sole cultural center, Rick Dillon, handsome, strong fellow, hard drinker, brawler, woman chaser and star of the local hockey team, has also decided to play the role of a marshal of the Old West. He wears the 10-gallon hat, totes a gun, sports a star and is the very image of television's Marshal Dillon.At first the town laughs with him, then it laughs at him, although respect is what Rick really craves. After all, what are his options? The hockey team, the only arena in which he stands outhe works as a clerk in a store for a livingis being closed down. He has an offer to go elsewhere to work as a building janitor, although he would like to work in "management."But life here has to be a dull dead end, and Rick becomes more the marshal, bringing the story to a sad, ludicrous, flamboyant finale. Real life just does not let one live in dreams without going through normal channels.Keir Dullea makes a fine, heroic nonhero. He is the very essence of the swaggering, not overbright clod who goes through all the motions of a wild one but who is really small potatoes. He has charm and humor, but it is all canned in the way of a cardboard hero of film  or paperback novel.Elizabeth Ashley, who is currently starring with Mr. Dullea on Broadway in "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," has a difficult assignment, as Rick's sexy but serious, honest and loving girlfriend, and she brings to it a passion and understanding that nicely offset the stridence that envelops the story.Under Peter Pearson's direction, the town, Delisle (population 700) and its environs also achieve star status. The cameras pan over the flat dullness of it all, emphasizing the flat-country vastness and isolation of the place, a fit setting in which one man's lonely trauma becomes the community's spectacle. The eruptions of the marshal and the glamour of hockey, erupting in a riot, make all kinds of sense on this stage. "Paperback Hero" is a simple but intriguing movie that says much if you are willing to listen.

title: Dave Anderson
description: With a blare of dog whistles, Jimmy Connors had been advertised as being available for interrogation at Madison Square Garden, but at the appointed hour yesterday only the coffee and the Danish pastry were visible. Jimmy went home to St. Louis, explained George Liddy, to settle some personal problems. In his striped tie and blazer, George Liddy described himself as the promoter of the $100,000 winnertakeall tennis match between Connors and Rod Laver at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas a week from Sunday at 10 A.M. there, an hour, surely by cameldence, when the casino is almost empty anyway. And this could be the start, Liddy said, of a new concept in tennis that would be like the heavyweight boxing championship a champion and a challenger in title matches. If the winner were to be Jimmy, for example, John Newcombe would be his obvious challenger in the next match. If the winner were to be Jimmy, the 22yearold Wimbledon and Forest Hills champion would do well to study the promotional tenets of Muhammad Ali, the real heavyweight champion. Prior to Ali's last tango with Joe Frazier early last year, a shadow of a doubt existed over the health of his right hand. John F. X. Condon of the Garden's boxing department implored Ali to appear to deny any damage, but Ali was reluctant.

title: Stroessner's Reign of Peace in Paraguay Has a Price
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay Latin America's most durable dictatorship has lasted so long that most Paraguayans were not even born when Gen. Alfredo Stroessner took power.

title: A JUDGE UPHOLDS PHILLIPS VERDICT
FOE OF PARK FAVORS U.S. AID FOR SEOUL
description: TOKYO, Jan. 20The head of South Korea's major opposition party called today for further United States military and economic aid to South Korea despite what he termed the dictatorial Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Income Up 17.9% for Aluminum Producer
CORONA LAMENTS LOSS OF 10 HOMES
description: Ralph Dellacona looked down 101st Street in Corona, Queens, where he has lived for 33 years, and shook his head angrily. The city took a nice neighborhood and drove it to the ground and all for nothing, he said.

title: Tough Drug Law Gains
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20, (UPI)A proposal that life terms be imposed on drug pushers won the consent of an Assembly committee today and moved into position for final approval by the Legislature. The bill, passed by the Senate last April, has the backing of Governor Byrne.

title: ALong Way and Far Cry From L.I.
description: TEHERAN, Iran  The apartment views include gleaming domes of mosques. But the children aren't allowed to ride their bikes and new arrivals are plagued by an ailment known as T.T.

title: PROTEST IS MADE ON THEATER GRANT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Representatives of American commercial and repertory theater groups have sent letters and telegrams to President Ford to protest the award of a quartermilliondollar grant by the National Endowment for the Humanities for the Royal Shakespeare Company to conduct special educational programs at several American universities this spring.

title: U.S. URGED TO PUT BRAKE ON ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 20Unless Americans put a brake on their everincreasing use of energy, the nation Will never achieve self  sufficiency, the head of the new Federal agency for energy research said today.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: A JUDGE UPHOLDS PHILLIPS VERDICT,
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld the murder verdict against William R. Phillips. He did so, he said, even though the prosecution had erred by failing to report that during the trial a juror had applied for a job with the District Attorney's office.

title: Policeman Is Killed in a Gun Battle Here
Makarios Calms Angry AntiU.S. Crowd
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 20Thousands of youthful demonstrators attacked the American cultural center here today. Major damage was averted only when Archbishop Makarios calmed the crowd.

title: RONAN WILL MAKE FISCAL DISCLOSURE
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, changed an earlier stand and agreed yesterday to make a financial disclosure to a New Jersey legislative committee investigating him, a committee lawyer reported.

title: SOME POWER LOST BY REP. WHITTEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 20Representative Jamie L. Whitten, the Mississippi Democrat whose 34 year of seniority have installed him in a powerful position in Congress, was stripped of his influence over consumer and environmental affairs by the House Appropriations Committee today.

title: Poll Shows Ford Is Leading Jackson and Muskie for 76
description: President Ford holds a slight edge over the two strongest Democratic contenders in the 1976 Presidential campaign, according to the results of a Harris Poll released yesterday.

title: DOLLAR DECLINES T0 14MONTH LOW
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 20 (UPI)The dollar, in the fourth week of one of its worst slumps, dropped to another 14month low in Paris today and in Zurich closed only a fraction above its record low of two weeks ago.

title: WOMEN ACTIVISTS CLASH WITH BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20Women activists, irate because Governor Byrne had appointed his commissioner of Community Affairs, Patricia O. Sheehan, to serve aso as acting director of the New Division on Women, converged at noon today on the Governor's office. They demanded that he appoint a fulltime permanent director instead.

title: PRICES EXAMINED IN COAL INDUSTRY
description: The Federal Energy Administration is contducting an intensive study of the coal industry's price structure to determine whether the industry is enjoying excess profits, Frank G. Zarb, Federal Energy Administrator, said yesterday.

title: New Woes Beset DallasFt. Worth Airport
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  Charles C. Smith, a Chicago sales executive, rushed up to a Delta Air Lines boarding gate at the DallasFort Worth Regional Airport here the other day, four minutes before his plane was scheduled to take off for Los Angeles.

title: Liberties Union Backs City U. Teacher
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has condemned the efforts at City College to oust Dr. Stanley W. Page and has called upon the institution's president to ask the faculty senate to restrain itself Dr. Page, a controversial history professor who has criticized some of his colleagues, is threatened with a violation of his freedom of speech under the First Amendment, according to the civil liberties organization, which says it stands ready to defend him.

title: Market Place
description: In the 1950's Walter Winchell, the late Broadway columnist, began touting stocks on his broadcasts. His tips invariably proved to be winnersno doubt because he had a considerable following.

title: Soviet Grain Crop Gaining
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) The Soviet Union's important winter grain crops are in mostly good condition now, but the outlook could darken quickly if a sharp cold spell hits, the Agriculture Department said today in a report.

title: Little Action, Big Gain
description: The two biggest states in the Union have just inaugurated Democratic GovernorsNew York for the first time since 1955, California for the first time since 1963. In both states the Democrats and the new Governors profess themselves to be more progressive than their predecessors; and when parties have been out of power that long they usually come back in on a wave of enthusiasm for change and reform.

title: Excerpts From Address by Chou to the Congress in Peking
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech by Premier Chou Enlai to the National People's Congress of China on Jan. 13, as made public in English translation by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency. The text of a resolution approving the Premier's report is appended.

title: C.I.A. ASKED FOR HELP, FILMMAKER CHARGES
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 20 (AP)A Canadian filmmaker charges that two Central Intelligence Agency representatives asked him to monitor activities of John Meier, a former aide to Howard Hughes, and Mr. Meier's dealings with former President Nixon's brother, Donald, according to Federal court papers filed here today.

title: Stein Subpoena Quashed; Bergman Testifies Today
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday quashed subpoenas that had been served on Bernard Bergman and others in the nursinghome industry by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs, headed by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein. The justice, Hyman Korn, said the commission had exceeded its authority to investigate economic matters and had moved into criminal matters.

title: ALL DALKON SHIELDS TAKEN OFF MARKET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The A. H. Robins Company said today it was taking off the market all Dalkon Shield intrauterine contraceptive devices of the type involved in 14 deaths and at least 219 cases of infected abortions.

title: FORD CHALLENGED BY TWO SENATORS ON OIL IMPORT FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Ford was confronted today with the first specific challenge from Congress over a key part of his economic and energy proposals that would increase fuel prices by imposing higher fees on imported crude oil.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the best ways for intermediate players to improve their skill in handling the dummy is to solve singledummy problems. These are practical exercises in technique: The solver is given his own hand, the dummy, the bidding and the opening lead and asked to decide the best procedure.

title: VW Shelves Project To Build Plant in U.S.
description: Volkswagen of America, the United States marketing arm of the West German automobile, maker, said yesterday that a change of management and falling sales have put a temporary end to the company's idea of building a United States manufacturing plant, The Associated Press reports.

title: Oil Exploration Pacts Set
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 20 (AP)Indonesia signed productionsharing contracts today with the Texas Overseas Petroleum Company and the California Asiatic Oil Company, both of the United States. The contracts allow the companies to explore for oil in a 6,865squarekilometer area in Central Sumatra.

title: Coast Transit Crash Kills 1
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)A Bay Area Rapid Transit test train travelling at more than 70 miles an hour smashed into a maintenance vehicle last night, killing one workman and causing an estimated $700,000 damage. The ninecar automated test train with one opertor aboard collided with the maintenance truck and carried it 400 feet, ripping up track and automatic control circuits.

title: Jobless Rate Rises In France to Reach A Postwar Record
Tenants Concert Raises Contribution to Neediest
description: A concert of Renaissance madrigals, motets, carols and anthems regaled the residents of 25 Parade Place, Brooklyn, as a greeting to the New Year and also resulted in a donation of $100 to the Neediest Cases Fund of The New York Times.

title: College and School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Stags to Disband Or Move Franchise
description: EDMONTON, Ontario, San. 20 (UPI)  The financially troubled Michigan Stags will either disband immediately or move to Baltimore, the World Hockey Association announced today.

title: Recalling Evolution of Seascape Play, Albee Sees Tale Not of Lizard, but of Life
description: Edward Albee's new play, Seascape, which begins previews tonight and opens on Sunday at the Shubert Theater, is about a middleaged married couple (Deborah Kerr and Barry Nelson) who encounter two lizardcreatures (Frank Langella and Maureen Anderman) on a beach. This is Mr. Albee's first play since All Over in 1971, and the first premiere that he has directed. It is also the first time that his cast has not been entirely human.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Preiser Submits Resignation As Correction Chief in State
description: Peter Preiser, the state's Commissioner of Correction since May, 1973, submitted his resignation to Governor Carey last night, saying he planned to leave the post on Feb. 18 to practice law here.

title: Bill to Erase MinorArrest Data Gains
description: ALBANY, Jan, 20In its first day of consideration of new legislation, the Assembly today approved a measure that would ease criminal proceedings against first offenders accused of misdemeanors or minor violations by ordering the sealing of court records and the expungement of the arrest record in cases in which charges were dismissed.

title: Snow and Ice Halt Horse Race Cards
description: Snow and icy track conditions forced the cancellation of horse racing at five major tracks in the East yesterday. Two races were run at Garden State before officials called off the program and racing never got under way at Bowie, Suffolk Downs, Lincoln Downs and Keystone.

title: Point Spread Rivals the Knicks as a Garden Drawing Card
G.M. Faces 2 Recall Suits Involving 816,000 Autos
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Department of Transportation said today that it had asked a Federal court to order the General Motors Corporation to notify the owners of an estimated 816,000 older model cars that the cars contain what the department alleges are safetyrelated defects.

title: State Bids Utilities Help Customers Insulate Homes
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)The State Public Advocate proposed an energysaving plan today that would require utility companies to insulate 750,000 homes on a nonprofit basis.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB payoffs sublect to 5% state tax.) FIRST$7,030, pace, mile.

title: Violet Smith Dead at 60; State Department Consul
description: Violet Smith, who retired 10 years ago as a consul in the State Department in Washington, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 215 West 91st Street.

title: Market Averages
description: Monday, January 20, 1975

title: Israel Asking Washington for Threefold Rise in Aid
Winner and Loser Coach N.H.L. Stars
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 20I dreamed I lost my lineup cards and didn't know who was playing with whom, said Fred Shero, who will coach the Clarence Campbell Division team tomorrow in the 28th National Hockey League AllStar Game. That must show I'm concerned.

title: A TOP AIDE QUITS IN EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Jan. 20 Otto Winter, the East German Foreign Minister, stepped down from his post today because of ill health. The Government appointed Oskar Fischer, a 51yearold member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, to succeed Mr. Winter.

title: Ronan to Disclose His Finances To Joint Legislative Committee
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, changed an earlier stand and agreed yesterday to make a financial disclosure to a New Jersey legislative committee investigating him, a committee lawyer reported.

title: Making the Most of Ritz Steam Bath
Queens Youth Is Arrested In Kidnapping of 3 Women
Sports Betting: What Are the Reasons?
Man Who Slumps Is Theme of Piece By Dance System
description: The Contemporary Dance System has been brilliantly successful in mounting works from the established repertory, but markedly less successful in creating it own new works. The final program of its current appearance was given on Sunday at pace University's Schimmel Center.

title: SHOP TALK
description: In this time of tight dollars, most people are not going to want to spend money for a child's room and then successively throw out furnishings as the child outgrows them.

title: The Bolling House
description: WASHINGTONIn the many years that I have been a member of Congress, the House has revealed itself to me as ineffective in its role as a coordinate branch of the Federal Government, negative in its approach to national tasks, generally unresponsive to any but parochial economic interests. Its procedures, timeconsuming and unwieldy, mask anonymous centers of irresponsible powers. Its legislation is often a travesty of what the national welfare requires.

title: Lehman Bros. Acquisition
description: Lehman Brothers, Inc., the investment banking house, said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of Abraham & Co., Inc., stockbrokers, and that Abraham's business would be terminated.

title: Citibank Simplifies Contract Agreement On Consumer Loans
description: The First National City Bank has taken the small print and confusing legalese out of its consumerloan agreements, the bank announced yesterday.

title: Antismog Program Upheld
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (UPI) An injunction sought by Los Angeles County to halt a state program requiring owners of 1966to70 cars in the area to install an antismog device was denied today in Superior Court. Judge Harry L. Hupp rejected an argument that the law was unconstitutional because it discriminates against owners in the Los Angeles area by requiring them to buy the $35 devices while persons in other parts of the state are not now required to do so.

title: Adm. Charles Martin, 83, Commanded Pennsylvania
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 20Rear Adm. Charles F. Martin, commander of the battleship Pennsylvania in World War II and later of Manus Island Naval Base in the Pacific during World War II, died here yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: U.S. Is Seeking use Of BritishRun Base At the Persian Gulf
description: LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP)The United States is seeking occasional use of airfield facilities at a Britishrun air base on Masira Island, which commands the entrance to the Persian Gulf, and Britain is considering the request, the Foreign Office said today.

title: French Disappointed
description: PARIS, Jan. 20Britain's decision to abandon a joint program with France to build a Channel tunnel provoked deep disappointment in Paris, but French officials said they hoped it would not damage other forms of cooperation between the two countries.

title: JERSEY SENATOR BANNED BY PARTY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20Senate Democrats voted to exclude Senator Alene S. Ammond of Camden County from their majority party caucus today following her renewed charges that some Senators were guilty of conflicts of interest and that the Senate was trying to kill a State Commission of Investigation inquiry into alleged political corruption in South Jersey.

title: TV: N.B.C.'s Death Stalk Is Preceded by Warning
description: NBCTV appears determined to tap California's High Sierras for entertainment and profit. The TV network tried, and failed, with Sierra, a weekly series about forest rangers thrust into thoroughly unbelievable situations. It tries and fails again, with Death Stalk, a 90minute madeforTV movie that will be foisted on the mass public at 8:30 tonight.

title: Beame Calls for Detente Between U.S. and Cities
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 20 Mayor Beame, exercising the leadership role conferred on him by the National Conference of Democratic Mayors, called today for an end to Federalcity budgetary friction and for the beginnings of domestic dtente.

title: Contract Awards
description: Two 737 twinengine jet passenger planes, valued at about $6.5million each, excluding spare parts, have been purchased by Pacific Western Airlines from the Boeing Company.

title: Ripley, BelieveItorNot PoleVaulter, Accepts Invitation to Millrose Games
OfficeMachine Maker's Rise in Net Lags
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings in both the final quarter of 1974 and the full year. However, the profit advances of 5.8 per cent in the quarter and 10.2 per cent for the year were well below the company's average gains in recent years.

title: Jazz Getting Hot as Maravich Goes Back to Old Scoring Style
description: When Coach Butch van Breda Kolff and his New Orleans Jazz were last in New York on Dec. 28, the Knicks sent them away with a sevengame losing streak.

title: Publisher of Book on Luciano Says It Was Based on Interviews
description: Little, Brown & Co., the Boston publisher of The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano, gave further explanation yesterday of why it thought the purported life story of the late mobster was authentic.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE ACTS TO INCREASE SUPPLY OF CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Federal Reserve Board today took its second major action in less than three weeks to combat the recession by making money for bank loans more easily available.

title: Pro Bowl Scoring
description: NFCFG, Marcol, 33. AFCWarfield, 32, pass from Griese (Gerela, kick). AFCFG, Gerela, 33. NFCGray, 8, pass from J. Harris (Marcol, kick) NFCTaylor, 8, pass from J. Harris (Marcol, kick) Attendance26,484.

title: Earnings Down by 68.9% for 4th Quarter
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday that its fourthquarter net income fell 68.9 per cent from the yearago level, while net income for the full year trailed 1973 by 38.3 per cent. Sales and other revenues were at highs for both periods.

title: Bench Marks
description: If the hearings on court reorganization that begin in Albany today send a message to the State Legislature that the public wants no further delay on reform measures, they will serve a good purpose.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Fetus Shot by Mother
description: GEENVILLE, S. C., Jan. 20 (UPI)A 40yearold Greenville woman has been charged with murder in connection with the shooting death of her unborn child. The police said that Betty Jean Beasley fired a .22caliber bullet into her stomach. Her 9monthold bbay was born about an hour later and lived a little more than a day. The woman is in satisfactory condition.

title: General Foods Reports 3Month Profit Decline
WAR IS INEVITABLE, CHOU SAYS IN TALK
Cyprus Reminder
description: The attack by Greek Cypriotes on the American Embassy in Nicosia and their assault on the British bases at Episkopi provide grim reminders that the festering Cyprus crisis still packs the potential for major confrontation and war. It is doubly tragic that the new violence exploded on the very day when representatives of the Greek and Turkish communities, after months of diplomatic sparring, had buckled down to substantive negotiations looking toward a political solution for the unfortunate island.

title: Beloit President Resigns
description: BELOIT, Wis., Jan. 20 (UPI) Miller Upton, president of Beloit College since 1954, announced his resignation today, effective Aug. 31. Mr. Upton, 58 years old, said he had no definite plans.

title: Police Chiefs' Head Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)  Glen D. King, former assistant chief of the Dallas Police Department, was named executive director today of the International Association of Chiefs of police. The association's executive committee chose him to succeed Quinn Tamm, who retires Feb. 5. Mr. King has served as director of the public affairs division of the Police Chiefs Association for more than four years

title: WORK RULES URGED ON USE OF ARSENIC
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Labor Department, warning that exposure to inorganic arsenic may cause cancer in thousands of American workers, proposed strict new work rules today on the use of the industrial chemical.

title: Music: Devoted to Bach
description: Anthony Newman, a lavishly gifted young organist and harpsichordist, stands at an important crossroads right how, and it should soon become evident whether he hopes to become a significant artist or will be content to be a semipopular entertainer with a cultist following. Both tendencies could be discerned at Mr. Newman's concert Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Pro Bowl To N.F.C. By 1710
description: MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) James Harris, forced into action when Jim Hart was injured, threw two touchdown passes in the fourth quarter tonight to give the National Conference an uphill 1710 victory over the American Conference in the National Football League's annual Pro Bowl.

title: 100 Homeless, 5 Injured In Harlem Tenement Fire
description: A fivealarm fire, whipped by 20mileanhour gusts, destroyed two adjacent fivestory tenements and damaged two others in Harlem las night, leaving at least 100 persons homless.

title: Daniel J. Sullivan, 59, Of Brotherhood of Clerks
description: Daniel J. Sullivan, secretarytreasurer of the 300,000member Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks, died Saturday at his horne in Deerfield, Ill. He was 59 years old.

title: Steel Production Slides by 1.3% To 2,556,000 Tons for Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 18 slipped by 1.3 per cent and remained well behind the total for the first 18 days of 1974, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Both Houses of Congress Planning F.B.I. Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Both houses of Congress were preparing today for inquiries into the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the files it maintained over the years on public figures and politicians.

title: Norman Isaacs Is Named Head Of 2 Newspapers in Wilmington
description: Norman E. Isaacs, associate dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, was named to be president and publisher of The Wilmington NewsJournal Company, which publishes two daily newspapers in that Delaware city.

title: Landsat Launching Reset
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Jan. 20 (Reuters) Landsat, the second Earth Resources Technology Satellite, is to be launched on Wednesday, space agency officials said today.

title: Revenue Sharing Scored By Civil Rights Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 20Twentytwo civil rights and civic organizations ranging from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to the JapaneseAmerican Citizens League, sent a letter today to President Ford saying they were dissatisfied with proposals before him to renew revenue sharing with minimum changes.

title: Unorthodox Voices
description: Two former Democratic United States SenatorsEugene McCarthy and Fred Harrishave chosen lesstraveled roads in their respective quests for the Presidency.

title: EUROPEAN SUMMIT IS DUE IN SUMMER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Administration officials said today that enough progress had been made in the EastWest conference on European security to allow the United States to begin planning for a final meeting next summer of the heads of state and Government of the 35 participating countries.

title: A Rise in Connecticut Sales Tax Urged
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 20Caught between the rising cost of municipal services and the limited resources with which to pay for them, a group of Connecticut Mayors asked Gov. Ella T. Grasso today to seek an immediate increase in the state sales tax and help them out of their predicament.

title: Kay Summersby Morgan Dies; Eisenhower Confidante in War
description: Kay Summersby Morgan, who was confidential secretary, driver and confidante to General of the Army. Dwight D. Eisenhower during World War II, died yesterday of cancer of the liver in Southampton (L. I.) Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 1111 Park Avenue.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item on I. F. Stone, the author and journalist, that appeared in the Notes on People column in The New York Times last Saturday contained erroneous information. A corrective item appears in the column today on Page 25.

title: Go Ye and Sin Unto the Upper Brackets
description: Has it been noted by students of American perversity that the Nixon scandals have produced one of the few financial bonanzas of the present bear market?

title: EDUCATION BOARD TO SAVE 700 JOBS
description: The Board of Education, told by Mayor Beame last week to lay off 700 employes to ease the city's fiscal crisis, will be permitted instead to avoid the dismissals by effecting $3.2million on other economies to cover the employes salaries.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed mixed yesterday in slow trading.

title: Protesting Parents Keep School In Harlem Shut for Second Day
description: A group of protesting parents kep Public School 186 in West Harlem closed yesterday for the second consecutive school day with another morning picket line as well as a sitin that has gone on since last Friday. The demonstrators are protesting the ouster of Harold L. Lomax as acting principal, a post he had held since September, 1969.

title: JOSEPH P. TOLINS
description: Joseph P. Tolins, a lawyer here for 50 years until his retirement some years ago, died yesterday in a nursing home in White Plains. He was 91 years old.

title: Roncallo Is Appointed To a $22,300 Position
New Jersey Briefs
description: A 364unit Rutherford gardenapartment complex has agreed to begin recruiting minority tenants, the State Division on Civil Rights announced yesterday. It was the first settlement of a discrimination complaint under the 1970 Multiple Dwelling Reporting Rule, which requires landlords to submit reports to the division on the number of minority tenants in their buildings.

title: Women Who Believe in New York Will Speak for Fashion Industry
description: Downed but not flattened by events of the last few years, part of New York's garment industry is pinning its hopes for revival on two tall, handsome women who are far more than clothes horses.

title: $11Billion of Oil Funds Invested in U.S. in 74
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) Oil  producing countries directly invested about $11billion in the United States in 1974, according to Gerald Parsky, Assistant Treasury Secretary.

title: Ford News Conference On TV at 2 P.M. Today
description: The CBS, NBC and ABC networks will televise President Ford's news conference today at 2 P.M. on Channels 2, 4 and 7, respectively, and Channel 13 will rebroadcast it at 6 P.M.

title: ROBERT N. GILMORE
description: Robert N. Gilmore, a retired Brooklyn lawyer, died yesterday at the home of his soninlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. F. Howard Healy, 39 Dundee Ave., Babylon, L.I. He was 91 years old.

title: Zaire Gets 3Way Loan To Expend Copper Output
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (Reuters)The World Bank, Libya and the European Investment Bank are lending Zaire nearly $221million to help expand its copper and cobalt output, the World Bank said today.

title: EARNINGS RAISED BY BANK AMERICA
description: Fourth  quarter operating earnings of the Bank America Corporation rose 16 per cent last year, the corporation, parent company of the nation's biggest bankthe Bank of Americareported yesterday.

title: Newspapers in France Attack ProArab Policies
Accused Sex Slayer Is a Suspect in Son's Death
description: Joseph Kallinger, the 39year old Philadelphia shoe repairman suspected in a threestate spree of rapes, robberies and murder, is a prime suspect in the mysterious death of one of his own sons last summer, the Philadelphia police disclosed yesterday.

title: Pro Hockey Scorers
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Georgia Power Co. Held Near Insolvency
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (Reuters)The Georgia Power Company is on the brink of insolvency Allen B. Wilson, a company vice president, told the Georgia Public Service Commission at rate hearings today.

title: Grumman Prepares Employes for Move to Iran
description: CALVERTON, L.I., Jan. 20 Arthur Gilmore, a tall, professorial  looking man, waved toward the freshly fallen snow and told his class: That's one thing Iran has in common with this country. But very little else. It's a different world you're going to.

title: CLEMENCY BOARD TO BROADEN DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Presidential Clemency Board, buoyed by the response to its broadcast campaign for applicants, said today that its members would travel across the country in the next two weeks trying to reach even more potential candidates for amnesty.

title: People and Business
description: Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, yesterday told members of the New York Bankers Association that the establishment of a public agency to lend money to creditstrained businesses should receive serious consideration.

title: Decision Awaited on a Permanent Times Sq. Mall
description: Mayor Beame is expected to decide soon on a proposal by midtown planners to turn a three  block section of Broadway at the northern end of Times Square into a permanent mall.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item on I. F. Stone, the author and journalist, that appeared in the Notes on People column in The New York Times last Saturday contained erroneous information. A corrective item appears in the column today on Page 25.

title: EUROPEAN SUMMIT IS DUE IN SUMMER
Korf Unit Sets Venture
description: BadenBaden, West Germany, Jan. 20 (Reuters)The Korf Steel Group said today that its Korf Industries, Inc., subsidiary of North Carolina will invest about $85million in a new steel plant at Beaumont, Tex. The plant will have a yearly capacity of 500,000 metric tons and will go into production in mid1976, the company said.

title: Arabs Free 10 at Orly, Surrender in Iraq
description: PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 21 Three Arab terrorists who held 10 people hostage in a washroom at Orly airport for 17 hours released them yesterday, flew off to the Middle East where six nations reportedly refused them sanctuary, and finally surrendered to authorities at Baghdad, Iraq, today.

title: Court Rejects Job Bias Charge Of an Unwed Pregnant Teacher
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 20An unwed, pregnant public school teacher who had been transferred to a librarian's job was denied reinstatement to her classroom by a District Court judge today.

title: Laver Bows, Metreveli Also Upset
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20Rod Laver, the most feared man in the tournament, followed Alex Metreveli to the sidelines in reversals marking the opening of the $115,000 United States pro indoor tennis championship today at the Spectrum.

title: QUARTERLY NET OFF for PAINE WEBBER
description: Paine Webber, Inc., parent of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's most prominent brokerage houses; reported to stockholders at its annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that firstquarter profits were down slightly. It was the first major brokerage firm to report so far this year.

title: WMCA REPRIMANDED IN ROSENTHAL SLUR
description: The Federal Communications Commission has reprimanded radio station WMCA for violating the personal attack rule of the Communications Act in an incident involving Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a Queens Democrat. However, it dropped a $1,000 fine against the station.

title: Montreal Faces Strike Renewal
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (UPI)  Ironworkers who stalled Olympics stadium construction for more than seven weeks threatened today to go on strike again tomorrow morning if they were not allowed to return to work.

title: Metropolitan Area Again Escapes Winter's Full IceandSnow Fury
description: Winter again, but only lightly, struck in the metropolitan area yesterday, as the city escaped with only a dusting of snow.

title: Bronx Man Surrenders In Putnam County Killing
description: A 23yearold Bronx man, who had been sought in connection with a weekend murder in Putnam County, was arrested here last night after he arranged to surrender with The Daily News.

title: Israel Asking Washington for Threefold Rise in Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Israel has asked the United States for more than $2billion in economic and military assistance for the next fiscal year, over three times what she currently receives from Washington in aid, American and Israeli officials said today.

title: Great Southwest Decree Set
description: The Great Southwest Corporation, a subsidiary of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, signed yesterday a consent decree agreeing not to make false or misleading state

title: GEOTEK HEAD GIVEN 30MONTH JAIL TERM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20Federal District Judge William T. Sweigert sentenced Jack P. Burke today to 30 months in jail for making false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the promotion of his Geotek oil exploration ventures.

title: Korvette Shows a Rise In ThirdQuarter Profits
description: The Korvette department stores, whose New York group is one of the area's largest retailers, substantially improved its pretax income in the third quarter and nine months ended Nov. 30, 1974. Korvette's results were listed in a financial report released yesterday by the parent company, the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation.

title: Dollar Shows Slump
description: The dollar, in the fourth week of one of its worst slumps, dropped to another 14month low in Paris although the price of gold rose somewhat in Zurich. Details on Page 50.

title: GOULD, INC., SUED BY ITE IMPERIAL
description: The ITE Imperial Corporation of Spring House, Pa., announced yesterday that it had filed suit against Gould, Inc., of Chicago and Kidder, Peabody & Co., Inc., of New York in the United States District Court in Chicago, charging that Gould and its stock brokerage house had violated the Federal securities laws. The suit grows out of purchases of common shares of ITE that Gould had been making since last July and that ITE says are for the purpose of acquiring control of the company.

title: Government Issues Show Price Drop
description: Government security markets were under pressure yesterday, but Wall Street closed down before it got word of the big good newsa lowering of reserve requirements by the Federal Reserve, a dramatic signal of further overt credit easing.
