title: Sports News Briefs
description: The New York State Boxing Commission initiated a series of meetings this week with Mike Burke, president of Madison Square Garden, to review the status of future boxing shows in the Felt Forum. At the meetings, Burke reiterated the Garden's contention that it had suspended boxing in the Forum for purely economic reasons, not for rowdyism by fans that occurred after several of the bouts.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, January 23, 1975

title: Mary Foote Moore, 64, Dies; Wife of Envoy to Ireland
description: Mary Foote Moore, wife of John D. J. Moore, Ambassador to Ireland, died yesterday of cancer in St. Vincent's Hospital, Dublin. She was 64 years old.

title: The Pop Life
description: The American Song Festival had a rocky beginning, but festival officials are busily forging ahead with plans for the 1975 installment.

title: ISRAEL REJECTS A PACT DEADLINE
National Guard to Protect Snowmobiles From Indians
Four Americans Win At New Zealand Meet
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan, 23 (UPI)A travelweary United States team, which arrived 40 minutes after the official opening of the New Zealand Games because of aircraft delays, still managed today to muster sufficient energy to win three events in track and one in swimming.

title: State to Investigate Horse Medications
description: Following a rash of illegal medications found in thoroughbred horses, and debates in the industry over legal and illegal drugs, the State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday appointed one of its members to investigate the question of medication of race horses. Joseph H. Boyd Jr. will launch the inquiry, which may take six months or longer. New York permits no medication for a horse once it has been entered in a race. Its rule in this regard is one of the toughest in the United States.

title: Oil Slicks Off St. Croix
Drop Reported in Coronary Death Rate
description: New statistics indicate that the nation has passed the peak of an epidemic of coronary heart disease that for decades has taken the lives of an everincreasing proportion of middleaged American men, a leading heart expert said yesterday.

title: CAREY LOSES BID TO DELAY OIL FEE
Sex Shops Alter the Face of Les Halles
description: PARIS, Jan. 23It is one of the oldest and youngest quarters of Paris.

title: Schlesinger Confident U.S. Can Support Israel in War
description: Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger says that he is confident that the United States can provide theresources to sustain Israeli fighting forces should a fifth Middle East war begin.

title: New Yorkers Played Key Role in House Rebellion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23When I came here in the 89th Congress, [Speaker John W.] McCormack told the freshman class: When you pass a committee chairman in the hall, bow low from the waistI always do, recalled Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the Westchester County Democrat who has returned to the House as a freshman.

title: HIGH COURT MAY GET DURKINWYMAN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. of New Hampshire said today that he might ask the Supreme Court to act if the Senate did n allow the state to resolve a disputed Senate election.

title: Indiana Standard Drops Merger Bid
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) yesterday announced that it had terminated its attempts to acquire the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: Twain's Plans for Fall
description: Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island will become the city's first middle school for gifted students next fall under a courtordered plan to improve the school's racial balance by offering special courses to attract more white students. Page 34.

title: Lawyer for Bergman Names Times and Reporter in Suit
description: Nathan Lewin, a lawyer for the nursing  home owner Bernard Bergman, yesterday filed a suit in Federal District Court here charging that The New York Times and one of its reporters, Frank J. Prial, published a statement about him that was malicious and in reckless disregard of the truth or, alternatively, negligent.

title: The Regents Retreat
description: If nothing more than a theoretical debate were at stake, one could hardly quarrel with the statement by the Board of Regents that integration does not, by definition, require that racial quotas be used in determining the proper or desirable composition of population within a school. But the Regents were not engaging in philosophical musings. In the light of reality, the labored references to quotas are, as Joseph W. McGovern, the board's chancellor, put it succinctly, straw men  easily blown down in a soft wind.

title: Exxon Quarter Net Up 9.3%
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, announced yesterday a 9.3 per cent increase in fourthquarter earnings and a 28.5 per cent increase for 1974. The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's sixth largest oil company, reported profit advances of 43.9 per cent for the quarter and 89 per cent for the year.

title: Minnesota Mining, 2 Officials Indicted Over Contributions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and two of its board members today on a charge of income tax conspiracy involving almost $634,000 in allegedly fictitious deductions for illegal political contributions.

title: Heading for the Last Hibernation
description: WASHINGTONThe Interior Department is selling out most of America's last remaining grizzly bears to the trophyhunting lobby.

title: STRIKE VOTED TODAY AT THE NEW SCHOOL
description: Clerical and library employes of the New School for Social Research, which includes the Parsons School of Design, voted to strike yesterday after contract negotiations broke down over salaries and issues concerning the use of students in some jobs.

title: Rangers Rout Flames; Islanders Defeated
The Days Of The Googol
16 Are Hurt in Explosion At Elizabeth Aerosol Plant
description: ELIZABETH, Jan. 23 An explosion in an aerosolcan paint factory here at 7:45 A.M. today injured 16 workers. Eight of the most seriously injured were admitted to two local hospitals for treatment of burns, contusions and shock.

title: ALBERT S. CARLSON
description: HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 23 (AP) Albert S. Carlson, professor emeritus of geography at Dartmouth College, died yesterday of cancer in a hospital here. He was 67 years old.

title: DR. FRANCIS J. WEISS, CHEMIST, ECONOMIST
description: Dr. Francis Joseph Weiss, a biochemist and economist concerned with developing food resources, died Tuesday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 76 years old and lived at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington.

title: Freight Traffic Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Association of American Railroads reported today freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.5 billlion tonmiles, 10.8 per cent be low a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 435,947 cars, 13.5 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 23.6 per cent below last year.

title: Market Place
description: The familiar practice by which companies have deferred costs for research and development by capitalizing them has been eliminated.

title: BankLending Rates A Target of Inquiry
description: An inquiry into banking practices that have subjected delinquent borrowers to interest rates as high as 70 per cent and to exorbitant legal fees was made public yesterday by State Attorney Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Abortion Ban Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, introduced a constitutional amendment today that would ban abortions except in cases when thhe continuation of pregnancy would result in the death of the mother.

title: Mark Twain Will Become A Magnet School in Fall
3 TOP ECONOMISTS BACK TAX REBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Three leading economists of both political parties, all former high Government officials, supported today President Ford's plan for a $12billion rebate of 1974 income taxes to stimulate the economy, although they differed on some details.

title: Rockefeller, in Chicago, Addresses Businessmen Naming His Grandfather and Others to a Hall of Fame
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23Vice President Rockefeller flew here tonight to perform his first outoftown VicePresidential chore, giving a speech to a group of business executives gathered to honor members of a business hall of fameincluding Mr. Rockefeller's grandfather.

title: Inland Steel Shows Net and Sales Gain In Quarter and Year
description: The Inland Steel Company reported yesterday sizable gains in sales and earnings for both the fourth quarter and full calendar year 1974. Shipments of raw steel, sales and earnings for the year reached new highs for the second year in a row, while sales and earnings were at new highs for any fourth quarter.

title: TESTIFY ON ATTICA, NEWSMAN IS TOLD
Books of The Times
description: Having a book reviewed by the late Cyril Connolly could be a mixed blessing for a writer. While Mr. Connolly was famous enough to confer a kind of instant recognition, he often tended, by the same token, to upstage both book and author. He seemed to take it for grantedand he was probably rightthat readers of The Times of London would rather have his views on most subjects than those of a stranger.

title: CORPORATE LOANS CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Corporate loans in New York City continued to fade away in the week ended Wednesday, reflecting the recession, and borrowing in the commercial paper market fell off, too. Interest rates dropped sharply, and the nation's money supply showed little growth.

title: New Dust Bowls?
description: Facts and figures set forth in a recent article in this newspapermost of them confirmed by the Soil Conservation Service of the Department of Agricultureraise questions of profound importance for the future of American farming. They warn of grave dangers to this country's ultimate capacity to meet world demands on its food production. They expose practices that threaten the very environment that makes that production possible.

title: Stanley Schneider, 45, Dies; Served Columbia Pictures
description: Stanley Schneider, an inde pendent film producer who was president of the Columbia Pictures division of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., from 1969 to 1973, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He would have been 46 years old Monday.

title: 2 Coaches From East Feted Here
description: The New York Football Writers Association honored yesterday two former assistant coaches at ColgateJoe Restic, now the head football coach at Harvard, and Jim Butterfield, head coach at Ithaca College.

title: Bridge:
description: Supporters of the United States team are cautiously optimistic about the prospects in the world team championship beginning tonight in Bermuda. The Italian team does not appear to be as strong as usual, although appearances may be deceptive.

title: Judge Forbids Testimony on Payment to Errichetti
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23Gerald Smith, the state's star witness in the trial of Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden, unexpectedly testified today that he gave Mr. Errichetti $500 in 1969 as a political contribution, not as a payoff for help in getting city painting contracts.

title: Delta and United Nets, Off in Quarter, Soar in Year
description: Partly reflecting a slump in air travel that engulfed the airline industry late in 1974, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines yesterday reported sharply reduced earnings for the fourth quarter.

title: People in Sports
description: I don't know any basketball players who have to fake an injury, said Bill Walton of the Portland Trail Blazers as he struck back at hints that his injury (a bone spur) is not real.

title: DOLLAR OFF AGAIN; OIL REPORTS CITED
News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 24, 1975

title: Britain Plans Referendum On Pulling Out of Market
description: LONDON, Jan. 23  Prime Minister Harold Wilson announced plans today for a nationwide vote by the end of June on whether Britain should withdraw from the Common Market.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 24, 1975

title: Britain Plans Referendum On Pulling Out of Market
description: LONDON, Jan. 23  Prime Minister Harold Wilson announeed plans today for a nationwide vote by the end of June on whether Britain should withdraw from the Common Market.

title: New Hampshire Challenge On WelfareAbortion Ban
description: CONCORD, N.H. Jan.23 (AP) A class action suit was filed in United States District Court today challenging New Hampshire's policy of prohibiting the use of welfare money for abortions.

title: Article 5  No Title
DOW INDEX UP 4.15 AS TRADING RISES
ENERGYTAX PLAN MAY CUT INCOMES
World Wheat Output To Drop FromYear Ago
description: LONDON, Jan. 23 (UPI)World wheat production in 197475 will show a sharp drop from the previous year, the International Wheat Council said today.

title: Article 2  No Title
DRUG UNIT FACING CONGRESS INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23 The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration is facing a Congressional inquiry into its operationson such diverse fronts as personnel hiring practices and internationalintelligence tactics.

title: Twain's Plans for Fall
description: Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island will become the city's first middle school for gifted students next fall under a courtordered plan to improve the school's racial balance by offering special courses to attract more white students. Page 34.

title: Chiefs Name Wiggin Coach for 3 Years
Auto Dealers Told: Get Back to Basics
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 Tommy Thomas, one of the 3,100 auto dealers who met here for five days to search for ways to get through one of the worst sales slumps since World War II, likes to illustrate his solution with a story about one of his salesmen.

title: Advertising
description: If you are one of those cat and kiddy lovers who is positively charmed by the recent Del Monte commercials with their adorable children, don't feel alone. There are many who feel just as you.

title: $36Billion Rise in Debt Limit Needed, Simon Tells Congress
City Disputes P.B.A. Stand On the Issue of Higher Pay
description: A special counsel for the city sought to show yesterday that police officers spent substantial amounts of time on activities other than crime prevention and that there had not been recent changes in their duties warranting salaries greater than those of firemen.

title: Rebates Increasing Sales Of Compacts at Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its rebate program had lifted sales of its compact cars, although its overall sales were still running behind yearearlier levels.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: PHILADELPHIA  Despite the continuing dissolution of the family from extended to nuclear  with even that atom frequently split into the smaller, singleparent unitmost people still cling to the belief that the family is the best childrearing institution we have. That belief pervades an unusual day care center here.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: $16Million in S. I. Construction Being Put Off by City This Year
CITY RIGHTS UNIT FINDS NBC SEXISM
description: The New York City Commission on Human Rights has found cause to believe that the National Broadcasting Company has discriminated against women in recruitment, in hiring, job classification, promotion opportunities and benefit programs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CASA GRANDE. Don't take the Chateau Madrid (7528080), at 48th Street and Lexington Avenue, for granted. Si, it's been around a long time, starting on Broadway over 30 years ago (as the Havana Madrid), then shifting to the East Side in 1951. At its present location (the old Hawaiian Room of the Lexington Hotel), this nightblooming Spanish lair retains its reputation as the most dependable, elaborate dinnershowcase in town.

title: Ford Would Allocate Oil if Tax Plan Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 23 President Ford, appearing on a television interview tonight after a busy day of jousting with Congress, said that if his plan for imposing energy taxes was rejected, he would accept arbitrary allocation of petroleum products instead.

title: Bank of England Attempts To Rescue Burmah Oil Co.
City Nullifies Designation Of Steinway Historic Area
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday nullified the designation by the Landmarks Preservation Commission of a row of 19thcentury houses as the Steinway Historic District in Astoria, Queens.

title: FORD THINKS TALKS MAY GO TO GENEVA if KISSINGER FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Ford said tonight that if Secretary of State Kissinger failed to make progress toward a new EgyptianIsraeli accord the United States would probably be forced to go to Geneva for a reconvening of the conference strongly advocated by the Soviet Union.

title: DERGRATS REACH AN UNEASY ACCORD
AMEX PRICES UP AS TRADING RISES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market rose yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: TV Review
description: Last week, on CBS's The Jeffersons Norman Lear gave the mass TV public situation comedy's first interracial marriage. Tonight, at 9 on ABC, his production company offers Hot 1 Baltimore, the first weekly series to carry the equivalent of a PG (parental guidance) rating. The first two episodes are prefaced with a warning: The following program deals with mature subject matter. Parental judgment and discretion are advised. Future episodes and appropriate warnings will be considered by the network on a casebycase basis.

title: No Indictment Voted In Collapse of Hotel That Killed 4 in '73
description: A Manhattan grand jury has found insufficient evidence to indict anyone on criminal charges in the 1973 collapse of the old Broadway Central Hotel which killed four persons, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced yesterday.

title: He Taught Nureyev and Baryshnikov
description: Behindthe dazzling performances of Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov that have held ballet audiences agog for the last several weeks here, there stands the specter of a gentle Russian man, almost unknown in the West, named Aleksandr Pushkin.

title: Big WatergateBook Advances Upset Many People, Ford Says
description: President Ford said last night that a good many Americans would no doubt be bothered by the large amounts of money being paid in book advances to some of the central Watergate figures who have pleaded guilty, been convicted or gone to jail.

title: Miller's 71 5 Strokes Off Pace
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23It turns out that Johnny Miller is human after all.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The New England Electric System said yesterday it would make a public offering of 2.5 million additional shares of commo stock in April. The proceeds will be used to repay shortterm debt.

title: Oklahoma ExConvict Arrested After Freeing Seven Hostages
description: TULSA, Okla., Jan. 23 (AP)Gerald Wayne Pike, a former convict accused of abducting seven persons in a 135mile rampage across northern Oklanoma this morning, was arrested without resistance in Tulsa later today.

title: People and Business
description: Roswell L. Gilpatrick, 68, who served as Deputy Secretary for Defense from 1961 to 1964, is scheduled to succeed Walter Burke, 52, as chairman of the hoard of the Fairchild Camera & Instrument Corporation. Mr. Burke, who became chairman four years ago, announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman and as a director of the company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif, after the annual meeting on May 2. He said he wanted to pursue other interests.

title: $300,000 in Jewels Taken On East Side After Ball
Music: Daphne Returns
description: In its 27th final season, the Little Orchestra Society is presenting a retrospective of some of the more important premieres in its history. On Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall, it revived Richard Strauss's Daphne. It had given the first United States performance of the opera in 1960, 22 years after its premiere in Dresden.

title: City Ballet's School Holds Open House
description: In 1934, George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein established a ballet school that they envisaged as the training academy of their own future company, now the New York City Ballet. Today, with 75 of the City Ballet's 85 dancers having studied at some time at the School of American Ballet, that dream has come true.

title: LaidOff Seatrain Workers Angry At Company, Carey, Ford, Union
description: They didn't even say thank you! said Pedro Vidal, a welder, as he read his dismissal notice from the Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation.

title: ALBERT S. CARLSON
description: HANOVERN. H. Jan 23 (AP) (AP)Albert S. Carlson, professor emeritus of geography at Dartmouth College, died yesterday of cancer in a hospital here. He was 67 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 23 (UPI)The Government told two major oil companies in Turkey today to step up their crude imports at Government imposed prices.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The law creating the state's Organized Crime Task Force was ruled unconstitutional yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Syracuse. The 1970 law that formed the task force to investigate and prosecute organized crime involving more than one county does not define organized crime. Justice Thomas Aloi said this omission has permitted unrestricted expansion of the task force's powers tionally protected rights of individuals. The ruling will be appealed.

title: Music: Revivals for Flute
description: John Wion is not only a superior flutist but also an excavator of works that have been buried by the glaciers, quakes and avalanches of musical history. His favorite digging area is the 19th century, where his efforts have unearthed some worthwhile pieces from the romantic and postromantic period.

title: Cyprus Talks Stall On Airport Question
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 23After two working sessions, the talks on the political future of Cyprus appear to be off to a rocky start.

title: Backlog Advances
Commodity Price Index Fell 7.3 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 200.7 from 208.0 last week.

title: MONSANTO PROFIT CLIMBS SLIGHTLY
description: The Monsanto Company, a leading diversified chemical producer, reported yesterday for the final three weeks of 1974 the smallest percentage earnings gain of any quarter of last year, largely because of a deficit in textiles. Results for the period and for all of 1974 still set records, according to a company spokesman.

title: Man Who Came to Dinner Is Monsieur le President
description: PARIS, Jan. 23Trying to rub a little gloss off his patrician image, President Valry Giscard d'Estaing went to dinner at the Left Bank apartment of a picture framer last night and regaled his hosts with folksy conversation about the weather and the cost of living.

title: Driver of Krupsak Car Hits the Carey Dog, Jet
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23Governor Carey's family dog, Jet, was struck by Lieutenant Governor Mary Anne Krupsak's official car this morning when the dog darted out into the street in front of the Executive Mansion.

title: Munitions Barges Get to Phnom Penh Despite Blockade
Offset Printing: Brighter Image
description: Offset, the printing process chosen by The New York. Times for its bright new plant in Carlstadt, N.J., produces a clearer, brighter image than letterpress, the traditional method. The difference is most noticeable photbgraphs and advertisements.

title: PENNEY CUTS PRICES ON SEWING FABRICS
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the country's largest retailer of fabrics, announced yesterday that it had reduced prices as much as 33 per cent on 37 of its most popular homesewing fabrics. Penney said that the rollbacks were the result of lower wholesale prices after a lone period of sharp increases.

title: Democrat in House Cricizes Liberals And Shifts to G.O. P.
Canadians May Lose Right To Tax Break for U.S. Ads
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 23The Canadian Government announced today that it would seek to abolish the tax concession that allows companies to deduct the cost of advertising in United States magazines or broadcasts aimed at the Canadian market.

title: Wood. Field and Stream: Salmon Issue
description: At the recent New England Atlantic Salmon Restoration Conference in Boston it was acknowledged that those who will be regulating the catching of salmonwhen the fish do returnface some sticky problems.

title: Glimmer of Sanity
COURTNEY JOHNSON, EXDEFENSE AIDE
description: Courtney Johnson, a former Assistant Secretary of the Army, died Wednesday in West Hartford, Conn. His age was 84.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Television
description: Morning

title: ZACH TOMS WHITE
description: Zach Toms White, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse & Co., certified public accountants, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J., yesterday. He was 33 years old and lived at 50 Portland Road in Summit.

title: 1,200 Urge U.S. Act in NaturalGas Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Little was left to chance this morning as a caravan of 30 buses pulled itself together from several shopping centers across Salem and Cumberland Counties in South Jersey and headed, with all the efficiency of a wellplanned raid, for the White House and Capitol Hill.

title: Major Oil Exporters Will Meet Today
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 23The major oilexporting countries will begin a highlevel meeting here tomorrow to discuss strategy and procedures for negotiations with oil  consuming countries on the world's energy and financial crisis.

title: JURORS SUBPOENA BERGMAN RECORDS
description: A Federal grand jury here has subpoenaed bank records of the Bernard Bergmans Towers Nursing Home, according to lawyers for Mr. Bergman.

title: LibbeyOwens Dividend Cut
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 23 Reuters)  The LibbeyOwens Ford Company said today directors cut the company's quarterly dividend to 40 cents from 55 cents. The dividend is payable March 10 to shareholders of record Feb. 18.

title: Ford Promotes Polish Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  President Ford today asked the Senate to approve a tax convention with Poland that was signed when the Polish leader, Edward Gierek, visited Washington alst October. Mr. Ford said that the convention was expected to encourage trade and investment between the two nations.

title: 20 Latin Countries Condemn U.S. Trade Act
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Twenty Latin  American and Caribbean countries today voted condemnation of the new United States trade act as discriminatory and coercive in a resolution by the governinc body of the Organization of American States.

title: Labor Chiefs Urge A Curb on Arab Oil; Support Rationing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Leaders of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called today for a ban on oil imported from the Arab nations that took part in the 19731974 embargo and for rationing at home.

title: Court Holds $3Million Bid Too Low for Knoll Club
description: NEWARK, Jan. 23A single bid of $3million for Bloomfield College's deficitplagued Knoll Country Club was rejected as too low by a Federal judge at a public auction here today.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT ASSAILS JACKSON
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23Roy A. Medvedev, the dissident Soviet historian, charged today that Senator Henry M. Jackson had sought pretentious personal publicity in his efforts to force the Soviet Union to relax emigration regulations for Jews.

title: WOMAN IN DELRAN STABBED BY YOUTH
description: DELRAN, N. J., Jan. 23 Young housewives and mothers in this quiet Burlington township suburb reacted fearfully today to the stabbing yesterday, morning of one of their neighbors, Helen Ehlers, by an unknown youth who was said to have come and gone on a bicycle.

title: Drop Reported in Coronary Death Rate
description: New statistics indicate that the nation has passed the peak of an epidemic of coronary heart disease that for decades has taken the lives of an everincreasing proportion of middleaged American men, a leading heart expert said yesterday.

title: FORD RAISES FEES ON IMPORTED OIL; FOES SEEK FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Ford signed today a proclamation increasing the import fee on petroleum amid accusations by Democratic members of Congress that his action constituted an abuse of presidential power.

title: Scouts Surprise Bruins, Win, 32
Government Scrutinizes Drug Story
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 (AP)A Federal official said today that a fullscale investigation is warranted despite Roxie Ann Rice's refusalon the advice of a St. Louis police investigatorto corroborate a story that she was a courier of drugs for professional football and basketball players.

title: I.B.M. CONVICTION IN ANTITRUST CASE UPSET ON APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A Federal Court of Appeals in Denver overturned today an antitrust conviction of the International Business Machines Corporation that had ordered the giant corporation to pay $259.5million to the Telex Corporation. At the same time, the lower court's judgment against Telex in a countersuit was affirmed.

title: LAG EXPECTED IN '75 IN EASTWEST TRADE
description: BERLIN. Jan. 24  EastWest trade between Eastern European countries and the 24 Western industrialized nations in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development will slow down this year, a WestGerman research institute said here today.

title: NEW SCHOOL STRUCK BY 153 EMPLOYES
description: A total of 153 employes of the New School for Social Research refused to work yesterday in a contract dispute over salaries, layoffs and benefits. They vowed to continue their strike into the busy registration week beginning next Monday.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Suit Over '74 Campaign Act
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) A Federal judge rejected today a Government motion to dismiss a lawsuit challenging the 1974 Campaign Practices Act on constitutional grounds.

title: Art: Sensual, Serehe Sculpture
Names of the Hospitalized and Injured
description: Following is a list of those injured in yesterday's explosion:

title: WILLIAM A. DONAGHY
description: The Very Rev. William A. Donaghy, who served as president of the College of the Holy Cross from 1954 to 1960, died yesterday at his home on the college grounds in Worcester Mass. He was 65 years old.

title: The Chillies Stir in the Ice Bowl
QUALITY INDEX IS REPORTED DOWN
description: Despite progress in some areas, the nation's overall quality of life declined slightly in 1974 from the previous year, by the reckoning of the National Wildlife Federation.

title: Auto Rebate Plans Spread Amid Glee
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24  The only thing missing was a brass band. The television cameras and bright lights were there, and so were the lieutenant governor of the state and a crowd. Confidence in America, proclaimed a huge red, white and blue banner.

title: The Ethnic Aspect of Supervisory School Jobs Here
Test Flow Is Reported For Nigerian Oil Well
description: The Pan Ocean Oil Corporaion and Delta Oil Nigeria, Ltd., a private Nigerian company, announced yesterday that an oil well about 20 miles south of Benin City in Nigeria had tested at flow rates of up to 14,674 barrels of oil and 16.5 million cubic feet of gas per day.

title: EARNINGS OFF 22% AT MARINE MIDLAND
description: Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a 10bank holding company including Marine Midland BankNew York, reported yesterday that operating earnings fell 22 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974 and 6.8 per cent for the full year. It attributed the showing entirely to loanloss provisions exceeding normal requirements.

title: WAGE SETTLEMENTS DOUBLED LAST YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Wage settlements last year almost doubled those of 1973, but did not keep pace with inflation, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Today's Entries at Hialeah
Indictment Charges Developer of Land Lied to Get Loans.
Nawab Tiwana, ExMinister Of Punjab, Led Unionists
description: Nawab Malik Sir Khizar Hayat Tiwana, who served as Minister and then as Prime Minister of the Punjab from 1937 to 1947, died Monday in Butte City, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Text of the I.B.M. Order
description: DENVER, Jan. 24 (AP)Following is the text of the order of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in the International Business Machines CorporationTelex Corporation case:

title: Article 2  No Title
New Yonkers Face Really Old Hand
Forbes Pleads Not Guilty In Hockey Assault Charge
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 24 (UPI)Dave Forbes of the Boston Bruins pleaded not guilty today to a charge of aggravated assault in an alleged attack on Henry Boucha of the Minnesota North Stars during a Jan. 4 game.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Sandino Hernandez, the jockey arrested last fall tampering in the paddock at Belmont Park, was convicted yesterday on a charge of tampering with a sporting event. Judge John Ca'pelli of Nassau County District Court found the 36yearold rider guilty of possessing an illegal batterypowered device known as a buzzer. The electrical device is used to shock a horse into greater speed.

title: Hospitals Agency Bars Layoffs for Second Time
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation rebuffed Mayor Beame for a second time yesterday, refusing to lay off any personnel in response to the municipal budget crisis. The agency proposed, instead, to effect economies through attrition and by reducing outlays for employe meals and housing.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: P.B.A. GIVES CASE FOR PAY INCREASE
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association put several police on the stand yesterday at a hearing in its contract dispute to describe the scope, sophistication and responsibilities of their duties.

title: Fraunces Tavern, Anglers Club Are Closely Tied to U.S. History
description: Fraunces Tavern, where Washington said farewell to his assembled officers, has long been celebrated in American history.

title: DRAFT VIOLATORS LISTED FOR SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Justice Departtnent released today a list of 4,400 Vietnamera draft law violators still subject to criminal prosecution or investigation and said that another 1,700 cases had been closed for lack of prospective merit.

title: FOOD BASKET COST ROSE 14% IN 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The average wekly cost of a consumer food market basket jumped 14 per cent in 1974, according to preliminary figures released today by the Department of Agriculture.

title: Man Accused of Plot to Kill A Judge and U.S. Attorney
description: A convicted stock manipulator was charged yesterday with planning to kill the judge and the prosecutor in the case that had resulted in his being sen tenced to four years in prison

title: HEINIE MUELLER DIES, CARDS OUTFIELDER
description: DE SOTO, Mo., Jan. 24 (AP) Clarence F. (Heinie) Mueller, a colorful outfielder for the St. Louis Cardinals in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday of cancer at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market made a strong advance yesterday in moderate trading.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 25, 1975

title: Ford to Recall 178,000 Cars To Replace Bad Seat Belts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Ford Motor Company will recall 178,000 1972 Maverick and Comet automobiles to replace faulty seat belts, the Transportation Department said today.

title: 2 JUDGES AT ODDS IN RAP BROWN CASE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24A Federal district judge said in court today that lie believed the testimony of a witness who said another judge, who sentenced H. Rap Brown to prison, vowed at a state bar meeting that he would get that nigger.

title: Bronx Youth, 19. Accused Of Attempt on Officer's Life
description: A Bronx youth was arrested yesterday and charged with attempted murder in connection with an incident Jan. 17 in which a bullet was fired through the cap of a police detective.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dr. Matthew W. Stirling Dies; Archeologist for Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Dr. Matthew W. Stirling, an anthropologist associated with the Smithsonian Institution for more than 40 years, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: FORD TO LAY OFF 44,500 FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24The Ford Motor Company said today that it was laying off 44,550 workers for next week and putting 2,000 more on indefinite layoff. The total number of Ford employes on indefinite layoff next week will be 33,125.

title: Separate Lawyer Is Retained For Kallinger's Son, Michael
description: Lawyers representing Joseph Kallinger, suspect in a threestate crime, spree, said yesterday that another lawyer had been retained for his 13yearold son, Michael, as part of an effort to guarantee that the youth's best interests would be served in court.

title: Indian Aide Denies Remark Attributed to Him by Bhutto
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 24P. N. Haksar; deputy chairman of India's Planning Commission, has described as concoctions the references to him made by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: Canada Says Policy Aim Is Independent Economy
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 24Canada has reconsidered her relations with the United States and decided to strengthen the economy and other aspects of national life in order to secure our independence, Allen J. MacEachen, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, said last night.

title: The Danee:Tetley's Sensuous Gemini
Canucks Conquer Flames
VALENTINE HOWELL
description: Valentine Howell, who retired in 1962 as an executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, died yesterday at his home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: East Germans Expecting High Prices and Hard Times
description: BERLINEast Germany, like the rest of the Communist states of Eastern Europe, is expecting hard times ahead and its leaders appear to be preparing the people for dramatically higher prices for oil and other raw materials from the Soviet Union.

title: Saudi Arabia and U.S. Concerns In Pact on Aramco Takeover
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Saudi Arabia and the four United States oil companies with shares in the Arabian American Oil Company have agreed to terms for a complete Saudi takeover of the company, the world's largest single producer of oil.

title: HOLDBACK DENIED ON NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Oil industry spokesmen reacted today to a Federal investigation of natural gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico by denying that they had held back production.

title: Hare's Knuckle Is a Play Of Mystery and Message
Vietcong Charges U. S. Has Sent Vast Supply of Bombe to Saigon
description: PARIS, Jan. 24A Vietcong spokesman charged here today that since the signing of the 1973 Paris peace agreements on Vietnam the United States had introduced 1.5 million tons of bombs into Saigoncontrolled territory.

title: WINE TALK
description: BOSTONThere is an old tale of how seven years of fat cows are followed by seven years of lean cows. I hope we are not coming into a period of lean cows.

title: Food in Fallout Shelters Urged for Poor
description: Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday that $4 million worth of food stored in civildefense. fallout shelters was in danger of spoiling, and he urged Mayor Beame to turn it over to the city's aged poor.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Wheat Plowed Under
description: SYRACUSE, Kan., Jan. 24 (UPI)Farmers in Hainilton County plowed up several thousand acres of winter wheat today in protest of falling wheat prices and an apparent lack of Government concern toward the industry. They said their action was spontaneous.

title: Teller Killed in Robbery
description: PANTEGO, N. C., Jan. 24 (AP)A bank teller was bound with heavy tape and fatally shot today by a man who held up an office of Southern Bank and Trust Company moments after it opened. The authorities identified the teller as Dorothy Cuthrell, about 50 years old. She was alone in the bank when the robbery occurred.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: How to Stimulate Our Economy

title: Aussie Sets 2 Marks in Swimming
Several Cut Level to 9% Low Since Early in April
description: The interest rates that big banks charge on loans to corporations continued to decline yesterday in reflection of the weak national economy and Federal Reserve action to push rates down.

title: POLICE KILL SUSPECT IN CANADA SLAYINGS
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UPI)An escaped convict sought for questioning in the nightclub massacre of 13 persons here this week was shot to death today in a raid on an expensive, chalet in the Laurentian Mom tains. according to the police.

title: Crabiel Seeks Dismissal of Indictment
HOUSE UNIT VOTES TO BAR FORD STEPS ON IMPORTS OF OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The House Ways and Means Committee approved today legislation that would not only stop President Ford from imposing higher fees on imported petroleum but would also prevent him from taking an alternative step he has been considering, establishment of restrictive quotas on imports.

title: CONGRESS SHIELD LIMITED BY COURT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (UPI)A Federal judge ruled today that the constitutional cloak that protects members of Congress On the floor of either house does not do so when they make speeches or television appearances outside the legislative chambers.

title: MAYORS CRITICAL OF SCHOOL RULING
SnowCountry Japanese Feel Less Isolated
description: YUZAWA, Japan, Jan. 20When Fuyo Kurihara stepped outside this morning there were five feet of fresh snow in front of her house on top of the four feet already there from earlier snowfalls. Until a few years ago Mrs. Kurihara, a 64 yearold owner of a house for geisha, or Japanese women entertainers, would simply have climbed out her secondfloor window and walked between the roofs of the old wooden houses in this mountain village.

title: Sadat Says He Has Reason to Believe That U.S. Will Recognize the P.L.O. Soon
description: PARIS, Jan. 24  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said in an interview published here today that he had reason to believe the United States would soon recognize the Palestine Liberaticn Organization.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it was challenging the acquisition of a competing producer and supplier of automotive parts by the BorgWarner Corporation. BorgWarner in 1972 acquired the Unit Parts Company, which is based in Oklahoma City, through a S10million exchange of stock.

title: 4 Killed, 44 Injured in Fraunces Tavern Blast
description: A thundering explosion believed by the police to have been detonated by Puerto Rican nationalists ripped through a 19thcentury annex to historic Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, killing four people and injuring at least 44 others.

title: Ruling Reserved in Bail Plea
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24 (AP)Judge Stanley Bedford of Superior Court reserved decision today on setting bail for Otto Neal Nilson, a certified public accountant charged with the 1972 murder of Joan Kramer, a socialite of South Orange. The 40yearold defendant, who lives in Maplewood, was charged two weeks ago with the slaying of Miss Kramer, who was found nude and strangled in a park in Union Township. He is being held in Essex County Jail.

title: MahJongg Fans Get Together For Tournament at Grossinger's
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y.The halls were alive with the sound of women saying two barn, and three crack, and six dot. And when they weren't talking, they were click, click, clicking their tiny tiles. The women could only be playing mahjongg, and they werevery seriously.

title: Oil Industry Profits Slip in 4th Quarter
Briefs on the Arts
description: Claude Monet's Study for DJeuner Sur L'herbe has been added to the exhibition The Impressionist Epoch at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The painting was lent by the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts, Moscow. it was one of the central group of 42 paintings when the exhibition was at the Grand Palais in Paris last fall, but was returned to the Soviet Union briefly for an impressionist exhibition there.

title: Meskill, Before Senate Panel, Calls Life Free of Wrongdoing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Former Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut testified at a hearing today on his nomination to be a Federal appeals court judge that there had been no wrongdoing on his part.

title: BEAME WEIGHING HOUSING PACKAGE
description: ALBANY, Jan, 24The state law that in effect lets a landlord charge whatever rent he chooses when a rentcontrolled apartment becomes vacant would be abolished under a package of housing bills likely to be sent here by the administration of Mayor Beame.

title: Anglican Church Enthrones Its 101st Archbishop of Canterbury
description: LONDON, Jan. 24  Dr. Donald Coggan, a slim bespectacled man of 65, struck three times on the door of Canterbury Cathedral, and was admitted to be enthroned today as the 101st Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: Ceitics Take Sixth in Row By Beating Kings, 9687
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)Dave Cowens's 20 points in the second half sparked the Boston Celtics to their sixth straight National Basketball Association triumph tonight, a 9687 verdict over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings.

title: Prince Becomes Copter Pilot
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, today qualified as a helicopter pilot.

title: BEAME WEIGHING HOUSING PACKAGE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24The state law that in effect lets a landlord charge whatever rent he chooses when a rentcontrolled apartment becomes vacant would be abolished under a package of housing bills likely to be sent here by the administration of Mayor Beame.

title: State's Health Chief Orders 2 Hospitals Here to Shut Down
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24Two private hospitals in New York City have been ordered to close, Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the acting State Health Commissioner, said today.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES TO BAR FORD STEPS ON IMPORTS OF OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The House Ways and Means Committee approved today legislation that would not only, stop President Ford from imposing higher fees on imported petroleum but would also prevent him from taking an alternative step he has been considering, establishment of restrictive quotas on imports.

title: Blood Center Begins Drive For RhNegative Donors
description: Because of a continuing low reserve of Rhesus  negative blood, the New York Blood Center has announced a yearround campaign for Rhnegative donors.

title: Hungarians Report U.S. Will Replace Ambassador
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 24  The United States Ambassador to Hungary, Richard F. Pedersen, will shortly be replaced, quailfied sources reported today.

title: Jersey Train Hits Auto
description: ALPHA, N. J., Jan. 24 (AP)A westbound Jersey Central passenger train slammed into an auto at an unmarked crossing in this Warren County community today, injuring the motorist, police said. The driver was Sesto Ferretti, 52 years old of Alpha. He was taken to Phillipsburg  Warren Hospital and listed in satisfactory condition.

title: 2 Hurt in West Side Building Collapse
description: A portion of the south wall of a partly demolished commercial building at Broadway and 96th Street collapsed yesterday evening, spewing bricks and mortar into 96th Street and injuring two persons.

title: Porcelains to Purveyors Armory Goes Antique
description: Antiques enthusiasts crowding the opening yesterday of the Winter Antiques Show found that the 59 participating dealers looked as settled as if they had been doing business in the stadiumsize Seventh Regiment Armory since this famous annual event began 21 years ago.

title: Dollar at New Low In Trailing Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 (UPI)The dollar fell to record lows today, ending the fourth week of one of its worst slumps Foreign exchange dealers said there was little expectation of an early recovery.

title: Turk Doubts Conciliation to Get U.S. Aid
description: KYRENIA, Cyprus, Jan. 24The commander of Turkish Army forces in Cyprus indicated in an interview today that there was little likelihood Turkey was prepared to make conciliatory moves before the Feb. 5 deadline for a Congressional suspension of American military aid to Turkey.

title: BRONX STORE OWNER IS SHOT IN HOLDUP
description: An armed South Bronx liquor store owner was shot three times and critically wounded eary today when he tried to resist a man and woman holdup team, the police said. The robbers were later caught.

title: Angry Opposition Is Awaiting OTB Ride Into Nassau County
description: Can we stop you? a Levittown woman asked James I. Nagourney, administrative vice president of Nassau County's new offtrack betting operation. No, he said.

title: Timken and Latrobe Sign An Agreement to Merge
description: The Timken Company, Inc., of Canton, Ohio, and the Latrobe Steel Company of Latrobe, Pa., have signed a memorandum of intent to merge Latrobe into Timken, it was announced yesterday.

title: No Justice in Jersey
description: Intervening for justice where citizens and politicians had failed, New Jersey's Supreme Court ruled in April, 1973, that heavy reliance on local property taxes had created wide disparities in education between rich and poor districts in violation of the State Constitution. Two months later the court ordered the Legislature to devise a more equitable system of financing public education by the end of last year.

title: BOMBERS CALLED INTENT ON KILLING
description: Fuerzas Armadas de Liberation Nacional, or F.A.L.N., the latest terrorist group arising from the Puerto Rican independence liberation movement, departs from the style of earlier Puerto Rican political organizations in a macabre way, according to the police. As one official said yesterday: They seem to want to kill people.

title: Dickinson Drops Dean's List
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Jan. 24 (UPI) The dean of Dickinson College, noting that grading has become more lax, says the school has decided to drop the dean's list as a means of honoring academically outstanding students. I didn't feel an honor was an honor when it embraced so many people, said Dean George J. Allan in announcing the end of the list. About 500 students, or 30 per cent made the dean's list in the spring semester last year.

title: Ford's Election Head White House Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)John R. Stiles, a retired builder who has managed all of President Ford's Congressional election campaigns, has been on the Federal payroll as a $125aday White House consultant, a Presidential spokesman has confirmed.

title: RALLY STRONGER IN BRITISH STOCKS
description: LONDON, Jan. 24  The clouds of gloom that hovered stubbornly over the British financial community for months have suddenly broken in response to a stock market rally that has astonished most of the experts because of its duration and intensity.

title: In Memoriam
description: KADINSamuel. In cherished memory of a loving and devoted father and grandfather. You will live in our hearts forever.

title: Special Prosecutor Briefly Interviews Bergman's Auditor
description: Samuel A. Dachowitz, accountant for Bernard Bergman, was questioned briefly yesterday by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy, subpoenaed by a United States Senate subcommittee and interviewed for a few minutes in the offices of Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor investigating alleged nursing home abuses.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Jan. 24, 1975

title: Officer Slain in Subway Is Buried Here
description: The muffled roll of a lone drum sounded softly as the body of the slain Police Officer Joseph R. Garcia was carried to his church yesterday morning.

title: RULE REQUIRES LIE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)One of the new reguliations safeguarding criminal records from public inspection requires employes to lie about the existenc of certain records.

title: Wanted: College pres., Eq. Op. Employer
description: The search for a college president, a somber activity once confined to weighty deliberations by tweedy academics in oakpaneled board rooms, has been extended to the classified advertising columns.

title: Two Injured as Roof an Wall Collapse
description: A portion of the roof and wall of a partially demolished, commercial building at Broadway and 96th Street collapsed yesterday evening, spewing bricks and mortar into 96th, Street and injuring two per, sons.

title: HOME TO CORRECT ITS FIRE HAZARDS
description: A Lambertville, N.J., nursing home has agreed to make firehazard corrections required by the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, thus avoiding a threatened cutoff of Medicaid funds under a new Federal policy, the agency's regional director said yesterday.

title: Hairdos That Look Relaxed
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J.  The hairdos of many suburban women seem to have changed in recent times. For one thing, they are less bouffant. Hair is softer, looserless of it is being set. and teased. They are, to put it simply, more like the easy styles one sees in New York.

title: Christian Ecumenism
description: Like longlost cousins meet ing again at a family reunion, denominationally separated Christians rejoiced in finding each other during the ecumenically minded sixties.

title: ExAide Calls Coast Reactor Unsafe
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 24 (AP)A former safety supervisor at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Eastern Washington says that the reactor there is the most dangerous in the country to work near.

title: Interest by Savings Groups On Escrow Accounts Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Federal savings and loan associations would have to pay interest on mortgage loan escrow accounts in certain states under a proposal made today by the Federal Home Loan Bank board.

title: East Or West Of Finland?
SAMUEL CLARK JR., JUSTICE AIDE, DIES
description: Samuel O. Clark Jr., an Assistant Attorney General in charge of the tax division of the Department of Justice from 1939 through 1945, died Tuesday in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 74 years old and lived in Bradenton, Fla.

title: Soaring Bank Earnings In Recession Draw Fire
People in Sports
description: Blanton Collier has been called out of semiretirement by Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, to assist the new head coach, Forrest Gregg. Collier, a Kentuckian has served as a scout of the Southeastern Conferance for the Browns since his retirement as head coach of Cleveland in 1970. His teams compiled a wonlosttied record of 76342 from 1963 though 1970 in the National Football League. He'll be in charge of quarterbacks.

title: L. I. Woman in Court Killing Ruldd Unfit to Stand Trial
description: MINEOLA, t L.I., Jan. 24JoAnne Brown of Uniondale was declared incapable of standing trial at this time on a charge of having killed Burr C. Hollister, a State Supreme Court law secretary.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Twelve Long Branch teachers and the president of the school system's custodial union were ordered to spend two days in the Monmouth County Jail for failing to obey an order to return to work during a school strike last October.

title: HOME TO CORRECT ITS FIRE HAZARDS
description: A Lambertville, N.J., nursing home has agreed to make firehazard corrections required by the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, thus avoiding a threatened cutoff of Medicaid funds under a new Federal policy, the agency's regional director said yesterday.

title: Japan Backs Arabs More Firmly, but Chides Them Over Oil Prices
Television
description: Afternoon

title: Lebanese Socialist Leads Drive For Increased Arab Aid to Egypt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24Appeals in the Arab world for additional aid to Egypt from the oilproducing nations are being led by a prominent Socialist member of Lebanon's Parliament.

title: ROWENA STEVENS, POCONO PRODUCER
description: Rowena Benson Stevens, producer for the Pocono Playhouse, a summer theater in Mountainhome, Pa. which she founded in 1947 and operated since then, died yesterday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 68 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

title: People and Business
description: Two top business leaders criticized yesterday different sections of President Ford's new economic program.

title: Smith Picks Up Scoring Slack for McAdoo
Peace on the Rails
description: The tentative peace pacts negotiated by the nation's railroads and four key unions represent welcome new steps away from the labor relations chaos that so often in the past forced Congress to grind out emergency laws to keep the trains running.

title: I. B. M. CONVICTION IN ANTITRUST CASE UPSET ON APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A Federal Court of Appeals in Denver overturned today an antitrust conviction of the International Business Machines Corporation that had ordered the giant corporation to pay $259.5million to the Telex Corporation. At the same time, the lower court's judgment against Telex in a countersuit was affirmed.

title: Wanted: College Pres., Eq. Op. Employer
description: The search for a college president, a somber activity once confined to weighty deliberations by tweedy academics in oakpaneled board rooms, has been extended to the classified advertising columns.

title: Ashe Is Upset by Fillol In Stirring 3Set Battle
Larry Fine of Three Stooges, FrizzyHaired Comic, Is Dead
description: Larry Fine, the frizzyhaired member of the Three Stooges comedy team, died yesterday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Home and Hospital in suburban Woodland Hills, Calif., after having suffered a stroke. He was 73 years old.

title: 4 Killed, 44 Injured in Fraunces Tavern Blast
description: A thundering explosion believed by the police to have been detonated by Puerto Rican nationalists ripped through a 19thcentury annex to historic Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, killing four people and injuring at least 44 others.

title: Art: Portraiture by 31 Painters
La Salle Tops Duquesne To Raise Record to 151
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP)Bill Taylor collected 23 points, and the 6foot10 inch Joe Bryant had 21 tonight to lead ninthranked La Salle to its 11th straight basketball victory, an 8879 triumph over Duquesne. La Salle has a 151 wonlost record.

title: Hospital Security Officer Slain While Stopping a Holdup Here
description: A security officer at St. Luke's Hospital was shot and killed yesterday morning when he halted a robbery of a bank delivery at the hospital.

title: Canada Says Policy Aim Is Independent Economy
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 24Canada has reconsidered her relations with the United States and decided to strengthen the economy and other aspects of national life in order to secure our independence, Allen J. MacEachen, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, said last night.

title: Notes on People
description: The president of the New Jersey Bar Association, Stanley S. Brotman of Vineland, will be nominated by President Ford to be a United States judge for the district of New Jersey, the White House announced yesterday. He succeeds Mitchell H. Cohen, who retired at 70 last August and was Camden County prosecutor before his appointment in 1962. Mr. Brotman, who is 50, has a private law practice in Vineland, where he was born and where he lives with his wife, Suzanne, and their two children. He is a graduate of Yale College and Harvard Law School.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 27yearold convict who has resisted for seven months all attempts to remove a bullet from his body was indicted on charges of murdering the police lieutenant who allegedly shot him in a Queens mugging. The suspect, John Smith of 710 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, was charged with the murder of Lieut. Henry Schmeiman who was shot fatally on the morning of June 20, 1974, in the Middle Village section while on his way to work at Police Headquarters.

title: A Bomb, Then Sirens Echo in Canyons
description: When Howard Brous heard the blast that shook the Broad Street area at lunchtime yesterday, he thought nothing of it. Such noises, he said, occur at least once a week as a result of such things as construction.

title: FortyTon Terrors
description: Three RepresentativesKoch of New York, Gude of Maryland and Hechler of West Virginiahave lost no time in moving to undo a mischievdus act of the preceding Congress. The three legislators have introduced a bill to repeal a sneakedin provision of the new Federal Aid Highway Act of 1974 allowing much heavier trucks on interstate highwaysas though they have not been monstrous enough.

title: Dr. Harry Finkelstein, 91, Orthopedic Surgeon, Dies
description: Dr. Harry Finkelstein, a retired New York orthopedic surgeon and a member of the original founding staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, where he was a former chief of orthopedic surgery, died yesterday at a nursing home in Tarrytown, N.Y. His age was 91.

title: Communists in '75 Vietnam Offensive Showing a New Flexibility
Wang Chiyuan, Painter, Calligrapher and Teacher
description: Wang Chiyuan, a painter and calligrapher who operated the School of Chinese Brushwork here since 1947, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 399 East 72d Street.

title: Financial Writers Elect
description: Sidney Rutberg of Fairchild Publications has been elected president of the New York Financial Writers Association. He succeeds William G. Flanagan of Business Week magazine.

title: The Scottsboro Case, a Lightning Flash
description: On a sunny afternoon in March, 1931, a sheriff's posse, halted a freight train passing through the sleepy north Alabama town of Paint Rock and rounded up nine black youths looking for work and charged them with raping two white prostitutes who were also on the train. Mobs gathered, the sheriff issued a call for the National Guard and the boys were transferred to a safer jail in the nearby county seat, Scottsboro.

title: WHEAT SUPPLIES IN U,S. UP SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Supplies of wheat in storage In the United, States are 19 per cent higher than they were a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: In Jackson Heights Now, Se Habla Mucho Espanol
description: Jackson Heights is still a Queens community of hedgeencircled singlefamily homes and garden apartments on quiet treelined streets. At the same time, a small number of Jackson Heights residents are responsible for what a Federal official called a great percentage of the cocaine illegally bought and sold in New York City.

title: Leading Foe of Old Regime Buried With Honor in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Gen. Humberto Delgado, leader of the opposition to Portugal's former authoritarian regime, was buried with full military honors today, 10 years after he was killed in Spain.

title: MANILA SAID TO USE NAPALM IN BOMBING
TV Reviews
description: The CBS schedule for tomorrow contains three programs of more than usual interest. The first, on the generally outstanding Camera Three series at 11 A.M., is Olympics of Dance,! a collection of filmed excerpts from the 1966 Varna International Ballet competition.

title: Patman's Career Fell Short of Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Two things were close to the heart of Wright Patman of Texas, who until this week seemed to be a power in Washington that would go on forever. They were lower interest rates and more limits on the independence of the Federal Reserve System.

title: Electric Minibus Travels On Ground and Overhead
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24A retired engineer has invented an electric transportation system that combines surface and overhead routes. A passenger will take a minibus from his home to a station where the bus is picked up and suspended by cables from a vehicle carrier that moves on a high rail structure at about 60 miles an hour. Albert B. Rypinski of Teaneck, N.J., was granted Patent 3,861,315 this week for the system. The patent is assigned to a company he formed, the DuoMode Electric Transport System, Inc.

title: Canadian Newsprint Gains
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UPI)Canadian newsprint shipments in 1974 totaled 9.9 million short tons, up 8.7 per cent from the 9.1 million tons shipped the previous year, the Canadian Pulp and Paper association said today. Canada's largest export market, the United States, imported a total of 7.2 million tons of newsprint last year, an increase of 5.6 per cent over the 6.6 million tons purchased by American buyers in 1973.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 25, 1975

title: 2 Free Throws Beat Colonels; 42 for Erving
Aim Set Higher By Stones
SOYBEAN FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Sharply higher soybean prices late in the trading session yesterday influenced higher wheat and corn prices on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Littler, Watson In Lead
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan, 24Gene Littler, who has won 25 events in his 20 years on the pro tour, and Tom Watson, who has won one tournament in three years of pro competition, took the lead today in the second round of the 34th annual Bing Crosby National proamateur golf tournaments.

title: Morton Tells West's Governors Nation Needs Their States' Coal
Court Backs Registration Of Canvassers in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24  The State Supreme Court upheld today, after ordering a little judicial pruning, two municipal ordinances that require doortodoor solicitors to register with the local police.

title: The Ethnic Aspect of Supervisory School Jobs Here
description: When the State Division of Human Rights told an East Harlem community school board earlier this month to replace a Puerto Rican woman principal with a white, nonHispanic man, it plunged into a thorny social and racial thicket that has entangled the city's educators and administrators for years.

title: Saxbe Gives Levi Briefing In 75Minute Private Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Edward H. Levi, President Ford's nominee for Attorney General, has, received a briefing on Justice Department issues and an introduction to the press corps from the man he would succeed.

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 24  The world team championship began here tonight, with five countries fighting for the title.

title: Oil Producers Meet in Algiers With Bid That West End Threat
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 24Algeria's Foreign Minister, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, opened a meeting of oil exporting countries here today by saying they would cooperate to overcome world inflation and poverty if industrial nations gave up threats of military intervention and economic confrontation.

title: Hospital Security Officer Slain Here Halting Holdup
description: A security officer at St. Luke's Hospital was shot and killed yesterday morning when he halted a robbery of a bank delivery at the hospital.

title: Recital
Dow Average Gains by 9.85 Points as Volume Climbs
description: The stock market, spurred by a further decline in interest rates, made a broad advance yesterday as trading increased.

title: Caldwell Is First In Nordic Skiing
description: GRANTHAM, N. H., Jan. 24 (AP)Tim Caldwell of Putney, Vt., a member of the United States Nordic ski team, won the 30kilometer race today at the Eastern crosscountry championships.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The revolution in men's clothes is revving up again. Halston showed the time was ripe when he displayed his first men's wear collection earlier this month, touching on everything from sweaters to evening clothes.

title: ANALYSIS DISPUTES FORD ON ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24A Library of Congress analysis released today by two liberal Democratic Representatives held that President Ford's energy plan, if enacted by Congress, would raise the Consumer Price Index by 3 per cent, not the 2 per cent postulated by the Administration.

title: Thompson Takes Blame for Defeat by Hays
description: WASHINGTON  Repre sentative Frank Thompson Jr. came back to his office Thursday afternoon with a new, shorterstyled haircut.

title: SAUL K. WOLPF
description: Saul K. Wolff, retired president of the Wolff Appliance Company, Long Island City, Queens, and a former president of the Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital, died Thursday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Aid to Saigon
description: From the very beginning of American involvement in Vietnam, the fundamental error has been the emphasis placed on a military solution to what was essentially, for most of the time, a political problem. The Ford Administration appears to be drifting into a repetition of that mistake.

title: Books of The Times
description: The general image of slavery in the antebellum South that has come down through the years was formed by the Abolitionists in the North. I will be as harsh as truth, and as uncompromising as justice, wrote William Lloyd Garrison in the first issue of The Liberator in 1831. He said that on the subject of slavery he would not think or write with moderation. Another New Englander set the moral tone with a novel that unloosed emotions. So you're the woman who started this war, President Lincoln, so the story goes, jestingly greeted Harriet Beecher Stowe.

title: Guard Mans Air Defense As Pentagon Trims Cost
description: OTIS AIR FORCE BASE, Mass.Ten years ago, this Air Force base on the shoulder of Cape Cod bristled with supersonic interceptor planes, Bomare antiaircraft missiles and atomic warheads hidden in concrete bunkers behind the scrub pine.

title: A Seductive Duet Danced by Antonio And Miss Holmes
description: Georgiana Holmes and Juan Antonio danced a lyrically sinuous duet, Dreamers, that was intelligently developed and seductively caressing to the eye at their joint concert Thursday evening at New York University's School of Education auditorium.

title: White House Denies Army Is Preparing Forces for Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24President Ford's press secretary categorically denied today that the United States was preparing three army divisions for possible use in the Middle East.

title: Misplaced Rigidity
description: President Ford is forcing a destructive confrontation by his refusal to consider the mounting objections in Congress and state houses to his plan for taxing petroleum imports. The problems of energy and economic revival urgently require cooperation with Capitol Hill, as the President himself has stressed; yet he is rubbing the wrong way even those legislators who might be inclined to meet him more than halfway.

title: DEMOCRATS REACH LOW TV AUDIENCE
description: Although leaders of the Democratic party received prime time from the three television networks this week to reply to President Ford's televised preview of his State of the Union Message, they reached a substantially smaller audience with three separate telecasts than President Ford did with one.

title: White House Denies Army Is Preparing Forces for Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24President Ford's press secretary categorically denied today that the United States was preparing three army divisions for possible use in the Middle East.

title: The Only Original Broadway Joe
description: The original Broadway Joe was back in New York yesterday, and with his arrival the years peeled away like the leaves of an artichoke. The real Broadway Joe, last name DiMaggio, was in town in connection with a syndicated weekly television series called Paul Hornung's Greatest Sports Legends, which starts on Channel 9, Feb. 4 at 10:30 P.M. Hornung, Golden Boy of the Green Bay Packers backfield when the late Vince Lombardi's teams dominated professional football. is a golden voice on the airwaves now, and his series is an exercise of nostaglia in which he interviews DiMaggio, Sam Snead, Jack Kramer, Gale Sayers and others duly licensed as living legends. Last putout of the 1936 World Series, a guy said to DiMaggio before the luncheon in Gallagher's where Hornung showed the film he and Joe had made. What was in your mind?

title: Reporter Covering Fire Dies
description: LEOMINSTER, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)  A newspaper reporter collapsed and died today while covering a tenement fire. Officials said that John H. Ekengren, 49 years old, a reporter for The Fitchburg Daily Sentinel and Leominster Enterprise, collapsed at the fire station while gathering information on the fire. Killed in the fire was Victor Monfils, 81.

title: Market Place
description: The surprisingly strong performance of lowpriced stocks so far this year has raised hopeshowever faintthat the worst of the bear market may be over.

title: GOING OUT Guide
W.H.O. Says Smallpox Has Decreased by 90%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Two Years After His Election, Miners Criticize Miller
Social Security Benefits to Top Receipts in '76, Panes Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24An advisory council of prominent private citizens reviewing the Social Security System said today that benefits would start to exceed tax receipts next year by several billion dollars.

title: Car Rebates Aid Westchester Dealers
SOVIET GOODS LAG AS ECONOMY GAINS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24The Soviet Union reported today that it had made economic progress in 1974, but figures released in the official Government report disclosed that there were numerous failures to meet goals for increased production of consumer goods.

Porcelains to Purveyors, Armory Goes
