description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24The Soviet Union reported today that it had made economic progress in 1974, but figures released in the official Government report disclosed that there were numerous failures to meet goals for increased production of consumer goods.

title: 4 Researchers Link U.S. Tornadoes To Driving on Right Side of the Road
description: An article in a scientific journal published in Britain, where people drive on the left, suggests that some American tornadoes occur because people in the United States drive on the right.

title: Miss Nadig Captures Downhill Skiing
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 24 (AP)MarieTherese Nadig, the Olympic nemesis of Annemarie Proell, struck again today by beating the Austrian ski ace in the World Cup downhill, a test race for the 1976 Winter Olympics.

title: Kissinger Asks Congress Partnership
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Secretary of State Kissinger, alarmed by the Administration's deteriorating relations with Congress, called today for a new national partnership to avoid domestic confrontations over foreign policy and to achieve agreement on specific issues.

title: Guard Mans Air Defense As Pentagon Trims Cost
Harold Sherburne, Investment Banker, Killed in Bombing
description: Harold H. Sherburne, a prom inent Wall Street investment banker and partner in charge of the New York office of Bacon, Whipple & Co., was killed yesterday in the lunchtime bombing at Fraunces Tavern. He was 66 years old and had lived at 480 Park Avenue and in Pine Orchard, Conn.

title: 9 AMERICANS OUSTED FOR SAIGON PROTEST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 25Nine American antiwar activists were deported from South Vietnam last night after they had staged a surprise demonstration in front of the United States Embassy.

title: FLU DEATH EPIDEMIC SPREADING TO COAST
description: ATLANTA, July 24 (UPI)Deaths from influenza remained above the epidemic threshold for the second consecutive week, with the disease spreading to the West Coast for the first time this winter, the National Center for Disease Control reported today.

title: Dianne Fromholtz a Rising Star on Courts
description: With Evonne Goolagong resting an injured wrist and Billie Jean King quitting the Virginia Slims circuit, the women's tennis field seems to be clear for Chris Evert. But one never knows When some youngster will find the groove and cause trouble for the favorite.

title: Growing Recession Is Threatening Some Job Gains Made by Disabled Workers
description: ALBERTSON, L. I. The growing recession is threatening some of the gains made by disabled workers in recent years. According to Federal figures, job placement of disabled workers in the United States dropped 39 per cent from 1973 to 1974, and now layoffs are also affecting the disabled.

title: Egypt's LongRange Plans Beset by ShortTerm Woes
description: CAIROIsmail Fahmy, the Foreign Minister of Egypt, told his French counterpart recently that Egypt had received from Gulf states and Iran pledges of credits and loans totaling about $3billion for industrial and agricultural development projects.

title: Explosion Puts Spotlight on a Block of City History
description: Had the explosion last Friday in the 19thcentury building adjacent to Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan been more severe, it might have managed to do what severar realestate concerns have been trying to do for some time: level one of New York's most historic blocks. But the blast was less severe than the high number of casualties it caused would suggest, and it did no structural damage to any of the block's buildings.

title: Richard C. Quittmeyer Is Fiance Of Denise E. Packer, Geologist
description: Denise Edwina Packer, an assistant geologist with Dames & Moore, consultants in the environmental and applied earth sciences, and Richard Charles Quittrneyer, a Ph.D. candidate in the department of geological sciences it Columbia University, plan to be married Aug. 16 in Livingston, N. J.

title: RUSSIANS COMPLETE 2D WEEK IN SPACE
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (Reuters) The two Soviet astronauts aboard the orbiting Salyut 4 space station completed their second week in space today. There was no indication when they plan to return to earth.

title: CLINIC FUND TRIAL ENDS IN DEADLOCK
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
2 Carver Chairs for Sale
description: A Carver Chair has long been a rarity in the antiques market, and its rarity is compounded when its place of origin is New Jersey.

title: MAJOR OIL STATES DECIDE ON SUMMIT TO DEFINE POLICY
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 25  The major oilexporting countries agreed to hold a meeting of their chiefs of state here in about five weeks, and postponed until then any decisions on negotiations with oil consumers.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Taxi cab drivers, bankers, academicians and small children invariably react in the same fashion when one identifies oneself as a film critic. What a peculiar way for an adult to make a living! Being ordered to the movies and then being paid for it. The kids, especially, are wonderstruck. In their minds it's not much different from being forced to eat popcorn eight hours a day. What a way to go! The job isn't all that simple, however. The following are some average days from a critic's diary.

title: A RecordSetting Dragster Ride Puts Mrs. Murphy in the Movies
description: Paula Murphy has been billed as the fastest woman on wheels since 1973 when she rocketed to a record 258 miles an hour in a dragster at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah.

title: Hood, a Do It Yourself Sailor, Reaches Top After 25 Years
description: When the softspoken sailor from Marblehead, Mass., couldn't find a job in a sail loft, he started his own. And now, 25 years later, Ted Hood has reached the top.

title: Pollution Fight Is Hurt by Engineer Shortage
description: TRENTONA shortage of engineers in the State's Department of Environmental Protection has blocked for more than two years New Jersey's efforts to obtain $311million in Federal funds for the construction of projects to control water pollution.

title: The Earthy Appeal of Pot Making
Fashion
description: Clever women have discovered that antique clothes have a magnificent cut and handdone details not often found in clothes these days. While antique dresses aren't necessarily inexpensive, they are elegant, oneofakind fashion.

title: Around the World in a Helicopter
description: HICKSVILLEA businessman here is planning to celebrate the nation's bicentennial next year by doing something that has never been done before.

title: 'Round the Globe the Long Way
Michigan Upholds an Ecology Law That Lets Citizens Halt Harmful Projects
description: LANSING, Mich., Jan: 25The Michigan Supreme Court this week unanimously upheld the state's 1970 Environmental Protection Act, which grants citizens the right to file suit to stop projects that may damage the environment.

title: U.S. Boxers Beat Soviet Team, 54
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 (AP)Leon Spinks of St. Louis outslugged Oleg Kartayev of the Soviet Union and lifted the United States to 5.4 victory in international amateur boxing tonight.

title: Frederick O. Nicholson Fiance Of Marian McCowin Mitchell
description: The engagement of Marian McGowin Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. MacNeil Mitchell of New York and East Hampton, L. I., to Frederick Ogden Nicholson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Elden Nicholson of San Bernardino and Laguna Beach, Calif., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: The Iceberg Hermit
description: The situation looked hopeless. Shipwrecked, alone, 17yearold Allan Gordon seemed doomed to freeze to death or die of hunger or thirst. Even if he found food, water and shelter, how could he endure an Arctic winter?

title: Throughout the World, the Show Must Go On
description: Football  in its many formson television is a Sunday afternoon epidemic of leisure. TV itself is a nightly narcotic. The theater attracts people everywhere with its inventions and its revivals. The spread of vast thematic amusement parks is to some a blight but to others a joy. Circuses and bullfights and championship tennis and dog races divert us. And because sports are so much with us, they are perforce big business.

title: Susan Tancer Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Susan Tancer to Leslie Robert Tolchin, son of Mrs. John Tolchin of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late Mr. Tolchin, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Tancer of Scarsdale, N.Y. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Gerulaitis and Riessen Attain Pro Net Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25Maybe Vitas Gerulaitis really is Bjorn Borg. Maybe this whole week has been some sort of puton, with the two young players switching roles for laughs.

title: SHEIK MUJIB GETS TOTAL AUTHORITY OVER BANGLADESH
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 25 Bangladesh, a fledging democracy of 75 million people, adopted an authoritarian Presidential form of government today.

title: Builders Try New Steps To Boost Home Sales
description: WHITE PLAINS  A few months ago, the Robert Martin Corporation was selling four condominiums a week in the 500unit development known as High Point of Hartsdale. Now we are selling two a week, says Martin Berger, the corporation's tall, assertive president. We have to restore some confidence in our potential buyers.

title: Armed Forces Recruitment Increases With the Help of a Sagging Economy
description: Rising unemployment and an uncertain economy have helped push recruiting figures beyond the goals set by the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force.

title: YUGOSLAV PRESS CONDEMNING U.S.
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20Despite Yugoslavia's proclaimed policy of nonalignment, the stridently antiAmerican tone of the country's controlled press has become even harsher than that in the Soviet bloc.

title: Negotiating With the P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTONAs part of his effort to find some rational solution to the Middle East conflict, Nathan YalinMor, visited me in Washington in December. Nathan YalinMor is an Israeli, a man who both looks and sounds extremely kind, and is, I am convinced, totally committed to a Middle East peace.

title: Derek Meets The Legend
description: In the quiet after midnight, the bar was still busy at Duncan's on East 53d Street, but most of the dinner crowd had departed. At the piano, Bill Halsey was tinkling the theme from The Sting and at a small table Toots Shor was drinking brandy and soda while he talked with a few friends.

title: Second Suspect, Also Wounded, Is Seized in Slaying of Hospital Guard Here
description: A second wounded suspect was arrested yesterday in the holdup murder of a security guard by two men Friday in front of St. Luke's Hospital. His alleged accomplice was listed in critical condition.

title: Nancy Jean Steinhardt Betrothed
description: Nancy Jean Steinhardt, a psychiatric social worker at the New York Medical College Mental Retardation Institute in Valhalla, N.Y., will be married April 5 to Stephen Fuzesi Jr., who is with the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell here.

title: Students and Parents Innovate to Meet Rises in College Costs
description: MADISONLast September, when the economic outlook was far less bleak than it is today, six students at Drew University consigned to the school their earnings from parttime jobs to be held during the academic year. The consignments were made in lieu of paying tuition directly and in one or more lump sums.

title: D. L. Massee Jr. And Gail Lione Plan to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. James G. Lione of Little Neck, L.I, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Ann Lione of Philadelphia and Atlanta, to David Lurton Massee Jr., son of Mr. Massee, Mayor of Marshallville, Ga., and the late Minnie George Fokes Massee. The wedding is planned for March in Philadelphia.

title: Linda Ronstadt Is Surer Now
7 Nobel Laureates Urge Search for Alternatives to Capitalism
description: Seven American and European winners of the Nobel Prize said yesterday that the current economic crisis in the advanced industrial democracies raises serious questions about the very nature of the economic systems in these societies.

title: Mansfield Urges President To Consult with Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that President Ford should consult more with key congressional Democrats, and warned that a confrontation between the executive and legislative branches would be counterproductive.

title: Design
description: It is time to celebrate nearhistory. It is time to look back 50 years to the world of tomorrow. Predicting the form of the future was serious business in the nineteentwenties. But it is not a world that the world of today would recognize, based as it was on the perfectability of man and a technology for creating noble, shining cities and universal peace. From the state of mind to the state of the city, we live in another world entirely.

title: Correction
description: A summary of President Ford's economic proposals in the Jan. J9 issue of The Week in Review erroneously implied that Mr. Ford and the automobile industry had reached final agreement on a timetable to improve carengine efficiency. The summary should have added that the agreement is subject to the passage of legislation by Congress.

title: Congressmen Sniff Peril to Clean Air Act
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the Senate Public Works Committee and House Commerce Committee who wrote the 1970 Clean Air Act have been reading the texts of amendments to it that the Administration will send up, and they are not happy.

title: The Little Girl Next Door Grows Up
description: All through the 1950's and 60's Barbara Cook was the ideal Broadway musical ingenueblonde, applecheeked and petite with a sweet, belllike soprano.

title: Rabin Says Arabs Would Find Israel Generous in Negotiations
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 25Premier Yitzhak Rabin said tonight that if the Arab countries held peace negotiations with Israel, they'll find us more generous than they think.

title: New & Novel
description: Years of the Hungry Tiger

title: ART VIEW
description: Fifty years after the publication of Andr Breton's First Surrealist Manifesto, the revaluation of Surrealism continues to be one of the focal interests of the current art season. We have already had a sizable exhibition devoted to the work of Yves Tanguy; the Man Ray retrospective remains on view at the New York Cultural Center; and next month (opening on Feb. 14 at the Guggenheim Museum) we shall be seeing the most comprehensive exhibition ever mounted of the work of Max Ernst. Meanwhile, a large exhibition of paintings, sculpture and drawings by another celebrated representative of the movement, the Chileanborn Roberto Matta Euchaurren, known simply as Matta, has come to the Andrew Crispo Gallery. Entitled Matta: A Totemic World end consisting of nearly 70 items, it is the most ambitious survey of the artist's work we have seen in New York since the 1957 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Italians Register Two Victories In Title Bridge Qualifying Play
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 25Italy made a strong start in defense of her world bridge team championship here, and led after two rounds of qualifying play. After winning their first match last night against France, 164, the Italians, spearheaded by Benito Garozzo and Giorgio Belladonna, crushed Indonesia, 100 today.

title: Dutch Devise Wary Energy Policy
description: THE HAGUE, the NetherlandsIn energypoor Western Europe, where most governments are trying to reduce oil use anddevelop crash programs to use more nuclear power and natural gas, the Netherlands is doing almost the opposite:

title: For Contrabandistas, Record Activity
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaMost commodities produced or traded in Latin America normally move on two levels, either along commercial channels or through the hands of smugglers.

title: Under Fluorescent Lights Indoors
PRIVATE TUTORING WORRIES MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 25The specter of private enterprise is haunting the Moscow high school system.

title: Mexico, After Brisk Economic Growth, Is Fearful of Impact of U.S. Recession and New Trade Curbs
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23Despite an unexpectedly high economic growth rate last year, Mexico is beginning to feel the effects of the recession in the United States and is becoming concerned about its eventual impact.

title: Plane Forced Down by Fire
description: MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP)  The rear engine of a Northwest Orient 727 burst into flames shortly after takeoff last night, forcing an emergency landing at Miami International Airport, the authorities said.

title: CITY ASKED TO CUT ITS CONTRACTORS
description: A municipal contract for $3.8million goes to a private firm to maintain parking meters. Other contracts are let to plant, remove and prune trees. Still another contract, this one for $10million, is signed for street resurfacing.

title: Kansas Convicts Receive 'Awareness Training
description: LANSING, Kan.It appeared to be a typical scene in a typical sensitivity training exercise: five people, men and women, black and white, grouped around a table, forbidden to speak, assigned to complete a puzzle before them by turning the jumble of yellow pieces into five equal squares, so each would have one.

title: Most Draft Evaders and Deserters in Canada Reject Ford's Amnesty Plan
description: TORONTO, Jan. 25As President Ford's conditional amnesty program nears its scheduled expiration, most of the draft evaders and deserters that it was intended to coax back from Canada are still here, with no plans to return.

title: Gregory Bruett Weds Miss Jelliffe
Arab Boy and Girl Hurt By Error in Gaza Strip
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 25 (AP)Israeli soldiers accidentally shot and wounded an Arab boy and girl in the occupied Gaza Strip today following a grenade attack that missed the soldiers, but set their jeep afire, the Israeli command reported.

title: NEEDIEST RECEIVE ANNIVERSARY GIFT
description: The Dempsey Clan of White Plains sent $63 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and said the money had been rounded up to commemorate your 63d anniversary.

title: Greeks Ask Where the Tourists Are
description: ATHENS  Everybody's shakey, said a tourist promoter recently. We're all looking for help.

title: Builders Fight License Law
description: RIVERHEADCalling the new Suffolk law licensing home improvement concerns too costly and unnecessary in the rural parts of the county, East End contractors will take their protest to the County Legislature when it meets here Tuesday.

title: ExMayor Whitton of Ottawa, Women's Rights Fighter, Dead
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 25 (AP) Former Mayor Charlotte Whitton, a fiery campaigner for women's rights, died today in a hospital here, She was 78 years old.

title: Two Years of Drift?
description: In his State of the Union Message, and again in his news conference last week, President Ford stressed his belief that the Federal Government's financial situation precludes starting any new programs that cost money and, furthermore, requires a cutback in many existing programs. The only exceptions to this rule are energy development and the military.

title: Barbara S. Lewis To Wed in March
Buildings Unit Orders Hearing On 96th Street Wall Collapse
Kissingers Visit Nixon at San Clemente
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. Jan. 25 (UPI)Secretary of State Kissinger had a long visit with his old boss, former President Richard M. Nixon,yestegday before beginninga private weekend in Palm Desert, Calif.

title: Mansfield to Run Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that my intention is to seek reelection from Montana in 1976. Senator Mansfield, 71 years old, is serving his fourth sixyear Senate term after 10 years in the House. He has broken all records for tenure as the Senate's majority leader, a position he has held since January, 1961.

title: Rams Have 4 of First 28 Picks In N.F.L. College Draft Tuesday
description: The Atlanta Falcons, a football team starting all over again from the bottom floor of the National Football League, will make the first move on Tuesday at the N.F.L.'s annual draft of college seniors who want to play football for real money.

title: Mail: Showmansip And Spiking a Ball
description: To The Editor:

title: Jeffrey Medoff Fiance of Debra F. Silber
description: The engagement of Debra Fran Silber to Jeffrey Roy Medoff has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gene Silber of Teaneck, N. J., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Sherwood Medoff, also of Teaneck.

title: Our money abroad
description: Money traders are the athletes of the financial world. The salaries the best of them command are monumental, and there is often highly competitive bidding among banks for a trader's services. Glamour accrues to these speculators from the foreign places they are in touch with hourly and from the seemingly cavalier way their multimillion dollar deals are made over the telephone. And when their careers are ever it is often their bodies that do them in: hearts and stomachs unable to stand another one of these casual deals. There are no elderly money traders, the stories go.

title: Eastern Bloc Plays the Role of an Economic Conquerer
MUSIC VIEW
description: Alittle offaxis hopping in recent weeks saw this Westsider going across town to look into the Light Opera of Manhattan at the Jan Hus Theater, and then downtown to gaze upon the latest ForemanSilverman extravaganza at the Westbeth Theater. The Light Opera of ManhattanLOOM, as it calls itselfwas doing Gilbert and Sullivan, as it has been doing the last seven years. Princess Ida was the operetta in Question.

title: Crown Bearers Are Attendants Of Darya Hoare
description: LONDON, Jan. 25Darya Hoare was married here today to JeanPierre Galy at the Russian Orthodox Church of the Assumption and All Saints in Knightsbridge. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael Fortounatto.

title: Albany Mall's Space Inadequate for State Workers
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25Even after the six marble office buildings of the Albany mall are finished this year, the state will have to continue to rent more than half a million square feet of private office space in Albany for some 3,000 state workers who will not be able to fit into the mall or the state office complex northwest of the Capitol.

title: Archeologists Find A Tomb Near Cairo Linked to Horemheb
French Minister Wins Poll
description: Special to The New York Times

title: One company one season
description: The Library of Congress cheekily classifies dance as nothing but a sport and shelves the subject somewhere between crossword puzzle collections and tracts on football strategies. This is one similarity not mentioned by Joseph H. Mazo in the occasional musings on the relationship between the two arts which pepper his portrait of a season with the New York City Ballet. Although dance and sports comparisons do occur in this study of a company (both are difficult, both are dangerous, both are smelly, etc.), Dance Is a Contact Sport actually has not much to do with sports and everything to do with dance.

title: Bucher, Retired Pueblo Skipper, Is Writing a Novel of Sea Life
description: POWAY, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) The novel is coming slowly. Lloyd M. Bucher wants it to be funny, the story of a torpedoman second class at work and play.

title: The Doctor's First and Last Prizefight
description: You can't always believe what they tell you, Dom Bufano was telling a visitor as he wrapped the hands of his fighter, Johnny Sullivan. They tell you the man you're fighting's a stiff, that he has a losing record, that he's had only a few fights. We don't know nothing about the guy we're fighting tonight except that he's a doctor, a veterinarian. They had him on TV and said it was his first fight, but you can't believe them.

title: 60 JERSEY VOTERS TELL IT TO BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25Dennis Fordham of Somerset asked Governor Byrne today for county Job.

title: Ohio Publisher and Four Others Die in Washington Plane Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25(AP) Three prominent residents of Columbus, Ohio, including the publisher of The Columbus Dispatch, were among five persons killed today when a twinengine plane struck a broadcasting tower, exploded and crashed on the American University campus, officials at the newspaper reported.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Only a handful of musicians ever reach the point where they are given virtual carte blanche to record whatever they please. Judging from his voluminous output, Daniel Barenboim appears to be among the one few and, at 32, he is probably one of the youngest artists ever to enjoy such autonomy. About ten years ago, the Argentinaborn Israeli pianist settled in London, quickly establishing himself as a prominent personality in that city's musical life and a frequent visitor to recording studios.

title: Guilty of 2 Murders in 62
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (UPI)  William Macumber, founder and former commander of the Maricopa County sheriff's search and rescue posse, was convicted yesterday on two counts of first degree murder in the slaying of a man and woman 12 years ago. The bodies of Joyce Sterrenberg and James McKillop, both 20 years old, were found on the desert north of Scottsdale, Ariz., on May 24, 1962.

title: Two East Side Synagogues Are Expanding
description: Two East Side synagogues are planning or have begun expansions of religious, educational and social facilities. Construction is under way for a $6million cultural center and day school for Park East Synagogue  Congregation Zichron Ephraim at 164 East 68th Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues. The eightstory structure will be linked at three levels with the congregation's 84yearold Byzantinestyle temple at 163 East 67th Street.

title: FOOD BASKET COST ROSE 14% IN 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The average wekly cost of a consumer food market basket Jumped 14 per cent in 1974, according to preliminary figures released Friday by the Department of Agriculture.

title: VIETNAM REFUGEES PUT AT 1.4 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Continued fighting in South Vietnam has displaced 1.4 million new refugees in the two years since the Vietnam ceasefire agreement was signed, a Senate subcommittee said today.

title: Christopher R., $3, Wins Stryker by 1 Lengths
AROUND THE Garden;
Man's Best Friend Is the Sofa's Enemy
And Now, 1975 Passes in Review
Child to the Oppenheimers
description: A daughter was born on Jan. 2 to Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Oppenheimer of Nutley, N. J., in the Clara Maass Memorial Hospital in Belleville, N. J. Mrs. Oppenheimer is the former Phyllis Eisenstadt.

title: 4Hour Checkup Finds Ford in Excellent Health
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25President Ford was pronounced in excellent health today after a routine annual physical checkup at the Naval Medical Center in nearby Bethesda, Md. He was told there was no need to change his daytoday living habits.

title: Madrid Shuts Down Its Nightlife Earlier To Save on Energy
description: MADRID, Jan. 25The Government is trying to save energy by getting the people of this city of night owls to bed earlier, beginning tomorrow night.

title: The World
description: China has adopted a new state Constitution that in effect tells how the Communist party intends to govern the country in the future. Even though MaoTsetung was not present as 2,864 delegates to the National People's Congress adopted the charter, it institutionalizes his policies.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)O. A. (Bum) Phillips, a 51yearold Texan known in the southwest for devising football defenses as tough as. his leather coat and shined boots, was promoted today from defensive coordinator to head coach of the Houston Oilers.

title: American Indian Council Seeks U.N. Accreditation
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 25In the name of 103 American Indian tribes, a group has set up an office nearby and is seeking United Nations attention to its longstanding territorial claims and demands for sovereignty.

title: High Jobless Rate in Suffolk Tied to Metropolitan Economy
Article 3  No Title
Liquori Followed His Pattern In Two  Mile Triumph on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 There is a big difference between running and racing, and no one demonstrates it better than Marty Liquori, who came from nearly half a lap behind to beat John Ngeno in the twomile run at the San Francisco Examiner Games last night at the Cow Palace.

title: JACKSON REBUFFS FORD ON RUSSIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan: 25 Senator Henry M. Jackson criticized the Ford Administration. today for trying to blame Congress for the breakdown in the SovietAmerican trade agree ment of 1972.

title: Field for Today's Prix d'Amerique Lacks Glitter of Past Years
description: PARIS, Jan. 25Every year around Prix d'Amrique time, the French have sipped their cognacs and proudly announced how much they would bet on Une De Mai, Tidaleum PeIo, Jamin or Ozo. Recently, though, the pride and romance have begun to made.

title: A Hungry World Struggles For More Food
description: THE fight for food is intensifying. An increasingly hungry world was harassed last year by spreading scarcities and rising prices. On top of skimpy harvests and enormous demand came the soaring cost of petroleum, needed to make fertilizer and to run agricultural machines.

title: Ford Accepts Resignation of Prosecutor of Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) sPresident Ford accepted today the resignation of George Beall, who prosecuted former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew on charges of income tax evasion. Mr. Beall resigned as the United States Attorney for the district of Maryland.

title: Economy vs. the Environment
description: TRENTONAs New Jersey sinks deeper into recession, the Legislature is close to final action on a bill that would require state agencies to assess the economic effects of their actions.

title: Utilizing Inflation In Latin America
description: BUENOS AIRESInflation is many things to many people. In the industrialized nations, East or West, it is being fought as a disease that could undermine economic systems.

title: Compromise Can Wait
description: For the moment, only lip service is left to enhance the spirit of cooperation President Ford and the Democrats in Congress said they would employ in producing a comprehensive program to improve the economy. The nature of that program is clearly going to evolve partly through necessary compromise, but mainly through political struggle.

title: Grow Up, Oedipus!
Sunday Observer
description: Dr. Gallup tells us the 10 most admired people in America are nine politicians and Billy Graham. I doubt it.

title: Bones Found in Odessa Of Prehistoric Animal
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 25 (Reuters)Builders reconstructing the old part of the Black Sea port of Odessa have discovered the remains of a singlehumped camel believed to have been killed by a sabertoothed tiger twoandahalf million years ago.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONBuried in the White House fact sheet on President Ford's energy program is a line that says the legislation the President seeks from Congress will include standby authority to increase production of domestic oil in an emergency.

title: A SALARY CUT SET BY MISS KRUPSAK
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25Puzzled and a trifle resentful at what she thinks is inordinate attention focused on her finances, family and offitial, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak plans to refuse $21,000 of her combined, $75,000 salary and expense allowance.

description: Canada

Byrne Meets Public
description: Governor Byrne met individually with 60 of his constituents in his office at the New Jersey House in an attempt to get closer to the voters. Page 19.

title: Gay Nagle Is Bride of Merrill T. Myers
description: Gay Trabue Nagle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Nagle of Houston and Merrill Thompson Myers of New York were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Lawrence Prast in the Chapel of the Beloved Disciple of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Through the Length of Africa, Change and Uncertainty

description: Thirty tenants of a luxury apartment building on the East Side are still locked in battle with their landlord nine months after he informed them he would automate their elevator so he could dismiss three employes.

title: Mecca Is Costliest City for Visitors, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25 (Reuters)  London has caught up with New York in living costs for the shortterm visitor, while Mecca, the Saudi Arabian place of pilgrimage, has become the world's most expensive city, according to the latest United Nations tables.

title: The Permanent War Economy
description: The New Deal did not end the Depression; World War II did, and the memory of that fact has had a profound effect on postwar politics. Critics of our enormous military establishment have pointed out the evil things it can cause (Asian war, nuclear annihilation) and the noble things it prevents us from doing (housing for the poor, etc.), but the critics have not managed to shake the unspoken public belief that largescale, even profligate military spending is a cornerstone of American prosperity.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Not long after Burt Ross, the $5,000ayear Mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., reported rejecting a $500,000 bribe offer by builders last May, he disappeared with his wife from public view. Federal marshals put him under guard at a hideaway because he was a potential court witness against the builders and his life had been threatened.

title: Coast Group Seeks Nuclear Plant Curb
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25While President Ford has been calling for the development of nuclear energy, a California environmental coalition reported this week that it was well on the way to qualifying a ballot proposition that could end atomic power generation in the state.

title: Catherine Sealy to Be Married To Peter Dee of Merrill Lynch
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Sealy of Dayton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Ann Sealy, to Peter Julian Dee, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Dee of Ridgewood, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: 53 EXC.I.A. AIDES JOIN DRUG AGENCY
