description: Using two Brooklyn neighborhoods as examples, a report by a nonprofit group concludes that workingclass areas are isolated from the people, services and money, which could help them to flourish as they should.

title: Ford Honored in Capital At Alfalfa Clab Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) President Ford was honored tonight at the 62d annual dinner of the Alfalfa Club, an organization of prominent men in government, business and the military.

title: Loan Helps Manila Battle Water Shortage
description: MANILAOf all the commodity shortages in today's world, Manila is afflicted with one of the most pressing a shortage of water. This has led to some anomalies:

title: Newark Airport RailBus Link Pushed
description: NEWARKGovernor Byrne has instructed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to press for a $400million, thirdrail type of transit line that would parallel existing commuter railroads and serve Newark International Airport by means of a milelong bus connection.

title: U.S. Sales Last Year Were Double Those of 1973
description: WASHINGTONRichard R. Violette, a lean, plainspoken Yankee from Presque Isle, Maine, does not look or talk like a merchant of death but rather like a career civil servant, which he is. The 49yearold Mr. Violette carries the title of Director for Sales Negotiations of the Defense Security Assistance Agency, which means he is in charge of selling arms to other countries. As such, he is undoubtedly one of the most successful, underpaid salesmen in history. At the top Civil Service salary of $36,000, he supervises arms sales that run into billions of dollars.

title: With Pensions Shaky, Retirees Look to Families
description: Pension plans are growing in a patchwork pattern around the world to cope with what was once, in a simpler time, mostly a family problem of caring for those who no longer could work.

title: LETTERS
description: In Defense of Words in Exhibits

title: A Family of Artisans Creates Cut Glass in Flemington
Vending Machines: State Controls Lax
description: There are virtually no state controls over the safety or quality of the millions of dollars of items sold to children annually through vending machines installed at shopping centers and chain stores.

title: Woman Survivor Loses Leg After Six Days in Canyon
description: VENTURA, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI)Barbaralu Wilson, 46 years old, who survived six days without food or water in a wooded canyon after an automobile accident, underwent surgery yesterday to amputate her gangrenous right leg, her doctor said today.

title: Birth Control Gains Support
description: SOME members of the family of nations, after arguing long and loudly over the problem of population pressure, are now doing something about it, even as the controversy rages on.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Fangs of Winter
description: Tomorrow night's full moon was known to the Indians of the Northeast as the Wolf Moon, a time when winter showed its fangs. The pioneer farmer took inventory at January's end and unless he had half his hay and half his wood unused he knew that cold and hunger would stalk his barns and house. He didn't bother to give a special name to January's sun, moon or stars. He opened a fresh stack of hay and cut another armload of fireplace wood.

title: Desperation Is Spreading in India and Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHITota Bibi has eight children and scant food to feed them. She came to Calcutta in a panic early last year with her family.

title: Doctor Again Held in Family's Murder
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 25 (UPI)Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald, charged by the Army five years ago with killing his wife and two daughters, then freed after a preliminary hearing, has again been charged with the slayings.

title: Mrs. A. D. Blue Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Dias Blue of New York on Jan. 13 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Blue is the former Kathryn Koshland, daughter of Stephen A. Kosbland, a partner in Loeb, Rhodes & Co., and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, and Mrs. Koshland of New York. The child, the couple's third, is named Jessica. Her father is the vice president of World Wide Information Services, Inc., a research concern.

title: Larry Coles Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Larry Cole of New York On Jan. 14 in New York Hospital. Mrs. Cole, the former Phyllis Weiner of Chicago, is librarian with WNET/Channel 13. The child, whose father is a reporter with The New York Daily News, is named Daniel Seth.

title: Very Rev. William Donaghy, ExPresident of Holy Cross
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 25 (AP)The Very Rev. William A. Donaghy, president of the College of the Holy Cross from 1954 to 1960, died here yesterday in the college infirmary. He was 65 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT EYES ITS SCHOOL CRISIS
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 25A proposed system to even out gradually some of the inequities in the financing of Connecticut's public schools appears to have no chance of becoming law in this year's regular session of the General Assembly.

title: The New Ivan: A Snobbish Consumer
description: MOSCOW  Aleksei and Larissa are typical of the rising young professional couples in the Soviet upper middleclass who have it madealmost. Their problem is not earning money, but finding something on which to spend it.

title: Princeton's Dinky Is Facing Abandonment
description: PRINCETON  With the battle cry of Save the Dinky, commuters from eight towns are pushing on three fronts to prevent the abandonment of a Penn Central shuttle line that has served this area for more than 100 years.

title: Callas onstage, Tebaldi off
description: James McCourt reorders priorities. Like La Tosca, his creatures live for art and live for love. They are operaphiles, and opera is the most important thing in the worldat last someone has had the courage to say that.

title: A Jockey Can Get Injured, but He Can't Ride Scared
description: A jockey just has to be lucky to go through his career of riding and not get seriously injured at one time or another.

title: Backhaus of U.S. Swims to 3d Title
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Sunday, Jan. 26 (AP)Jenny Turrall of Australia captured her third gold medal of the New Zealand Games today and barely missed a world swimming record in the women's 800meter freestyle.

title: Extensive Hearings To Open on Betting
description: FREEHOLD  James M. Coleman Jr., the Monmouth County Prosecutor, is one of only three lawenforcement officials in the country who are serving on a 15member commission that is charged with developing a new national policy toward gambling.

title: Wolf Sends His Fans Bouncing As J. Geils Band Delights Crowd
description: Those who might have worried that the marriage of Peter Wolf, the lead singer of the J. Geils Band, to Faye Dunaway would undercut that Boston band's raunchy bluesrock energies should have been at the Academy of Music en 14th Street on Friday night.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Four out of 10 Americans in a survey report the experience of a powerful spiritual force which seemed to lift them out of themselves
Nuclear Plant to Be Shut By High Radiation Emissions
description: CALVERT CLIFFS, Md., Jan. 25 (UPI)Maryland's largest utility will shut its Calvert Cliffs nuclear power plant Feb. 1 because of radiation emissions far above acceptable levels.

title: The Nation
description: The current fiveyear, $30.2billion program of Federal revenue sharing is not due to expire until Dec. 31, 1976, but already the plan's critics and defenders are seeking to influence the legislation required for an extension.

title: CLEANUP IS BEGUN BY RENT STRIKERS
description: For the tenants of 945 and 947 Amsterdam Avenue, they say, it's been years of no heat, days of no water, darkened hallways, rippedopen mail boxes and falling ceilings. Yesterday, they took over the two apartment houses, declared a rent strike and began to fix up the premises, hoping to make, their apartments reasonably livable.

title: CITY POST RABBI QUIT UNDER FIRE IS FILLED
description: A 50yearold rabbi who was previously employed in the City Department of Health has been named director of special projects for the Department of Social Services to replace Rabbi David Haymovitz, who resigned under pressure last month.

title: $10Million Suit Names Hefner and Companies
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI)Hugh Hefner, publisher of Playboy magazine, and some of his companies have been named in a $10million suit filed by a woman who charged that she had been injured in a fall at the Playboy Mansion West after being drugged.

title: Canada Expands Investing Controls
description: OTTAWA  Controls on foreign investments in Canada, applied since last April to takeover bids, will be extended this year to the establishment of new businesses and the expansion of existing enterprises.

title: Princeton Trackmen Retain Title
Nonpolitical Channels
description: The Office of Telecommunications Policy, created under President Nixon in 1970 to coordinate Federal activities in national and international broadcasting, has one foot in the Commerce Department and the other in the White House. Roy Ash, retiring head of the Office of Management and Budget, would like to see it shifted to Commerce where its personnel can play a technical role; President Ford plans to keep it within the Executive branch as a channel to and from the White House.

title: For Iberians, Throes of Transition
This Week in Sports
description: The Felt Forum, which used to have professional fights weekly, lights up tomorrow for an amateur program. The Soviet Union boxing team provides the opposition on an 11bout card with a United States allstar team. First bout is 8 o'clock. Tickets are $8 and $5.

title: BUSY ASIAN STRAIT BEING RECHARTED
description: Maritime experts of four Asian nations, meeting in Tokyo, are completing navigational charts for the busy Malacca Strait, where the recent grounding of a Japanese supertanker spread an extensive and damaging oil slick.

title: SUBURB POLL FINDS A DISILLUSIONMENT
description: The Regional Plan Association said yesterday that 10 years of opinion surveying had convinced it that although most Americans are moving away from old cities into suburbs and were telling pollsters they disliked cities, they are not getting what they really want.

title: Reagan Seeks Platform for White House Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25Heads turned to follow the slender, squareshouldered man who moved in graceful strides across the hotel lobby, a thoroughbred walking between his aides, two exercise ponies.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Given five to 10 years, the Chinese could dominate world markets in all their handicrafts, one of the light industries that Premier Chou Enlai said last week should receive top priority, after agriculture, in that nation's economic development.

title: Amy Wightman Is Bride
description: Amy Eileen Wightman and John Joseph Hogan, both of New York, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Ernest Hunt in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lisle M. Wightman of Tucson, Ariz. Her husband is a son of Mrs. Raymond P. Hogan of Noank, Conn., and the late Mr. Hogan.

title: INDIA STATE TENSE AFTER 74 REVOLT
description: AHMEDABAD, India, Jan. 16 Chimanbhai Patel, a pudgy, bespectacled former Chief Minister, sat in his living room, drank sweet, milky tea with several associates and gossiped and chatted over the telephone.

title: Bangladesh
At 78, Irving Maidman Wants Out
description: Irving Maidmart, long a major owner of Times Square properties, has concluded that there is no hope for the area for a decade at least and that he should get out.

title: JON GARRISON SINGS IN SCHICCHI AT MET
description: Jon Garrison, the tenor who sang the part of Rinuccio in Puccini's Gianni Schicchi at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday night, was making his official Met debutif you do not count his fall appearances as the Hotel Porter in Britten's Death in Venice. He did those as a member of the Metropolitan Opera Studio.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: As the World DevelopsA Tale of Three Cities
Rockefeller, 5 Weeks in Job, Is Totally Relaxed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25After five weeks in the VicePresidency, Nelson A. Rockefeller says that he fully understands the limitations of the job and adds, I'm totally relaxed about it.

title: Headliners
description: It's been more than four years since Ruchel Magee and three others engineered an escape from the Mann County Courthouse, taking five hostages with them. One hostage and three of the inmates were killed; Magee escaped and was later captured. Since then, a complicated series of legal actions has delayed the case. First Magee was scheduled to go on trial with Angela Davis, the black activist who was accused of supplying the weapons for the escape. But his case was severed, and he was tried an charges of murder, aggravated kidnapping and simpIe kidnapping. The trial ended in a hung jury, and he was scheduled to be retried on the simple kidnapping charge when he suddenly pleaded guilty to a charge of aggravated kidnapping. The charge carries a sentence of from one to five years; the second, a penalty of life imprisonment without parole. Since then, Magee has tried to withdraw his plea, but his request was turned down by the United States Supreme Court. Last week, he was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.

title: Price of Honey Rises in State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25 (AP)The price of honey rose more than eight cents a pound in New York State last year, compared with 1973, the state reported today. The State Crop Reporting Service said producers received 52.6 cents per pound last year, compared with 44.3 cents in 1973 and 31.5 cents in 1972. The service also said honey production dropped 3 per cent to 6.2million pounds in 1974 in New York, because of cool, wet weather.

title: Maryland Shuns Oil Talks
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 (AP)Maryland has decided not to attend a meeting tomorrow in Boston of Attorneys General of 10 Northeast states to discuss possible court action to block President Ford's tariff on imported oil. But the Deputy Maryland Attorney General, Henry R. Lord, did not rule out the possibility of joining legal action later, if it is in the interest of the state.

title: Southwest Squatters Under U.S. Pressure
description: TAOS, N.M.Last October, the United States Bureau of Land Management sent a letter to the residents of Apadoca, a Mountain village in northern New Mexico, saying that every house in town was on Government land.

title: Venezuelan Power Is Bolstered by Oil
description: CARACAS, Venezuela Wealth is nothing new to this oilrich nation of 12 million people, but international political power is. And 1974 saw Venezuela emerge as an important economic and political force in Latin America.

title: Oil Search Off Ireland Is Pursued Vigorously
Food Day: The Focus of a Cause for Everybody
description: Last summer, a high school girl asked Dr. Michael Jacobson what she could do about food prices and the world food shortages when she got back to school. Remembering the days of the civil rights and antiwar movements, Dr. Jacobson suggested that the girl organize a teachin at her school.

title: Margaret Friedrich Sets June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Otto Friedrich of Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Emily Friedrich, to Mark Lee CarsonSelman. He is the son of Mrs. Jose Martinez of Santa Fe, N. M., and Arthur Selman of Las Vegas, Nev. A June wedding is planned.

title: Rutherford Facility In Its New Home
description: RUTHERFORDThe Rutherford Museum will reopen today in its new home, the 18thcentury Yereance House at 91 Crane Avenue.

title: Sharon Ditmars Married to R. A. Zellmer
description: Sharon Montgomery Ditmars and Richard Allen Zellmer, 1973 graduates of Northwestern University, were married yesterday morning on the Northwestern campus in Evanston, Ill. The ceremony was performed in the Howes Memorial Chapel by the bride's uncle, the Rev. W. B. Heyward of the First Presbyterian Church in Dunedin. Fla.

title: For Artists, a Tax Haven in Ireland
description: DUBLIN  At last Ireland has found a way to keep her sons of prodigal talent at home.

title: CEMETERIES
description: SIX CEMETERY PLOTS. Mount Ararat CemeteryLong Island. $1800.

title: PANEL RECOMMENDS U.S.I.A. REVAMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (Reuters)A special study panel has tentatively recommended a major reorganization of the United States Information Agency that includes withdrawing its authority over the Voice of America broadcasting service. it was disclosed today.

title: A Report on The Dangers To the Right Of Free Speech
description: If there is any principle of the Constitution that more imperatively calls for attachment than any other, it is the principle of free thoughtnot free thought for those who agree with us but freedom for the thought that we hate.

title: Glenn's Man Loses As Ohio Democrats name a Chairman
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 25Ohio Democrats, ignoring charges of a bossed party from Senator John H. Glenn Jr., have elected a wealthy, young Dayton businessman and close political associate of former Gov. John J. Gilligan to be the new state chairman.

title: AztecsThunder Trade Satisfies Both Coaches
description: A dollar for a hundred, was the way Alex Perolli, coach of the San Antonio Thunder, described the deal his team made with the Los Angeles Aztecs last week.

title: Double Exacta: $57,397
description: The second Saturday of the double exacta at the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation brought a whopping $57,397.50 payoff. The double exacta is based on picking the exact onetwo finish of the featured eighth race at Bowie and in the featured ninth at Hialeah.

title: Europe, Unlike U.S., Still Likes Gold
ComputerasMapmaker
description: The blending of the ancient science of cartography with modern computer technology is providing researchers, in many fields with new ways to understand and transmit the information they gather. By using the computer for otherwise timeconsuming computations and interpolations of data, cartographers can make computer maps and charts graphically express the relationships between statistics, and dramatize these relationships for a larger reading public.

title: TV VIEW
description: Jacob Bronowski's 13part series on science, The Ascent of Man, got off to such a stately start on public television earlier this month that it seemed in slow motion: I am at the navel of the world, said Dr. Bronowski, as the B.B.C. camera panned the Omo basin of the East Africa Rift Valley and at least one member of his audience thought about lint.

title: Who played what how
description: History at its simplest is the story of past facts and in his Philharmonic: A History of New York's Orchestra Howard Shanet profits from America's love of recordkeeping to tell his story with such particularity that his book should prove extremely useful for a long time to come.

title: Middle Eastern Nations Hold the Line on Oil Prices
description: THE oilproducing countries intend to resist adamantly pressure for a reduction in the price of oil during their forthcoming talks with the industrialized consumer nations.

title: Point of View
description: The next three to six months can be expected to clarify the important and highly controversial question of To what extent, if any has the Eurocurrency system been responsible for compounding inflation during the last six years?

title: SAIGON UNITS PRESS DRIVE ON MOUNTAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 (AP)South Vietnamese Government forces met heavy resistance today to their effort to recapture a strategic mountain 55 miles northwest of here, according to reports from the field.

title: U.S. Sees Easing of World Arms Outlays
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25A United States survey made public today showed that 136 nations spent about $241billion on defense in 1973, but that the growth of world military spending has appeared to be slowing down in recent years.

title: Who's Left Holding the Bag?
description: PARISIt is an anonymous business, says gold dealer Antoine Kyrilis. Rarely does one ask the name of a customer. Yes, he recounted in his shop in downtown Paris behind the sign in the window showing prices for ingots, bars and coins that day, quite a number of people here thought the prices would go up when Americans came into the market.

title: The New IvoriansJapanese Silkworms
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory CoastA Japanese effort to introduce silk culture into Africa has shown positive results, according to managers of the project, and largescale production is getting under way at an experimental site near here.

title: Endpaper
Article 1  No Title
Baltic Nations Trying to Save Their Sea
description: COPENHAGEN  People have been talking for years about how to keep the Baltic Sea from going the way of Lake Erie. By spring they should have an idea of the state of the patient.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayMohawk Valley of K.C. allbreed, State Armory, Washington Avenue, Schnectady, N.Y.; 1,104 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Artists Leaving Suburbs
description: In 1971, when Diane Waldman, curator of exhibitions at the Guggenheim Museum, commented in the media that no art existed between the Hamptons and New York, she inflamed the sensibilities of artists in the Huntington area. In fact, 18 of them even formed the Huntington Group to prove it was not so. But now, several of them are having second thoughts.

title: Article 2  No Title
Epilogue
description: The romantic marriage of a Long Island woman and a Russian medical studentwhich had everyone's blessings, including those of Soviet Premier Aleksei N. Kosyginhas ended in divorce, it was disclosed last week. The love story began in 1970 when Debbie Brackman, a Russianlanguage major at Barnard College, was touring the Soviet Union and met Valery Kremniov. They were married in Russia the following year. Eleven days after the marriage, however, her visa expired and Mrs. Kremniov was forced to return to the United States alone. She finally appealed to Mr. Kosygin, and two months later her husband was allowed to leave the Soviet Union. Less than two years later the couple separated, and were divorced last April. Miss Bradman, now 25, said of her experience,I don't think I made a mistake by marrying, It was just a stage in my lifepart of my journey to find myself.

title: Crime, a Heavy Tax on Economies Old and New
Teaching Children Lots of Things, Musically
description: Eighty  five fifth  graders, each with a guitar, sat in a large classroom at the High Point School in Orland Park, Ill, recently, as Jo Elyn Deuehr, their language arts teacher, led them through the lyrics of the first verse of the folk song My Darling Clementine. Okay, she said, now let's go through it again, and I want you to strum your guitars every time we come to a noun.

title: Mighty Krupp Shows German Change
description: ESSEN, West GermanyKrupp, long a symbol of German economic might, has found doing business with oilproducing capitalists in Teheran and Soviet Communists in Moscow has one common denominator: They cut off your telephone conversations when they have to change recording cassettes, one of the company's negotiators said.

title: Drama Group Signs Pact With Church
description: The Masterworks Laboratory Theater, housed in Brooklyn Heights' defunct Spencer Memorial Church, has signed a contract with the New York City Presbytery to continue using the church facilities through June, 1975, according to Ray Barnitt, a theater board member.

title: College Programs Show One Is Never Too Old to Learn
description: Long Island colleges are getting together with the elderly in a variety of special programs aimed at drawing persons over 60 into the world of 18yearolds.

title: 2 SEIZED IN PARIS IN 72 HIJACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Two suspects sought since 1972 on charges of hijacking a commercial airliner that flew them to Algeria after they were paid almost $500,000 ransom, were arrested yesterday in Paris by the French police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: STAMPS
High Sugar Prices Benefiting Cuba
description: MIAMICuba's 1975 economic prospects appear to be excellent principallybecause of high world sugar prices.

title: Roses Will Blossom In Winter, If Grown
description: There are roses to grow, yearround, even in the coldest pockets of the Northeast. These are the miniatures, perfect imitations of hybrid teas and floribundas with nickel and dimesized blooms in brilliant colors. They outperform their bigger relatives with profusion, and like Florida, they are more fun in the wintertime.

title: Five Killed in Plane Crash
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Jan. 25 (UPI)A 15monthold girl was the sole survivor when a twinengine Cessna 310 crashed into a wooded area just south of Tallahassee Municipal Airport in heavy fog last night, killing five persons. The child, Holly Hill, was listed in satisfactory condition. The victims were identified as John Gary Hill, 27, the plane's pilot, and his wife, Jean Hill, 24, the baby's parents; Rufus H. Robinson, Joseph C. Robinson and William J. Felton, all in their 50's and all from Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: SCIENTISTS GATHER for MAJOR PARLEY
description: Several thousand scientists, teachers, students and laymen were gathering here yesterday to partake of that scientific smorgasbord  the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opens tonight.

title: C. M. Studley to Wed Christine C. Champey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Graham J. Champey of New York, formerly of Boston, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Christine Cathryn Champey, to Charles Martin Studley of Boston, son of Mrs. James F. Kirk of Pompano Beach, Fla., and the late Lisle C. Studley.

title: He Fears Russians More Than Israelis, Works With Kissinger
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In terms of wealth athis personal disposal, Saudi Arabia's King Faisal ibn Abdul Aziz may be the richest man who ever lived. He spends little on himself, and he radiates a remarkable melancholy. Ulcers have ravaged his flesh; his face reflects emotions that range from diffidence to disdain. He hates to talk, except to give hints.

title: Israel Profits From Phosphates, Thanks to King Hassan
description: BEERSHEBA, IsraelThe phosphate industry here last year wiped out a $30million deficit in nine months and began pilling up profits, thanks to an Arab monarch.

title: What Happened to the Gold Rush of 75?
description: The first three weeks of January, when Americans were permitted to purchase gold for the first time in 41 years, were more notable for what didn't happen than for what did.

title: john CampbellWallace To Wed Cecilia Mendez
description: Mr. and Mrs. Manuel P. Mendez of Quezon City, the Philippines, and Williston Park, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cecilia Mendez, to John Campbell Wallace of Jakarta, Indonesia, and Upper Montclair. N. J. He is the son of Mrs. Mary Lee. Wallace of Upper Montclair and of William H. Wallace of Palatine, Ill.

title: GABON IMPORTING RAILROAD LABOR
description: LIBREVILLE, GabonSome 3,000 people from droughtravaged Upper Volta have been recruited to help build a 500mile railroad in Gabon.

title: To Think the Unthinkable, Discuss the Unmentionable
description: The following are excerpts from the opening section of the Woodward Committee's report:

title: Frederick Brockway Gleason 3d Is Fiance of Ann Powell Lackey
description: Ann Powell Lackey and Frederick Brockway Gleason 3d, a grandson of the late William T. Dewart, who was president and publisher of The Sun here, will be married in March in St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: The Bankers
description: By Martin Mayer. 545 pp. New York: Weybright and Talley. $15.

title: Altar Girls Trying to Gain Acceptance
description: Canon law decrees that girls may not take the place of altar boys in the Roman Catholic mass, but the rule has been breached in a number of dioceses and church officials have been obliged to stop the practicebut not without demurrer.

title: Common Market: Too Little in Common
description: BRUSSELSThe Common Market has finally come to grips with one of its severest longrange problems  the wide variation in income levels of its 250 million citizens, who range from Eskimos in Greenland and fishermen of Sicily and western Ireland to bankers and industrialists in Paris, Hamburg and Milan.

title: Injured Officer Backed By Beame in Job Bid
description: Mayor Beame gave his wholehearted support yesterday to a bill that would halt the dismissal of Angel F. Poggi Jr., the rookie police officer injured last Dec. 11 in an explosion for which a group of Puerto Rican nationalists claimed responsibility.

title: Turmoil Now Turns To Racing Optimism
description: Even to a casual follower of the motor sports scene, it's no secret that the United States Auto Club has been going through tough times.

title: Film BoxOffice Receipts In 74 a Record $1.9Billion
description: American Moviegoers spent more money at the box offices last year than ever before, according to Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: The Leisure of the Communist Class
INVESTING
description: This coming Tuesday will see Wall Street restaging a big play of the new season after a sudden turn of events hurriedly rang down the opening curtain last November. This play seems virtually assured of hit status, thanks to immense preopening interest. Meanwhile irony and suspense are playing their part.

title: DAY SCHOOL FUNDS for JEWS URGED
description: Leaders of the Rabbinical Council of America, disappointed in their past appeals to the organized Jewish community for substantially large allocations to Jewish day schools, have proposed a new approach direct grants to qualified students whose families cannot afford the high tuition.

title: FUNDSHARING RISE for CITIES URGED
TV VIEW
description: Recently, at a lunch sponsored by American Women in Radio and Television, the guest speaker was Dan Rather. The promised subject was Broadcasting's Role in America's Political Future, but the CBS correspondent, with selfeffacing charm, politely ignored that invitation to lofty pronouncements. Being profound is tricky while your audience is still occupied with broiled chicken.

title: Steel Workers Get Raises
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (AP)About 400,000 steel workers will get a costofliving increase of 12 cents an hour on Feb. 1, I. W. Abel, United Steelworkers president, said Thursday. Another 36,355 union members in the containers industry will receive a similar raise on Feb. 15, he said.

title: Problems Mount for Byrne on State Unit for Women
description: TRENTONSome of the most ardent feminists in the state privately admit that the new, yettobeactivated Division on Women may turn out to be more symbolic than productive. But for a variety of reasons, it has become the cause clbre of women in New Jersey.

title: Folding Unit Can Be a Workbench, Sawhorse or Vise. Goes Anywhere
description: Designed to serve as portable workbench, sturdy sawhorse, folding tool stand, or multipurpose worktable that can be used anywhere, the unique workcenter pictured above also has a builtin large capacity, full length vise in the top. It can be set up at either of two heightsa 23inch sawhorse height, or a 32inch workbench height.

title: Trinidad Moves Up the Oil Ladder
description: PORTOFSPAIN, Trinldad and Tobago  The bizarre currents that carry petroleum about the Hemisphere, quickened last month after an infusion from this small nation's new oil fields.

title: Mile Victor, ShotPutter Hayes Stars
Australia Steps Up Search for Foreign Capital
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaPrime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia stated at a news conference last year: We want foreign capital.

title: Court Solves School Budget Quandary
description: TRENTONThe State Supreme Court's decision last week to give the Legislature at least eight more months to devise a new system of financing public schools in New Jersey has eliminated the chaos that surrounded the drafting of local school budgets for the school year beginning in September.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Every month seems to see a new entrant in the superhero paperback sweeps. Now we have Stark, and the first of his series is FUNERAL RITES by Joseph Hedges (Pyramid, 95 cents). John Stark is a murder machine. We find him in jail, from which he is helped to escape. Much later, infinities later, he has taken care of a master criminal and his henchmen. The writing has such transcendental goodies as: Behind his harmless facade lurked a plumbless depth of evil. Or such wonderfully stimulating dialogue as:

title: Beirut in the Computer Age
description: BEIRUT, LebanoriAkram Hannoush, a Lebanese systems engineer, has a promising new business going in the Middle East with computers that work in both Arabic and Roman characters.

title: Lining Up for a Share of the Arabs' Oil Fortune
description: ROME  Italy's economic problems probably are not as dire as President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger seemed to imply when they worried aloud recently that a certain unnamed but easily identifiable European country might collapse and need considerable United States aid in 1975. Nor are the problems as manageable as Italian Government officials like to imply whenever they ride the international circuit in search of yet another loan.

title: Heather Watts Is Joyous In City Ballet's Scherzo
description: Some ballets surprise by their durability, staying on longer in repertory than might have been anticipated and displaying a real, if modest, strength. Jerome Robbins's Scherzo Fantastique from the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Festival has endured with its somewhat florid costumes intact. Saturday afternoon it welcomed Heather Watts and Daniel Levans as its lovely lead couple at the New York State Theater.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Common Cause, the public  interest lobby Whose many goals include reforming the country's state legislatures, has called on the New Jersey Legislature to get tough with itself and enact strong, new laws pertaining to the financing of election campaigns.

title: Into the Quagmire Again
description: President Ford closed his interview with the National Broadcasting Company on a chilling note. Despite repeated prodding by John Chancellor (Does it make you uneasy to sit on that couch in this room and have experts in Vietnam saying, Only a little bit more and it will be all right?'), Mr. Ford kept insisting that only a little bit more aid to South Vietnam would make everything all right in Indochina.

title: Exodus From Surinam Is Gathering Momentum
description: PARAMARIBO, SurinamNearly 308 years after the Dutch surrendered their claim to Manhattan Island to the British in exchange for Surinam, the Hague is preparing to grant the people of this South American land full independence no later than the end of this year.

title: Fog Shuts Coast Airport
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (UPI) Fog closed the Los Angeles International Airport for about an hour and a half early today. It was reopened at 7:15 A.M. Pacific Standard Time.

title: FREE CHOICE HELD ISSUE IN ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) A physician from Boston who is on trial for manslaughter in a case that may extend the United States Supreme Court's abortion decision said today that freedom of choice was the central issue in the controversy.

title: Outstanding Entries In Millrose Track At Garden Friday
description: 60Yard DashSteve Williams, Ivory Crockett, Steve Riddick, Houston McTear, Dr. Delano Meriwether, Hasely Crawford.

title: Son to the Finkelsteins
description: A son was born Dec. 31 to Mr. and Mrs. Alan Finkelstein of Forest Hills, Queens, in New York Hospital. Mrs. Finkelstein is the former Susan Carol Platt.

title: Buchanan, ExAide to Nixon, To Write Political Column
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, who was a special assistant to the President in the Nixon Administration, will write a thriceweekly column of political and social commentary beginning the first week in March.

title: Astronomy, Physics Make A Marriage in the Heavens
description: More than 250 years ago, Sir Isaac Newton, the English mathematician and philosopher, showed that the movements of even the most distant celestial bodies are governed by the same laws that control the fall of an apple from a tree on earth. With Newton's formulation of the laws of motion and gravity, a fundamental change occurred in man's understanding of nature. It was realized that physical laws are universal.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Helped by some bullish economic news, the stock market last week made a broad advance in active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 21.98 points at 666.61. The best gainers were some of the blue chips, glamour issues and special situation stocks.

title: YUGOSLAV ASSAILS BRITISH WAR ROLE
description: Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav dissident writer awaiting trial on charges of disseminating hostile propaganda, in articles published abroad, has asserted in a new article that Marshal Tito's Communistled Partisans gained control of Yugoslavia in World War II only after Britain abandoned the royalist Chetnik forces led by Gen. Draia Mihailovich.

title: POLICE SEEKING 2 IN TAVERN BLAST
Metropolitan Briefs
description: An outbreak of influenza cases here in the next few weeks was forecast yesterday by Dr. Lowell E. Benin, the City's Health Commissioner. Dr. Bellin said he had based his opinion on the 300 random samples of blood from persans of varying age groups examined every month by his department's bureau of laboratories. According to Dr. Bellin, the percentage of persons with influenza symptoms, which had ranged from 10 to 20 per cent in the previous four months, rose to 48 per cent in the first week of January.

title: Transit Difficulties Grow in Many Nations
In West Africa, Optimism Develops
description: DAKAR, SenegalSince independence in the early Sixties, we did not seem to be getting anywhere. But now, we can see a futurea bright one, a businessman commented recently.

title: OneTime Strangers Become a Family by Choice
An Agreeable Evening With H. L. Mencken
description: WALTER KERR

title: Canadian Farmers Profiting Despite Drop in Wheat Grade
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba This is the poorest grade crop for decades, an official of the Canadian Wheat Board said late last year.

title: Fire Department to Screen 500 With a View to Laying Off 180
description: The Fire Department, responding to the Mayor's order to cut an additional 180 men from the force to save money, has asked 500 recently appointed firemen to provide proof of their current residence and their military service to be used as a basis for determining who will be laid off.

title: Nigerians Plan Petrochemical Industry
description: LAGOS, NigeriaThis nation, which now produces more than 2.3 million barrels of lowsulphur oil a day, plans to spend more than $5billion between now and 1980 to develop her petrochemical industry.

title: Brazil's Economic Boom Rolls On
description: RIO DE JANERIOBrazil's rapidly expanding economy smashed through a host of problems in 1974 to post a 10 per cent gain in its gross national product for the seventh consecutive year.

title: Henry Roberts to Wed Miss Savage
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Savage of Lebanon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine E. Savage, to Henry Plant Robberts, son of A. Sydney Roberts of Wakefield, R.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mary Ellen Plant Roberts.

title: Andrea Grass to Be a Bride in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew, N. Grass Jr. of Scarborough, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Grass, to Michael John Mooney, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Mooney of Brighton, S. I.

title: Memorial Services
description: WEISKOTTERThe Rev. Dr. Robert F., died January10th In New York City. He was pastor of St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 1004 Bedford Ave., Brooklyn. Memorial services, Sunday, January 26, at 2 P.M. at the Church. Friends are Invited.

title: GUNMEN PUNISHED, P.L.O. ANNOUNCES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25The Palestine Liberation Organization has announced that it has inflicted what it calls severe punishment on the Palestinian gunmen who hijacked a British airliner from the Persian Gulf to Tunis in November.

title: 4 Basic Requirements Listed for Judging Breeds at Shows
description: Integrity, judgment, deportment and knowledge were cited by Alfred E. Treen as the basic requirements for judging at the twoday seminar on quality judging at Waukesha, Wis., two weeks ago. The workshop conducted by the Waukesha Kennel. Club, drew 106 participants from 12 states. Leonard Brumby Jr., the senior vice president of the American Kennel Club. urged arbiters to go slowly in seeking to qualify for additional breeds. He told how provisional judges must be observed in at least two of their provisional assignments and that some are asked to do three more before being approved. Others are rejected.

title: Put the Fire Out Now, Henry
description: PARISHenry Kissinger's imminent trip to the Middle East is perhaps the mosturgently important of all his visits to that terrible minefield. For the atmosphere has been steadily zigzagging tip toward a new conflict that might well explode beyond regional limits.

title: The Young Are. Falling for Yurts
MISSES CRYER, FORD SING OWN SONGS FREE
description: Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford are probably best known, insofar as they are known at all in this town of short memories, as the composers of of Sweet Isaacs, which swept years ago: They have also written two other shows and, such productions being few and far between, have composed a variety of unaffiliated songs.

title: 1ST MAN SENTENCED for WOUNDED KNEE
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 25 (AP)The first sentence resulting from the 1973 Indian occupation of Wounded Knee, S. D., was handed down today by Judge Warren K. Urbom in United States District Court.

title: Scholarship to Be a Memorial
With 6 Skiers in Family, Doctor Ponders the Cost
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I., Jan. 24 Dr. John Egner, a skiminded urologist who confesses he never was partial to mathematics as a student, now concedes his ability to add, subtract and divide has become increasingly important in considering his favorite winter sport. When I was a med student at Syracuse University about 20 years ago, the physician said, I used to pile into a car with some of my classmates. We'd head for such Vermont ski areas as Mount Snow and Big Bromley. Naturally, in those days, the expense was a key factor.

title: Five Held in Slaying at Bank
description: PANTEGO, N.C., Jan. 25 (AP) Five men were held without bond today, charged in a bank robbery slaying. The victim, Mrs. Dorothy Cuthrell, about 50 years old, was killed yesterday while working in the Pantego branch of the Southern National

title: Miss Whelan Bride Of Robert Bossart
description: Mary Elizabeth Whalen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Whalen of Rockville Centre, L. I., was married yesterday morning to Robert Tilghman Bossart, son of Mrs. Walter L. Bossart of Mount Lebanon, Pa., and the late Mr. Bossart.

title: Jeans or WomblesMad for Fads
description: In Italy, it's loden coats. In Beirut, it's pinball machines. Britain is currently mad about Wombles, and blue jeans are still big in the Soviet Unionalthough definitely pass in France. And in Japan, the fad of the moment is streaking, closely followed by the occult.

title: The Chatter's Back at the Most Visited Home in the World
description: MAMIE EISENHOWER, then First Lady, was visiting a famous American mansion open to the public when the manager of the attraction announced: This house is toured by 50,000 people a year. Later, to friends, Mrs. Eisenhower laughed, 50,000 people! We get that many through the White House every day before lunch.

title: Miss Coles Fiancee Of Howard Haykin
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Coles of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Coles, to Howard Haykin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haykin of Brooklyn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Merrill Gay Tomlinson Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ford Tomlinson of New Vernon, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Merrill Gay Tomlinson, to Marvin Dice Batchelder, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Batchelder Jr. of Medina, Ohio. A wedding in the fall is planned.

title: G.O.P. Plans a Comeback With TV and Voter Drive
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25The Republican party announced today a comeback plan involving a national television series and a massive voterregistration effort.

title: Weimar
description: Walter Laqueur has made it his mission as a writer to introduce to a wide audience some of the more complex problems of contemporary history, such as ArabIsraeli relations, the history of Zionism and the German Youth Movement. He is director of the Institute of Contemporary History and the Wiener Library in London and coeditor of The Journal of Contemporary History. In this volume, he has turned to one of the most complex problems of all: the rich, dizzying cultural life of the Weimar Republic.

title: Dayan Doubts That a New War Is Imminent
description: ZAHALA, Israel, Jan. 21Moshe Dayan has never run with the crowd.

title: Localization of Mental Aid Urged by Carey Study Unit
description: Governor Carey has been Urged by his mentalhealth task force to decentralize the mammoth and controversial State Department of Mental Hygiene and to give more power to community groups and voluntary mentalhealth organizations as a means of improving treatment and rehabilitation of the mentally disturbed.

title: John Reddy, Feature Writer And Jack Paar Collaborator
description: John F. X. Reddy, a roving editorsince 1958 with The Reader's Digest, for which he wrote personality articles, died Friday of a heart attack in New York Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 52 Riverside Drive.

title: Ghanaians Bottle Palm Wine
description: ACCRA, GhanaThe cork pops from the longnecked bottle and is followed by an amber froth. But this is not champagne, either French or Californian. It is African palm wine, successfully bottled for the first time and carbonated for added. sparkle.

description: A turreted Gothic structure of roughhewn stone built in 1891 houses the Hennepin County Court House in Minneapolis.

description: HONG KONGIf OPEC can do it, why can't we? has become a prevailing theme of economic thinking throughout. Asian countries with key raw materials in sufficient quantities to give them good bargaining leverage in world markets.

title: ORT PARLEY PICKS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: The election of Harold Friedman, a Jewish communal leader and an investment banker, as president of the American ORT Federation marked the opening last night of the 53d annual convention of the organization at the Americana Hotel.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Senate dealt an all but fatal blow this week to President Ford's proposal that Social Security benefit increases be held to 5 per cent this year.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. Press of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Baylor Press, to Homer Obed Brown of Williamsville, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. O. Brown of McAlester, Okla.

title: Why Congress Said No To the Film Institute
Across generations, across a continent, across the ice
description: This is not quite one of those trendy pregnancy novels. There is not much in it about sex, or about whether a 15yearold girl should sleep with a boy; except for a brief, unchallenged right to life statement, the question of abortion is skirted because it is too late for the girl to have one; and the pregnancy is written off as a mistake by the characters, including the adults, who all seem innocent of knowledge about birth control.

title: Mrs. Pollitz Has Son
description: A son was born Jan. 7 to Mr. and Mrs. Edward Pollitz Jr. of Manhattan in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Pollitz is the former Daniele Elkabach. of Paris. The child is named Nicholas Sazerac.

title: Indiana Wins 21st; Louisville Is Upset
Vivien Kellems, Foe of Tax System, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) Vivien Kellems, who battled the Federal tax system as discriminatory against single people, died early today in a hospital here. She was 78 years old.

title: Georgetown to East Berlin: New Home for an Elegant Hostess
description: BERLINLorraine Cooper was one of Washington's most elegant hostesses. Since early December, she has been setting up what she hopes will be an elegant home in East Berlin, a Communist capital that is separated by much more than a wall from her native Pasadena, Calif., or from the society of Kentucky, where her husband, John Sherman Cooper, was long a United States Senator.

title: Card of Thanks
description: ESCOEThe family of the late Emanuel Escoe gratefullyacknowledges the largo number of cards, letters and other. warm expressions of sympathy received from their friends, associates and family In their recent bereavement.

title: MORE POOR FAMILIES NOW LED BY WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Census Bureau reported today that poor families, both white and black, are increasingly headed by women.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Where there's a will, there's a way. Remember that one? From the age of oversimplification, no doubt. But one might take as example the fate of two historic buildings, in two cities, to see how this nice oldfashioned maxim does, or does not, work today. These two buildings have a lot in common.

title: Emil Rieve, Unionist, Dies; Headed Textile Workers
description: Emil Rieve, founding president of the Textile Workers Union of America and long influential in top labor councils, died Friday night of a heart attack at his home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Estebanico
description: In the early part of the 16th century, four menthe sole survivors of an illfated Spanish expeditioncrossed the continent of North America from Florida through Texas to the Pacific. One of them, Alvar Nuez Cabeza de Vaca, told of their experiences in a famous Relation, or letter, to Charles V. King of Spain. In this book, written also as a letter to Charles V, the author narrates the story from the point of view of Esteban the Blackamoor, who was one of Cabeza de Vaca's companions on this incredible journey and thus the first black man to cross North America.

title: State Hearing the Sound of Bluegrass
description: SOMERSETA restaurant in front of a bowling alley near Rutgers University, a room that has been a pool hall and then a topless gogo parlor, has become a stoppingoff place for nationallyknown bluegrass music groups.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: City PersonnelSystem Changes Urged
description: Major changes in the city's personnel system were urged yesterday in a twopart study made public by the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City.

title: It Is Possible That Only a Trickle Will Ever Go to Market
description: WASHINGTONBillions of barrels of oil lie buried in the sands of northern Alberta and beneath the Rocky mountains of ColoradoUtah, enough oil to make Canada and the United States wholly independent of foreign supplies for decades, or until the era of energy from the sun and sea that may lie over the horizon of the 21st century.

title: C. R. Zeppie Is Fiance Of Marybeth M'Manus
description: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth McManus to Christopher Robert Zeppie has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph McManus of Manhasset, L. I., parents Of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Vincent M. Zeppie of Queens Village, Queens, and the late Mr. Zeppie.

title: Rubins Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Dr. Lewis Rubin, chief resident in urology at Mount Sinai Hospital, and Mrs. Rubin of New York on Jan. 7 in that hospital. Mrs. Rubin is the former Ruth Linden. The child, the couple's second daughter, is named Jeri Linden.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: *Somerville Inn, U. S. 22, Somerville. (201) 7251415. In 1940, Mrs. Florence Nash, the wife of Edward Nash, a WOR correspondent, bought a threestory building here and renamed it the Somerville Inn. A devastating fire in January, 1962, destroyed everything except the kitchen; however, with the help of her partners, Charles Berman and Gene Cohen, Mrs. Nash designed and opened the new Somerville Inn a year later.

title: Institute President Named
description: SOCORRO, N. M., Jan. 25Dr. Kenneth W. Ford, 48yearold professor of physics at the Boston campus of the University of Massachusetts, was named yesterday as the 14th president of the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology here. He succeeds Dr. Sterling A. Colgate, who resigned effective Jan. 1.

description: SANTIAGO, ChileOne of the oldest economic mysteries of Latin America is the ability of outwardly impoverished and debtridden nations to obtain new foreign credits and refinance existing obligations.

Trenton Fighting Bid to Move Post Office
description: TRENTONA decision by the United States Postal Service to transfer its main facility here to a new 31acre site in nearby Hamilton Township has provoked strong opposition among local civic and political leaders and prompted Senator Clifford P. Case to look into the proposed move.

title: A Resurvey of the 312  Mile MasonDixon Line Goes On
description: ELKTON, Md., Jan. 25 Back in the seventeensixties, when a couple of British surveyors named Mason and Dixon drew the line that symbolically separates North from South in the United States, they set up about 300 waisthigh limestone obelisks to mark the boundary.

description: Jan. 30New York Region, Sports Car Club of America meeting at Dragon Seed Restaurant, 9511 37th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, 8 P.M. All interested persons welcome. Guest speaker: Bruce Wennerstrom, expert on track safety. Information: David Rivkin, phone (212)5443295.

title: Alexandria Carey Married at St. Patrick's
description: Alexandria Carey, the eldest of Governor Carey's 12 children, was married, to Hank McManus yesterday afternoon in a friendly family ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Specter of Nationalization Haunts Britons
description: LONDON  Businessmen sometimes say that British industries would be about the last target of wealthy Arabs.

title: Brandt Joins State Election Drives
description: BERLIN, Jan. 25My, it is good to be here, Willy Brandt said the other evening as he walked into Jule Hammer's bar, where West Berlin's Social Democrats often gather for a beer and a chat.

WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Wool, the oldest of the textile fibers, has gotten a new lease on life after several years of decline.

title: Italy's Reds. GainingNew Local Pacts
description: ROME, Jan. 21  Following the example of Christian Democrats and Communists in Venice, representatives of Italy's two biggest parties appear to be joining forces in some other local governments.

title: Economic UncertaintyJapan Can Depend on That
Connors and Martin Win Net Semifinals
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 25 (AP)Jimmy Connors overcame an openingset loss to Karl Meiler of West Germany tonight en route to a 67, 62, 62 victory and a spot in the final of the Birmingham indoor tournament. His opponent will be 18yearold Billy Martin of Palos Verdes. Calif.

title: China: Unstable Stability
description: The first meeting in a decade of China's National People's Congress and the adoption of a new state Constitution appear to codify the domestic political changes and the moderate trend that has prevailed since the reversal of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Penguin Rally Erases Lead
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 Playing without their leading scorer, Rod Gilbert, who was nursing the flu back in his hotel room, the New York Rangers faded badly during the last two periods and dropped a 52 decision to the Pittsburgh Penguinstonight before a setllout crowd of 13.403 at the Civic Arena.

title: City Opera In Harmony With Village Of Freeport
description: FREEPORT  The New York City Center Opera Company is bringing opera to Freeport and the community is Joining in The performance will mark at least two firsts.

title: Children's Irradiation Therapy Linked to Cancer in Adulthood
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)An unusually high incidence of cancer of the thyroid is being seen in adults who were treated with irradiation of the head and neck as children, researchers report.

title: Charlotte Bergen Beginning a Series Of Free Concerts
description: Charlotte Bergen inaugurated a series of three free symphonic concerts at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon before a large and loving crowd. Yesterday's program was devoted to Beethoven, with forthcoming concerts planried for Brahms (March 22) and Schubert (May 10).

title: Records off the record
description: Things are a lot more complex than Aryeh Neier suggests, and I believe in my heart that Aryeh Neier knows it. In Dossier, subtitled The Secret Files They Keep on You. the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union builds the public record case by case with numbing, if not chilling, effect. You, of course, are the private citizen; they are many and hydraheaded: organizations such as your school, police precinct, mental hospital, juvenile and criminal court, addictiontreatment center, credit bureau, De fense Department and F.B.I. which keep files on you that may contain unevaluated, outofdate or erroneous information. These secret files, Neier proves with little difficulty, are far from secret. The information contained therein, be it accurate or false, is disseminated a) thoughtlessly; b) conscientiously; c) unscrupulously; d) punitively; e) malevolently [pick one to fit your personal conspiracy level] to other organizations such as your prospective employer or your bank, and in this manner you become a victim.

title: A Jackrabbit Is Reported On Endangered Species List
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Jan. 25Tourists who recall seeing countless numbers of jackrabbits while driving across the desert areas of southern New Mexico in years past will find it hard to believe that one species of this longeared mammal is on the verge of extinction.

title: Canada Mirrors Anxieties of U.S.
Cynthia Lansburgh Wed To Charles McAdam 3d
description: The marriage of Cynthia Lloyd Lansburgh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ranger Lansburgh of Greenwich, Conn., to Charles Vincent McAdam 3d took place there yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ballet: Dennis Wayne as Billy the Kid
description: Eugene Loring's Billy the Kid is extraordinarily resilient. Created for Lincoln Kirstein's Ballet Caravan some 40 years ago, this has been the most successful of all Americana ballets. At the City Center 55th Street Theater yesterday afternoon, American Ballet Theater's newest recruit, Dennis Wayne, danced his first Billy and scored a bullseve.

title: Los Angeles Police in Training To Curb Recession Protests
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25The police here are being trained in special crowdcontrol techniques to enable them to cope with any protests that might occur during the current recession.

title: Surge by Kings Gets 55 Draw

description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Samuel Knox of Rye, N. Y., Sarasota, Fla., and Cincinnati have announced the engagement of Mrs. Knox's daughter, Nancy Jeanne Loeb, to William Henry Rackoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Raymond Rackoff of Pittsburgh.

title: Oil Wealth Bypasses Ecuadoran Indians
description: QUITO, EcuadorSimon Bolivar, the Liberator, referred to this lovely capital as the convent. Perhaps he was thinking of its isolation, its beautiful setting high in the Andes, the cleanliness of its streets or the traditionbound Quitenos who, as he said, view all change as apostasy.

title: HEBERT'S TENURE AIDED HOME TOWN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25Representative F. Edward Hbert's fouryear tenure as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee brought many military installations, most of them still in the construction stage, to his home town.

title: Around the World, Alternate Energy Is Sought
description: IN an attempt to harness the earth's heat, Soviet scientists hope to drill slanted holes two miles deep into the side of a volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula, that appendage of the Asian land mass north of Japan. The plan is to pump river water into some boles and extract from other holes steam that will drive the turbines of a 300.000kilowatt generating station.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 12:30 P.M. (Channel) Eyewitness News Conference: Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, is the guest.

title: 4 Seized in Upstate Robbery
description: LEWIS, N.Y., Jan. 25 (UPI)Two men and two women were charged with firstdegree robbery today after they allegedly beat an 83yearold physician at his home here and then robbed him of $5,000, the state police reported. Troopers said the victim, Dr. Philip Kuntz, had been admitted in fair condition to Champlain Valley Physicians' Hospital in Plattsburgh. The four suspects were identified as Harold A. Crowningshield, .34 years old, his wife, Wanda Lee, 33; Nancy M. Lapier, 24, and John S. Meachun, 24, all of New Milford, Conn. Troopers said the four had previously lived in the Essex County area.

title: Kissinger Negotiates With Congress
L.I.R.R.AWAITING GASTURBINE CARS
description: The Long Island Rail Road's first four gasturbine electric cars will be carrying passengers on regular runs by late spring or early summer, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reported.

title: Cynthia J. Edstrom Engaged to Cadet
description: Announcement has been made by Judge Richard E. Edstrom of the District Court of Nassau County and Mrs. Edstrom of Valley Stream, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Jean Edstrom, to Cadet Terry Higdon Byce of the United States Military Academy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mills McNeel Byce of Greensboro; Ga. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Economy, the Military and the Communists Create Uncertainty
description: LISBONAll the movies, both skin flics and important films, as well as plays, books and periodicals that were banned during the 50year SalazarCaetano dictatorship are now available in Portugal. As crowds flock to the cinemas, the end of censorship is a concrete sign that the country has broken out of political and cultural isolation.

title: Linda R. Beach, William A. Howe Planning Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morrison H. Beach of West Hartford and Groton Long Point, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Rebecca Beach, to William Appleton Howe of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Morris Howe of Augusta, Me.

title: Roncallo Appointment Scored
description: MINEOLAWhen the Republican  controlled Nassau County Board of Supervisors named former Representative Angelo D. Roncallo last week to the $22,300ayear parttime post as a member of the County Board of Assessors, it did so over the heated objections of the Democratic party.

title: Two Indian Tribles in Maine Voted Seats in the House
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 25The House of Representatives has voted, 107 to 40, to give representatives of two Indian tribes House seats and speaking privileges.

title: How the Goshdarn Networks Edit the Heck Out of Movies
BRIDGE
description: Bridge is played by human beings, not by machines, and their behavior frequently furnishes significant information. It is an unfortunate necessity that the bridge rules impose a double standard in this regard. A player is fully entitled, at his own risk, to draw what inferences he chooses from the behavior of his opponents. But he must Ignore the hesitations and mannerisms of his partner.

title: Officer to Wed Miss De Vylder
description: Mary Frances DeVylder and Lieut. Bruce Stuart Lemkin, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Lemkin of Laurel Hollow, L. I., plan to marry May 24 at St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Cheshire, Conn.
