description: JEDDAH, Saudi ArabiaEach time the big green jets marked Saudia zoom off the airport runway here for London, Bombay or any of 20 destinations within the kingdom, the profits add up for Saudi Arabian Airlines.

title: State Layoffs Pose Test for New Law
description: TRENTON  The agency that mediates labor disputes involving New Jersey's public employes began last week to exercise broad new powers affecting 200.000 state, county and municipal workers and, in turn, the public at large.

title: Iran's Oil Exports Said to Drop by 10%
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 25 Iran's oil exports have fallen by more than 10 per cent this month compared with December and the downward trend, which began late last year, is likely to continue in the months to come, an influential Teheran newspaper, Kayhan International. reported today.

title: Drew Crolius Sets A Wedding in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen Potter Crolius of Westport, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Drew Crolius, to William Alexander Bell Davidson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davidson of Montreal, formerly of Weston, Conn. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Byrne Seeks Housing Aid
description: TRENTONIn his annual message to the Legislature earlier this month, Governor Byrne identified the nation's sagging economy as his administration's foremost problem. The recession already has created a major deficit in the current state budget, and it promises to create one of about $600million in the budget that the Governor plans to present to the Legislature next month.

title: Factory Jobs in Sharp Decline
description: TRENTONWhen Governor Byrne established a select committee last week to look into the reasons behind New Jersey's deteriorating business climate, he had something deeper in mind than the recession, which has burdened the state with one of the highest unemployment rates in the nation.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Ralph Kiner, after being voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame on his 15th and final electoral attempt: I never gave up hope but it was getting tougher and tougher because a lot of people who saw me play have died.

title: For Asian Agronomists, Hope Lingers
description: MANILA  Although the promise of the Green Revolution seems sadly unfulfilled at a time when newspapers regularly carry pictures of starving Asians and Africans, agricultural experts throughout Asia remain hopeful that food production can be markedly increased.

title: Music Notes: A New Award and a Novel Opera
description: Lynn Harrell and Murray Perahia could not be more dissimilar physically. The former is tall, blond, a bit heavyset; the latter is short, dark and slight. They have one agreeable thing in common: they are the first winners of the Avery Fisher Award, a prestigious prize to be given annually by Lincoln Center. It includes a $5,000 check, appearances with the New York Philharmonic and the center's Chamber Music Society and a recital in the Great Performers Series.

title: Miss Byrne Sets Nuptials
description: Thomas R. Byrne, Ambassador to Norway, and Mrs. Byrne of Oslo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ann Byrne, to Douglas William Ell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ell of Trumbull, Conn. A July wedding in White Plains is planned.

title: Signs of Recession Are Few On Southern Yachting Circuit
description: There are few signs of recession on the southern yacht racing scene. The annual Southern Ocean Racing Circuit opens its sixrace thisi Friday at St. Petersburg, Fla., and the S.O.R.C. chairman, Tom Downs, has 84 entries for the first event. He has 82 more for the big race, St. PetersburgtoFort Lauderdale, which starts on Feb. 5.

title: Ballet Theater Is Superb With Fall River Legend
description: Lizzie Borden was acquitted of killing her father and stepmother with an ax in 1892 in Fall River, Mass. You wouldn't know this, however, by looking at Fall River Legend, a ballet about Lizzie created by Agnes de Mille in 1948 and performed for the first time this season by American Ballet Theater on Friday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Franc, Not Fraud, Is the Swiss Lure
description: GENEVADespite all the talk about Swiss banks serving as tax hideouts, you would be surprised by the small number of foreigners who open accounts here simply to cheat their tax collector, said Claude Basset of the Union Bank of Switzerland.

title: Villagers Toiling With a Purpose
description: COLOMBO, Sri LankaIt is Sunday morning, and the little village of Hurigama is a scene of turmoilbut it is turmoil with a purpose. Hoelike mammoties glint In the sun as bronzed young men chop furiously into the earth. Beside them, old men an loin cloths fill baskets with the dirt. Girls, forming a line, briskly pass the baskets along. Children scamper about. Everyone in the village seems to be present.

title: Mayors Press Legislators for More Aid to Cities
description: TRENTONWhen a group of New Jersey mayors gathered here last week to confer with legislative leaders, the prime aim of the parley was to dramatize the financial plight of the cities.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Most teachers of photography, as well as practicing professionals, agree that the fastest way for someone to learn how to take and print good photographs is to take a course with a good teacher, or at a reputable school.

title: Offer Withdrawn In Sale of Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (UPD7 The head of a local group that has offered to buy the financially troubled Indiana Pacers withdrew his offer tonight, throwing the American Basketball Association club's future into limbo again.

title: Met Squash Racquets
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS.

title: Storage Tank Dispute on S.I. Persists
description: Four years ago two huge storage tanks in the Staten Island community of Rossville were thought to be the answer to New York's dwindling supply of natural gas. Today they remain emptytargets of Federal and city investigations into their safety.

title: Mexico Becomes Oil Exporter
description: MEXICO CITY Growing pessimism about Mexico's economic future has been abruptly transformed into optimism by important new oil discoveries in the southeast of the country.

title: The World, as Wealth Shifts, Is Shaken by Uncertainty
Dani McGrath Has Nuptials
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi in Weston, Conn., at noon yesterday, Daniale Cushing McGrath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Henry McGrath of Essex and Ashford, Conn., was married to William Manson Tate Jr., son of Mr. Tate of Baltimore and Leonetta McGill Tate of Cockeysville, Md.

title: Fordham Gives Navy 7160 Loss
description: Darryl Brown sank straight points as Fordham took a 17point lead early in the second half and beat Navy, 7160, last night at Rose Hill gymnasium.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 26, 1975

title: Aluminum Company Turns to Rice
description: ACCRA, GhanaWhat is a Californiabased multinational industrial and mining company doing in the ricegrowing business in West Africa?

title: Changes Are Proposed In Brooklyn Bus Service
description: A proposal to improve bus service in the East New York, Canarsie and Brownsville sections of Brooklyn has been placed under discussion by community leaders and officials of the city's Transportation Administration.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ANOTHER big bank has gone under, and the nation survives. The rapid succession of three large American bank failures in the last 16 months might have been expected to send devastating shock waves through the whole banking system. It didn't happen. The shocks appear to have been absorbed. But the collapses have nonetheless raised questions about how sturdy the system is and whether the bank regulatory authorities are sufficiently watchful.

title: CLUES ARE FOUND IN LEONIA MURDER
description: A hunting knife, handgun and jewelry taken from the Leonia, N.J., home where a 21yearold nurse was murdered Jan. 8 were found scattered along a residential street near the murder scene late Friday and yesterday morning, Bergen County authorities reported.

title: Tourism in Europe Is Running Out of Gas
Legislature Welcomes 46 Freshmen
description: ALBANY  When the 198th session of the New York State Legislature convened, 38 Assemblymen and eight, State Senators took their seats for the first time. Their ranks include a 23yearold newlywed from Oswego and a 59yearold woman from New York City's West Side who has been active, as she puts it, in the politics of confrontation for the last decade.

title: In Europe All Isn't Tranquil for Roche
An Ivorian Ship Comes in
CHESS
Great Disorder Under Heaven
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Officials here are watching with the utmost attention, and with some relief, the latest political developments in China particularly the reemergence of Premier Chou Enlai at the fourth National People's Congress in Peking.

title: Susan West Bride of W. W. Ayres
description: St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan DeForest West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph O'Neal West of Wellesley, to Warren William Ayres, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Ayres Jr. of Pittsburgh.

title: Algeria Fighting Sahara's Advance
Mr. Teng and Mr. Chang Are Apparently in the Line of Succession
description: HONG KONGLast Oct. 1, when China marked the 25th anniversary of Communist rule, two members of the leadership happened to be seated next to each other at an outdoor theater in a Peking park where kindergarten children were performing an elaborate masque illustrative of life on the communes. Television film of the event was later shown here and what was striking, whenever the camera panned the audience, was the strong silence of the two leaders, the only persons there, it seemed who weren't making small talk.

title: Head Coach of the Browns
description: After 10 years of professional football, Forrest Gregg announced his retirement and took a job as assistant coach at the University of Tennessee.

title: The World
description: Continued

title: Egypt Reports Gromyko Will Visit Feb. 3 for Talks
description: CAIRO, Jan. 25  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will come to Cairo on Feb. 3 for continuing consultations, the Egyptian Government announced tonight.

title: The mystical experience
description: What is a mystical experience like? What feelings does one have during it? Although it is often difficult to put into words, Andrew M. Greeley and William C. McCready compiled a list of possible descriptions drawn from the writings of Marghanita Laski and others. In a national survey they conducted, they asked some 600 persons who said they had had one or more mystical experiences to check off suitable descriptions. Many of those questioned checked off more than one description. The descriptions, and the percentages that each received, follow:

title: Gulf Dealers Fight GasandGo Plan
LETTERS
description: The American Place Replies

title: Mall Landscaping Plan To Cut Capital Parking
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Preparations for an anticipated jam of millions of automobileborne visitors here during the American Revolution bicentennial celebration next year are colliding with the interests of the Washington area's harried auto commuters.

title: A lead weight on the Navy's conscience?
description: The naval court of inquiry that looked into the loss of the nuclear  powered submarine Thresher, which went down in April, 1963, with 129 men aboard, decided that the evidence failed to establish that the sinking was caused by the intent, fault, negligence or inefficiency of any person or persons in the Naval Service or connected thereto.

title: What to do about the end of the world
Food
description: Hot soup can serve admirably as mainstay of a midwinter mealdepending, of course, on the occasion. For a light lunch, a light soup such as lentil or borscht might be served. For a meal of substance, a fish or gumbo type would be appropriate. Add a good loaf of bread, a wedge of cheese and a bottle of wine, and the meal is complete.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: A star is a star is a star. Or is she? A couple of Sundays past, reading these pages in my usual desultory fashion, I was startled to come across a headline: Is She a Prisoner of Balanchine? Now I didn't actually know that Balanchine had gone into the prison business. Under the headline I saw a picture I instantly recognized as a dancer from New York City Ballet, Patricia McBride. Wow, I thought! Wow! This is going to be a pretty interesting investigative report by. John Gruen. I mean, seriously, if a director of a ballet company (and that is what Balanchine ishis full name is George Balanchine, and I happen to know that he is the director of a New York based dance company called New York City Ballet) has a dancer in prison, I mean, honestly, this has got to be kind of weird.

title: Gamblers May Die Broke, But Many Are Willing to Take a Chance They Won't
description: When Arab stands side by side with Zionist, when capitalist and Communist forget they are at odds, when rich man and poor compete, it is a safe bet that one thing has brought them togethergambling.

title: Vietnamese People Buffeted by Economic Chaos
description: SAIGON, South VietnamA middleaged woman squatted in the middle of Truong Minh Ky Street as a pack of teenagers, brandishing sticks and hurling bricks, charged a nearby police barricade.

title: Miss Raidt Is Fiancee Of Ens. James Geiger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Raidt of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Mary Raidt, to Ens. James M. Geiger, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Geiger of Briahtwaters. L. I.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Hunting Bluebill From L.I. Blind Yields Only One Drake
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I.Throughout the day, highflying flights of bluebills went by out of range, riding down the gray skies with a snowladen north wind on their tails.

title: Discreet Scramble for Arab Sales
description: The headlong rush of American industrialists to do business with oilrich Arab nations has caused a quiet reshaping of both corporate and Government policy in the United States.

title: In Nigeria, East and West Meet
description: LAGOS, NigeriaThe Soviet Union is playing a big role in Nigeria. It is establishing a petroleum institute, setting up a steel mill and conducting geological surveys to determine the country's mineral resources.

title: DR. HARRY SOLOMON, INTERNIST HERE, 80
description: Dr. Harry Aaron Solomon, a specialist in internal medicine and cardiology, died yesterday at his home, 1016 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 80.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: DALLASOn the immense display floors of the Dallas Convention Center last week, at one of the largest annual conventions that takes place anywhere, suppliers to the homebuilding industry were displaying just about any product a builder can put into a home.

title: 3d Day of Oil Slick in West
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI)A thin sheen of oil from natural seepage coated the waters about five miles off the coast here in a 30mile strip for a third day today, but a Coast Guaid spokesman said it did not threaten wildlife or beaches. The oil oozes out at about the rate of 60 barrels a day at all times, but is usually dispersed, by wind and wave action. the spokesman said.

title: Caso Urges Review of Medicaid System
description: MINEOLA, L.I, Jan. 25Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso called last week on Governor Carey for a fullscale review of the state's Medicaid rate formula because of increasing costs.

title: Arabists of U.S. Deny an AntiIsraeli Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Some of them wear replicas of scimitars as tie clips and some have framed quotes from the Koran in classical Arabic script on their office walls.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: RASPBERRIES (Jan. 12)

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Four leases for a total of 110,000 square feet of space at an aggregate rent of more than $15million have been signed in the 41story office building at 810 Seventh Avenue.

title: Sports Editor Defeats 601 Shot on Last Stride
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 25Seven years ago at Hialeah Earlie Fires won the Widener on Sette Bello, who returned exactly $100. Today the jockey came within one stride of another big upset in Hialeah's $32,350 Royal Palm Handicap. A crowd of 20,255 watched.

title: As Inflation Slows Down
description: If the sudden and dramatic worsening of business conditions during the last four months has taught us anything, it is that, while the economy may be sick, the price system is alive and well. It took a crisis atmosphere to break the inflation, but it now appears that the general condition of price increases and the expectation of even more increases are just about finishedat least for now.

title: Canada Demonstrates STOL Service
Steeken, British Team Lead Riding Rankings
description: Hartwig Steeken of West Germany has been ranked No. 1 in the unofficial annual world rating of horse show riders, and Britain has been placed as the top team.

title: NUMISMATICS
HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Where the Jobs Are
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand In a world where the numbers of jobless are rising alarmingly, New Zealand remains a haven of full employmentand this has been achieved despite tight economic conditions here, too.

title: Some ways big money is made, held, spent
description: By Richard J. Barnet and Ronald Mller. The Power of the Multinational Corporations. 508 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $11.95.

title: Kathleen Dowd Is Biide
description: Kathleen M. Dowd, daughter of John P. Dowd of Garden City, L. and the late Catherine Rogan Dowd, was married last evening to Brian P. Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Reilly of Verona, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of the College of New Rochelle by the Rev. Joseph, Hart of Rochester. He was assisted by the Rev. Bernard Rogan of Bethesda, Md., an uncle of the bride. The bride is assistant to the dean of continuing education at St. Francis College.

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 26A strong start by Italy in the world championship here has been overshadowed by an allegation that one of the Italian pairs has been circumventing the bidding screens and communicating improperly by foot signals.

title: OIL STATES OFFER WIDE CONFERENCE WITH CONSUMERS
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 26The major oilexporting countries adopted a political and economic strategy today to counteract what they have regarded as a United States policy of confrontation and military threats.

title: Riessen Wins Pro Net Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26Marty Riessen, who once was voted the sexiest player on the men' tennis tour, achieved a competitive milestone today by outlasting Vitas Gerulaitis, 76, 57, 62, 67, 63, for the United States Professional indoor singles title.

title: Ballet: Busy Weekend With Three Fine Troupes
Federal Courts to Initiate Code For Rules of Evidence on July 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26For the first time in the nation's history, lawyers trying cases in Federal Court will be operating under uniform rules of evidence in every jurisdiction in the country, beginning July 1.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Allows First Sale By American Beef
description: OMAHA, Jan. 26 (UPI)Federal Bankruptcy Judge David Crawford has approved the sale of the American Beef Packers, Inc., feedlot operation at Minatare, Neb., to the Premier Corporation of Fowlerville, Mich., a cattle company.

title: Klammer Captures Sixth Cup Ski Race
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 26 (AP)Franz Klammer, a 20yearold son of peasant parents from the tiny Corinthian village of Mocswald, Austria, set a skiing record today by winning his sixth World Cup downhill race in a row.

title: Drug Agency Official Is Center of Senate Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations is expected to begin executive sessions hearings tomorrow on the operations of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and the controversy surrounding Vincent Promuto, the agency's $29,000ayear director of public affairs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1975

title: Fire Union Head to Offer Plan Today to Save Jobs
description: The head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association said yesterday that he would present a proposal today to Mayor Beame that would save the jobs of firemen scheduled to be laid off next Friday under the city's fiscalausterity program.

title: Information Phone Books Give Way to Fast Microfilm
2 Slayers Got Less Than 5Year Terms
description: Miguel Figueroa was killed at the age of 16shot in the back on a Manhattan street corner.

title: Littler Wins Crosby Golf
description: Gene Littler won the Bing Crosby National proamateur golf tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif., by four strokes yesterday with a final round 73 and a 72hole total of 280, eight under par. Page 33.

title: In Memoeriam
description: BOOKCHINRose, In cherished memory of my beloved sister died 1961. DANIEL.

title: Will It Make Me Fat?
description: Dr. Gustavo Molina of Chile has been a leading figure in public health in Latin America for years; a book of his is a standard text. He was not in politics in Chile. But as an interne he had roomed with Dr. Salvador Allende, and he was a lifelong friend. At Allende's request he came out of retirement in 1970 to administer a region in Chile's longestablished national health service.

title: Japan Braces for Influx Of Oil Money of Mideast
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26Almost exactly seven hundred years ago, Japanese warriors waited in the cold gray dawn along Ithe beaches for an imminent invasion of the Mongol horde that was eventually repelled with the help of a Kamikaze, or divine wind. Today, the Japanese are nervously awaiting an invasion from the Middle East.

title: Nation's Most Artful Dartists Thrive in Barroom or Ballroom
description: America's best dartists left their bars and basements yesterday for a smokefilled, maltsmelling ballroom where the United States championships were staged.

title: Pistons Top Bulls By 10293
MachineTool Industry Broke Records Last Year
description: By most measures, the machinetool industry in 1974 had the best year in its history.

title: Earthquakes in California
description: BRAWLEY, Calif. Jan. 26 (AP)Another series of mild earthquakes rumbled through this desert town today. City employes remained on emergency standby in the event of a major quake. More than 30 tremors have been felt in the Imperial Valley community since Thursday, and scientists believe a newly formed earthquake fault south of town could be responsible.

title: Connors Downs Martin in Final
A Reserve Helps Nets Beat Pacers
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 26 Outside the Nassau Coliseum, while the winds were whipping up to 50 miles an hour, Mike Gale, a reserve guard, was helping the New York Nets whip the Indiana Pacers, 115111, before a crowd of 12.153.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Industrial and consumer resistance to buying sugar is causing a backup at American ports as ships carrying raw sugar cannot discharge their cargoes at warehouses oversupplied with the highpriced commodity.

title: Ford Seems to Enjoy His Use of TV To Battle Congress Over Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Shortly before making his nationally televised speech on his economic and energy proposals from the White House library on Jan. 13, President Ford, who had been urged by his aides not to wear what they called a funny tie, showed up wearing, a rather plain, nondescript tie and asked his television adviser, Robert Mead:

title: The New and Newer Music Fails to Impress at Tully
description: The musical prophets of the last quarter century, as far as most composers were concerned, were Webern and Varese, and until the last decade or so there was hardly anything being written or played at contemporary concerts that did not fall deeply in debt to one or the other, or both. Slowly, however, these debts are being paid off.

title: Japan Braces Herself for Influx Of Oil Money From the Mideast
description: feelers from Middle Eastern financiers interested in the steel, petrochemical, shipbuilding, and shipping industries. One report here has it that financiers have already expressed interest in buying 10 per cent of an unidentified major Japanese company.

title: Littler Wins Crosby Golf
description: Gene Littler won the Bing Crosby National proamateur golf tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif., by four strokes yesterday with a final round 73 and a 72hole total of 280, eight under par. Page 33.

title: Eligible Crime Victims Fail to Claim Aid
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26  Although virtually every department in state government is complaining of a shortage of money these days, there is one state agency that seems to have enough to give away, but it does not have as many takers as it feels it should have.

title: DR. KING BUGGING BY F.B.I. VERIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. said today that the Senate Watergate committee had obtained evidence that the Federal Bureau of Investigation used electronic listening devices against the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. during the 1964 Democratic National Convention.

title: New Bard College Head, 28, Optimistic
description: Leon Botstein, who at the age of 28 has just been named the new head of Bard College starting July 1, likes being college president these days because he feels he is presiding over a collapsing institution.

title: 1,500 Call In During 4Hour WNET Retirement Show
description: A telethonstyle special on retirement and aging was given yesterday afternoon over WNET, and an estimated total of 1,500 viewers called in during the program for advice on problems ranging from Social Security to nursing homes.

title: Japan Tanker Mishaps
description: TOKYO Jan. 26 (AP)Japanese insurance companies paid more than $11million for damages from 19 accidents involving Japanese ships in the Strait of Malacca in the last four years, the newspaper Asahi Shimbun said today the narrow strip of water between Indonesia, Malaysis and Singapore is Japan's oil lifeline to the Middle East. About 1,700 Japanese tankers pass through the strait each year.

title: Personal Finance: Billing Late Taxes
description: If you have been using Uncle Sam as a banker by not paying or by underpaying your tax bills, be prepared for a 50 per cent increase in the interest rate beginning July 1.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the Preface of his Weimar: A Cultural History, Walter Laqueur defends himself almost apologetically for writing an introductory survey of Weimar culture. (I hope I shall not be criticized for failing to accomplish something I did not want to achieve in the first place: namely to provide a full, definitive history of Weimar culture.) And repeatedly throughout his survey he reminds us of the superficial order he is imposing on historyfor example, that the artistic impulses that dominated the Weimar period were really rooted in the time before World War I, or that many of the leaders of Weimar cinema survived the Nazi period, or that the significant prose writers of the nineteentwenties can't be pigeonholed according to politics and esthetics.

title: SAIGON SAYS SHELLS KILL 8 AT TAY NINH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  Rockets that Communists fired into Tay Ninh city killed 8 people and wounded 9 today, the Saigon command reported. The command said that 26 rockets, in two salvos, struck the provincial capital 55 miles northwest of Saigon.

title: Queens Chamber Concert Is Conventional, but Good
description: The Queens Chamber Symphony, which offered the third of six concerts yesterday afternoon at the Public Theater on Astor Place, will hardly win prizes for adventuresomeness of repertory. All six programs stick determinedly to wellknown pieces by the bestknown composers of the 18th century.

title: Count Basie Bands Provide Material For Jazz Repertory
description: Count Basie's bands of the last 25 years provided the New York Jazz Repertory with source material for a concert last night at Carnegie Hall that sporadically achieved a fullbodied Basie spirit.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
East End Hotel to Close; Home for Young Women
description: The East End Hotel, founded In 1911 as a home away from home for genteel young women who came to the big city for work or study, will close on March 3.

title: FUNERAL TOMORROW FOR VIVIEN KELLEMS
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan, 26 (AP)  A private funeral was planned here for Tuesday for Vivien Kellems, a foe of the Federal tax system who spent nearly 30 of her 78 years battling the Internal Revenue Service.

title: INSURANCE MOTIVE RAISED IN SLAYING
description: A Rochester auto worker, who has been charged with the machete murder of his brotherinlaw was tile beneficiary of a $50,000 insurance policy on the victim's life, the Rochester police said yesterday. They said the suspect was also being investigated in connection with six other suspicious deaths, including those of his two sisters.

title: Plea Bargains Resolve 8 of 10 Homicide Cases
description: Almost eight of every ten defendants who are accused of homicide in New York and who plead guilty to a reduced charge are freed on probation or receive a prison term of less than 10 years. And of those receiving a maximum 10year term, most will be eligible for parole in three years.

title: 3 Major Homicide Charges
description: Under New York State law there are three major categories of homicide.

title: Miss Huntley Scores HighJump Victory
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 26 (AP)Joni Huntley, troubled by a bad hack, failed in an attempt at the world women's highjump record but broke her own American record at the New Zealand Games today.

title: Grete Sultan, Pianist, Performs John Cage's Etudes Australes
description: John Cage has used star maps before in his music, but never so pervasively as in his recently completed Etudes Australes. Mr. Cage estimates that it will take two evenings to perform all 32 etudes. Grete Sultan offered the premieres of only the first, second and eighth of them at her Alice Tully Hall recital Saturday night, and that really isn't enough to say anything about the entire piece.

title: Spreading Bolivian Strike Cuts Tin Industry Exports
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia Jan. 26, (AP)  Onefourth of Bolivia's tin industry is now paralyzed by strike that government officials say is costing the country over $1.5million a day in exports. Tin is the nation's No. 1 export.

title: RIPE OKRA SEEDS HELD NUTRITIONAL
description: Okra seeds, usually unnoticed when eaten in the immature stage along with the green pod, could become a significant source of protein in many poor countries if harvested after maturity, a University of Rhode Island nutritionist has asserted.

title: JOSE A. MORA, 77, DIPLOMAT, IS DEAD
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 26 (UPI) Jose A. Mora, former Foreign Minister of Uruguay and Secretary General of the Organization of American States, died here today. He was 77 years old.

title: Advertising
description: If and when the Department of Defense begins an advertising program it will be a continuation of its attempts to make the various recruiting efforts of the services more efficient.

title: Aging Belasco Preens for a New Theatrical Life
description: In the fading mural high over the proscenium at the Belasco Theater on West 44th Street, the lush figure of Mother Love still shelters Innocence, Devotion still dispels Grief with a kiss. The sky is serene, and there Is no hint of a closing night.

title: 2 Leonia Killing Suspects Facing New Accusations
description: Several victims of manboy holdup team who terrorized a Leonia household and killed a 21yearold nurse will view a police lineup in Harrisburg, Pa., this morning to see if they can pick out a 38yearold Philadelphia man and his 12yearold son as the perpertrators of the Jan. 8 crime.

title: 40TH MOVIE AWARDS GIVEN OUT AT SARDI'S
description: The 40th annual presentation of awards by the New York Film Critics Circle was held yesterday at Sardi's. The plaque for best movie of 1974, Amercord, was accepted by Franco Cristaldi for the Federico Fellini film. Mr. Fellini was also judged the top director. Howard Kissel, vice chairman of the critics group, presided.

title: Excess Profits of 7 In the State Ordered Returned to the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  The Federal Renegotiation Board has ordered 153 defense contractors, Including seven New Jersey companies, to refund a total of $70.2million in excessive profits from Government contracts.

title: Speziale Tiny Jewel In Village
description: Since one never knows where opera is going to turn up nowadays, it is probably not surprising that Haydn's Lo Speziale was performed  very stylishly  in the chancel of St. Luke's Chapel in Greenwich Village on Saturday night.

title: The Supreme Court and Rights of Pupils: A Challenge Posed to Powers of Schools to Expel or Suspend
Plea Bargains Resolve 8 of 10 Homicide Cases
description: Almost eight of every ten defendants who are accused of homicide in New York and who plead guilty to a reduced charge are freed on probation or receive a prison term of less than 10 years. And of those receiving a maximum 10year term, most will be eligible for parole in three years.

title: Bill Ordering Pool In Malpractice Suits Gaining in Albany
description: Senate leaders are predicting quick passage this week of a bill that would force the state's insurance companies that write personal liability policies to participate in a pool to provide medical malpractice insurance coverage.

title: VOTE IN THAILAND APPEARS SUCCESS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, Jan. 27  The people of Thailand voted yesterday in an election unusually free not only for Thailand but for much of the rest of Asia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nursinghome administrators in Connecticut, contrary to law, licensed by a board dominated by the nursinghome industry, according to a report by state auditors.

title: Pace Wins Grand Prix
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 26 (AP)Jos Carlos Pace of Brazil, driving a Brabham, took the lead in the 32d lap and won the Grand Prix of Brazil at the Interlagos course today.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Air from Suite No. in D, Bach; Piano Concerto No. 1, Chopin.

title: Nestle Company Adds Ayer International
description: The Nestle Company, because of expansion and growth requirements, last week added N. W. Ayer ABH International to its agency list.

title: Albee's Seascape Is a Major Event
description: Hats off, and up in the air! A major dramatic event.

title: Brown Takes Spotlight From Presidential Hopefuls as Coast Democrats Meet
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 26 Four potential Democratic rivals for the Presidential nomination came to the California State Democratic Central Committee convention this weekend and found the spotlight trained on the new Democratic Governor, Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: Tennis Results
description: AT PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.

title: Bill Ordering Pool In Malpractice Suits Gaining in Albany
description: Senate leaders are predicting quick passage this week of a bill that would force the state's insurance companies that write personal liability policies to participate in a pool to provide medical malpractice insurance coverage.

title: Lisbon Moderates Battle To Stem Far Left's Gains
description: LISBON, Jan. 26Portugal's moderate forces sought today to stem the surging power of the far left in the wake of last night's disruption of a political convention by rioters.

title: Alabama Well Fire Put Out
description: FAYETTE, Ala., Jan. 26 (UPI)  Using several dozen truckloads of water, firefighters snuffed a 40foot high gas well ace today that had burned over five million cubic feel of gas since Wednesday. No one was injured in the blaze which: started from a spark when two pipes brushed against each other as workmen were trying to choke off a flow of gas fumes.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetingsfor week follows:

title: Mayday and Playboy
West Berlin Is Curbing Immigration by Jews
description: BERLIN  As in the 19th century, Jews fleeing persecution in Russia are wandering through Western Europe in search of homes.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Harper & Row has agreed to integrate racially and sexually all jobs in its publishing business, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced. He said the company, while denying any violation of law, had signed an assurance of discontinuance of such practices and had promised to recruit, hire, train and promote women and members of minority groups.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The tax rebate and reduction program announced by President Ford two weeks ago has created considerable controversy. While generally applauded in broad outline, details have been attacked by economists, labor leaders and politicians.

title: Proxmire, Stevenson Offer WagePrice Rollback Plan
Sorry, Wrong Number
description: One of this city's deepening mysteries is the destination of its buses. While most other cities in this country and abroad manage to provide the pertinent information at each bus stop, New York withholds such data as though it were protecting secret troop movements.

title: Egyptians Put Sharp Queries to Premier
description: CAIRO, Jan. 26  In what was considered an indication that President Anwar elSadat had decided, at least for the time being, to continue his policy of political liberalization, Premier Abdel Aziz Hegazi recently received a group of students and permitted them to question him sharply.

title: 2 CHURCHES SEEK JOINT COMMUNION
description: A Roman Catholic church and a Lutheran church in Wyandanch, L.I., have formulated a Statement of Our Common Faith that they hope may leads to the joint celebration of communion, a cardinal tenet of Christian belief.

title: MRS. JOHN W. CUTLER
description: Rosalind Fish Cutler, widow of John Wilson Cutler, an investment banker, died Saturday at her home, 167 East 82d Street. Her age was 88.

title: Littler Wins by 4 Shots In Crosby Golf on 280
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 26Gene Littler, whose flawless swing and unflappable temperament explain why they call him Gene the Machine, calmly fended off stiff winds and a couple of dangerous bogeys today to shoot a oneoverpar 73 and win the 34th annual Bing Crosby National ProAmateur tournament.

title: INSURANCE MOTIVE RAISED IN SLAYING
description: A Rochester auto worker, who has been charged with the machete murder of his brotherinlaw was the beneficiary of a $50,000 insurance policy on the victim's life, the Rochester police said yesterday. They said the suspect was also being investigated in connection with six other suspicious deaths,, including those of his two sisters.

title: Couple in Forest Hills Die In Apparent MurderSuicide
description: A 54yearold Queens man and his wife, 50, described by neighbors as a quiet and apparently devoted couple, died yesterday morning at their Forest Hills apartment in what homicide detectives called a murdersuicide.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: New York City's Budget Woes

title: Maine Gets Personnel Grant
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  A $55,000 grant to the state of Maine was announced today by the United States Civil Service Commission regional director, Charles A. Maher, and Gov. James B. Longley. The grant under the Intergovernmental Personnel Act of 1970 will be used for training and information services in state managementlabor relations, for continuing affirmative action assistance for state administrators and for training programs for Maine state, county and local government employes.

title: Law Parley Is Cool to Idea Of a New Appeals Court
description: CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 26A proposal to create a national court of appeals as a buffer for the Supreme Court met with skepticism and even hostility this weekend at a national conference on appellate justice.

title: Volcano Peril Indicted
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 26 (UPI)A Federal report released today warned 35,000 persons living on the Island of Hawaii that they were in the path of an awakening volcano that has a potential for lava flows, falling rock, drifting gases, clouds of volcanic ash, violent ground ruptures and tidal waves. The report was preGeological Survey for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Zone Changes May Hold Pate of Alphonsus College
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, Jan. 26 The planning board is scheduled to deliver a report here tonight on proposed zoning changes that may provide some clues to the use it would like to see made of Alphonsus College.

title: BILL MAY RESTRICT FOREIGN INVESTING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) A bill allowing the President to block foreign investors from buying more than 5 per cent of the stock of any American company with assets of $1million or more is to be Introduced tomorrow by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Devecka Takes Nordic Combined Title
description: GILFORD, N.H., Jan. 26Mike Devecka of Bend, Ore., overcame today the jinx that has plagued him for the last two years by regaining the national Nordic combined ski championship he held in 1972.

title: Bruins, Flyers Play 22 Tie
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)Phil Esposito's second goal of the game and 45th of the season carried the Boston Bruins to a 22 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game involving last year's Stanley Cup finalists.

title: 10 Held in Coast Drug Raid
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (UPI) Ten persons were arrested and one million amphetamine pills and 5260,000 worth of LSD were confiscated in two separte raids, the police said today.

title: Approach to Oil Pricing Pleases Next to No One
description: President Ford's proposals for raising the prices of oil products across the board have stirred more opposition than almost any other element of his economic program. To discourage consumption and encourage production, he would levy a fee on imported oil, impose higher domestic oil taxes and decontrol prices.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Davis boys and a United States Military Academy cadet will try to help United States amateur boxers score second straight victory over the Soviet Union tonight at the Felt Forum. The scheduled 11bout match will be the fourth and final stop for the touring Russians. The American team beat the Soviet Union in St. Louis Saturday night, 54, winning two bouts by default.

title: Article 1  No Title
OIL STATES OFFER WIDE CONFERENCE WITH CONSUMERS
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 26The major oilexporting countries adopted a political and economic strategy today to counteract what they have regarded as a United States policy of confrontation and military threats.

title: Rosedale Residents See Raisin, A Play About Racial Prejudice
description: It was just a play, a story about a black family living on the South side of Chicago in the nineteenfifties that uses a windfall to buy a home and move to a white neighborhood, a move their white neighborstobe try to prevent.

title: A Soviet Child of War Wants to Visit U.S. Father
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26As the plot of a modern opera or play, the story might seem derivative or even banal:

title: DR. SIDNEY KAHR
description: Dr. Sidney Kahr, a psychoanalyst and psychiatrist, died here Friday night at the age of 70.

title: MAJOR FINANCINGS ARE SET IN WEEK
description: Major financings in both me corporate and Government sectors will take place this week again and the background of a spectaculer decline in shortterm interest rates.underwriters are expected to price the landmark $600 million debt issue of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which is scheduled for public offering tomorrow.

title: Carey Names Ward Corrections Head First Black Chosen
description: Benjamin Ward, former police official and New York City Traffic Commissioner, was named by Governor Carey yesterday as the State Commissioner of Correctional Services.

title: CRASH VICTIMS KIN GET FORD MESSAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) President Ford sent telegrams of condolence today to the families of three prominent executives from Columbus, Ohio, killed in the crash of a private airplane in Washington yesterday.

title: A Tough New Beame
description: Last week Mayor Beamed learned that 42 city workers that he thought had been laid off in response to his orders were actually paper people, long gone from the city payroll, but listed as current cuts by departmental heads who were apparently loath to dismiss their employes. The Mayor's reaction, was uncharacteristically swift, and decisive. He called the commissioners and department heads involved and told them with considerable heat, according to aides: I want those numbers matched. Now. Today. I want the people!

title: 2 GUILTY OF ROBBERY THAT LED TO KILLING
description: After three days of deliberation, a Supreme Court jury in the Bronx returned firstdegree robbery convictions on Saturday against two men for their part in a 1973 bar holdup in which an offduty police officer was slain.

title: About New York
description: The ifs that determine who shall live and who shall die when disaster strikes are so many, have such a fictional quality about them, that it is fruitless to speculate on the whys and why nots. The odds against any New Yorker's being one of the four people killed in Friday's terrorist explosion that wrecked the Angler's Club next door to Fraunces Tavern were more than a million to one. They were infinitely greater against the death there of Alejandro Berger, a 28yearold executive from a Philadelphia company.

title: Whither, Off Broadway?
description: Off Broadway began as an alternative to Broadway. In contrast to the main theatrical marketplace, it offered a home to new writers, actors, directors and forms of theater.

title: Auto Union Head Terms Car Price Cut Unfeasible
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The nation's car makers cannot lower their prices because it would mean losing money, the president of the United Automobile Workers said today.

title: Rangers Set Back Kings, 32
Screen: 'Love at the Top':French Import Lacks Drive of British
description: "Love at the Top," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is a 1973 French comedy that dimly recalls a number of nineteen-fifties English comedies about the rise and rise of cynical young men possessingand possessed byambition. There is one major difference: The English comedies, films like "Room at the Top" and "Nothing but the Best," were essentially concerned with the English class system and how to beat it."Love at the Top" has no such nourishing drive. It's about nothing more than what it seems. It's the story of a timid bank clerk (Jean-Louis Trintignant) who, under the direction of a second-rate novelist (Jean-Pierre Cassel), who conceives brilliant real-life plots, becomes one of the richest, most powerful men in Paris through a complicated series of liaisons with beautiful women and their protectors.Michel Deville ("Benjamin," "The Bear and the Doll") is one of those directors whose work is never more than competently stylish, and most of that stylishness is the kind that can be bought as easily as furniture, by hiring the right actors, cameramen, set designers and so on. In addition to Mr. Trintignant and Mr. Cassel, the cast includes Romy Schneider, as a badly used house-wife, and Jane Birkin, as a sunny-natured streetwalker. They have true style, but it can't upgrade the movie much.There is even something second-rate about the title that the film's distributors have chosen for the American release. The original French title, which was also that of the Roger Blondel novel on which it's based, is "Le Mouton Enrag" (The Mad Sheep). That's hardly a zinger in translation but it's better than the warmed-over associations of "Love at the Top."

title: HOUSE HEARINGS SET ON A.T.&T. RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The chairman of the House Communications subcommittee announced today that he planned to hold hearings on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's proposed rate increase.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Gary Wilensky, former tennis pro at Grossinger's and the Concord, has transferred his sphere of operations to Lexington Avenue, where his Tennis Lover shop has everything to outfit man, woman or child for the courts. The proprietor is particularly proud of the selection of sneakers he offers by such manufacturers as Dunlop, Bata, Adida, Puma, Tretorn, Capezio, Keds, Conyers, Chris Craft and Point Set and of the teaching equipment he carries, things like rebound nets, ballthrowing machines and handwrist positioners ($2.50). Customers are often treated to movies of championship play at Forest Hills and, in warm weather, will be able to practice their strokes in the back yard and see themselves on instant replay videotape.

title: BRIEFCASE FOUND AT BOMBING SITE
description: Police experts yesterday found fragments of a black attach case that they believe was used to bring in the bomb that killed four persons and injured 53 in Friday's explosion at a Fraunces Tavern annex.

title: Veterans in Prison Not Told of Rights, G.A.O. Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  A Government Accounting Office report has charged that the Veterans Administration has failed to inform 44,000 imprisoned veterans of their rights to benefits.

title: Merchants of Death
description: Millions of words have been written in the past three decades about the dangers of nuclear war and rightly so. But the arms that have killed more than ten million human beings since World War II have all been conventional weapons. Most of them have been obtained through an international arms trade that makes Basil Zaharoff and the other merchants of death of an earlier era look like peanut venders.

title: Auto Union Head Terms Car Price Cut Unfeasible
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The nation's car makers cannot lower their prices because it would mean losing money, the president of the United Automobile Workers said today.

title: The Rights of Children
description: In ruling that the public schools may not resort to disciplinary suspensions without an explanation, the Supreme Court has enunciated the doctrine that children, too, are entitled to the benefits of fair and evenhanded justice. Obviously fair as this doctrine may seem to be, there are still many adults who regard it with suspicion.

title: The Tax Package Weighed
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford has moved in a new direction to turn the economy around and has finally presented an antirecession and energy program. Congressman Al Ullman, the new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has said that the tax aspect of the program will be his first priority, so let's look at it.

title: FORD AND WILSON TO DISCUSS EUROPE
description: LONDON, Jan. 26 Prime Minister Harold Wilson is expected to tell President Ford this week that he plans to urge the British to vote to remain in the Common Market when they cast their ballots in a referendum this summer.

title: Earnings at Airco Climb In Quarter and Full Year
description: Airco, Inc., reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the last quarter and full year ended Dec. 31. The diversified industrial concern noted the gains were made despite the very substantial earnings reductions that resulted from a change in its inventory valuation from average cost to lastin, firstout method.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Striking retail clerks in South Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware called membership meetings for 10 A.M. today, and union officials said there could be a settlement of their twoweek walkout. Charles Gentile, controller of Philadelphia Local 1357 of the Retail Clerks Union, said negotiators were closer to a settlement. He added that if a settlement was reached, rankandfile members could vote on a contract proposal today.

title: Gunman Wounds 5 at Chicago Wrestling Match
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) Five persons were wounded late last night, one critically, by a gunman who fired from balcony area at a professional wrestling match in Chicago's International Amphitheatre.

title: EUROPEAN STOCKS IN A BIG REBOUND
description: PARIS. Jan. 26The Western world's badly battered stock markets have been rallying since Jan. 1 even while many experts have been saying that prospects for business are not so bright as the rally would indicate.

title: KATHERINE CHAQUENEAU
description: Katherine Leslie Chaqueneau, retired chairman of the Jamaica Water Supply Company, a post in which she succeeded her late father, Warren Leslie, in 1951, died Saturday at her home, 130 East 67th Street. She was about 70 years old and the widow of Julien Chaqueneau.

title: Bellino II Leads French Sweep, In Rich Prix d'Amerique Trot
description: PARIS, Jan. 26A saddle cloth was replaced by a sulky today, but big Bellino II still had the right equipment to win a championship.

title: Baron Robert Silvercruys Dies Longtime Belgian Envoy to U.S.
description: Baron Robert Silvercruys, who retired in 1959 after 15 years as Belgian Ambassador to the United States, died Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 81 years old and also had a home in Nantucket. Mass.

title: Doctor Cites Agency Over Cancer Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  A Government scientist has accused the Federal health agency he works for of needlessly exposing American workers and persons living near some factories to the risk of cancer.

title: SYRIA SAID TO WEIGH DEMILITARIZED ZONE
description: President Hafez alAssad of Syria has told the United States Ambassador, Richard W. Murphy, and a group of visiting Americans that his Government might accept a demilitarized zone on the SyrianIsraeli border, Time magazine reports in its current issue.

title: President and Wife at Bicentennial Film Premiere
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 26 (UPI)President and Mrs. Ford went to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts tonight where they watched the premier of a national bicentennial film called City Out of Wilderness: Washington. After the performance Mr. Ford told a laughing audience, We may be out of the wilderness but we're not yet out of the worlds.

description: Theater

The report was preGeological Survey for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Effect on Jobless Rate Questioned by Experts
description: The emphasis on our economic efforts must now shift from inflation to jobs.

title: Senator to Introduce Bill To End FairTrade Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 26 (AP) Senator Edward Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, is planning to introduce tomorrow legislation to repeal pricefixing statutes, generally known as fairtrade laws.

title: MRS. LAWRENCE MILLER
description: Marjorie Keyes Miller, a prominent social figure here and in Nantucket, Mass., died Saturday at her home here. She was 64 years old and also lived in Nantucket, Rome and Assisi, Italy.

title: ALEJANDRO H. BERGER
description: Alejandro H. Berger of Cherry Hill, N. J., who was with the international division of Rohm & Haas, a Philadelphia plastics and chemical company, died Friday in the lunchtime bombing at Fraunces Tavern. He was 28 years old.

title: 4 Saigon Nuns Reported Hurt In a Street Clash With Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (AP)Scuffles broke out between the Saigon police and a group of Buddhist nuns today after a convention held by political opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: MODERATES LEAD IN THAILAND VOTE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Mon day, Jan. 27  The people of Thailand voted yesterday in an election unusually free not only for Thailand but for much of the rest of Asia.

title: MINNESOTA ROCKS AID EARTH STUDY
description: Analysis of rock samples from Minnesota by two independent methods has given strong support to the view that the formation from which they came may be the oldest on earth, opening a new window into this planet's early history.

title: London Police Find Paintings
description: LONDON, Jan. 26 (Reuters) A missing Renoir is believed to be among three paintings recovered by the police in a raid on a west London house, the police said today. The Renoir, Woman in a Flowered Hat, was stolen from an aircargo consignment bound for the United States last year. Its owner, Samuel Maslon of Minneapolis had unsuccessfully offered the painting for auction in London at $138,000.

title: FREDERICK H. NACHMAN
description: Frederick H. Nachman, a former financial editor of The Frankfurter Zeitung, died here Saturday. He was 84 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: For Men, The Look Is Casual But Curly
description: Curly hair is in, reads the advertisement showing a Man with a headful of Orphan Annie curls. If your hair is straight like mine, it's smart to curl it, it's carefree.

title: 200 JobSafety Employes Plan Battle to Keep Posts
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26About 200 employes of New Jersey's occupational safety and health program plan to fight all the way in an effort to save their jobs, which are threatened by the Federal Government's scheduled takeover of the program on April 1.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Rarely has any column elicited such a heated response as one that appeared in these pages some time ago concerning Indian pudding. It appeared under the heading, As American as the Tomahawk.

title: After Prison, a Chance to Learn and Earn
description: Rosa was a cocaine dealer. Tracy killed a man. Penny stole a pair of shoes from Saks Fifth Avenue, and Gloria earned $8,000 a week as a prostitute.

title: 2 Slavers Got Less Than 5Year Terms
FELLOWSHIPS SLATED TO ASSIST NEWSMEN
description: A new fellowship program for working journalists who specialize in economic news was announced yesterday by Princeton University and the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.

title: Bomb Indictments Latest Battle in Textbook War
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 25  A selftaught Fundamentalist minister who has nelped to lead a stormy sixmonth protest against the use of certain books in local classrooms denied yesterday that he was involved in the bombing of a school here last year.

title: Masnik of Uruguay Signed by Cosmos
description: Juan Masnik, captain of Uruguay's World Cup team, has signed with the New York Cosmos, the North American Soccer League team announced yesterday.

title: HOMICIDE AND THE COURTS
NursingHome Licensing Assailed in Connecticut
description: Nursinghome administrators in Connecticut have been licensed, contrary to law, by a state board dominated by the nursinghome industry, according to a report by state auditors made public today.

title: Legislature's Largesse Leaves Carey Unmoved
description: Despite his State of the State austerity declaration that the days of wine and roses are over, Governor Carey does not intend to challenge or even criticize the highsalaried new posts and hefty pay increases handed out by legislative leaders last week, even though aides said As that they could badly undercut the Governor's efforts to control state spending.

title: Earthquakes in California
description: BRAWLEY, Calif. Jan. 26 (AP)Another series of mild earthquakes rumbled through this desert town today. City employes remained on emergency standby in the event of a major quake. More than 30 tremors have been felt in the Imperial Valley community since Thursday, and scientists believe a newly formed earthquake fault south of town could be responsible.

title: 3 Major Homicide Charges
description: Under New York State law there are three major categories of homicide.

title: Skate Champion Victor
description: HEERENVEEN, The Netherlands, Jan. 26 (AP)Norway's Sten Stensen, defending world champion, won the men's European speed skating championship today with a total of 177.567 points for the twoday meet. Harm Kuipers of the Netherlands finished second with 178.087 points.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Now that the State Legislature has been given more time by the State Supreme Court in its quest for a new method of financing public education, backers of other important pieces of legislation are moving to get their bills to the floor for votes.

title: Target for Reform
description: With commendable firmness and sense of direction, the Securities and Exchange Commission has pumped new forte into the drive to reform Wall Street's brokerage business. May 1 is reaffirmed as the date for ending monopolistic pricefixing of brokers commissions on public orders, despite the anguished pleas of factions in the securities industry who fear the pressures of competition.

title: REV. WILLIAM J. EDGAR
description: The Rev. William J. Edgar, pastor of the Incarnation Roman Catholic Church, Bellaire, Queens, since 1971, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: JANE S. SHEPPARD
description: Jane Steketee Sheppard, a former securities analyst for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, investment counsel, died yesterday of a rare protein disorder at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 45 years old and lived at 1165 Park Avenue and in Southport, Conn.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: World hunger! Who will survive?

title: The Meskill Nomination
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has wisely decided to give former Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut his day in court before taking a vote on his nomination to sit as judge on the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Instead of railroading through the Meskill appointment as a matter of Senatorial courtesy or blocking the nomination and leaving unanswered questions about his political dealings in Connecticut, fairness requires further disclosure about his past and possible future as a jurist.

title: Turks in Cyprus Hold Census for Economic Plans
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 26The people of the Turkishheld north of Cyprus were confined to their houses all day today while the Autonomous Turkish Administration tabulated the spoils of last summer's war.

title: HOWARD A. ACHESON
description: Howard A. Acheson, chairman of Acheson Industries, Inc., maker of specialty lubricants, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Frank McHale Dies at 84; Former Democratic Leader
description: MIAMI. Fla., Jan. 26 (AP)Frank M. McHale, former Democratic national committeeman from Indiana, died here today. He was 84 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BLITHE SPIRIT As the first stand up entertainer at the Grenadier (7532960), a pleasantly chic restaurant at 863 First Avenue (48th Street), a singer named Rosetta scores neatly. She is plain delectable as she sails through a nice mixture of tunes, vintage and new, prattles amusingly about nothing at all, flashes the sauciest dark eyes in town and dimplingly suggests that she's having a fine time of it in love and life.

title: CHARLES N. WALDRON
description: Charles N. Waldron, who had served Union College as secretary of the graduate and alumni council, history teacher, editor of the alumni magazine, director of admissions and secretary, died Saturday at his home in Rensselaerville, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

title: Murphy Victor In Ski Jumping
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 26Those howling wintry winds blew Earle (Swede) Murphy right into the winner's circle today.

title: Barbershop Singers Harmonize for Church
description: It was a scene out of a time gone by: barbershop singers harmonizing, and the community closing ranks to pay for damages caused by a church fire.$6,000 was raised at the benefit. The church was built 75 years ago on Glenwood Road, according to Leon Avakian, international president of the Barber Shop Harmony Society.

title: Ford's Popularity Continues to Drop In the Eagleton Poll
description: The rating by New Jersey residents of President Ford's job performance continued to decline this month, accordihg to the latest New Jeriey Poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute of. Politics at Rutgers University.

title: Fire Destroys Geneva Store
description: GENEVA, Jan. 26 (UPI)Geneva's bestknown department store, Grand Passage, was destroyed by fire this morning. The police estimated the damage at $10million to $20million. There were no casulties. The cause of the fire was not known.

title: UsedCar Dealer Slain
description: A 28yearold man described by the police as an informal used car dealer, was shot and fatally wounded yesterday afternoon shortly after he was called from his Bronx home to see a prospective customer. The victim, Christopher Saxbe of 1647 Popham Avenue, was found in an alley three blocks from his home, shot five times in the head. He died at Morrisania Hospital about three hours after the 1:45 P.M. incident. Detectives said robbery was apparently not the motive, but they didn't know what was.

title: Vote Numbers Fell in Nov. 5 Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26A record number of Americans were old enough to vote in the Congressional elections last November, but the number who registered and the percentage who voted were down significantly from recent elections, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
ROCKEFELLER SEES FINDING THAT C.I.A. VIOLATED CHARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Vice President Rockefeller said today he believed that the investigative commission he heads would find that the Central Intelligence Agency had violated its charter by undertaking activities within the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Words Don't Fail 4 Coaches After Basketball Teams Do
description: Basketball coaches say strange things in defeat:

title: Dissatisfied U.S. Reviewing Policies Toward U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26 The United States, which has attacked recent United Nations decisions and warned of eroding American support, has begun a highlevel review of its policies toward the world organization and all its affiliates, according to a highranking American official.

title: Swift as an Insurance Salesman
description: Rick Wohlhuter is a Chicago insurance salesman who can run faster than a usedcar salesman. He is the finest halfmiler in the world, the finest athlete in the world of track and field, and a mortal cinch for the Sullivan Award as the finest amateur athlete in the United States. That's triple crown that not even Secretariat could wear. When Wohlhuter runs the Howe 880 in the 68th Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden Friday night he will wind up a year that has been merely perfect. Since winning this race last winter he has competed not only at a half mile but also at 800 meters, 1,000 yards and a mile, and has never been beaten, not even as a member of the University of Chicago Track Club's relay team. In passing, he broke his own world record for the half mile and set a record of 2:13.9 for 1,000 meters, the classic distance known to the French as Le Grand Mille. His time of 1:44.1 for 880 yards is the equivalent of 1:43.4 for 800 meters, threetenths faster than the world mark held by Italy's South African, Marcello Fiasconaro, but he wasn't timed at 800 in that race. In races at the metric distance he hit 1:44 once and 1:43.9 twice.

title: Father of Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 26On Jan. 10, 1972, Sheik Mujibur Rahman returned to his native land after nine months in a Pakistani prison. My life's goal has been fulfilled, he said, his voice breaking with emotion, at the tumultuous reception given him in Dacca by half a million Bengalis. My Bengal is independent.

title: Jackson Voices Opposition To Arms Aid to Vietnam
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he would vote against a request for $300million in military aid to South Vietnam this year.

title: China Experts Find Clues in a Photograph
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 26The only face that stands out clearly in the one and only photograph published so far of the assembled Chinese leadership at the session of the National PeoPles's Congress held earlier this month belongs to a man who wasn't therethe venerated Mao Tsetung. A huge portrait of the chairmanabout 30 feet high judging from the photographs hangs over the rostrum on which the rest of the leadership is carefully arrayed in tiers. In the very first row of the photograph, someone is seated behind three microphones, possibly reading a speech. Analysts who have looked at the tiny, blurred image through a magnifying glass say they are sure that it is Premier Chou Enlai.

title: NEW NEGOTIATIONS DUE ON NOVITIATE
description: GRESHAM, Wis., Jan. 26A resumption of negotiations with armed Menominee Indians who have occupied the Alexian Brothers novitiate near here since Jan. 11 was expected tomorrow, amid indications that the National Guard would shift from its conciliatory stance to a more active role.

title: U.S. and Indochina: A Crossroad
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26On the second anniversary of the Agreement on Ending the War and Restoring Peace in Vietnam, the United States appears to be nearing a crossroads in its Indochina policy. In both South Vietnam and Cambodia, Communistled forces are pressing military advantages. In both countries there is a chance for deepening American involvement, or continued disengagement and a search for political solutions to war.

title: ISRAELIS SAY EGYPT REDEPLOYS ARMOR
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 26  Reports that Egyptian armored columns have been advancing toward the Suez Canal in the last few days have reached military headquarters here.

title: Pakistan's Food Situation And Economy Rebound
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 23  Three years after the breakup of Pakistan, the nation has unexpectedly emerged as the most economically buoyant on the Asian subcontinent.

title: Schenectady Best Goes To Bulldog
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 26It was no puzzle to Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone today at the Mohawk Valley Kennel Club show. For the red brindle and white bulldog whose nickname is Puzzle was named best of 1,103 dogs in the century old, red brick State Armory building at the first allbreed show in the East this year.

title: Television
description: Indian children in World Hunger: Who Will Survive? on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1975

title: ROCKEFELLER SEES FINDING THAT C.I.A. VIOLATED CHARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Vice President Rockefeller said today he believed that the investigative commission he heads would find that the Central Intelligence Agency had violated its charter by undertaking activities within the United States.

title: West Berlin ls Curbing Immigration by Jews
description: BERLIN  As in the 19th century, Jews fleeing persecution in Russia are wandering through Western Europe in search of homes.

title: Vietnam, 63 and Now
description: The writer headed the Polish delegation to the International Control Commission in Vietnam in 1963 and 1964. In 1968, the Government dismissed him as professor of law at Warsaw University. He is now professor of political science at Queens College of the City University of New York.

title: 3d Held in Georgia Killings
description: BLUFFTON, Ga., Jan. 26 (UPI)The authorities arrested a third suspect last night in the executionstyle slayings of four persons at a small rural grocery Wednesday. A spokesman for the Georgia State Patrol said that John Hennon Bristow, 26 years old, of Blakely had been picked up by agents of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation and sheriff's deputies in Blakely and charged with four counts of murder.

title: Pakistan's Food Situation And Economy Rebound
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 23  Three years after the breakup of Pakistan, the nation has unexpectedly emerged as the most economically buoyant on the Asian subcontinent.

title: REV. JOSEPH COLLINS, CATHOLIC EDUCATOR
description: The Rev. Joseph B. Collins, director from 1942 to 1968 of the National Center of Religious EducationConfraternity of Christian Doctrine in Washington, died there Thursday. His age was 77.

title: ISRAELIS BELIEVE WEST BANK HAS OIL
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 (AP)Israeli geologists say there may be as much as seven billion barrels of oil under the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, the state radio reported today.

title: Olympics Crisis Will Be Tackled
description: LONDON. Jan. 26 (AP)Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, is going to Amsterdam, the Netherlands, on Tuesday to talk with his three vice presidents on the crisis threatening the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal.

title: Greek Protesters Attack 2 Officers From U.S. Vessel
description: CORFU, Greece, Jan. 27 (AP) A United States destroyer today canceled its visit to this Greek island at the Athens Government's request after two of its officers were attacked during antiAmerican riots.

title: An ExRanger Gets a Personal Plea to Help the National Parks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Ansel Adams, one of the world's most noted scenic photographers, carried his plan today for improved national parks to a onetime Yellowstone ranger: Gerald R. Ford.

title: Law Unit for Poor Warns of Cutbacks Without New Funds
description: The agency that provides legal representation in noncriminal matters to the city's poor will curtail its services within the next few weeks unless it gets more money, its official said yesterday.

title: WNET to Replace Its Program Guide With Smaller One
description: Image,the magazine and prograrn guide mailed to members of WNET/Channel 13, will cease publication in March to be replaced in April by a smaller program guide, called 13. A Guide to Good Viewing.

title: Market Place
description: There was a flurry of activity in Wall Street when it became clear some months ago the United States Government was going to allow. citizens to own gold for the first time since the Great Depression.

title: 2.7% DROP SHOWN IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The nation's productivity, or output per manhour, declined sharply again in the fourth quarter, and for 1974 as a whole showed its first decline2.7 per centsince records began to be kept in 1947, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Sadat and Giscard Talk in Paris; Egypt Seeks Arms and Backing
description: PARIS, Jan. 27  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt arrived today for a threeday visit seeking French arms, nuclear reactors, credits and political support.

title: Supreme Court Rules Out Retroactivity on Opening Up Juries to More Women
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Last week's Supreme Court ruling that criminal trial juries must be drawn from panels that reflect female representation in the community cannot be applied to overturn convictions rendered before the decision, the Justices held today.

title: Fritz Selbmann, 75, Dead; ExEast German Official
description: EAST BERLIN, Jan. 27 (Reuters)Fritz Selbmann, a former East German Deputy Premier who fell into disfavor in the late nineteenfifties, died last night at the age of 75.

title: Bruins Tie Scouts On Marcotte Goal
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 27 (UPI) Don Marco tte, with assists from Phil Esposito and Wayne Cashman, flipped in a goal with 46 seconds left tonight, giving the Boston Bruins a 33 tie with the Kansas City Scouts.

title: MRS. EUGENE HOLMAN
description: Edith Reid Holman, widow of Eugene Holman who was chairman of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), now the Exxon Corporation, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 2 East 67th Street.

title: JUSTICES TO STUDY AN EQUALPAY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress could compel states and cities to provide the same wages and working hours for their civil servants, including policemen and firemen, as Federal employes receive.

title: Turkish Airlift Ends
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 27 (Reuters)Turkey today ended her airlift of TurkishCypriote refugees from British bases in Cyprus and prepared to ship them back across the Mediterranean to Turkishheld northern Cyprus.

title: 4% Price Increase On Film Scheduled By Eastman Kodak
description: Professional and amateur photographers will pay 4 per cent more, on average, for still and movie film ordered from the Eastman Kodak Company after Feb. 28, the big photographic concern said yesterday. The Kodak announcement said the increased price for its roll film reflected higher cost of raw materials and manufacturing expenses.

title: U.S. GIVES OPECTALKS QUALIFIED APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (Reuters)The United States welcomed today the agreement by oilexporting countries to hold an international energy conference. But United States officials said there was still insufficient Western unity to warrant a meeting of producers and consumers.

title: Kuwaitis Planning for Day When Oil Ebbs
Delay Sought in a Bankruptcy Until U.S. Holds Bribery Trial
City Orders 13,000 To Begin Working Staggered Hours
description: Mayor Beame directed yesterday that 13,000 city employes working south of Canal Street begin working staggered hours. The employes would join 220,000 in private industry in midtown and downtown who are already in the fouryearold program.

title: 100 Drown in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 27 (AP)  About 100 persons aboard a ferryboat are believed to have drowned when the ferry and a steamer collided and the ferry sank in the Buriganga River, seven miles from Dacca. The accident occurred Saturday night. Officials said about 200 persons had been aboard the ferry and about 100 swam ashore.

title: Stock Market Up Sharply In 32.1MillionShare Day
description: The stock market erupted in a sharp rally yesterday in the heaviest trading day in New York Stock Exchange history.

title: U.S. PLEDGES AID FOR SAIGON ANEW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The State Department marked the second anniversary of the Paris ceasefire accords today with a pledge that the United States would continue to support the Saigon Government with military and economic aid.

title: China Cancels TwoThirds Of Orders for U.S. Wheat
description: The Chinese Government has canceled contracts to buy 601,000 tons of American wheat scheduled for shipment between next month and September, Cook Industries, Inc., a major grain trading company, announced yesterday.

title: Rockefeller Gifts in State Criticized but Found Legal
description: A state advisory committee found yesterday that Vice President Rockefeller's gifts to state aides while he was Governor did not violate the state Code of Ethics but that the gifts were not in the public interest because they created a great deal of suspicion.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1975

title: Bruins' Star Sets Hot Pace
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
BEAME DISMISSES 11 HIGH OFFICIALS AS CUTS CONTINUE
