description: Mayor Beame yesterday dismissed 11 highsalaried, appointed city employes, including five holdovers front the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: FORD TO FREE FUND FOR WASTE PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Environmental Protection Administrator Russell E. Train announced today that the Ford Administration was releasing in the next fiscal year $4billion for construction of municipal waste treatment plants. The funds will come from the $9billion previously impounded by former President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Corporate Profits: The $30Billion Hoard

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP)Joe Frazier and Jimmy Ellis, two former world heavyweight champions, have signed for a scheduled 12round bout in Melbourne, Australia, on Sunday, March 2. The bout is being promoted by Global Productions, Ltd., of Seattle, of which Joe Williams is the director of promotions.

title: Bhutto Says Mujib Destroyed Democracy in Bangladesh
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 27 (UPI)Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said today that Sheik Mujibur Rahman had destroyed democracy in Bangladesh by becoming president under a oneparty system.

title: Ford Eases CutOff Rule On Qualifying for a Rebate
description: Special to The New York Times

title: INCREASE IS URGED FOR COMPANY DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27A committee representing 10 Federal regulatory agencies recommended today a major expansion of the information that corporations file with Government agencies.

title: China Cancels TwoThirds Of Orders for U.S. Wheat
description: The Chinese Government has canceled contracts to buy 601,000 tons of American wheat scheduled for shipment between next month and September, Cook Industries, Inc., a major grain trading company, announced yesterday.

title: U.N. ASKS STOCKPILE OF 18 COMMODITIES
description: GENEVA, Jan. 27 (Reuters)A $10.7billion plan to establish world stocks of 18 major commodities, to stabilize prices and assure supplies, was published here today by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

title: High 1974 Oil Prices Put Trade Deficit at 3Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The sharply higher cost of oil imports pushed the nation's trade deficit to $3.07billion last year, the second largest in this century, the Department of Commerce reported today.

title: Jersey Legislature Will Begin Inquiry On Nursing Homes
description: The New Jersey State Assembly voted in Trenton yesterday to set up a joint legislative committee to investigate the state's nursinghome industry. The bipartisan resolution, sponsored by Senator John J. Fay Jr., Democrat of Colonia, was passed by the State Senate Jan. 6.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)The dollar's slide of last week continued today.

title: Canada's Trade Surplus Off
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Statistics Canada said today that Canada's 1974 trade surplus narrowed to $419million from $1.998billion in 1973. Exports advanced 26 per cent to $31.95billion, while imports increased 35 per cent to $31.53billion it said.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEW APPARATUS FOR FIREMEN

title: Article 5  No Title
description: MOTORCADE FOR JOBS

title: Honest Intelligence
description: Some extraordinary chapters for the history of national intelligence services are being written these days. The head of the United States intelligence community has gone public with a remarkable description of normally secret operating procedures of the Central Intelligence Agency. The Senate is moving into an evaluation of the nation's overall intelligence requirements, foreign and domestic, asking questions and raising issues that have gone substantially unchallenged since 1947.

title: Plan to Save 860 City Jobs By Retirements Is All but Dead
description: City and union otticials conceded yesterday that a proposal to avert the dismissal of at least 860 civil servants by seeking the early retirement of older workers had all but collapsed.

title: Jackson Indicates He Will Announce His Presidential Candidacy on Feb. 6
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 27Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington will announce his candidacy for the ]976 Democratic Presidential nomination in a fiveminute network commercial before the 11 P.M. news on Feb. 6, he is telling supporters here.

title: High 1974 Oil Prices Put Trade Deficit at 3Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The sharply higher cost of oil imports pushed the nation's trade deficit to $3.07billion last year, the second largest in this century, the Department of Commerce reported today.

title: Paint Contractor Denies Deal With Camden Mayor
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27A painting contractor whom the state was relying on as its star witness against Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden gave further testimony today that again tended to absolve the Mayor of misconduct charges.

title: DR. HYMAN L. RACHLIN
description: Dr. Hyman L. Rachlin, a psychoanalyst and psychiatrist, died Sunday at his home, 35 Park Avenue. His age was 78.

title: Chain Sales in December Up 7.6% From 73 Level
C.I.A.F.B.I. INQUIRY VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Senate voted, 82 to 4, today to create a special committee to investigate the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and more than a dozen other intelligence and law enforcement agencies of the Government.

title: LEGISLATORS COOL TO LOAN FOR U.D.C.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Reflecting the obvious unhappiness of their members, the legislative leaders of both parties said today that there was no chance of action this week on Governor Carey's plant to shore up the foundering Urban Development Corporation with a $178million emergency state loan.

title: A Pattern Long Developing
description: During the long Watergate ordeal, Richard Nixon and some of the men around him frequently insisted that whatever they might have done that was questionable was no worse than what other Presidents and Administrations had done in the past. That is not much of a defense, even if it could be demonstrated as fact; but substantial new charges do suggest that President Lyndon Johnson used and profited from illicit wiretaps in the campaign year 1964.

title: Soviet Doubles Oil Price in East Europe
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 27  The Soviet Union today was reported about to double the fixed price for oil it has been charging its East European allies. Until now it has been selling them oil at roughly onethird of world market prices.

title: LUCILLE S. KATCHEN
description: Lucille Svet Katchen, a pianist and a director and member of the concert committee of the Monmouth (N. J.) Arts Foundation, died yesterday in Monmouth Medical Center. She was 71 years old and lived at 384 Highland Avenue, Elberon, N. J.

title: Judgment Faulted on Rockefeller Gifts
description: A state advisory committee found yesterday that Vice President Rockefeller's gifts to state aides while he was Governor did not violate the state code of ethics but that the gifts were not in the public interest because hey created a great deal of suspicion

title: Case on Moriarty Built on Wiretaps, Prosecutor Asserts
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27 (AP)Wiretap evidence forms the basis of the state's case in the trial of Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarity and 19 other men and women on gambling charges, the prosecution said today.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Board to Fingerprint School Personnel
description: Fingerprint checks of recent candidates for city school jobs, including those of teachers and security guard, have found that a number had arrest records for sexual offenses, child abuse, illegal possession of guns and other offenses.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Sportfishermen vs. Seiners
description: Late last November, the Department of the Interior proposed that a 4mile stretch of the Cape Hatteras (N. C.) National Seashore be reserved for sportfishermen Only, seven days a week, from Dec. 14, 1974 through April 30, 1975.

title: Mrs. Court Wins In Close Match
New Jersey Briefs
description: The Otis Elevator Company, which was accused racial segregation at its assembly plant in Harrison, agreed to give preference to black and female job applicants. In an agreement signed by a lawyer for the company and officials of the United States Equal Opportunity Commission, Otis said it would bring its Harrison labor force to racial and sex levels equal to the rest of the Newark metropolitan area.

title: Duryea Upholds Sport Unit
description: HAUPPAUGUE, L. I., Jan. 27Perry J. Duryea Jr. dissented today with Governor Carey's call to do away with the New York State Sports Authority. The Assembly's Republican minority leader urged that the agency, which was created to finance the building of municipal facilities through bonds, be given a chance to prove itself.

title: Tenneco Quarter Net Off, But Year's Profit Is Up
E.C.A.C. Threatened by New League
description: The future of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, seriously threatened by recent defections, may be further jeopardized by a formal basketball conference being organized by seven major Eastern universities. Penn State, which resigned from the E.C.A.C. last year, and Pittsburgh, which will resign in June, hope to join five E.C.A.C. members West Virginia, Duquesne, Rutgers, Syracuse and George Washington  to form this league.

title: NEW LISBON PACT SOUGHT BY SOARES
description: LISBON, Jan. 27Foreign Minister Mario Soares, speaking as the leader of Portugal's Socialist party, warned today that the nation faced the possibility of civil war if democratic Government was abandoned as a result of Communist moves.

title: BEAME DISMISSES 11 HIGH OFFICIALS AS CUTS CONTINUE
description: Mayor Beame yesterday dismissed 11 highsalaried, appointed city employes, including five holdovers from the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: New Corrections Chief
description: In his 24 years with the New York City Police and Traffic Departments, Benjamin Ward, the newly named State Commissioner of Correctional Services, has found himself in some exacting situations. There have been situations requiring the sensitivity and tact of a diplomatas when he became the first black police officer to preside over departmental disciplinary trials.

title: Ray Plea for Access To Trial Data Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)The Supreme Court cleared the way today for lawyers for James Earl Ray to gain access to evidence gathered by the State of Tennessee in investigating the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: 2d Jet Almost Hit Ridge Near Dulles
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Several weeks before a Trans World Airlines plane crashed west of here Dec. 1, another jetliner came perilously close to hitting the same mountain ridge.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1975

title: BONN ABORTION LAW MAY BE OVERRULED
description: BONN, Jan. 27An unconfirmed television report that West Germany's highest court is planning to declare unconstitutional a recently passed abortion law caused an uproar here today.

title: AIRLINES PROPOSE NEW YOUTH FARES FOR EUROPE TRIPS
description: International airlines said yesterday that they had voted to restore cutrate youth fares between this country and Europe April 1, in a bid to help stimulate sagging transAtlantic travel and to deter American young people from going to Canada to catch cheap flights. The airlines agreement, however, must be approved by government regulatory agencies on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Agency Rejects a Plea to Delay Sale of Plant That Employed 200
description: Robert Abrams, Bronx Borough President, reported last night that a quasipublic agency in Albany had rejected an 11thhour effort to block the sale at auction today of the equipment of a south Bronx cabinetmaking factory that employed 200 workers.

title: Stock Market Up Sharply In 32.1MillionShare Day
SLIDE CONTINUES FOR THE DOLLAR
description: SLIDE CONTINUES FOR THE DOLLAR

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 27The two Italian experts accused here of using foot signals in the world team championship were severely reprimanded by the World Bridge Federation in the early hours of today, but allowed to continue playing in the tournament.

title: DR. HARRY BERLER
description: Dr. Harry Berler, a dentist for 57 years, who formerly headed the dental department of Bronx Hospital, died here yesterday at the age of 78. He lived at 320 Central Park West.

title: Rubber Plant Shutdown
description: NATCHEZ, Miss., Jan. 27 (UPI)  The Natchez plant of the Armstrong Rubber Company closed down for two weeks today; idling some 900 employes. R. E. Parson, the manager, said: that the shutdown was necessary to reduce large inventroies of passenger car Aires. He also said that Armstrong plants at Hanford, Calif., Nashville and Des Moines, Iowa, were closed for 14 days.

title: Ford Held Open to Compromise on Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) President Ford told Republican and Democratic Senators today that he was willing to compromise with Congress on his economicenergy program the Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, reported.

title: Gibson Signs, Saying 75 Will Be His Last Season
N. & W. LIFTED NET 25% IN 4TH PERIOD
description: Despite a 28day strike last fall by coal miners, the Norfolk & Western Railway Company, which derives about 35 per cent of its annual revenues from hauling coal, reported yesterday a 25 per cent earnings increase for the final quarter of 1979.

title: City College 6Year Program In Law Gets Final Approval
description: The Board of Higher Education last night gave final approval to City College's new program to accelerate the training of urban lawyers, but not before one board member urged that the program be monitored to prevent ethnic discrimination in its selection procedures.

title: ENJOYABLE SINGING BY MISS THOMPSON
Uganda Leader Marks His Fourth Year in Power in an Atmosphere of Fear and Disarray
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 26At a garden party celebrating the fourth anniversary of Maj. Gen. Idi Amin's seizure of power in this East African nation, a Uganda major wearing a kilt of the Royal Stuart tartan and a cap resembling that of the Gordon Highlanders strolled across the lawn with a bottle of beer.

title: U.S.I.A. Is Set for Major Changes if Study Group Has Its Way
5 Mexicans Killed By Bombs Planted By Leftist Rebels
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 (Reuters)Five people were killed and nine wounded today as dynamite bombs planted by leftwing guerrillas went off in the Mexican capital and provincial cities, the police said. [Some reports said the number hurt was approaching 30.]

title: Newsprint Usage Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) The total estimated newsprint used in the United States last year declined slightly from the amount consumed in 1973, it was announced today. The American Newspaper Publishers Association said 10.3 million tons of newsprint were used in 19741.3 per cent less than the year before.

title: Soviet Boxers Win Here, 82
description: The United States amateur boxing team showed a lack of talent that was accompanied by a lack of spectator sportsmanship last night as the Soviet Union won eight of 10 bouts at the Felt Forum.

title: 6 Bombs Go Off in England After I.R.A. Talks
description: LONDON, Jan. 27Six bombs were exploded in Britain today and at least 23 persons were injured, 19 of them in a single incident.

title: Village in India Has Bank Run by Women for Women
description: BOMBAY, IndiaA couple of years ago, when Shalini Patil, a young social worker here, was visiting her native village, some farmers wives complained that they wanted to buy cows and set up a small dairy business, but no bank would grant them a loan.

title: 3 RAIL SYSTEMS STRUCK BRIEFLY
description: Strikes were called at midnight Sunday against the Burlington Northern, the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway and the Louisville & Nashville Railroad by four craft unions in an apparent protest over the lack of a contract. Workers picketed in 13 states.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court on a Wide Variety of Issues
Study Links Diabetes Pills To Heart Disease Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Pills used by more than 1.5 million Americans to control diabetes are probably hazardous and capable of causing premature death from heart disease, according to a major statistical study released today by the American Medical Association.

title: NADJARI STUDYING PISTOL LICENSING
description: A special state grand jury is hearing testimony that police officers and their superiors accepted bribes to help merchants obtain permits for pistols to protect themselves against hold. up men.

title: Japan Offers Original Catfish
description: There is an old Japanese saying: In baseball, the legs go first.

title: 7 ECONOMISTS SAY 16BILLION TAX CUT IS NEEDED AS SPUR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Seven economists of varied political persuasions agreed unanimously today that a tax reduction of at least the $16billion size proposed by President Ford was needed to pull the economy out of its recession.

title: Gurney Trial Is Postponed Because of Surgery Plea
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP)A Federal judge postponed today the bribery and conspiracy trial of former United States Senator Edward Gurney until Feb. 24 to give Mr. Gurney time to undergo surgery of an undisclosed nature.

title: CITY PENSION PLAN TO BE FILED AGAIN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Victor H. Gotbaum, head of the biggest municipal union in New York City said today that a pension agreement negotiated with the city in 1970, but not approved by the Legislature, would be reintroduced within two weeks.

title: Pipeline Blast in Iowa
description: MEDIAPOLIS, Iowa, Jan. 27 (UPI)A MichiganWisconsin natural gas pipeline ruptured early today, causing an explosion and flames that lit up the sky and could be seen for 100 miles. Des Moines County sheriff's police said. No casualties were reported.

title: House G.O.P. Rewards Jarman, ExDemocrat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)  House Republicans rewarded Representative John Jarman of Oklahoma today for switching from the Democratic party. They gave him a highranking position on the House Science and Astronautics Committee.

title: Needed: A Program
description: President Ford is insisting on acceptance of a taxrebate plan that gets money into circulation too slowly and that gives too much to the welltodo. He is determined to bull through his inordinately expensive energy program, which, although theoretically returned to lowincome groups via tax cuts and grants, would add at least $30 billion to fuel costs, and could add double that to living costs as higher energy bills worked their way into the entire cost structure. The impact of this mammoth oil and gas bill would be to worsen both inflation and the slump.

title: On the Jobless Line in Cleveland: It's Rough, but There Are a Lot of People Out of Work
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 As they push their way out of the cold and through the heavy glass doors of the threestory, redbrick building at 3150 Chester Street, it's easy to tell the new people from the ones who have been coming around for a while.

title: Rabin, at Israel Bond Rally, Bids Moscow Resume Ties
description: ELATH, Israel, Jan. 27 Premier Yitzhak Rabin urged the Soviet Union today to stop ignoring Israel diplomatically and to renew contacts if it wants to play a meaningful role in the Middle East.

title: QualitySchool Integration Plan For Twain Is Upheld by Judges
description: A decision designed to end racial segregation at Mark Twain Junior High School in Brooklyn was affirmed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: 18 Christian Leaders Attack Debilitating Secular Influences
Hearings on LILCO Plants At Jamesport Are Put Off
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Carbide Net Soars 105.4% Shell Gains
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday fourthquarter net income of $152million, or $2.49 a share, up 105.4 per cent from the yearearlier $74million, or $1.22 a share. This was exceeded only by last year's thirdquarter net of $2.54 a share.

title: Welfare Monitor
description: When the old Welfare Council was created fifty years ago to coordinate the activities of scores of private philanthropic societies in New York City, there was no Social Security system, no governmental insurance for the unemployed and no vast network of public relief and manpower agencies ministering to the needy.

title: Public Is Responding on Tavern Blast
description: The request for information about last Friday's bombing of a Fraimces Tavern annex, which killed four persons and injured 56, has produced quite a bit of response, a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: People in Sports
Byrne to Seek Income Tax And Cut in the Sales Levy
South's Opposition Grows To a Tax on Natural Gas
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25The South, following the lead of New England, is producing growing opposition to President Ford's proposals to conserve energy by forcing up prices.

title: AIRLINES PROPOSE NEW YOUTH FARES FOR EUROPE TRIPS
description: International airlines said yesterday that they had voted to restore cutrate youth fares between this country and Europe April 1, in a bid to help stimulate sagging transAtlantic travel and to deter American young people from going to Canada to catch cheap flights.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ROSE 2.3% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week lended Jan. 25 rebounded with a gain of 2.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association placed the latest week's output at 2.62 million tons and a production index of 107.2, the highest level since the final week of November, 1974. This compared with the 2.56 million tons poured in the week ended Jan. 18 when the index stood at 104.8.

title: Great Neck School Chief Is Discharged
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Jan. 27Often engulfed by hisses and shouts, the Great Neck school board voted 3 to 2 this morning to dismiss Mortimer J. Abramowitz, the superintendent since 1970, and tonight voted to hire a replacement, Murray Hart.

title: Lovers, a New Homosexual Musical
description: Years ago when Mart Crowley made the remark in The Boys in the Band that went, if memory serves, Show me a happy homosexual and I'll show you a gay corpse! one doubted its truth. Since then the forces of Gay Liberation have made homosexuality more open and socially acceptable then ever before. This seem a fair thing.

title: Lawyers for Carter Say Judge Erred on Appeal
description: Defense lawyers in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triplemurder case said yesterday that a judge who had rejected an appeal for a new trial had unwittingly participated in suppression of evidence and should have disqualified himself from ruling on the appeal.

title: MEETING ON RIGHTS FOCUSES ON POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27A coalition of civil rights supporters gathered here today to talk about a civil rights program in the new session of Congress, but they spent most of the day discussing the need for economic relief for the nation's minorities and poor.

title: BROUN AWARD WON BY TIMES REPORTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Selwyn Raab, a reporter for The New York Times, received the Newspaper Guild's 1974 Heywood Broun Award today for an article revealing new evidence that called into question the murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the boxer and John Artis.

title: Newspaper Ad Men Elect
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP)James F. Urbanksi, business manager of the Tribune Company, publishers of The Tampa Tribune and Tampa Times, was elected president of the International Newspaper Advertising Executives Associa tion at the group's annual winter conference today.

title: Century After Stanley, 150 Navigate the Congo
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)An international team of explorers who braved waves, a whirlpool and fever in an expedition down the Congo River, returned safely to Britain today.

title: 3 Harrisburg Victims Identify Leonia Slaying Suspect
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 27At least three witnesses to one of the crimes charged to Joseph Kallinger picked him out of a police lineup here today as the man who had bound, gagged, and robbed them at a bridge party here last month.

title: Notes on People
description: The Park Avenue penthouse truck farm of Stewart R. Mott, the General Motors stock heir and political philanthropist, is the target of a contractbreaking action filed yesterday by his fellow shareholders in the cooperative apartment building at 74th Street.

title: CHANGE IS URGED IN EXTRADITIONS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27Joseph C. Woodcock Jr. the Bergn County Prosecutor, staged a oneman lobbying campaign in the State House today to include juveniles under the terms of New Jersey's extradition law.

title: Brezhneo Very Tired, Budapest Editors Told
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 27Senior Hungarian newspaper editors have been told in a briefing by Communist party officials that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was very, very tired.

title: AMEX STOCKS UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed sharply higher yesterday in the largest volume of trading since Dec. 30.

title: Double Wedding Goes On In Maine Despite Injuries
description: BANGOR, Me., Jan. 27 (AP)Undaunted by a traffic accident that injured four members of the wedding party, two couples from this area were married here as scheduled last Saturday night.

title: TOTI DAL MONTE, 81, SOPRANO OF THE 20'S
description: TREVISO, Italy, Jan. 27 (UPI) Toti Dal Monte, one of the great sopranos of the nineteentwenties and thirties, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: Legislature Gives Its Final Approval To UnitPricing Bill
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27  The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a unitpricing bill that requires supermarkets in the state to post the price by ounce or pound for all food, beverages, personalcare items and household items.

title: FRANK W. REED
description: Frank William Reed, who was president of the New York Financial Writers Association in 195657, died yesterday at his home, 29 Mary Street, Valley Stream, L.I. He was 72 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: Catholic School Week Is Promoted on Radio
description: Five New York radio stationsWCBS, WOR, WNBC, WRFM and WNEWwill be running an unusual paid radio message the rest of this week. It will be promoting Catholic School Week, which begins Sunday.

title: Pop Music
description: Barbara Cook, with a long career as an ingenue in such Broadway musicals as The Music Man, Candide, She Loves Me and The Grass Harp behind her, made her concert debut at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night to an audience so enthusiastically responsive that she appears to have become an instant cult figure.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Strongly Defends India's System of Democracy
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 27On the 25th anniversary of India's Constitution Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has stanchly defended the nation's democratic system and compared some of her opponents to Nazis and Fascists.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Jan. 27, 1975

title: Chess:
description: When the organizers of the Lublin international tournament invited Mikhail Tal to join 15 other participants, it was like opening the hen house for the fox. Not since the days of the great Akiba Rubinstein and Savielly Tartakower has Poland had a grandmaster, and the only two grandmasters who entered besides Tat were Mato Damjanovic of Yugoslavia and Levente Lengyel of Hungary, both well past their prime.

title: Pacers' Purchase Approved
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Jan. 27 (AP)American Basketball Association trustees approved the sale of the Indiana Pacers today to a sixmember group of Indianapolis investors.

title: Stolen Explosives Used
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 27Robert Dwyer of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, said today that recent bombings in Puerto Rico attributed to leftwing groups seeking independence for the island had used Iremite, an explosive that he called more powerful than dynamite.

title: Books of The Times
description: Le Corbusier's housing project for workers at Pessac, France, of 1925, was once composed of pure, clean forms, rationally arranged for light and air. The housing seemed to embody many of modern architecture's formal and social goals. But to many of the occupants, the buildings were just white boxes, not houses; they cared far more that they had been denied decorations than that they were given great amounts of light and open space.

title: Steingut Seeks 2Party Reform Of LawyerLegislators Ethics
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut said today he was seeking bipartisan reform of legislative ethics that would generally tighten disclosure requirements and restrictions on permitting lawyerlegislators to practice before state agencies.

title: Keystone: Racing as Unusual
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP)Journeymen and apprentice jockeys filled out Keystone race track's ninerace card today as many regular riders refused to mount because they said the track was too wet and unsafe.

title: Magruder's Belongings At Prison Farm Stolen
description: ALLENWOOD, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP)Jeb Stuart Magruder, who was jailed for his part in the Watergate conspiracy, went back to the Federal prison farm here last weekend to collect his belongings. They had been stolen.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EMERGENCE The immediately postwar face of Vienna is dim to many Americans now that World War II has receded so far into the past. The television rerun of a movie like Graham Greene's thriller The Third Man set amid the rubble, is one kind of reminder. Many American tourists know modern Vienna as one of the most beautiful of European capitals.

title: Board to Fingerprint School Personnel
description: Fingerprint checks of recent candidates for city school jobs, including those of teachers and security guard, have found that a number had arrest records for sexual offenses, child abuse, illegal possession of guns and other offenses.

title: Foreigners Dining in Peking Find the 35c Special Hard to Get
description: PEKING, Jan. 27It was to have been a simple beerandnoodles lunch, the way the Chinese man in the street would have it. The four of us, three Americans and a Canadian, sat at a table near the potbellied stove and asked the waitress for the standard fare. She smiled, and scurried away to bring us what we hoped would be the 35cent meal.

title: State and Campus
description: In ordering the termination of some weak doctoral programs at several universities, the State Education Department has embarked on a delicate and potentially risky mission. The first closing orders stated that the programs to be eliminated were of inadequate quality. But university administrators have been informed that doctoral manpower needs will also be taken into account.

title: Philharmonic Delves Into Past for Program Notes
description: For some veteran New York Philharmonic concertgoers, reading the new program notes for the orchestra's concerts may seem like turning the clock back. Last weekend's concert program, for example, included Mozart's Concerto for Flute and Harp, and the note for it was written in 1931 by Lawrence Gilman, program annotator for the orchestra from 1921 to 1939.

title: TREASURY SHIFTS STAND ON SAVINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Treasury disclosed today new compromise positions on the two most controversial aspects of the proposed legislation making basic reforms in the nation's deposit institutions.

title: Zambia Acts to Combat Slumping Copper Prices
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, San. 27 (AP)The Zambian Government has canceled all import licenses issued during the last 13 months in a bid to save foreign exchange following the slump in copper prices.

title: Galileo, a Stage Piece, Opens Film Series
Latins, Upset Over Trade, Postpone Talks With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Argentina, citing the new United States Trade Act, notified Washington and 22 other hemisphere governments today that as host country she had decided to postpone indefinitey a conference of foreign ministers set for Buenos Aires in March.

title: Seton Hall's Star in Recruiting Inquiry
description: Msgr. Thomas G. Fahy, president of Seton Hall University, confirmed last night there was evidence that Gler Mosley, sophomore star on the basketball team, had been recruited and should not have played last year, when he led the Pirates to national status.

title: Bucks Edge Jazz On Buzzer Shot
City Expresses Gratitude To 63 Foster Grandparents
description: Sixtythree foster grandparents who have been giving loving attention to emotionally and physically handicapped youngsters throughout the city were honored by the city yesterday in a ceremony at which Mrs. Abraham D. Beame officiated.

title: Joy Along Wall Street
description: Yesterday's strong rally and heavy turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was but the most visible manifestation of a market upsurge that has been developing over the last six weeks or so. During this period interest rates have plummeted to 7 per cent from as high as 12 per cent for majorbank certificates of deposit and to as low as 4 per cent from 9 per cent for commercial paper. As a result, large amounts of money that had been invested in these highyielding cash equivalents have been moving into the stock market.

title: They Have Learned the Art of Building a Home Cheaply
description: BATH, Me.The Shelter Institute, located one flight up in a turnofthecentury building at 72 Front Street here, offers a basic course in home building. Thus far its three founders, their friends and students have been responsible for starting or completing 20 houses in this area where commercial building is at a virtual standstill.

title: Psyche, the White Rock Girl: No Longer Topless
description: Some say it's better to die on your feet than to live on your knees. Not Psyche, the White Rock girl.

title: 7 ECONOMISTS SAY 16BILLION TAX CUT IS NEEDED AS SPUR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Seven economists of varied political persuasions agreed unanimously today that a tax reduction of at least the $16billion size proposed by President Ford was needed to pull the economy out of its recession.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday, January 27, 1975 AMERICAN EXCHANGE (Volume 3,246,820 shares)

title: Attorney GeneralDesignate Asserts Death Penalty, if Enforced, Is Deterrent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Attorney Generaldesignate Edward H. Levi said today he believed that the death penalty, if enforced and applied to a limited category of offenses, would be a deterrent, and that its imposition ought to be left to individual states.

title: N.F.L. to Draft Today; Giants, Johnson Wait
description: The first question people ask Ron Johnson these days is the last question that would have entered his mind one year ago: Will you be traded or kept by the New York Giants?

title: 3 Held in Prison Plot
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The State Department of Institutions and Agencies announced today the arrest of three persons for trying to smuggle shotgun shells into a woman's prison. A department spokesman said that Euston Harp, Louis Westbrook and Henrietta Smith, all of New York City, were arrested at the woman's prison at Clinton with six 20guage shotgun shells in some giftwrapped yarn. They were visiting Mary DeForrest, 29 years old, a former gogo dancer, who is serving 20to25 years for murder in the July, 1970, slaying of her boyfriend in Lakewood.

title: GARDNERDEMR TO ACQUIRE DEMCO
description: GardnerDenver, Inc., of Dallas, a manufacturer of equipment for the petroleum, mining and construction industries, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Demco, Inc., in exchange for 1,356,750 shares of Gardner  Denver common stock.

title: MILTON ROSENBLATT, INTERNIST, DIES AT 67
description: Dr. Milton B. Rosenblatt, a specialist in internal medicine and chest diseases, died Saturday in Columbus Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 36 Gramercy Park.

title: Albany Cakewalk
description: Members of both parties in the State Legislature must have had cotton in their ears and laughter in their hearts when Governor Carey told them three weeks ago that the state government no longer could draw on a neverending horn of plenty.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Harrisburg Victims Pick Leonia Suspect
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 27At least three witnesses to one of the crimes charged to Joseph Kallinger picked him out of a police lineup here today as the man who had bound, gagged, and robbed them at a bridge party here last month.

title: MAJOR OPPOSITION TOPS THAI VOTING
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 27 The middleoftheroad Democrats, long Thailand's major opposition party, won the largest number of seats in the election yesterday for the new national assembly, but they fell far short of the majority needed to choose a Premier.

title: I.B.M. SURGES $20 ON MIDWEST BOARD
description: International Business Machines Corporation stock, responding dramatically to a favorable Federal Appeals Court ruling in Denver last week, surged $20 a share in heavy trading on the Midwest Stock Exchange yesterday but failed to trade on the New York Stock Exchange, its principal marketplace, because of what the Big Board called a tremendous influx of orders.

title: FORD FUND SHIFTS ITS ARTS DIVISION
description: The Ford Foundation, which has announced a fouryear program to reduce its annual grants by more than 50 per cent, has reorganized its mechanism for disbursing funds to the arts in anticipation of the budget cutback.

title: C.I.A.F.B.I. INQUIRY VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Senate voted, 82 to 4, today to create a special committee to investigate the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and more than a dozen other intelligence and law enforcement agencies of the Government.

title: Karpatkin Memorial Today
description: There will be a memorial meeting today for Marvin M. Karpatkin, the lawyer active in civil rights causes, in the Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, at 5:30 P.M. Mr. Karpatkin died here Jan. 13.

title: Opiate of the Rulers
description: Henry Kissinger telephones in the night. He is exhausted from shuffling Chinese, Cypriotes, Arabs, Senators, Pakistanis, reporters, and now he has an overpowering urge to unwind on a little Vietnam.

title: Indiana Wins 22d, 73 to 57
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 27 (AP)  Indiana's offense started sluggishly but came to life in the second half tonight and the undefeated, No. 1ranked Hoosiers routed Illinois, 7357, in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Rockefeller Names Panel to Assist in Planning Science Advisory Apparatus for the Executive Branch
description: Vice President Rockefeller, who has been asked by President Ford to make plans for a new science advisory apparatus in the executive branch, has named a group to assist him.

title: Dr. Ralph F. Sikes, 66, Dies; ExYonkers Health Official
description: Dr. Ralph F. Sikes, who was health commissioner of Yonkers from 1948 until his retirement in 1971, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital there. He was 66 years old and lived at 25 Pilgrim Avenue in Yonkers.

title: Mysterious Moe Is DeClassified
description: Even as a majorleague catcher and shortstop for 15 seasons, Moe Berg was a mystery man, a big questionmark guy, as Casey Stengel once said. But never was he more mysterious than in 1934 when he walked through the streets of Tokyo in a black kimono. He was there as a member of an allstar team that included Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, but he had ignored the game in Omiya that day. Instead, with a bouquet of flowers, he entered St. Luke's Hospital where, speaking in Japanese, he introduced himself as a friend of Ambassador Joseph Clark Grew's daughter, Mrs. Cecil Burton, who had recently given birth to a daughter. Mrs. Burton's room was on the seventh floor. But when Moe Berg got off the elevator, he walked to a stairwell and went up to the roof, one of Tokyo's highest at the time. After unstrapping a motionpicture camera from beneath his kimono, he filmed industrial plants, oil refineries, railroad yards and warships in the bay. He reattached the camera to his body, picked up the bouquet and put it inside his kimono. Quickly he left the hospital. He never visited Ambassador Grew's daughter.

title: New Highs Posted by National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday new highs in fourthquarter earnings, while sales and earnings for the full year also rose to records.

title: Court Rejects Liddy's Plea That Sirica Erred in Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Supreme Court today rejected G. Gordon Liddy's contention that United States District Judge John J. Sirica had failed to give him a fair trial.

title: Study Links Diabetes Pills To Heart Disease Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Pills used by more than 1.5 million Americans to control diabetes are probably hazardous and capable of causing premature death from heart disease, according to a major statistical study released today by the American Medical Association.

title: CHARLES BANINO, 73, HEADED BOSTON RITZ
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 27 (AP)Charles L. Banino, former chef and president of the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Boston, died here Saturday at Notre Dame Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Union Oil Also UpMarathon Lists Drop
description: The Shell Oil Company and the Union Oil Company of California announced higher profits yesterday for the quarter and full year of 1974, while the Marathon Oil Company reported a decline for the quarter but an advance for the year.

title: EASTLAND DENIES HE TOOK A BRIBE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Senator James 0. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, has branded as totally false a report that he had received $50,000 to $60,000 to intervene with the Justice Department on behalf of Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas oil billionaire.

title: Music: Linda Ronstadt at Her Best
description: Linda Ronstadt, the countryrock singer, no doubt owes her success in part to looks and charm, and those attributes hadn't deserted her at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday night.

title: JURY CLEARS WIFE OF RALEIGH MAYOR
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 27Marguerite M. Lightner, the wife of Raleigh's first black Mayor, was acquitted by an allwhite jury here tonight of a charge that she had conspired to receive and dispose of a shoplifter's stolen goods.

title: Dr. Claude Eberhart, 63, Dies; Preventive Medicine Authority
description: Dr. Claude M. Eberhart, medical director in charge of the health and welfare division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died of a cardiac arrest on Saturday at his home, 150 Woodridge Drive, New Canaan, Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: Advertising
description: We feel that 1975 is a year when lots of companies are going to do wellbut do well by doing business differently from the way they did it in the past, said Edward J. Crane, vice presidentmarketing of the Emery Air Freight Corporation.

title: People and Business
description: Major changes in top personnel are expected to be announced later this week by some of the country's bestknown retail stores.

title: U.S. TO ANNOUNCE RISE IN FOOD AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Ford Administration plans to announce this week a $500million increase in the food aid program, to $1.4billion, as it continues to negotiate with legislators over how much of the total should be allocated for political rather than humanitarian purposes, according to Administration officials and Congressional aides.

title: RCA Tubeless TV Camera
description: The RCA Corporation introduced yesterday two new solid state tubeless blackandwhite television cameras using an image sensor called a chargecoupled device, that performs the functions of vidicon tubes. The company said the new camera sensors were the first solidstate units to be fully compatible with present TV monitors and accessories, eliminating the need for equipment modifications. The compny predicted a $300million market for such cameras in the next decade.

title: Preserving Everyone's Noo Yawk
description: Every time the Landmarks Preservation Commission designates another building as a landmark, the outside of which must be retained in its present state, the commission rewrites New York City's architectural history. Since it tends to designate the stately mansions of the rich and buildings designed by famous architects, the commission mainly preserves the elite portion of the architectural past.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Latins Postpone Talks

title: Few Arab Hijackers Punished by P.L.O.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27Sources close to the Palestine Liberation Organization say the guerrilla group has been able to punish only four Arab terrorists for hijacking operations that it disavows.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne announced yesterday that he would propose still another state income tax in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature next week, this one to be coupled with a reduction of the state sales tax to 3 per cent from 5 per cent. Although the Governor, a Democrat, would not provide specific figures, it was believed that the proposed income tax would be geared to raise $1billion and would be calculated at roughly the same rate as the one Mr. Byrne had unsuccessfully sought last summer1.5 to 8 per centor half the rate of the New York State income tax.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CANTOR JACOB STEIN
description: Cantor Jacob Stein of the Merrick (L.I.) Jewish Center died Sunday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 62 years old and lived in Hollis Hills, Queens.

title: Boston Paper Raises Price
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)The Boston Sunday Herald Advertiser has raised its price from 50 cents to 60 cents, citing tremendous increases in the cost of operating through the last several years.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (Reuters)The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a bill authorizing $275million in Federal funds to help the bankrupt Penn Central and other Eastern railroads. Trustees of Penn Central said that the railroad might have had to shut down completely by the end of February had the Federal funds not been forthchoming. The trustees said the railroad needed $225million to stay in operation.

title: Karen Logan, No.1 in Basketball, Seeks Top Superstar Identity
description: ROTONDA, Fla., Jan. 27Karen Logan couldn't understand why people were asking for her autograph today.

title: NO TAX REFUND SET ON CAR REBATE HERE
description: Newcar purchasers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, who get a manufacturers rebate will receive no refund of the 4 to 8 per cent sales tax they pay in New York on the original purchase price, the 6 per cent in Connecticut or the 5 per cent in New Jersey.

title: Irving Gets A Capezio For Music
Dances by Bowyer Are Small Dramas With Core of Truth
description: If It were not for an inner core of gritty truth, Bob Bowyer's small dance dramas would be indistinguishable from revue sketchesin the mind one moment and out the next. As it is, some linger on. He joined JoAnn Bruggemann and Marcus Schulkind for a weekend of performances at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: A T. & T.'S NOTES WILL YIELD 7.75%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's record offering of $600million in new debt was priced tentatively last night at levels below last November's original financing thatwas withdrawn after the Justice Department filed an antitrust suit. Thus, in the largest debt issue ever scheduled for the market by a utility or industrial company, A.T.&T. stands to save an estimated $13.5million in interest payments over the life of the issue.

title: REP. KLUCZYNSKI OF ILLINOIS DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Representative John C. Kluczynski, Democrat of Illinois, died today of a heart attack at his home in Chicago. He was 78 years old.

title: GEM DEALER ROBBED OF $70,000 EMERALDS
description: A Miami jewel dealer was robbed of $70,000 worth of emeralds here last night when a man he believed to be a prospective buyer and three other men took the gems at gunpointfrom his motel room near La Guardia Airport, the police reported.

title: TV: Enlightening Study of Franklin Ends Tonight
description: CBS's fourputmonthly series on Benjamin Franklin concludes tonight at 9:30, with The Statesman, a 90minute drama. It is the best of a generally good lot, perhaps because the writer, Edward Diamond, can pick up where the other scripts left off. The stuffing of purely biographical information is not quite so lumpy. The character of Franklin has already been developed to the point where drama considerations can come first.

title: Storm Lashes Philippines, Killing at Least 30 People
description: MANILA, Jan. 27 (AP)A tropical storm whipped up giant waves and triggered landslides that killed at least 30 people over the weekend before blowing itself out over the South China Sea, the official Philippine news agency reported today.

title: OFFICIAL DENIES CANCER CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Edward J. Baier, acting director of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, denied today that his agency ever downplayed the risk of cancer to the American worker.

title: 80,000 Butchers in Italy Close to Protest Low Sales
description: ROME, Jan. 27 (AP)Italy's 80,000 butchers closed their shops today to protest high prices and poor sales, but one butcher running what he called a meat boutique faced trial for selling veal at $10.50 a pound.

title: PRICES OF WHEAT SLIDE FOR MARCH
description: The announcement just before the close of trading that China had canceled orders for about 600,000 tons of wheat depressed the price on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday to $3.90 a bushel for the March delivery. This compares with a price of $4.04 on Friday.

title: Liquori Is Waiting For Bayi
Wilson for Europe
description: Prime Minister Harold Wilson's scheme has now been unveiled for keeping Britain in the European Economic Community (E.E.C.) without seriously splitting his divided Labor party.

title: Urban Design, Entrenched in the City's Bureaucracy, Finds Less Support Under Beame
description: There was one architect on the staff of the City Planning Commission in 1967. Now there are 48, with 30 more in affiliated agencies.

title: EDMUND A. DUFFY
description: Edmund A. Duffy, a veteran reporter and wire editor of The Long Island Press, died Sunday at his home in North Baldwin, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Polaroid Sales Bonus Increased on SX70's
description: Photographic dealers who sold close to a million Polaroid SX70 cameras in this country last year will be paid about $8.25million as a bonus by the Polaroid Corporation under a partnership program.

title: WILLIAM BROOKS, NBC EXECUTIVE
description: William F. Brooks, who was director of news and special events at the National Broadcasting Company from 1942 to 1946 and then a vice president until 1952, died yesterday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 230 East 48th Street.

title: Ida Fuller, 100, Who in 40 Got First Social Security Check, Dies
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Jan. 27 (AP)Ida Fuller, who received the first Social Security check issued in the United States, died today in a nursing home. She was 100 years old.

title: Stolen Explosives Used
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 27Robert Dwyer of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, said today that recent bombings in Puerto Rico attribued to Leftwing groups seeking independence for the island had used Iremite, an explosive that he called more powerful than dynamite.

title: JOSEPH ROSENBERG
description: Joseph Rosenberg, a staff reporter on The Wall Street Journal since 1972, died Friday of kidney failure in Duke University Hospital, Durham, N. C. He was 49 years old and lived in Millburn. N. J.

title: KISSINGER HOPEFUL ON SINAI FORMULA IN MIDEAST TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he believed a formula could be found in the Middle East to reconcile Israel's desire for progress toward peace with Egypt's insistence on the return of additional occupied territory in Sinai.

title: Stock Prices Rise In Heavy Trading; U.S. Steel Net Is Up
description: The stock market rally slipped into lower gear yesterday. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened with substantial gains and then gradually slipped back.

title: More Egalit for the Discard Fraternit
description: PARIS, Jan. 28President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who has been trying to thaw the icicles of aloofness from his high office in recent months, has taken another step in the direction of democratization by ordering the dropping of titles of nobility from invitations to the Elyse Palace.

title: TWO GUILTY ON GIFT TO NIXON CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) A Baltimore construction company and its two top executives pleaded guilty today to making an illegal $5,000 corporate contribution to Richard M. Nixon's 1972, reelection campaign.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Former Patrolman William R. Phillips was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life for the murders of a pimp and a prostitute in New York on Christmas Eve, 1968.

title: Bergdorf Planning 4 to 6 More Stores
CITY JOBLESS RATE CUBS 1.1 TO 8.5%, WITH 269,700 IDLE
French Adopt Plan To Cut Fuel Imports
DACCA SHIFT STIRS DOUBT AND CHEERS
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 28 The changeover to a presidential form of government and the establishment of a new administration have stirred uneasiness and distrust among some Bengalis and diplomats.

title: Market Averages
description: Tuesday, January 28, 1975

title: Ashe Victor in Richmond Net Tourney
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 28 (UPI) Thirdseeded Arthur Ashe breezed to a 62, 63 victory over Corrado Barrazzutti of Italy tonight in the first round of the 10th annual Richmond world championship tennis tournament. Ashe eliminated the 21yearold Italian in less than an hour.

title: Chef Wang's Recipes (Cont'd): Spicy Seafood, Chicken Soong
description: SHRIMP AND CRAB MEAT SZECHUANSTYLE

title: Investigator Tells of Cash Found in Policy Search
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 28An investigator for the Hudson County Prosecutor's office testified today that he had found $630 in cash in a dresser drawer while searching the apartment of Ann Kelly, one of 20 defendants charged with numbersgame violations here.

title: Regents and State U. in Long Island Dispute
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I.The lush, wooded campus of the State University College here has become the focal the of a conflict between the State Board of Regents and the trustees of the Stare University system.

title: Last Hired, and Usually the First Let Go
ABRAMS PRESSING BID TO SAVE JOBS
description: An auctioneer's chant echoed through the cavernous Acrite Industries plant, in the Bronx yesterday even as Borough President Robert Abrams accelerated his efforts to save the bankrupt cabinetmaking operationand the jobs of 200 workers formerly employed by the company.

title: KISSINGER HOPEFUL ON SINAI FORMULA IN MIDEAST TALKS
Thomas Reichman, Filmmaker, 30, Dies
description: Thomas Reichman, a docuMentary film maker and cameraman, was found dead Sunday night in his house at 34 Barrow Street in Greenwich Village. Mr. Reichman, who was 30 years old, was described by the Medical Examiner's office as an apparent suicide by gunshot wound.

title: Fund for Neediest Goes Over Million Forth Yearin Row
DR. LEONARD COHEN
description: Dr. Leonard Cohen, a mathematics professor at City College since 1951, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, while on vacation in Aruba, Netherlands Antilles. He was 46 years old and lived in Fort Lee. N. J.

title: Terrorists in Argentina Kill High Labor Ministry Official
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28 (AP) Terrorists firing submachine guns from a car killed a high Labor Ministery official and a companion today, police sources said.

title: St. John's Is Victor
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 28 (UPI)  George Johnson and Mel Utley tallied 18 points apiece to lead St. John's to a 7263 victory over Villanova tonight.

title: 2 New Carter Lawyers Opposed by Prosecutor
description: The Passaic County Prosecutor has asked a New Jersey judge to block Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from selecting two outofstate lawyers in their appeal of triplemurder conviction.

title: Jewish Leader Says Soviet Is Vital to a Mideast Accord.
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 (UPI)Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that he thought Israel should forsake United States peace moves and return to the Geneva conference because Middle Eastern peace could not be achieved without Soviet cooperation.

title: Pittston Co. Increases Earnings By 398.8% in Fourth Quarter
description: The Pittston Company, the nation's largest independent coal producer, reported yesterday that net income for the fourth quarter of 1974 increased 398.8 per cent from a year earlier. Similar increases were reported for the year, despite a nearly 2millionton decrease in the amount of coal the company sold.

title: F.B.I. Control
description: A longburied memorandum from the files of the Senate Watergate Committee makes it plain that the Nixon Administration did not invent the abuse of governmental police power to trample on individual rights. According to the memorandum, the former head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Atlantic City office told the committee that, at the request of the Johnson White House, the bureau conducted illegal electronic surveillances of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders at the Democratic National Convention in 1964. The former F.B.I. agent also reported that information gathered in the surveillances was reported directly to President Johnson by Cartha D. DeLoach, then assistant to J. Edgar Hoover, on a direct telephone line set up to bypass the White House switchboard.

title: CAMDEN INDICTS LEONIA SUSPECT
NEW INDOCHINA AID IS ASKED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Despite new warnings of strong Congressional opposition, President Ford asked Congress todayas his aides had said he wouldto appropriate $300million in additional military aid for South Vietnam and $222million more for Cambodia.

title: Ziegler Draws Rebuff At Michigan State U.
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 28The student government board at Michigan State University voted 7 to 3 tonight to withdraw financial support for a planned Feb. 25 speech by Ronald L. Ziegler, who had been press secretary to former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Dialogue on Oil
Dance: Masks and Vigor
description: The gruff vigor of Chhau, the Masked Dance of Bengal, lends itself to narrative dances extolling the virtues of courage, war and the hunt. The acrobatictinged style was barely known in India outside its own district until 15 years ago, and was seen in Western Europe only in 1972. The first opportunity United States audiences have had to see the company, also named Chhau, and its roughhewn and brilliantly costumed dancing was at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Prices on the Amex rose again yesterday for the second straight day but not as much as in the previous session. Trading, however, was slightly lighter than on Monday. Prices in the overthecounter market also rose in steppedup trading.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Frazier Hits 39 As Knicks Win
description: Coach Red Holzman's idea of giving Mel Davis his first National Basketball Association starting assignment worked out well enough last night, but a superb allround game by Walt Frazier was the ingredient that lifted the Knicks to a 115111 victory over the Atlanta Hawks before a crowd of 17,754 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sexual Revolution Cooling, Research Panel Reports
description: The sexual revolution is cooling down as some of the avantgarde find that sexual variety without affection leads to frustration, tension and jealousy, a panel of researchers said yesterday.

title: Militant Indians Cut Off Talks; Charge One of Band Was Shot
description: KESHENA, Wis., Jan. 28 Negotiations to settle the 28day occupation of a vacant Roman Catholic novitiate by armed Menominee Indians were abruptly broken off late tonight by the militant Indians over what they said was the wounding of one of their band by a vigilante or a National Guard.

title: East Stars Overwhelm A.B.A.'s West, 151124
description: SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan 28 (AP)Freddie Lewis of the Spirits of St. Louis scored 26 points tonight as the East Squad trounced the West, 151124, in the American Basketball Association's AllStar game.

title: Governor Seeks Local Aid From His 10 cGasoline Tax
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Governor Carey indicated today that at least some of the proceeds from his proposed 10centagallon gasoline tax would be earmarked to help financially presed local governments, in the new state budget he will present to the Legislature on Thursday.

title: Advertising
description: There are 46 million American households headed by husbandwife (or wifehusband) teams, and it is becoming increasingly important to marketers to know how one half influences the other in spending their total annual income of $624billion.

title: Economic FollowUp
Market Place
description: The news that the International Business Machines Corporation had won a reversal of a $259.9million antitrust judgment reached the stock market at a time when the technical position of the market was already favorable.

title: Recital
description: A song recital in which the piano stays covered and silent at the back of the stage? Elinor Amlen's program at the New Church on Monday was just such an event; her only instrumental partners were a violin, oboe and clarinet, heard alone or in various combinations. In its specialized way, the soprano's concert was intriguing, even when one longed for fuller, lower sonorities to support the voice.

title: Beame Acts to Tighten Control Over Guns Here
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday steps to curb the use and possession of guns here.

title: Senator Church Heads New C.I.A.F.B.I. Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Senator Frank Church was named today to head the Senate's new commitee investigating United States intelligence organizations. He said the panel would review the work of Vice President Rockefeller's commission on the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Oilers Down Aeros
description: EDMONTON, Ontario, Jan. 28 (UPI)Ken Baird's 21st goal sparked the Edmonton Oilers to a 75 victory over the Houston Aeros tonight in the W.H.A. The powerplay effort midway through the third period snapped a 55 deadlock.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Planning Commission proposals for a major urbanrenewal effort in the Bathgate section of the Bronx and for rezoning to strengthen the residential Pelham GardensLaconia neighborhood will be discussed at a public hearing at the Bronx County Court House at 7 o'clock tonight. The commission also suggested, in two miniplans issued yesterday to guide local development, that a nonprofit group be empowered to rehabilitate existing housing in the section east of Crotona Park, that East 161st Street be rezoned to prevent incursion of manufacturing on a commercial and housing district, and that transportation access be improved in the Baychester section.

title: Inland Housing Unit Ended
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI)The Inland Steel Urban Development Corporation has announced it will begin phasing out operations of InlandScholz Housing Systems, its modular housing plant at Milan, Mich. The company said the Government's withdrawal from programs encouraging the manufactured housing industry and the current recession made it impossible for the venture to succeed. The company is a subsidiary of the Inland Steel Company, Chicago.

title: Boston Globe Indicates Hoax on Brezhnev Visit
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28Editors at The Boston Globe said today that the newspaper was apparently the victim of a hoax in its recent report that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was believed to be here for cancer treatment.

title: Four Sentenced to Prison In Counterfeiting on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28Four men who produced $8.3million in counterfeit currency with paper, press, plates and ink supplied by the Secret Service will begin jail terms Monday.

title: French Adopt a 10Year Plan To Reduce Importing of Fuel
description: PARIS, Jan. 28The French Government decided today on a 10year program to reduce the country's dependence on imported fuel from the present level of 75 per cent of energy used to 55 or 60 per cent.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 29,1975

title: U.S. Oil Concerns to Leave Namibia
description: Four of the five American oil companies that have been under pressure from church groups to leave Namibia (South  West Africa) have served notice that they are pulling out of their offshore prospecting ventures in the disputed territory.

title: CARTER LAWYERS FOCUS OF DISPUTE
2D WITNESS BACKS MAYOR ERRICHETTI
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28A second state witness testified today that Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden had exercised no improper influence in the awarding of city painting contracts.

title: New Hampshire Tangle
description: The Senate has sensibly voted to entrust its Rules Committee with the task of unsnarling the New Hampshire Senatorial dispute in which one candidate was certified the winner by ten votes and then his rival was certified the winner by two votes. Since neither man has a clear claim, it was only logical to seat neither pending the outcome of the Rules Committee's examination of the results.

title: Fund for Neediest Goes Over Million For 5th Year in Row
description: For the fifth consecutive year, donations to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have exceeded $1million. The 159 latest contribu tions, aggregating $15,742.63, raised the total receipts to $1,004,024.50 in the fund's 63d annual apeal.

title: Pace of Trading Is Hectic As Price of I.B.M. Climbs
description: Brokers huddled sixdeep around Post No. 10 on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. E. F. Hutton  232!. a broker shouted. One, five hundred, he yelled again. I sold you 500, someone replied.

title: Davis to Consider Offers From Football, Baseball
description: ROTONDA, Fla., Jan. 28In his first seven swings in the baseballhitting competition of the ABCTV Superstars program today, Anthony Davis managed one foul ball that the catcher had no chance on. The New York Jets may have a good chance of signing their first choice in today's National Football League draft.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES PRICING OF SUGAR
description: The Justice Department disclosed yesterday in Washington that a Federal grand jury in New York has been investigating alleged pricefixing by major sugar refiners during 1974, when sugar prices soared 400 per cent.

title: JUDGE IS APPOINTED IN BANKRUPTCY CASE
description: Judge John J. Galgay was named here yesterday bankruptcy judge in the case of the Investors Funding Corporaof the Bankruptcy Act, according to James Bloor, trustee.

title: City Considers New Proposal by Unions to Save Jobs
description: The city and its labor unions yesterday recessed until today considerations of what First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh called additional suagestions in efforts to forestall the layoffs Friday of more than 1,000 Civil Service workers.

title: A Tougher Time Is Ahead for ChildSupport Evaders
description: Fathers who evade or ignore childsupport obligations will be in for a considerably tougher time as a result of Federal legislation signed earlier this month by President Ford.

title: Fragmented Thai Parties Seek Coalition After Inconclusive Election
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 28 The leader of the moderate Democratic party, which won the most seats in Sunday's inconclusive election for a National Assembly, met today, with leaders of other parties in an effort to put together a coalition.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: New York Adds Defensive End From Saints
description: It was billed as the National Football League's annual selection meeting, but for the Jets there was a lot more to the hectic day than the routine selection of college players.

title: MRS. EUGENE HOLMAN
description: Edith Reid Holman, widow of Eugene Holman who was chairman of Standard. Oil Company (New Jersey), now the Exxon Corporation, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 2 East 67th Street.

title: In Memoriam
description: FARRINGTONGeraldine A. Jan. 29. 4th anniversary, In loving, memory of my dear sister. Brother PARNELL.

title: CLEAN PESTICIDE TESTED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Jan. 28British researchers and chemical companies are working toward mass production of a pesticide that is largely free of the cumulative and toxic environmental effects associated with DDT and the other chlorinated hydrocarbons.

title: Court Finds No Obligation For Police to Sound Siren
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28 (AP) A state appeals court ruled today that a policeman had no legal obligation to sound the siren on his car while chasing a suspect.

title: Echo of a Rumble
description: On a summer night in 1959, 16yearold Salvador Agron, the Cape Man, went to a gang rumble in a Hell's Kitchen playground. While gang members held two teenaged boys down, he stabbed them to death. Now 31, he is an inmate at Green Haven Prison in Stormville. He will not be eligible for parole until 1993. Following are excerpts from a letter he sent to The New York Times.

title: Deere & Co. Raises Dividend
description: MOLINE, Ill., Jan. 28 (UPI)Deere & Co. said today it was increasing its quarterly dividend on common stock to 45 cents a share from 40 cents. The dividend is payable April 1 to shareholders of record March 3.

title: Use of Food Stamps Soars As Jobless Turn to Them
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28More unemployed American workers are turning to the food stamp program, so that 17.1 million people8 per cent of the American populationare purchasing their groceries with these coupons, Department of Agriculture figures are reported to show.

title: Bills Raise Prices
description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., Jan. 28 (UPI)The Buffalo Bills of the National Football League announced today an increase in ticket prices, ranging from 50 cents to $1.50, for the 1975 season. The highest priced seats will sell for $13.50, the lowest $6.

title: Dance, Girl, Dance, Blends Rivalry and Sympathy
description: Last Saturday night, 800 to 900 people jammed the Directors Guild Theater in Hollywood for a tribute to Dorothy Arzner, which was produced by the Committee of Women Members of the Guild. Miss Arzner was Hollywood's only woman director in the nineteenthirties.

title: EXPEEKSKILL JUDGE CITED FOR PERJURY
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan, 28A Westchester County grand jury has indicted a former Peekskill City Court judge, Hugo Scuccimarra, for perjury in denying before a judicial inquiry that he had made sexual advances toward the mother of a defendant appearing before him.

title: Fiscal Crisis Perils Proposed Hotel Here
description: John Portman, the Atlantabased architect and developer, said yesterday that plans for the 54story, 2,000room hotel proposed for Times Square would be abandoned unless longterm financing could be found within five to six months.

title: DOLLAR ADVANCES IN TECHNICAL RISE
description: LONDON. Jan. 28 (AP)The dollar staged what dealers described today as a technical recovery from its recent steep slide:

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: (Some of Major Corporations Reporting Yesterday)

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 28  The defending champion Italian team suffered its first defeat in the World Bridge Federation's Berumda Bowl tournament today, losing to the Indonesians by 48 international match points.

title: Prices of Wheat Futures Rally; May Potatoes Slip Temporarily
description: Prices of wheat futures staged a vigorous recovery late yesterday after a decline that began Monday in response to the cancellation by the Chinese of contracts for 601,000 tons of wheat.

title: ARTILLERY SHELL GUIDED BY LASER
Quarter Rise 194.8%
description: Sharply higher profits were announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: The Divided Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Democratic party has made a poor showing at the beginning or the 94th Congress. It knows what it is againstPresident Ford's energy programand it knows what it wantsto replace him in the White House in 1976but it has no party policy on energy to substitute for the policy it opposes.

title: Falcons Choose California Passer
description: A big quarterback from California, Steve Bartkowski, was complimented yesterday by the National Football League. Bartkowski became the first player from an exceptionally talented group of college athletes to be picked in the N.F.L.'s 40th annual draft as the Atlanta Falcons predictably chose the 6foot4inch, 215pound athlete.

title: 2 Hurt in Protest
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP)Two persons were hurt and 18 were arrested when two veteran groups occupied the South Vietnamese consulate for about an hour yesterday to protest continued aid to South Vietnam.

title: Danish Government Resigns 3 Weeks After the Elections
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark. Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Denmark's minority Liberal party Government resigned tonight only three weeks after the country's last general elections.

title: Antonin Novotny,70, Dies; Czech Dictator, 195368
description: Antonin Novotny, the Communist party leader who wielded virtual oneman rule in Czechslovakia from 1953 until 1968, when he was forced out by the Prague Spring democratic reforms of Alexander Dubcek, died yesterday at the age of 70.

title: Streetwalkers Are Rezoned
description: PANAMA CITY (UPI)Immigration Director Temistocles Arjona says authorities this year have relocated nearly 7,000 foreign prostitutes who roamed the city streets with tourist cards. He estimated the number of foreign prostitutes still active in the city at about 1,000.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F.A. CUP

title: Top Women Performers Plan Gala Benefit at U.N.
description: A gala benefit concert, with some of the bestknown women performers in pop music, is being planned for the United Nations General Assembly on the evening of March 8.

title: E.E.C. Coal Output Off 10%
description: LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Coal output in the European Economic Community member states fell by 10 per cent last year to 243 metric tons, compared with 270 metric tons in 1973, the community's statistical office said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28 (Reuters)The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that home mortgages were likely to become easier to obtain in coming weeks than they were last year. The board reported a net increase in savings of $550million lr.st month.

title: Pool of Doctors Insurers Is Voted by State Senate
Talleyrand Of Arabia
BILL WALSH, 61, DIES; A DISNEY PRODUCER
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (UPI) Bill Walsh, a writer and producer for the Disney studio, whose achievements included the Mickey Mouse Club and Davy Crockett televion series and films including Mary Poppins, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 61 years old.

title: New Theory: Pyramids Built in Century
description: The six major pyramids of Egypt were not built one after another, as long assumed, but, according to a British physicist, were the product of a national effort crowded into a single century some 4,500 years ago.

title: Turkey Is Reducing Her Cyprus Force By 1,000 Soldiers
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Turkey announced today that she would withdraw 1,000 troops from Cyprus in what appeared a token concession to United States Congressional pressure for a Cyprus settlement.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Iran Plans Big Project to Make Teheran a Major World Capital
description: The Iranian Government has begun plans for a major development in Teheran that, if built in its entirety, will be one of the most extensive newtown projects of the twentieth century.

title: TV: Williamstown Version of Chekhov's Seagull
description: For tonight's twohour installment of Theater in America, on public television at 9 o'clock, Jac Venza, executive producer of the series, has gone to the Williamstown Theater Festival for a production of Chekhov's The Seagull. The stage production was directed by Nikos Psacharopoulos, artistic director of the theater. For television, he is joined by John Desmond as codirector.

title: Arthur Judson Dies at 93; Leading Concert Manager
description: Arthur Judson, for decades the leading American concert manager, died yesterday at his home in Rye, N. Y. He was 93 years old.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28In times of recession, when industrial corporations must scramble to bring costs in line with reduced sales and shrinking profits, the easy, standard tactic has been to lay off employes.

title: G.&W. TO ACQUIRE A BOOK PUBLISHER
description: Simon & Schuster, Inc., a bookpublishing company that has been the subject of numerous merger bids, entered an agreement yesterday to be acquired by Gulf & Western Industries, Inc. Under terms of the agreement Gulf & Western will exchange one of it shares for each eight shares of Simon & Schuster common stock.

title: Three Specialties From Chef Wang
description: PON PON CHICKEN

title: Stage: Women, Wittily
description: To call Charles Pierce a female impersonator is a little like comparing a RollsRoyce with a Toyota. To start with, one is cheaper than the other.

title: Action by State Urged To Guard Credit Rating
description: If New York State fails to appropriate funds for Urban Development Corporation bonds, the state's credit rating will be affected, Brenton W. Harries, president of the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday in a speech delivered in New Orleans.

title: Albany Lobbyists Are Still Thriving Despite Dearth of Wine and Roses
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28The state today made public the first entries tin this year's list of registered lobbyistsa milliondollar adjunct to the Legislature that deals in earnest advice, quiet meals and onetoone personal relationships unknown to most lawmakers constituents.
