title: Carey Considers Easing Of Penalty for Marijuana
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Governor Carey said today that he was considering the removal of criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana and replacing them with a system of fines or mandatory attendance at health clinics for treatment.

title: COURT REINSTATES DEATH CONVICTION
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)The State Supreme Court today reinstated the manslaughter County woman in the death of one of her twin daughters.

title: Du Pont Profit Plunges; Ohio Standard's Soars
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter last year fell 75.5 per cent below those of the final quarter of 1973. For all of 1974, the nation's largest chemical producer said profit was down 31.1 per cent from 1973, despite record sales for the quarter and the year.

title: Folk Art: Meeting Of Minds
description: It's all therethe carousel animals, the whittled figures, the quilts and appliqus, the weathervanes, the downhome scenes, the duck decoys, the mechanical toysthe wit and naivet, the humor and vitality, the fantasy and earthiness of American folk art.

title: FUNDS BLOCKED FOR G.O.P. DINNER
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28A Superior Court judge today issued an order blocking the distribution of any funds collected at a Republican State Committee dinner scheduled to be held tomorrow night until a clear understanding is reached on the recipients of the funds.

title: SOUTHERN RAILWAY POSTS RISE IN PROFIT
CORRECTION
description: A review in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified the writer of the script for The Statesman, a drama presented on CBSTV. The writer was Edward Adler.

title: Paper Exports Are Rising
description: JACKSON, Miss, (UPI)Mississippi ranks among the top 50 states for the export of paper and allied products and bentonite. In the past decade the state has doubled its export of paper and allied products and now ranks sixth. Mississippi ranks second in the export of bentonite.

title: PROFIT OF CON ED UNDER 73 LEVELS
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday that net income for both the final quarter of 1974 and the full year trailed 1973 levels, despite a strong comeback from its earnings slump last spring.

title: Drug Agency Keeps Ban On BirthControl Shield
Loss to Princeton Avenged by Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28To the Penn players, there was no place like home tonight as they gained sweet revenge by beating Princeton, 7557, before 6,297 basketball fans at the Palestra.

title: People and Business
description: The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, James J. Needham, ever on the lookout for ways to spark the equity markets, is talking up an idea that American corporations should be allowed to deduct common dividends as a business expense.

title: Books of The Times
description: Granted, H. P. Lovecraft may not be a name to conjure with. Still, he's a writer who happens to have piqued my curiosity over the years. He first caught my attention when, as an overimpressionable adolescent, I read in that irresistible Modern Library Giant, Great Tales of Terror and the Supernatural, two thoroughly gruesome Lovecraft stories: The Rats in the Walls, about a gentleman cursed with hereditary cannibalism, and The Dunwich Horror, concerning a manyfooted something that takes to ravaging the Massachusetts countryside, squashing houses and devouring cattle and people. Years later, my morbid interest further provoked when a learned friend told me that Lovecraft used to concoct his horror stories while wandering the streets of Providence, R. I., under the cover of night, because he thought his face too ugly to be exposed by day.

title: Knicks LineUp
description: TELEVISIONCHANNEL 9, 8 P.M.

title: Butz Sees Little Effect In China Wheat Cutback
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP)Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that China's cancellation of large wheat contracts from the United States will have no appreciable effect on this nation's consumers.

title: A NASSAU LEADER FACES CHALLENGE
description: A top campaign aide of Governor Carey's is challenging the leadership of Stanley Harwood, the Nassau County Democratic chairman, in what many politicians believe is the latest Carey purge of Democratic leaders who opposed his nomination.

title: Indian Satellite Planned
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 (Reuters)India plans to launch its first satellite in April from the Soviet Union with a Soviet launcher vehicle, it was announced today P. D. Bhavsar, scientific coordinator of the Indian space research organization, said the satellite was built by Indian scientists and engineers. It would carry instruments to conduct experiments in fields such as Xray astronomy and solar neutron gamma rays.

title: Junta Is Putting Ethiopia First, But It Says Little and Does Less
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 22When the army took control of this country in September it propagated a nowubiquitous sloganEthiopia firstbut it did not say what was meant.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified the writer of the script for The Statesman, a drama presented on CBSTV. The writer was Edward Adler.

title: Queens Officer Suspended; Narcotics Inquiry Is Cited
description: Detective Joseph Michel of the 103d Police Precinct was suspended last night for conduct unbecoming a police officer and prejudicial to the good order and efficiency of the department.

title: N. B. A.'s Kennedy Is Cited For Aiding Black Athletes
description: For presiding over the National Basketball Association as it became the first major league to use blacks as coaches and general managers, Walter Kennedy was honored twice yesterday.

title: ARTILLERY SHELL GUIDED BY LASER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Army has successfully tested a laserguided artillery shell that defense officials believe will revolutionize the role of artillery on the battlefield.

title: Social Workers Striking
description: WARWICK, R. I., Jan. 28 (AP)  Rhode Island social workers stayed off their jobs today for the second consecutive day after three hours of negotiations with state officials last night failed to end a contract dispute.

title: Everyone Was Patently Reasonable
description: At 10 A.M. precisely, Pete Rozelle took his stance at the front of the room and addressed a microphone in patently reasonable terms: Order in the court! With those words the supreme being of professional football opened the National Football League's annual auction of human flesh, the draft of college boys, which Judge William P. Schweikert of the United States District Court has ruled patently unreasonable and illegal.

title: Straight A's Are Rarely In the Cards
description: NEW HAVENI don't know whether things have actually gotten crummier or whether I've just been feeling more impotent about making them less crummy, but I do know that I don't enjoy reading about them anymore. The newspaper used to receive a thorough workout but now I just give it a quick onceover, skimming items of importance halfheartedly.

title: Phillips Sentenced to 25 Years to Life; He Insists He Was Framed in Retaliation
Neighborhoods: Cop of the Block Project Is Calming BedfordStuyvesant's Tension
description: In quiet times, the police officers patrolling a corner of the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn have taken to dropping in at the homes of residents for a few minutes of friendly talk.

title: Files of F.B.I. Showed It Harassed Teacher
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Counterintelligence Program of the Federal Bureau of Investigation attempted to encourage the dismissal of an Arizona State University professor in 1970 by filing an anonymous, derogatory letter about him with a college committee that was reviewing his teaching contract, according to documents from F.B.I. files.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS SEEK COMPROMISE TO CUT OIL IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Repreentative Al Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed today that a special committee of topranking members of Congress would try to work out a compromise plan for reducing oil imports that would avoid a confrontation between the White House and Congress.

title: McGivern, Citing Salary, Plans to Leave the Bench
description: Declaring that continuing on the bench would work a financial deprivation on his family, Owen McGivern said yesterday that he was resigning from one of the state's top judicial posts to join a large midtown law firm.

title: Sports Today
description: Baruch at York, 8 P.M.; Concordia at Pratt, 8 P.M.; Iona at Army, 8 P.M.; Kings Point at Wagner, 8 P.M.; Lehman at Queens, 8 P.M.; Montclair State at Monmouth, 8 P.M; NewarkRutgers at New York Poly, 8 P.M.; C. W. Post at Brooklyn, 8 P.M.; Rider at Fairleigh Dickinson (Rntherford), 8 P.M.; St. Joseph's at Hofstra, 8 P.M.; Stevens at Pace, 8 P.M.

title: Rape Suspect Seized
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 28 (UPI)  A parsipanny driver who fled the United States last August after being charged with the rape and beating of a Boston waitress was arrested today in Canada, authorities here said. Morris County Prosecutor Donald Collester said Curtis Knapp Jr., 25 years old was taken into custody in York, Canada. He is accused of raping a 20yearold waitress on June 19 last year near the Jersey City reservoir.

title: State Department Bombed in Protest
description: A bomb exploded in the State Department building in Washington early this morning shortly after callers identifying themselves as Weather Underground members warned news organizations they were setting off bombs in protest at United States aid to South Vietnam.

title: LOOPHOLE IN LAW MAY AID TEACHERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28A loophole in the Emergency Jobs and Employment Assistance Act, which was enacted to provide benefits to jobless people, may legally extend millions of dollars in assistance to thousands of schoolteachers when they take their vacations this summer, officials of the Department of Labor said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 29, 1975

title: PONTIAC DEALERS IN A LOCAL OFFER
description: In an effort to spur lagging new car sales, the Metro New York/New Jersey Pontiac Dealers Association yesterday introduced a specially customized automobile for sale only in the metropolitan area.

title: A Chef Recalls The Long Road From Shanghai
description: If you wanted to become a chef back in the old days in China, Tsung Ting Wang said through an interpreter, the most important attribute you could have was the ability to observe. When you were an apprentice  and I was placed in a Shanghai kitchen when I was 11 years old  the chefs never would tell you every trick in the trade. The principal duties were to keep the kitchen clean, make the chef's bed and draw warm water for his bath. In less important matters you made the rice and warmed the wine. At the end of five years you would graduate to higher things.

title: School Superintendent in Great Neck Gets Job Back Pending Albany Appeal
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Jan. 28 Thirty hours after being dismissed, Mortimer J. Abramowitz was temporarily reinstated as Superintendent of the embattled Great Neck School District this afternoon, by order of Ewald B. Nyquist, the state's Commisioner of Education.

title: Foreign Stock Index
DR. SAMUEL H. BELL
description: Dr. Samuel H. Bell, a dentist on the Lower East Side and in the Bronx for 42 years, died yesterday at his home in the Bronx. He was 79 years old.

title: TREASURY SELLS $3BILLION NOTES
About New York
description: New York ne Nieuw Amsterdam, is an ancient city, unlike most of its fellow American settlements. Rembrandt lived most of his life during the city's Dutch days, although he apparently never thought of visiting his country's colony where so much of his work would hang at a cost greater than the whole place was then valued.

title: Koch Of fers HomeCare Bill for Aged, With Government and Children Paying
description: A bill to offer home care as an alternative to sending the elderly to nursing homes was introduced in Congress yesterday by Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan.

title: Marcos Discloses StepUp of Fighting In Mindanao Area
description: MANILA, Jan. 28President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the Moslem insurgents on Mindanao Island controlled three major towns and were staging frequent ambushes of military detachments. A battalion commander and 41 of his men were killed, he said.

title: Kissinger Deplores Delay in Latin Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Secretary of State Kissinger said today that Latin America's yearlong new dialogue with the United States was in jeopardy as a result of the postponement of a hemisphere foreign ministers meeting in Buenos Aires.

title: Profit Taking Slows Market's Rally; Volume Is Second Highest in History
description: The stock market rally, while powered by the heaviest trading in history, nevertheless slipped into lower gear yesterday and only managed to finish with a moderate gain.

title: Hope for the Parks?
description: When Ansel Adams, the renowned scenic photographer, visited the White House the other day to discuss the National Park System, President Ford told him: If anyone has the basic feeling for parks, I have.

title: SENATE REFUSES SEAT FOR WYMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Eleven weeks after the Nov. 5 Congressional election, the Senate took the first step today toward deciding whom the voters of New Hampshire elected as their junior Senator.

title: MAISIE WARD, 86, PUBLISHER, DIES
description: Maisie Ward, the publisher, biographer and Catholic activist, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital at the age of 86. She lived at 7 Tonnele Avenue. Jersey City.

title: ANKER TO BE GIVEN A NEW CONTRACT
description: The Board of Education will soon offer to extend Irving Anker's contract as School Chancellor, probably for another two years, and the 63yearold educator is regarded as almost certain to agree to continue in the school system's top administrative post.

title: Heinz Birthday Gifts Spur Reader's Fantasy
description: When he read here last week that H. J. Heinz (of 57 varieties fame) sent gift boxes to everybody in Who's Who when they reached their 57th birthday, Frederic C. Decker of Brookfield Center, Conn., was moved to fantasy. He wrote:

title: Uncertainties in Cyprus Afflict Economy
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 24The political uncertainty that envelops this Mediterranean island is severely hampering efforts to reconstruct the Cypriote economy.

title: LINCOLN CENTER LOOKS TO PAY TV
description: It is 7 o'clock. A family in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, enters the communications room of their home and switches on television. A projector as low to the floor as a cocktail table casts the nearly lifesize images onto a concave 4by8 screen. The picture is in color and is accompanied by stereophonic sound.

title: Asarco Cuts Price Of Copper Cathode
Two Hungarian Dissidents In Pact With Government
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 28  Two noted Hungarian sociologists, whose positions have been precarious since they underwent five days of police interrogation last November on suspicion of subversive agitation, say they have reached an agreement with the Government by which they hope to be able to continue their work.

title: SOVIET CURBS SHIPS IN U.S. LOBSTER AREA
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 28 (AP) The Soviet Government has ordered Russian fishing trawlers to remain out of areas designated for American lobstermen to drop their traps in the Georges Bank.

title: Panel Ends Questioning of Levi; Confirmation Support Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Senate Judiciary Committee completed its questioning today of Attorney Generaldesignate Edward H. Levi and, although several witnesses remain to be heard, the committee's speedy recommendation of his confirmation is expected.

title: Armco Steel Corp. Is Laying Off 617 At Plant in Ohio
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Armco Steel Corporation said today it would lay off 617 employes at its Middletown steel works, effective Feb. 2.

title: Use of Food Stamps Soars As Jobless Turn to Them
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28More unemployed American workers are turning to the food stamp program, so that 17.1 million people8 per cent of the American populationare purchasing their groceries with these coupons, Department of Agriculture figures are reported to show.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS SEEK COMPROMISE TO CUT OIL IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Repreentative Al Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed today that a special committee of topranking members of Congress would try to work out a compromise plan for reducing oil imports that would avoid a confrontation between the White House and Congress.

title: Consumer Notes
Fire Kills Hotel Worker
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Neighborhoods: Cop of the Block Project Is Calming BedfordStuyvesant's Tension
description: In quiet times, the police officers patrolling a corner of the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn have taken to dropping in at the homes of residents for a few minutes of friendly talk.

title: HAROLD E. WISWALL, BANKER, 62, IS DEAD
description: Harold E. Wiswall, vice president in charge of the insurance department of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Monday apparently of a heart attack, in the Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, New Hyde Park. He was 62 years old and lived at 18708 Wexford Terrace, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Woman Held as Head of Gambling Ring; Police Say It Booked $50Million a Year
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28A series of 35 coordinated police raids in five counties today smashed a gambling ring that handled more than $50million a year in lottery, sports and horse bets, according to lawenforcement officials.

title: Betting Gimmicks: Attack and Praise
description: While a top racing official was criticizing gimmick wagering yesterday, the Offtrack Betting Corporation was looking forward hopefully to bigger and better doubleexacta payoffs.

title: More Egalite for the Giscard Fraternit
description: PARIS, Jan. 28President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, who has been trying to thaw the icicles of aloofness from his high office in recent months, has taken another step in the direction of democratization by ordering the dropping of titles of nobility from invitations to the Elyse Palace.

title: High Court in Manila to Hear Petition Against Referendum
Kaiser to Raise Dividend
description: The Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation announced yesterday in Oakland, Calif., that it was raising its regular quarterly dividend to 30 cents per share of common stock from 25 cents a share. The dividend is payable Feb. 28 to shareholders of record Feb. 10.

title: Carey Considers Easing Of Penalty for Marijuana
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Governor Carey said today that he was considering the removal of criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana and replacing them with a system of fines or mandatory attendance at health clinics for treatment.

title: Miss Hamill Choice For Skating Crown
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 28  Dorothy Hamill of Riverside, Conn., last year's senior women's champion, is expected to win again as the United States figureskating championships begin tomorrow despite an ankle injury suffered last month.

title: Ocean Parkway Gets Landmark Designation
description: Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn and two upperBroadway neighbors, Verdi Square and the Central Savings Bank, were granted protected status yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which thus guarded the cites against unregulated change of destruction.

title: Wassily Leontief Will Leave Harvard For Post at N.Y.U.
description: Wassily Leontief, who won the Nobel Prize for Economic Science in 1973, is leaving Harvard University where he began his career as an instructor 44 years ago, to become a professor of economics at New York University.

title: 3MONTH NET OFF Al MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., the diversified financial services holding company that owns the giant brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., reported yesterday a 9.9 per cent decline in earnings for the final quarter of last year but a 2.2 per cent gain for all 1974.

title: Liv Ullmann: Living What She Acts
description: Film gives Liv Ullmann a misty innocence. The camera catches and holds each expression in the kaleidoscope of feeling that passes in a moment over her face.

title: Most Active Stocks
description: Tuesday, January 28, 1975

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES PRICING OF SURE
description: The Justice Department disclosed yesterday in Washington that a Federal grand jury in New York has been investigating alleged pricefixing by major sugar refiners during 1974, when sugar prices soared 400 per cent.

title: People in Sports
description: Herb Washington, a sprinterturned basestealer, said yesterday he had been offered an undisclosed salary increase by the Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley. Washington is the only major leaguer used exclusively as a pinchrunner. Although last season, his first, was a controversial one, including a pickoff in the World Series, Washington said his confidence had been bolstered since he was given a raise in tune with the times.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark has begun hearing evidence of alleged police corruption in Union City, linked to a gambling raid there last week by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Charles Pascale, a Union City police captain, was subpoenaed to testify before the panel tomorrow.

title: Leading Seoul Paper Fights for Survival
CITY ACTS TO KEEP POLICEMAN ON JOB
description: Racing against time, the City Council unanimously passed a measure yesterday to block the layoff of a 22yearold probationary police officer who lost his right eye and received other injuries in an East Harlem bomb explosion on Dec. 11.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling Per metric ton) COPPER

title: Fordham Subdues Columbia
CITY JOBLESS RATE CLIMBS 1.1 TO 8.5%, WITH 269,700 IDLE
description: Almost 37,000 more New York City residents lost their jobs in December, pushing the unemployment rate here up 1.1 percentage pointsfrom 7.4 to 8.5 per centand the total of jobless to 269,700, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: U.S. STEEL NET UP 64% FOR QUARTER
description: Despite a substantial decline in shipments of steel products in the final three months of 1974, the United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported profits of $171.4million, in the period, an increase of 64 per cent over the fourth quarter of 1973.

title: Panel Finds Little Effort to Alleviate Health Risks Women Workers Face
description: Although half of American women now work outside their homes, little attention has been paid to the special risks female workers may face from exposure to toxic chemicals and other onthejob hazards, a panel of experts on occupational health said yesterday.

title: Food Prices Up Again, As Beef Specials End
description: Specials on beef cuts disappeared last week from most of the city's food markets, and meat cuts rose 3 to 18 cents a pound in price, causing the cost of New York City's market basket for a family of four to rise 1.6 per cent above that of the previous week.

title: Innovative Planner
description: Jaquelin Taylor Robertson says his favorite city is Peking  an odd choice, he acknowledges, for an architect and planner who made his professional reputation as a member of New York City's innovative planning and designing team Under the administration of John V. Lindsay. But Mr. Robertson, whose appointment as head of the team that will draw up a $5billion master plan for downtown Teheran was made public yesterday, has always had somewhat of an international outlook.

title: With the Consumers
description: Between now and March, through the new sixteennation International Energy Agency, the oilconsuming countries will try to agree on parallel programs for conservation of 2 to 3 million barrels of oil a day7 to 10 per cent of imports. Joint programs to bring in new energy sources will seek agreement on a system of guarantees for new investment against later dumping of cheap. Arab, oil in Western markets. To these elements of joint consumer action is to be added the alreadyagreed $25billion Solidarity Fund to help weaker industrial countries carry their oilpayments deficits.

title: Islanders Set Down Stars, 62
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 28 They were billed as the new Minnesota North Stars, but they played the same way as they had when shut out by the Islanders back in October. Tonight only the score and the crowd count were different; New York 6, Minnesota 2, before an audience of 14,169 at Nassau Coliseum. The victory was the Islanders 19th in the National Hockey League, equaling their total of last year.

title: HANOI ASSERTS U.S. MUST HALT FLIGHTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)Hanoi said today that the United States must halt reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam, provide it with reconstruction aid and end military involvement and intervention in South Vietnam to obtain a peaceful settlement.

title: Percy Sees Limits to American Aid for Israelis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Senator Charles H. Percy, just back from a trip to the Middle East, said today that there were limits to United States support for Israel, and he asserted that Israeli leaders were unrealistic to believe they could avoid contact with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Defense Department awarded the Northrop Corporation a $67.8million contract for F5E aircraft for foreign sales and the use by the United States Air Force.

title: Goldwater Asserts Nixon Would Like to Return to Polities as a Spokesman for the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28 (UPI) Senator Barry Goldwater said today that former President Richard M. Nixon had told him that he would like to get back into politics to help the Republican party.

title: Julia Sanderson Is Dead at 87; Musical Comedy Star of 1920's
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 28 (AP)Julia Sanderson, a star of Broadway musical comedies in the nineteentwenties, died last evening at her home here. She was 87 years old.

title: Flunked Woman Recruit Fights State Police Ouster
description: SEA GIRT, Jan. 28 (UPI)Jane Hostetler Bulaga was dismissed as a state police recruit yesterday for failing essential firearms skills and disciplinary requirements.

title: F.C.C. Limits New Purchases Of Broadcasters by the Press
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission barred today any future purchases by newspaper owners of radio or television stations that serve the same market. It also ordered 16 such existing combinations to be broken up.

title: Giants Jeered After Taking Simpson
description: In further attempts to strengthen their offense, the New York Giants selected Allen (Big Al) Simpson, a 260pound tackle from Colorado State, and Danny Buggs, a wide receiver from West Virginia with sprint speed, as their top two choices in the college draft yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS DROP PANEL CHAIRMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Representative Leonor K. Sullivan of Missouri was deposed today as chairman of the Consumer Affairs Subcommittee as leadership changes continued in the House of Reprecentatives.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EASY TO TAKE Since coffeehouse theaters, like the old Cafe Cino, have all but vanished from Greenwich Village, it's good to be able to welcome a new one, an enterprising, unhurried nook called the Persona Cafe Theater that's off to an apt start with the lovely old KaufmanandHart romp, You Can't Take It With You. Nice place, nice show.

title: Severe Limits on 2 Antibiotics Advocated at a Senate Hearing
description: WASINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) Several doctors told Congresssional investigators today that they favored severe restrictions on two widely prescribed antibiotics that have been linked to at least 14 deaths.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Governor Seeks Local Aid From His 10c Gasoline Tax
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Governor Carey indicated today that at least some of the proceeds from his proposed 10centagallon gasoline tax would be earmarked to help financially pressed local governments, in the new state budget he will present to the Legislature on Thursday.

title: Music: Janacek Mass
description: The Glagolitic (or Slavonic) Mass by Leos Janacek is one of those craggy, intensely personal, tough evocations of a more primitive time that, like Le Sacre du Printemps, hurtles the listener's psyche through several layers of the subconscious. Aldo Ceccato and the Detroit Symphony made an ambitious, if not always successful, attempt at the score last night in Carnegie Hall. A very large audience was on hand, taking advantage of the opportunity to come to grips with a seldomheard masterpiece.

title: Sadat Inspects Advanced French Arms
description: PARIS, Jan. 28The Presidents of Egypt and France met today for the second day and the Egyptian leader inspected advanced military radar equipment and missiles that he might purchase.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: In an effort to reach out for new audiences,. Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and the Shubert organization are introducing a performing arts subscription series to be known as PASS. The program will enable people to buy tickets at regular prices for a package of four performances that includes a choice of either Tosca or Falstaff at the Metropolitan Opera, a choice of either Dybbuk Variations or Dances at a Gathering at the New York City Ballet and Equus at the Plymouth and Sherlock Holmes at the Broadhurst.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Iran Plans Big Project to Make Teheran a Major World Capital
description: The Iranian Government has begun plans for a major development in Teheran that, if built in its entirety, will be one of the most extensive newtown projects of the twentieth century.

title: House Democrats Endorse Own Study on Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29A Democratic study group unanimously recommended today that the House create a bipartisan select committee to investigate the activities of all Government intelligence agencies.

title: Appeals Court Says Practices by I.B.M. Were Competitive
description: DENVER, Jan. 29 (UPI) A Federal Appeals Court. in explaining why it overturned a lower court decision, says the International Business Machines Corporation's alleged antitrust practices were part of the competitive scene in a highly competitive business.

title: Film: Cliches Trail 'The Nickel Ride':Jason Miller Has Lead in Real-Estate Drama Role as a Fixer Proves a Study in Worry
description: Those who choose to see Robert Mulligan's "The Nickel Ride" must be prepared to work very hard and then be defeated in trying to follow the plot, since this action picture resists an earthling's comprehension. In fact, it's the most confusing movie I've seen since several reels got mixed up during a Greek film of radiant obscurity. At any rate, this heap of murk opened yesterday at several neighborhood theaters.The movie appears to be a drama of real estate. Jason Miller plays a neighborhood fixer who is attempting to lease a warehouse for the storage of stolen goods; however, the deal is delayed, and he's threatened by the minor hoods who are his clients. His role is a study in worry: the angst rarely leaves his deep-set lemur's eyes. We watch him worrying in profile, in full and three-quarter face, standing or sitting or lying down, in daylight and darkness, on the phone, in his office and out of doors. All in all, he seems more vulnerable to an anxiety attack than to an assailant's bullet.Although much of the narrative is unfathomable, the audience knows almost everything that's going to happen, since we're warned by a series of triumphant movie clichsincluding one of the silliest prophetic dreams that's been filmed of late. Throughout, there are little lulls that promise immediate violence. And when someone buys a rabbit's foot it means that he'll have bad luck; when a character resolves to go straight and leave "the business" it's obvious that he'll be shot; when a couple plan a vacation we know that they won't take it. The movie also employs the maddeningly ancient device of a live man talking to a dead onewithout realizing that he's wasting his wisdom on a corpse."The Nickel Ride" is handsomely, filmed in bleak pastels, but the numerous close-ups manage to stress the slowness of the action, and quick cuts can't dispel the tedium. Bo Hopkins has some good moments as a chatty sadist with a face full of ominous grins; nodding his head in malicious innocence, he's given to bursts of inane chuckles. Linda Haynes is desperately bland as Mr. Miller's girlfriend, although her lines don't help: she has to say (of the woods) "So crisp and green!" and "I'm a big girl!" when her lover conceals his worries from her, and "Oh, business, business, business!" when he doesn't.What with the references to characters we haven't met and to events we never see and to the good old days that will never come again, one wonders if the director actually wanted to make a different picture. If only he had.

title: Market Continues Rise
description: The stock market scored its sixth straight rise after mild profit taking early in yesterday's session in continued active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 705.96, up 11.19 points. Page 47.

title: Sir Philip Brocklehurst, 87, Antarctic Explorer, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Sir Philip Brocklehurst, Army officer and Antarctic explorer, died last evening at the age of 87.

title: Prisoner Kills St Vincent's Visitor, Shoots Policeman
description: A deranged prisoner disarmed and shot his police guard and fatally wounded a visitor last night before his effort to escape from St. Vincent's Hospital turned its corridors into the scene of a grim chase.

description: Elizabeth Bartholomew Van Dusen, wife of Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, former president of the Union Theological Seminary, died yesterday at her home, 27 Armour Road, Princeton, N.J. She was 80 years old,

title: CHAMPION DAVIS, EXRAILHEAD, DIES
description: Champion McDowell Davis, who worked his way up to president of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad after starting as a 14yearold messenger boy, died Tuesday at Cape Fear Valley Hospital in Wilmington, N.C. He was 95 years old.

description: A detective commander who previously headed an investigation of the Black Liberation Army was put in charge yesterday of a major police search for Puerto Rican nationalists believed responsible for recent bombings in the city.

title: Defect in a Reactor Leads U.S. to Order 23Plant Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The discovery of cracks in the emergency cooling system of an atomic reactor in Illinois has forced the Government to order utilities operating half of the nation's reactors to shut down within the next 20 days and search for similar possible faults in their power plants.

title: 'Alice,' Young Widow Finds Herself
description: Alice Hyatt (Ellen Burstyn) would seem to be up a creek. She lives in semi-urban New Mexico, married to a human slug who drives a soft-drink truck and who is so alienated from their 12-year-old son Tommy (Alfred Lutter) that when we first see the family together it seems as if the father is no more than a particularly unpleasant, demanding boarder. Suddenly and fortuitously everything changes. Donald, Alice's husband, is killed in a highway accident and Alice must take charge of her own life, which, until this time, she has always left in the care of others.Martin Scorcese's "Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore," which opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater, is the fine, moving, frequently hilarious tale of Alice's first lurching steps toward some kind of self-awareness and self-sufficiency.The story moves across the American Southwest as Alice and Tommy, their belongings stuffed into their station wagon, set off on the journey back to Alice's home town of Monterey, Calif. The geography is familiar and mostly flat, strewn with motels, drive-in restaurants, taverns, service stations and dinersthe bright, shiny artifacts of America's mobile optimism.The interior landscape of the film is something else again. It's a Krazy Kat world where it's difficult to tell the difference between night and day, between robust laughter and hysterical tears, where the brick that hits you in the head may cause a slight concussion but may also knock some sense into you. The experience is scary but if you keep your wits about you, as Alice ultimately does, the chances are that things will work out. You'll get a slight purchase on survival, on life."Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore" seems especially remarkable because it, was directed by the man who first smashed into our consciousness with an entirely different kind of movie, "Mean Streets," a male-dominated melodrama about life in New York's Little Italy."Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore" is an American comedy of the sort of vitality that dazzles European film critics and we take for granted. It's full of attachments and associations to very particular times and places, even in the various regional accents of its characters. It's beautifully written (by Robert Getchell) and acted, but it's not especially neatly tailored.It begins rather badly, with an unnecessary sequence showing Alice as a little girl, and then jumps forward to Alice's home life with her slob husband, played at such a high pitch you're not sure that Mr. Scorcese and the actors will be able to sustain whatever it is they are about. You don't know at first. It's a comedy that creeps up on you, somewhere near the Arizona state line, as Tommy begins to get on Alice's nerves by threatening to be carsick.At the center of the movie and giving it a visible sensibility is Miss Burstyn, one of the few actresses at work today (another is Glenda Jackson) who is able to seem appealing, tough, intelligent, funny and bereft, all at approximately the same moment.It's Miss Burstyn's movie and part of the enjoyment of the film is in the director's apparent awarenessof this fact, as in a sequence in which Alice is making a little extra money by singing and playing ersatz cocktail-piano in a roadside tavern. Alice is never going to bring show business to its knees, but the beer drinkers love her and Mr. Scorcese circles his camera around her as lyrically as if she were Ida Lupino knocking the customers dead in "Road House."Of equal but less spectacular importance are the supporting players, including the men. Although this is a movie that takes women seriously, and although it is essentially the chronicle of Alice's liberation, Mr. Scorcese has not shortchanged the actors, especially Harvey Keitel, as a small-town sadist who traps Alice for a while, Kris Kristoffersen, as the comparatively gentle rancher who wins her, and Alfred Lutter, as her son who, when the chips are down, is not at all bad.Two other performances must be noted, those of Diane Ladd and Valerie Curtin as waitresses in a diner where Alice works. Their marvelous contributions in small roles are a measure of the film's quality and of Mr. Scorcese's fully realized talents as one of the best of the new American filmmakers.

title: Drive on Drug Smuggling Focusing on Florida Area
description: MIAMITen years ago, whey David Westrate was 21 years old and just beginning a career as a narcotics agent on the West Coast, a seizure of 200 pounds of marijuana was what he called tremendous something the whole office turned out for.

GrainExport Curb Eased; Soviet Cuts Wheat Orders
description: Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said yesterday that Federal export curbs on wheat and soybeans, imposed last October because of fears of domestic shortages and soaring food prices, would be relaxed.

title: ACCORD EXTENDED IN ABBEY SEIZURE
description: SHAWANO, Wis., Jan. 29 The Alexian Brothers, a Roman Catholic order, agreed tonight to extend until noon Friday a proposed agreement to settle peacefully the 29dayold occupation by armed Menominee Indians of a vacant novitiate that the Alexians own in nearby Gresham.

title: Some Find Rock n Roll Now Rock n Recession
description: Has rock n roll become rock n recession?

title: Some Nursing Homes Please Patients and Officials
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y.Elsie Wright, a young nurse at the Sarah Neuman Nursing Home here, has been chastised lately by friends who identify her with the nursinghome disclosures.

title: Cornell Puts Its Athletic House in Order
description: Cornell football fans have the same desires to win that possess college football fans around the country. Cornellians also try to exert the same pressures in search of the Ivy League College championship. The result is Sports a new head footNotes ball coach now and then if Cornell falls short of the top too often. The latest Big Red coach is George C. Seifert, 36yearold native of San Francisco, who was hired Monday to replace Jack Musick, a nice guy who fell short too often during his nine years as head coach.

title: BEAME CANCELS LAYOFFS FOR 391 IN 2 CITY UNIONS
description: Mayor Beame, in what he called a milestone in labor negotiations, announced early this morning that in return for union concessions, 391 civil service workers scheduled to be dismissed from the city payroll tomorrow would be retained.

title: CAREY CAMPAIGN IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: Arthur H. Schwartz, chairman of the State Board of Electons, said yesterday that the board was reviewing two charges that Governor Carey's; campaign organization violated the election law and expected a decision on one of them soon,

title: Carbide Raises Dividend
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing its regular quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share of common stock from 55 cents. The dividend is payable March 1 to shareholders of record Feb. 7.

title: Defect in a Reactor Leads U.S. to Order 23Plant Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The discovery of cracks in the emergency cooling system of an atomic reactor in Illinois has forced the Government to order utilities operating half of the nation's reactors to shut down within the next 20 days and search for similar possible faults in their power plants.

title: POLL FINDS PUBLIC DIVIDED ON PARDONS
description: The Gallup Poll said yesierday that public opinion was closely divided on whether pardons should he granted to the four top figures in the Nixon Administration who were found guilty in the recent Watergate coverup trial.

title: Laver Match Is Priceless for Connors
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 29Jimmy Connors checked in at Caesars Palace today for Sunday's $100,000 tennis match against Rod Laver, and insisted that the money wasn't the inmortant thing.

title: Head of C.I.A. Inquiry
Columbia Gets Harper Archives
description: Harper & Row has turned over to Columbia University a collection of firstedition books, letters and contracts with authors that covers American publishing history for most of the 19th century and sheds new light on the careers of such writers as Mark Twain, Herman Melville and Henry James.

title: FORD GETS PROTEST FROM BLACK CAUCUS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Reports that President Ford may appoint John Bell Williams, former Mississippi Governor, to the new Federal Elections Commission drew an angry protest today from the Congressional Black Caucus.

title: Profit of Bethlehem Steel Up 133.4%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday reported a gain of 133.4 per cent in fourthquarter earnings. On Tuesday, the United States Steel Corporation reported a quarter profit of $171.4million, up 64 per cent.

title: 6 Mayors, Seeking Aid, Find Carey Is a Good Listener
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29 The Big Six Mayors made their ritual pilgrimage to Albany for state aid today and said afterward that Governor Carey had seemed sympathetic to the idea of alterations in the budget he will make public on Friday.

title: Shifting Sands . . .
description: Past weeks of quiet diplomacy have brought Secretary of State Kissinger and the rival. governments of the Middle East to the verge of a new round of peacemaking. Just below the surface are a number of signs of shifts in longstanding attitudes on all sides, enough to give some reasonable hope for significant softening of the ArabIsraeli confrontation.

title: U. S. EASING CURBS ON GRAIN EXPORTS; SOVIET ORDER CUT; Butz Says Action on Wheat and Soybeans Puts Trade Back on Free Basis; FOREIGN DEMAND IS OFF; 3.7MillionBushel Russian Cancellation Follows One by Chinese on Monday

title: Legislators Find Ennui, Not Whoopee, in Albany
description: ALBANYThe front door at the Ambassador bar banged open. Doug the bartender looked up and saw an Assemblyman lurch in, slump against the wall, then walk unsteadily toward the bar.

title: One Man's Basket Case
description: The abolition of parliamentary government in Bangladesh and the assumption of full dictatorial powers by Sheik Mujibur Rahman are the desperateand futileacts of a bankrupt regime. They cannot retard, and may even hasten, the infant Bengali nation's descent toward chaos.

title: Jets Select Fire's Scott, Receiver
description: While the Giants drafted linebacker the Jets selected last year, a placekicker who kicks barefoot and a cousin of Joe Morgan, the baseball star, the Jets intensified their involvement with the World Football League yesterday. They drafted one of that league's top pass receivers.

title: U.S. Called Lax on NewTowns Program
description: Six years ago, a Federal cornmission urged the development of 110 new communities to accommodate 20 million of the nation's expected additional inhabitants in the following three decades. Only 16 such new towns, with an eventual capacity of less than one million people, have come into being and they are having financial difficulties.

title: Columbia Gets Harper Archives
description: Harper Row has turned over to Columbia University a collection of firstedition books, letters and contracts with authors that covers American publishing history for most of the 19th century and sheds new light on the careers of such writers as Mark Twain, Herman Melville and Henry James.

title: General Motors Will Shut Seven Plants for a Week
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP) The General Motors Corporation said today it was shutting down seven car assembly plants for one week beginning Monday and would temporarily lay off 15,505 production workers.

title: Books of The Times
description: Every social convulsion eventually spawns its own set of clichs and oversimplifications. Max Weber had a word for this process: He called it bureaucratization, the reduction of innovations or inspirations to routines or formulas. What is so interesting about Families and Survivors Is that it shows bureaucratization simultaneously at work on two levels: the social and the literary. On the social level. Alice Adams has reduced the emergent womar of the nineteenseventies to a formula; on the literary level, she does as much for, on to, certain innovations in the novel form

title: Ford Firm on Oil Levies, But May Shift on Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Ford indicated today that he would be willing to compromise with Congress on tax cut legislation, but appeared to rule out any concessions on his program to reduce oil imports.

title: Skate Lead Held by Miss Hamill
description: OAKLAND. Calif., Jan. 29  Dorothy Hamill of Riverside, Conn., led the senior women's event at the United State figure skating championships after the compulsory figures today. But a rising crop of young skaters is bunched closely behind the defending champion.

title: St. Kitts, at End of Era, Is a Changing Caribbean in Miniature
description: BASSETERRE, St. Kitts When Col. Charles Walwyn recently remodeled a centuriesold sugar mill on his plantation, installing rooms for tourists, an era ended in this oldest British dependency in the Caribbean.

title: Canada to Charge U.S. More for Oil
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (UPI) Canada will increase the cost of oil exported to the United States through a 40centabarrel increase in its export tax, Energy Minister Donald MacDonald said yesterday.

title: Portuguese Cancel Rallies By Rival Leftist Parties
description: LISBON, Jan. 29 (Reuters)The Portuguese Armed Forces Movement, which effectively controls the country, tonight canceled plans by the Socialist and Communists to hold rival demonstrations planned for Friday.

title: When I Hear the Dog, I Follow Him
description: As a teenaged extra in the cast of thousands at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, he understandably was obscure.

title: Hialeah Entries
description: Horses listed In order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Tervuren Pioneer Seeks Elusive Goal
description: Although Edeltraud Laurin has bred 26 Belgian tervuren champions  no small achievement, since the breed has been registered with the American Kennel Club for only 16 years she has never had a working winner. However, our breed is making tremendous strides, said the West Wellington, Conn., resident, and one of these days I hope to get a blue rosette.

title: Jersey Paper Plant Gets Incentive Plan
description: The Garden State Paper Company and its two unions announced yesterday a labor agreement providing for a bonus for each ton of paper produced and an arbitration procedure aimed at achieving a decade of labor peace.

title: Market Conzinues Rise
description: The stock market scored its sixth straight rise after mild profit taking early in yesterday's session in continued active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 705.96, up 11.19 points. Page 47.

title: Films
description: LA BELLE ET LA BETE (1946; 95 minutes) by lean Cocteau, with Josette Day and Jean Marais, 12:30 and 3 P.M. Sunday at Films for Children Program, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. 9567078.

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda , Jan. 29Barring improbable accidents, North Americal will oppose France in one world team championship semifinal here tomorrow, and Italy and Indonesia will clash in the other.

title: Belfast Catholic Shot Dead At LunchHour Chess Game
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland , Jan. 29 (UPI)Two Protestant gunmen surprised three men at a lunchhour chess game today and killed one, a Roman Catholic.

title: Penguins Turn Back Hawks, 61
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Pittsburgh Penguins scored two shorthanded goals within 17 seconds tonight while killing a fiveminute penalty and exploded for four goals in the second period to take a 61 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Yariv Resigns Israeli Information Post
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 Aharon Yariv, Israel's Information Minister, resigned today, saying that Premier Yitzhak Rabin was running the Government in a manner that he described as inappropriate and inadequate to meet the needs of the current situation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: REALITIES A timely subject and a provocative panel a significant organization and a minimal admission pricethese portend a rewarding program tonight on Sexism and the Criminal Justice System sponsored by the Fortune Society. The time: 8 P.M. The place: the Meeting Hall of the Ethical Culture Society Building at 2 West 64th Street. The price $1.

title: JERSEY CITY SETS RAPEVICTIM PLAN
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29 The Jersey City Medical Center and the police here today announced a new program designed to give priority to medical and pyschological treatment of sexual assault victims.

title: Municipal Stations Fear Cutback in Staffs and Fare
description: The city's Muncipal Broadcasting System said yesterday that austerity measures might force it to curtail broadcasts on WNYCFM radio between midnight and 6 A.M. and to cut back service on the other cityowned stations, WNYCTV/Channel 31, and WNYCAM radio.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Long Island Lighting Company began yesterday offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe, at $11.75 a share, to an additional 2,505,340 common shares on a basis of one new share for each 10 shares held of record Jan. 29, 1975. The ??? that the underwriters managed by the First Boston Corporation would purchase ??? scribed shares in the rights offering,

title: Snowden Tries to Block Book Attacking Monarchy
description: LONDON, Jan 29 (AP) Lord Snowden brother  in  law of Queen Elizabth II, has tried to halt publication of a book altacking the British monarchy and what it called the mon1 tarchy's prostituted entourage," but his request has been rejected, the publishers said Wednesday.

title: Haig Pays Army $91 For Liquor Shipment
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 29 (UPI) Gen. Alexander Haig Jr. has repaid the Army $91 in shipment charges for liquor shipped here in a crate marked glassware, an aide said today

title: Jets Choices
description: James Scott, Henderson J.C., wide receiver, Everett Taylor, Memphis State, defensive back; Charles James, Jackson State, defensive back; Jon Bradford, Central, Ohio, running back; Bert Cooper, Florida State, linebacker; Dan Spivey, Georgia, defensive tackle; Joe Fields, Widener, center; Brison Manor, Arkansas, defensive tackle; Greg Wells, Albany (Ga.) St., guard; Mike Bartoszek, Ohio State, tight end.

title: Prisoner Kills St. Vincent's Visitor, Shoots Policeman
description: A deranged prisoner disarmed and shot his police guard and fatally wounded a visitor last night before his effort to escape from St. Vincent's Hospital turned its corridors into the scene of a grim chase.

title: Lebanon Calls an Arab Meeting For Aid Against Israeli Raids
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 Lebanon has called for an urgent meeting of the Arab League Defense Council next Tuesday to consider Israeli raids into southern Lebanon, but Lebanese political forces are divided over what form of help should be sought.

title: Westinghouse Shows a 4thQuarter Loss
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a fourthquarter net loss of $76.2million compared with net income of $23.6 million, or 26 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1973.

title: Service for John Hastings
description: A memorial service for John J. Hastings, assistant vice president for public information of Columbia University, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. at Columbia's St. Paul's Chapel. Mr. Hastings died Jan. 8.

title: SCHLESINGER SEES NEW WAR THREATS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that troubles may break out in number of areas as a result of the decline of United States military power.

title: Vessels With Rice Reported to Reach Cambodian Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia , Thursday, Jan. 30 (AP)  Port officials here announced today that six vessels out of a convoy of 16 had arrived before dawn, completing a run through Mekong River gunfire. The vessels carried food, ammunition and fuel.

title: The Detroit Disease: An American Infection
description: DETROITNowhere in America can the nation's disregard for its cities and the failure of the nation's economic policies be seen so clearly as in Detroit. Nowhere are the nation's other grave problems so obvious: racism, unemployment, crime, the lack of landuse laws, the dreadful failure of forty years of housing programs, a costly transportation system that depends so heavily on the automobile.

title: Market Place
description: Some financial observers are wondering if there might not be a more effective means of informing the public of the purchase and sale of securities by officers and directors of public companies.

title: 4 in Movie Challenge Fornication Laws
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29 Two actors, a director and an accountant accused of fornication and lewdness in making the Xrated movie Deep Sleep asked a Federal court here today to overturn two state laws prohibiting such acts by unmarried couples.

title: Dollar Advances in Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 29 (UPI) The dollar gained on European money markets today, but most dealers said technical adjustments were responsible. In London and Zurich gold rose $2 an ounce to close at S178.25.

title: Head of C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The dominant feature of the decor in the Capitol Hill office of Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, is a large oil portrait of a Republican predecessor, the late William E. Borah. .It is less surprising than it might seem. In different eras, Senator Borah and Senator Church emerged from the same landlocked Mountain State as outspoken critics of United States intervention in the affairs of other nations Mr. Borah as the leading advocate of isolationism until his death in 1940 and Mr. Church as an early advocate of disengagement from the war in Southeast Asia. Both Idahoans were domestic liberals whose views often clashed with a majority of their constituents. And both were regarded as among the most polished orators of their times.

title: News Summary and Index
description: China's Foreign Ministry disclosed that Teng Hsiaoping has been named army chief of staff. In the past year the 71yearold Communist party veteran and army political commisar has also become the principal deputy premier under Chou Enlai and one of five deputy party chairmen under Mao Tsetung. Purged and vilified during the Cultural Revolution, he now holds a central position to oversee the succession to Chairman Mao, 81, and Mr. Chou, nearly 77. [Page 1, Columns 67.1

title: Six Jews in Moscow Defend Jackson Role In Dispute on Trade
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29 A half dozen Jewish activists today defended Senator Henry M. Jackson against recent charges that he had attached emigration conditions to the nowdefunct trade agreement to advance his own political amhitinng

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: In Memoriam
description: MYERSJack, died I969. Lovingly remeMheyed. Your Jessie and Family. STEINHARDTHoward. Always remembered and sadly missed. FAYE.

title: Assistant and Appeals Chief Are Named by Morgenthau
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney. nnounced yesterday the appointment of Pierre N. Leval, 38 years old, Mr. Morgenthau's former campaign manager, had served as chief of the appeals bureau in the United States Attorney's office when Mr. Morgenthau was head of that office.

title: POLICY ON MUSIC IS TOPIC FOR FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Some wellknown musical talents began performing verbally here today in a program without an audience  a Music Policy Conference staged by the National Endowment for the Arts. The purpose is to help the endowment, whose music program is the largest area of its arts funding, define issues and problems in the field.

title: EDICAID BILLED FOR ROLLSROYCE WITHA GRUFFER
description: State auditors testified yesterday that partial examinations of 125 nursing homes had so far turned up $8.6million in unwarranted billings to Medicaid, including a RollsRoyce and a chauffeur for one operator, fuel for the yacht of another and alimony for the former wife of a third.

title: Vietcong Said to View 1975 as a Turning Point
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29A document that is reportedly guiding the Communists current military campaign envisions 1975 as a turning point but not the end of the struggle in South Vietnam.

title: NEWSWEEK PUTTING BYLINES ON ITS NEWS
description: Newsweek will place bylines on the majority of its news articles, starting with the issue on the newsstands Monday.

title: Busmen in London Strike to Protest a Slaying, but the City Copes
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 A strike by bus crews over a fatal assault on a black bus conductor left this city without buses today. Although it rained all day, Londoners coped well and there was little disruption

title: Economist Warns Against U.S. Negotiations With Oil Exporters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29M. A. Adelman, a prominent oil economist, told Congress today that the United States should not go to an oil conference With exporting countries and should not negotiate a world price agreement with them.

title: LISBON AND ROME SET DIVORCE PACT
description: LISBON, Jan. 29Portugal and the Vatican have reached an agreement in principle on amending the Concordat between them to allow Portuguese courts to grant divorces to those married in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Palestinian Group Declares Hijackers Face Jail or Death
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 29 The Palestine Liberation Organization announced today that it had decided to treat the hijacking of airplanes, ships or trains as crimes and would impose death penalties on hijackers if their actions led to the loss of life.

title: Reynolds Securities Shows Drop in Preliminary Income
description: Reynolds Securities, Inc., the stockbrokerage house, reported yesterday that preliminary income fell in the fourth quarter of 1974 to $1.5million, or 38 cents a share, from $1.9million, or 48 cents, a year earlier. Revenues edged down to $24.4million from $24.6million.

title: Ford's OverAll Policy and Prospects of Opposition in Congress
Delayed OilTariff Effect Indicated by F.E.A. Rules
description: An examination of Federal Energy Administration regulations indicates that consumers will not feel the effect of price increases on petroleum products until March if President Ford goes ahead with his plan to impose a fee of $1 a barrel on imported oil on Feb. 1.

title: Black Leader Guilty on Taxes in South
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 29 Former State Senator Leroy R. Johnson, the first black elected to a Southern legislature in modern times and one of the most powerful blacks in Dixie for more than a decade, was found guilty today by a Federal jury Of submitting a false tax affidavit to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Notes on People
description: The next Governor of American Samoa will be Earl Baker Ruth, a former Republican Representative from North Carolina who was defeated for reelection in November.

title: Migration From the Metropolitan Area Viewed by Planning Group as Threat
description: The metropolitan area faces the most serious social and environmental consequences because of a continued scattering of population, the Regional Plan Assnciatinn said yesterday.

title: Compromise Tax Bill
description: The tax bill that Chairman Ullman of the House Ways and Means Committee has introduced is a marked improvement over the tax cut proposed by President Ford, but it still falls shortin both net stimulative effect and equityof the fiscal legislation needed now.

title: FASHION TALK
description: George Stavropoulos has this terrible problem. It's almost an obsession. After he knocks himself out making clothes for women to werar during the day, invariably the evening things set people oohing and aahing.

title: Pacers Herald Nassau's OTB
description: Nassau Downs OTB staged its first race yesterday, a nonbetting affair through the streets of Westbury, Uniondale and Hempstead. L.I.

title: Swiss Woman, 18, First in Cup Slalom
description: ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 29 (AP)LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland, who had won only once previously, beat the world skiing elite today as she captured the slalom race at the Arlberg Kandahar ski meeting, a World Cup event.

title: Sadat Says French Agree To Sell Jets to Egyptians
description: PARIS, Jan. 29  President Anwar elSadat said here today that France had agreed to sell supersonic Mirage fighter planes to Egypt.

title: F.D. A. Head Says 2 Drugs Are Linked to 32 Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Two frequently prescribed antibioties have been associated with at least 32 deaths, Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of Food and Drugs. said today.

title: ASSOCIATED PRESS ERRED ON LOBBYIST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) An Associated Press dispatch earlier this month, reporting that a former Washington lobbyist, Fred B. Black Jr., was convicted in 1964 of income tax evasion, failed to report that the conviction was overturned and that Mr. Black was acquitted in a second trial.

title: F.B.I. Counterintelligence Is Under G.A.O. Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, said today that he had ordered an investigation by the General Accounting Office into the counterintelligence programs of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Woman Is Slain In Queens Holdup
description: The bookkeeper of a Maspeth, Queens, moving and storage company was fatally shot in the head and the owner of the company was critically wounded early last night in what the police described as an execution during a holdup of the company's warehouse at 5101 Flushing Avenue.

title: Drought Wilts an Industrial State in India
description: RANPUR, India  Vast stretches of land in the western state of Gujarat are barren. Drought has afflicted 13,000 of the 18,000 villages. Fodder is in short supply, and thousands of cattle have perished.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: We Deserve a Break, Residents Of W. 86th St. T ell McDonald's
description: Hi Hart, the cleaner, is pinning flyers on his customer's clothes. Moe Greengrass fears for the reputation of his sturgeon. And a Presbyterian minister says the whole thing is a test of the little man against the big corporation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 29 (UPI)There is no question of staging the 1976 Summer Olympics anywhere else than in Montreal, Lord Killanin, president of the Intern,ational Olympic Committee, said today.

title: The OneChild Family:
description: You have so much to offer a child. How can you stop after only one?

title: U. N. COMPROMISE IS URGED BY SCALI
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28The United States chief delegate, John A. Scali, called today for a new spirit of constructive compromise between the older members of the United Nations and the newer and more numerous countries of the third world.

title: Miller, a Pianist, Makes His Home In 20th Century
description: Robert Miller is that rare bird, a pianist who feels completely at home in the 20th century. His program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, for instance, looked no further back than Stravinsky's Serenade in A, which is dated 1925, and even that piece appeared only because of a premiere that Mr. Miller decided to postpone.

title: Rockefeller Visits Jersey To Help G.O.P. Cut Debt
description: MILLBURN, N. J., Jan. 29In his first partisan political foray since being sworn into office last December, Vice President Rockefeller visited New Jersey tonight in an effort to revitalize a state Republican party that has been debilitated by Watergate, the disastrous gubernatorial campaign of Charles W. Sandman Jr. and the economic ravages of the nation's continuing recession.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Mets signed Bud Harrelson yesterday, three weeks before the opening of spring training. Harrelson agreed to his 10th contractfor about $70,000. The Met shortstop was home in California with his parents and two children, and also I with a case of flu. Harrelson has missed 152 games over the last three seasons because of injuries55 last summer with a fractured right hand and a sprained right knee. But he said, I felt better physically this winter than I have in a few years.

title: 6,000 IN D.C. FLEE IN BOMB THREATS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Bomb threats against Federal buildings caused the evacuation of nearly 6,000 Government employes in Washington today, after an early morning explosion in the State Department.

title: AN EXPOLICE HERO FACES A LIFE TERM
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29 A former New York City policeman, who won the departmental Medal of Honor and a dozen other citations for bravery before service wounds forced his retirement, has pleaded guilty here to armed robbery, it was disclosed today.

title: Rudel Leaving Kennedy Center As Music Head
description: Julius Rudel has resigned the music directorship of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, a post he has held since the center opened in the fall of 1971. Mr. Rude, who is also director of the New York City Opera and a conductor, said he had made the Move because he was finding it impossible to hold the two directorships, with all the planning involved, and make music at the same time.

title: Landmarks in Retreat
description: This is, unfortunately, a time of retreat. There is a backing off from social programs, from environmental interests, from urban planning and landmark preservation, from the pursuit of the necessities and amenities that make a better society. Not the least indicator of what is happening is the State Supreme Court decision against the landmark designation of Grand Central Terminal in New York City.

title: Scott and Liberty Lobby Witness Clash On Levi's Association With Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Senate Republican leader Hugh Scott, and a spokesman for the conservative Liberty Lobby clashed today about the loyalty of Attorney Generaldesignate Edward H. Levi.

title: The Thrill Is Gone
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 During World War II, Donald M. Nelson headed the War Production Board; the former Sears, Roebuck executive typified the businessman who came to Washington to put his managerial iskills to work to win the war.

title: Brezhnev Seen on Way From Home to Kremlin
U.S.Soviet Program
description: Technological exchanges with the Soviet Union, a key element in American foreign policy, are being hampered because the Federal Government is poorly organized to promote them, according to the chief scientist of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: BILL WILL FIGHT FOOD STAMP RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The House Agriculture Committee moved speedily today to try to stop the Ford Administration's plan to cut the food stamp program by $650million on March 1.

title: Republican Leaders Doubt That Nixon Can Aid Party Now
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)  Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona, the House minority leader, said today that former President Richard M. Nixon might be effective in helping the Republican party at some future date"but not now".

title: PETER COPELAND, 70, 4 STORES ARCHITECT
description: Peter Copeland, an industrial architect, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan and in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Through A Looking Glass
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 Anyone aware of what American leaders said on our way into Vietnam must have a sense, these days, of reliving the past. But it is not the pleasurable nostalgia of Proust. For what is familiar is the selfdeception, the confusion of objectives.

title: Puppets, Magic, Music
description: WHAT'S THE MATTER, LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD? by National Puppet Productions, 1:30 P.M. Saturday, at Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. $1. Children under $ must IA accompanied by an adult, children under 3 not admitted. 5341672.

title: U.S. Begins Bargaining Round On Western Cooperation in Oil
description: PARIS, Jan. 29 The United States has begun a new round of difficult bargaining with Western industrial nations to intensify the consumer cooperation it feels is necessary before any meeting with oilproducing states.

title: ABOUREZK SEEKS OILCONCERN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, citing a variety of studies showing that oil companies are increasing their investments in coal, nuclear power, geothennal steam and solar technology, introduced today legislation to prohibit oil companies from owning assets in other energy industries.

title: ... Toward Geneva?
description: Former Foreign Minister Abba Eban and other influential Israelis more inhibited in what they can say publicly are reportedly asking if Israel might do better skipping over a few phases of the stepbystep approach to peacemaking, in which bits of territory are traded for bits of peace, and try instead for a comprehensive peace settlementfinal borders, recognition, Palestinian rights and allright away.

title: 19 Indicted in Heroin Traffic in City
description: Federal and city law enforcement officials yesterday an, flounced the indictment of 19 alleged heroin traffickers and the seizure of more than half al million dollars in cash at the; home of a couple in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Phillips Profit Down 2.5%; National Distillers in Drop
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday a 2.5 per cent decline in profits for the fourth quarter of 1974 but a 74.5 per cent advance for the full year.

title: Idea That Plants Emote Is Rebutted
description: The hypothetical secret life of plants, including the notion that a household philodendron can be happy or sad, remained secret yesterday despite a panel discussion by six researchers before a meeting of the country's largest scientific body.

title: Iran and Britain Pact Set
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Iran and Britain signed today a protocol for economic, technical and industrial cooperation involving 150 projects with a total value of :more than $1.19billion. The protocol, signed by the British Secretary of State for Trade Peter Shore and Iranian Minister of Commerce Fereydoun Mahdavi, provides for Britain to supply Iran with I cargo ships of 20,000 tons capacity each, Mr. Mahdavi said.

title: Teng Heads China's Army; 3d Major Role in Regime; Back in Power Alter 66 Purge, He Also Holds State and Party Jobs
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 29  Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping, who has returned to leading government and party positions in Peking in the last year, has now also been named army chief of staff, a Foreign Ministry spokesman disclosed today.

title: Clinton Gymnasts Develop Dynasty
description: Gymnastics, a suburban sport, has taken a firm hold at an inner city school. Since Yamashitas and Swedish falls became almost as popular as zone presses and fast breaks at DeHigh Witt Clinton in the Bronx, the School school's gymSports nastics team has won 75 straight dual meets and the last eight public Schools Athletic League championships. Philosophically I'm prepared for a defeat, say the Governors coach, John Traetta. I could accept it if it was for the proper reason. There has been no proper reason since 1966.

title: HarlemOwned Hotel Situated in the Virgin Islands
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE Virgin Island The Harlem Commonwealth Council has achieved a feat here, 1,500 miles from its home base, that seems impossible to accomplish at 125th Street and Seventh Avenue, in the heart of Harlem.

title: Rutgers Drops Cason
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.,. Jan. 29 (AP) Les Cason, a 6foot9inch center for the Rutgers University basketball team, was dropped from school for academic reasons, a university spokesman said today. Cason, a junior, scored an average of 5.6 points per game.

title: Military Cooperation Foreseen As IranianSaudi Ties Increase
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 28Relations between the two Middle Eastern oil superpowers, Iran and Saudi Arabia, have shown signs of improving in recent months, in the view of highly placed Iranians and diplomats here, and are likely to improve further as the Saudi armed forces grow stronger and more selfconfident.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne invited the Governors of East Coast states or their representatives to a meeting tomorrow in Princeton to discuss policy on offshore oil drilling and President Ford's energy program. Mr. Byrne said Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, of the Senate Subcommittee on Oceans and Atmosphere, were also expected to attend.

title: Wimbledon Concession Is Small
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP)Prize money at Wimbledon this year will surpass $250,000 for the first time, a spokeman for the AllEngland Tennis Club said today.

title: Unions and Paper Plant Agree on Incentive Plan
description: The Garden State Paper Company and its two unions announced yesterday a labor agreement providing for a bonus for each ton of paper produced and an arbitration procedure aimed at achieving a decade of labor peace.

title: Drive on Drug Smuggling Focusing on Florida Area
description: MIAMI Ten years ago, wher David Westrate was 21 years old and just beginning a career as a narcotics agent on the West Coast, a seizure of 200 pounds of marijuana was what he called tremendous something the whole office turned out for.

title: West German Trade Surplus Set a Record in 1974
description: BONN, Jan. 29 West Germany's trade surplus in 1974 was a record $22billion, the federal statistical office in Wiesbaden reported today. The surplus for December was $2.1billion, bigger than in any previous month.

title: FETUS'S SURVIVAL STRESSED IN CASE
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The prosecution rested today, using its final witness to emphasize the central theme of its case: that the fetus aborted by Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin could have lived if given the chance.

title: GULF OIL REFUSES REFINER PAYMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Gulf Oil Corporation refused today to pay to other oil companies $3.9million due by Friday under a Federal program to equalize refiners costs.

title: Race Group to Aid Ellsworth's Horses
description: CHINO, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP)  Thoroughbred racing groups pledged financial aid today for Rex Ellsworth, the owner accused of having starved. horses at his ranch near here.

title: ZONING PROPOSAL STIRS RIVERDME
description: Special zoning protection for a large part of the Riverdale section of the Bronx as a green belt was supported by homeowners at City Planning Commission hearings yesterday, but opposition was voiced by several educational and other institutions owning large tracts of land in the area.

title: P.L.O. Declares It Will Punish Hijackers
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 29The Palestine Liberation Organization announced today that it had decided to treat the hijacking of airplanes, ships or trains as crimes and would impose death penalties on hijackers if their actions led to the foss of life.

title: Falling Crane Kills Worker
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan . 29  William J. Paoletti, 26 years old, of Shelburne Falls, Mass., died in Hartford yesterday afternoon from injuries that resulted when a crane fell on him here at a construction site where he was working earlier in the day. The toppled crane at the site of water pollution abatement plant, knocked out a 4,100volt power line causing a loss of electrical service for about 15 minutes to nearly 1,000 customers, including the local radio station.

title: 'Street Fighter,' Karate Film, Full of Inane Violence
description: Like the late Bruce Lee in the slew of bloody capers he dominated, Sonny Chiba, a Japanese newcomer to the karate school of Oriental cinema, now is proving he too can handle all the bad guys and gals from Hong Kong to Tokyo  in "The Street Fighter," which landed, gushing gallons of synthetic gore, in local houses yesterday.
