If nothing else, this Japanese-made, English-dubbed import illustrates that its inane violence deserves the Xrating with which it has been labeled.Mr. Chiba, a stocky, muscular type, who has mastered a combination of Chinese boxing and the grunts, groans, grim stares and balletic hands-and-feet mayhem of karate, is immersed in a plot as complex as chop suey. Basically he's battling Yakuza gangsters who have joined with the Mafia to kidnap a gorgeous oil heiressand, incidentally, he has also incurred the enmity of another karate champ, whose brother he has killed and whose sister he has ruined.Obviously the story is not the thing here. And Mr. Chiba is not so much a hero as a rough citizen who appears to savor the bloodletting and the killing karate chops. He even rips the genitals from a would-be rapist and the throat from another adversary to indicate his love of this bloody contact sport."I think we're in trouble," observes Gerald Yamada, his clownish sidekick, at one point in the murderous goings-on. It's an understatement for everyone concerned, including viewers.

title: Advertising
description: A couple of weeks ago Cathy Cash, a dynamic, pixyish redhead with sparkling eyes and a quick, wide smile, took over the job of vice president for communications of Bloomingdale's, the departmentstore chain.

title: House Democrats Endorse Own Study on Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A Democratic study group unanimously recommended today that the House create a bipartisan select committee to investigate the activities of all Government intelligence apencies.

title: People and Business
description: Kenneth R. Cole Jr., the last remaining senior White House aide from the Nixon Administration, will join the Union Camp Corporation as a corporate vice president, effective March 3. Mr. Cole, who is 37 years old, joined the White House staff in 1969 as special assistant to the President and became deputy director of the Domestic Council in July, 1970. He has been executive director of the council since December, 1972, and Assistant to the President for Domestic Affairs since January of last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: Lew Archer Joins the Police LineUp at NBC
description: First confession of the day: I have never read any of Ross Macdonald's privateeye fictions. Second confession: After the watching the first episode of NBC's Archer, a new :%veekly series exploiting the character created by Mr. Macdonald, I doubt I will ever read any of his privateeve fictions.

title: W. Kentucky Pin Defeat On La Salle
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (UPI)Field goals by Mike Odemns and Johnny Britt in the last 25 seconds enabled Western Kentucky to upset 10thranked La Salle, 9187, tonight in college basketball. The loss snapped La Salle's 11game winning streak.

title: Fun for Children
description: The Paper Bag Players are back in New York with their latest imaginative offering, Everybody, Everybody. It consists of revuelike sketches that blend art, music, dance and drama and has a tempo that carries one happily from relaxing mood to suspenseful melodrama.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 11 contained erroneous information about Fred B. Black Jr., a former Washington lobbyist. A corrective article appears on Page 18.

title: Accord Is Reached. in Long Newark Rent Strike
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29  The Newark Housing Authority and the Columbus Homes Tenants Association today signed an agreement ending a fourandahalfyear rent strike at the 6,000 resident low  income project in the city's North Ward.

title: F.D.A. Eases Food Rules to Raise Supply
description: The Food and Drug Administration is modifying some of its regulations in ways that the agency believes will help to supply the nationand ultimately the worldwith adequate quantities of nutritious food, a lawyer for the Federal agency reported here yesterday.

title: RUSSIAN ASSAILS CONSUMER STRESS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29Government planners are being advised that paying too much attention to consumer goods could make Soviet citizens greedy, egotistical, dependent and doctrinally weak an Communism.

title: Mary Arnold Prentiss Is Dead; Won 30 National Tennis Titles
description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Jan. 29 (AP)Mary Arnold Prentiss, one of the country's top senior women tennis players, died Sunday at her home here. She was 58 years old.

title: Islanders Set Back Stars, 43
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 29 (LJPI)Denis Potvin knocked in Bob Nystrom's rebound to break a 33 tie and lift the New York Islanders to 43 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight in a National Hockey League game

title: Buddy Bunker, 62, Is Dead; Photographer Won Pulitzer
description: OMAHA, Jan. 29 (AP) Earle L. (Buddy) Bunker, a Pulitzer Prize winning photographer, died today apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 62 years old.

title: Rockefeller Visits State to Help G.O.P.
description: MILLBURN, Jan. 29  In his first partisan political foray since being sworn into office Vast December, Vice President Rockefeller visited New Jersey tonight in an effort to revitalize a state Republican party that has been debilitated by Watergate, the disastrous gubernatorial campaign of Charles W. Sandman Jr. and the economic ravages of the nation's continuina recession.

title: Books of The Times
description: Every social convulsion eventually spawns its own set of clichs and oversimplifications. Max Weber had a word for this process: He called it bureaucratization, the reduction of innovations or inspirations to routines or formulas. What is so interesting about Families and Survivors is that it shows bureaucratization simultaneously at work on two levels: the social and the literary. On the social level, Alice Adams has reduced the emergent woman of the nineteenseventies to a formula; on the literary level, she does as much for, or to, certain innovations in the novel form.

title: Refinery Picketing Quiet
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., Jan. 29 (AP)  Picketing at the Continental oil Company refinery here Was peaceful today following several reported incidents Tuesday and a deliberate act of sabotage, company spokesmen said someone had shut the valves on a 24inch natural gas pipeline early ycsterday causing the gas to be flared through safety valves. The hourlong shutoff caused a temporary gas cUrtailment to several area businesses.

title: Douds Appointed Coach
description: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 29 (UPI)Dennis Douds, an assistant coach for nine seasons, was named today to replace Charles Reese as head football coach at East Stroudsburg State College.

title: MEDICAID BILLED FOR ROLLSROYCE WITHA CHAUFFEUR; Auditors Tell of $8.6.MilIion in Unwarranted Outlays at 125 Nursing Homes; EXPATIENT CITES ABUSE; Says at State Hearing Nurse Hit HimDoctor Testifies About Poor Treatment
description: State auditors testified yesterday that partial examinations of 125 nursing homes had so far turned up $8.6million in unwarranted billings to Medicaid, including a RollsRoyce and a chauffeur for one operator, fuel for the yacht of another and alimony for the former wife of a third.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Public Service Commission has asked the New York Telephone Company to take steps to insure that police departments throughout the state are not recording incoming calls illegally. A commission spokesman said the action had been taken in response to complaints that the Sheriff's office and the New Rochelle and Mount Pleasant Police Departments in Westchester County were making such recordings.

title: FORD BRIEFS TEAM FOR AARMS PACT Tells Delegates to Adhere to the Vladivostok Principles in New Geneva Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Ford instructed American negotiators today to work out a nucleararms accord with the Soviet Union in accordance with the principles he agreed to last November with Leonid I. Brezhnev at their meeting at Vladivostok.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Drug Experts Recommend Marijuana as a Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) A drug expert said today that marijuana is good medicine for many ailments and doctors should be free to prescribe it.

title: Eastern Ski Operators Report a Season Boom
Martin Plays Lawyer in 'Mr. Ricco'
description: In "Mr. Ricco," a very bad urban melodrama directed by Paul Bogart, Dean Martin plays a brilliant San Francisco criminal lawyer much as if brilliant San Francisco criminal lawyers modeled their behavior on successful television personalities such as Mr. Martin.Everything about the character Mr. Martin plays, a man named Ricco, looks like displaced Southern California; the tan, the hair-set and even the boredom, which suggests the fellow wants to get back to that old gang of his in the Polo Lounge as quickly as possible. When the TV personality isn't being directly evoked, the movie relies on reversals that are inside jokes for about 60 million people. Mr. Rico drinks nothing but milk (he has an ulcer) and is such a terrible golfer he uses his dog to cheat for him.The story is about the search for someone who we are meant to believe is a black militant leader turned cop-killer. It doesn't hold much water. It's such a clumsy movie it makes all the actors look dreadful, which may or may not be the fact."Mr. Rico" opened yesterday at the Forum and other theaters.

title: Bonn Trade Surplus Reaches 22Billion
description: BONN, Jan. 29  West Germany's trade surplus in 1974 was a record $22billion, the federal statistical office in Wiesbaden reported today. The surplus for December was $2.1billion, bigger than in any previous month.

title: Trial Opens for Man Involved In French Connection Inquiry
description: A major narcotics defendant, his 26yearold son and an alleged associate werrt on trial in Federal District Court here yesterday on charges of conspiracy to sell large amounts of heroin, but another defendant failed to appear and forfeited bail of more than $200,000.

title: SIMON LOEB, FOUNDER OF ACCOUNTING FIRM
description: Simon Loeb, founder and retired senior partner of the accounting firm of Loeb & Troper, died Tuesday, apparently of a stroke, at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 9 Birch Road, Yonkers.

title: Iran Loan to Peru Is Set
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Iran has agreed to lend Peru $100million for the construction of a pipeline to carry oil from the Amazon jungle to the northern Peruvian coast, the Financial Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: TROOPER DRAGGED AND SHOT IN JERSEY
description: A New Jersey state trooper was seriously injured last night at the New Gretna toll plaza of the Garden State Parkway when he was dragged 1,000 feet by a car escaping a police, blockade. The trooper was also shot in the shoulder.

title: Oakland Police Detonate Bomb Alter New Warning
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 29 A bomb that failed to explode last night in the Oakland Federal office building was detonated in the street this morning by a bomb disposal squad.

title: Legislators Find Ennui,Not Whoopee,in Albany
description: ALBANYThe front door at the Ambassador bar banged open. Doug the bartender looked up and saw an Assemblyman lurch in, slump against the wall, then walk unsteadily toward the bar.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company has awarded a $127.3million contract to the National Shipbuilding Company, San Diego, to build two 150,000deadweightton Catalinaclass tankers. The steamturbinepowered ships will used to haul oil from Alaska's North Slope to West Coast ports.

title: DROUGHT IN SOMALIA IS SAID TO KILL 1,500
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y . Jan. 29A prolonged drought in Somalia has resulted in 1,500 deaths from hunger and has crowded relief camps with 230.000 refugees, a Government snokesman said here today.

title: Central Park Zoo Plan Would Ban Big Animals
description: All the big animals in the Central Park Zoothe elephants, the lions, the gorrillaswould be taken from their homes at the zoo, which has been described by critics as an inhumane habitat, and shipped to other cities, under the latest plans of the Parks Department and the New York Zoological Society.

title: SCHOOL AIDE GOT JOB FOR HIS WIFE
description: The superintendent of scandaltorn Community School District 9 in the Bronx conceded yesterday that he had helped his wife obtain a job as a consultant for a contractor that had received more than $1million in business from the district.

title: WEATHERMEN GOT NAME FROM SONG
description: The Weather Underground, the radicals who claim responsibility for yesterday's bombing of the State Department and for planting a bomb in Oakland, Calif., started out as the Weathermen.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The economic indicators used by the Government to forecast future economic sends are sliding downward at a record pace, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Steelers Cap 442Player Draft By Picking Nebraska Sleeper
description: The National Football League's draft of the supposedly best 442 college sencniors ended last night at 7:58 when the Pittsburgh Steelers, the league champions, made the last selection.

title: Space Needle Parachutists
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 29 (AP) Two young men parachuted 520 feet from the observation platform of Seattle's Space Needle, landed on a nearby street and sped away laughing with two accomplices in a ian, the police said.

title: Fairleigh Tops Rider
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 29 Rich Conrad scored 25 points tonight to lead Fairleigh Dickinson University to a 7775 overtime triumph over Rider College.

title: Senate Approves 275Million in Aid For Penn Central
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Senate approved today $275million in emergency grants and loan guarantees to keep the Penn Central Railroad from shutting down next month.

title: TurkHeld Cypriotes Find Idleness Is Foe
description: YIALOUSA, Cyprus, Jan. 25 About 40 men of all ages sat around the small wooden tables of the village cafe, some playing cards, others talking over small cups of coffee or large cups of tea. Near midday, the streets of this village of about 2,000 were nearly empty.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 11 contained erroneous informtion about Fred B. Black Jr., a former Washington lobbyist. A corrective article appears on Page 18.

title: Migration From Metropolitan Area Called a Threat
description: The metropolitan area faces the most serious social and environmental consequences because of a continued scattering of population, the Regional Plan Association said Yesterday.

title: Japan and Soviet Union Sign Oil Search Accord
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP) Japan and the Soviet Union signed a $100million credit agreement yesterday for oil and natural gas development off the Soviet island of Sakhalin.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Twentyfive men were charged with conducting a largescale gambling operation in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx. The operation allegedly took bets totaling $50million a year on horse races and other sports events, according to a prosecutor at the arraignment of the defendants in Federal District Court here.

title: E.P.A. BAN ON LEAD IN GAS IS VOIDED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A federal appeals court here has ruled against regulations that would have gradually eliminated lead from gasoline beginning this year.

title: Exxon Dividend Cut To $1.25 in Quarter
description: The board of the Exxon Corporation cut the company's dividend to $1.25 a share for the first quarter of 1975 from $1.55 a share in the fourth quarter of 1974. In the first quarter of 1974, Exxon the world's largest oil company paid shareholders $1.10 a share, the same as that for the final quarter of 1973.

title: PRICES OF WHEAT MOVE NARROWLY
description: Wheat futures prices closed with little change yesterday after fluctuations following news that the Soviet Union had canceled an order for 3.7 million bushels of American wheat.

title: BOUGHTON COBB JR., EXPERT ON BOATS, 50
description: Boughton Cobb Jr., a technical adviser and writer on marine construction, died yesterday of cancer at his home on Shore Road, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. He was 50 years old.

title: Giants Choices
description: John Tate, Jackson State, linebacker; Mike Mahoney, Richmond, wide receiver; Terry McClowry, Michigan State, linebacker; George Martin, Oregon, defensive end; Marsh White, Arkansas, running back; Ricky Townsend. Tennessee, kicker; Jim O'Connor, Drake, running back; Jim Micklos, Ball State, tight end; Rondy Colbert, Lamar, defensive back.

title: QUARTER NET UP 51% AT BRANIFF AIRWAYS
description: The Braniff International Corporation, the holding company for Braniff Airways, said yesterday that its airline subsidiary earned $6.7million, or 34 cents a share, during the fourth quarter of 1974. The earnings were 51 per cent higher Wan the $4.4million, or 22 cents a share, reported during the same period in 1973.

title: 25 Indicted Here in Operation Of $50Million Gambling Ring
description: Twenty  five men were charged yesterday with conducting a gambling operation that allegedly took bets totaling $50million a year on horse races and other sports events.

title: A 2d Visit to Rockefeller Office By Bergman in 73 Is Reported
description: A second meeting in former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's Manhattan office involving top state officials and Bernard Bergman, the central figure in current investigations of the nursing home industry, has been confirmed in depositions obtained by state investigators.

title: Teng Heads China's Army; 3d Major Role in Regime
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 29 Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping, who has returned to leading government and party positions in Peking in the last year, has now also been named army chief of staff, a Foreign Ministry spokesman disclosed today.

title: 1974 TRADE BY U.S. WITH CHINA SET PEAK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) United States trade with China climbed to a record total of $922.1million in 1974 but is expected to decline by about 40 per cent this year because of reduced Chinese agricultural purchases, the National Council for United StatesChina Trade has reported.

title: Conviction Overturned
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP)The conspiracy conviction of Lewis !Cates, former Philadelphia Deputy City $olicitor was overturned yesterday hy the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

title: Falling Crane Kills Worker
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 29  William J. Paoletti, 26 years old, of Shelburne Falls, Mass., died in Hartford yesterday afternoon from injuries that resulted when a crane fell on him here at a construction site where he was working earlier in the day. The toppled crane at the site of water pollution abatement plant, knocked out a 4,100volt power line causing a loss of electrical service for about 15 minutes to nearly 1,000 customers, including the local radio station.

title: FRANCE ARRESTS 4 IN DRUG SMUGGLING
description: PARIS, Jan. 29The French police are working on a narcotics smuggling case that they say is just in its beginnings with the arrest of four men in Marseilles Saturday.

title: Ford Firm on Levy On Oil but Indicates A Tax Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Ford indicated today that he would be willing to compromise with Congress on tax cut legislation, but appeared to rule out any concessions on his program to reduce oil imporn.

title: Greece Cutting Taxes
description: ATHENS, Jan. 29 (Reuters)Greece today announced tax cuts for the poor as part of measures to cope with inflation and economic stagnation. A statement said the cuts would affect 95 per cent of taxpayers, while taxes would be raised on incomes exceeding $32,000.

title: Lakewood Boasts A Cuban Hotshot
description: When Coach Bob Nastase of Lakewood High first saw him, he could tell immediately that Reinaldo Henry was fascinated by the game of basketball as both stood watching a group of youngsters playing in a summer recreational program. Verbal communication was not necessary for Nastase to discern the youngster's fondness of the game. Nor was it possible. For Reinaldo had just come to this country from Cuba With his family and could not speak English.

title: Survey Sees 1 Million Youths As Lacking Jobs Next Summer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A survey of the nation's cities shows that more than three million youths will be looking for summer employment this year, and that, about half of them will likely go unemployed, according to a report released today by the office of Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: F.B.I. Counterintelligence Is Under G.A.O. Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, said today that he had ordered an investigation by the General Accounting Office into the counterintelligence programs of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 4 in Drug Ring Found Guilty; ExProsecutor Had a Role
description: A jury in Federal Court in Manhattan has returned a verdict of guilty against four members of a narcotics supply ring in which a former Queens prosecutor admitted taking part.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Seers and the Law
description: Predicting the future is against the law in New York City, where 1,000 gypsy readeradvisers and an unknown number of selfproclaimed psychics are busily engaged in that work.

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE

title: TERMS ARE REVISED FOR A BANK MERGER
description: Revised terms for the merger of the Empire National Bank into the National Bank of North, America were announced yesterday.

title: Screen: La Rupture 70 Chabrol Work Has Virtues, Difficulties
description: Claude Chabrol has reportedly described his 1970 melodrama, La Rupture (The Breakup), as belonging to his Fritz Lang period, which may be one of its virtues as well as one of its difficulties.

title: Marcos Rule Challenged In Top Philippine Court
description: MANILA, Jan. 30In the presence of a crowd that overflowed to the street, and amid high emotions, the Philippine Supreme Court heard a petition today filed by 14 persons who charged that President Ferdinand Marcos was not in office legally and could not legally call a referendum.

title: Kidnapping of Patricia Hearst Remains a Mystery as First Anniversary Approaches
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30It is now almost a year since Patricia Hearst was dragged screaming from her apartment in Berkeley on the night of Feb. 4, 1974. and the mystery of where and how she is remains as deep as ever.

title: NBC, With New President, Moves Into Contention for Leadership
description: In the respect that movies are a director's medium and the Broadway stage a producer's, television is an executive's medium. The heroes of the hour are not those who make the shows or perform in them but those who establish network policy and are most responsible for selecting and assembling the program fare.

title: Ford Opens First Talks With Prime Minister Wilson
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain conferred with President Ford at some length today on international energy and economic problems on the first day of the British leader's getacquainted visit with the new Administration.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Giant Floodgates May Save Sinking Cities
description: London and Venice, which are both sinking, may eventually be saved from drowning by the construction of giant sea gates.

title: Ethics of Medicine And the Spirit Of Western Culture
description: HOUSTONThe spirit of Western culture, which is the spirit of modern scientific medicine, is today an erratic wind that cannot sustain fullblown the sails of our technological voyage.

title: Help Vowed for 6 Orphaned by Hospital Slaying
description: A little more than a year ago the six young Walker children lost their mother when the car she was riding in crashed into a cemetery gate. Now their father it dead. too.

title: Bonn Lists Million Jobless
description: BONN, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The number of unemployed rose to 1.15million in West Germany this month, the highest figure in 16 years, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week ??otaled an estimated 15 billion ??onmiles, 10.8 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 449,240 cars, 13.7 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 27.3 per cent below last year.

title: CHASE CUTS PRIME HALFPOINT TO 9%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday reduced its prime rate to 9 per cent, the lowest rate charged by a major bank since March, 1974, as corporations continued to cut back their borrowings.

title: Nyquist Delays Hearings On Five lntegration Cases
description: The State Commissioner of Education, Ewald B. Nyquist, announced yesterday that he Would put off scheduled hearings on five longstanding schoolintegration orders until the Board of Regents gave him a clarification of its recent statement disavowing, the use of racial ratios in integration efforts.

title: Wilson: A Talent for Surviving
description: LONDON, Jan. 30While Prime Minister Harold Wilson was in Washington meeting President Ford today, his political opponents were decrying economic rot in Britain, officials were warning of the dangers of more terrorist bombs and the Government suffered a minor defeat in Parliament on a pensions bill.

title: FOOD STAMPS PLAN OPPOSED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The House Agriculture Committee approved today a bill to prevent an increase in the cost of buying food stamps that the Ford Administration plans to put ino effect March 1.

title: Some Special Attention In Syndicated Research
description: The Magazine Research Development Committee, which will attempt to unravel the knotty problem of syndicated magazine research, met for the first time on Wednesday and decided to meet twice a month at least for the next five months and to issue a public progress report every three months.

title: The Kind of Night Opera Fans Live For
description: It was one of those nights that opera fans live for, full of backstage theatrics, onstage suspense and even some passably good singing. The Metropolitan Opera's Tosca on Wednesday night brought on Teresa ZylisGara for her first appearance here in the title part, and paired her with Carlo Bergonzi as Cavaradossi. The Italian tenor was returning to the Met after several seasons of muchdeplored absence.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: SOUTH AFRICANS SAID TO ACT AGAINST DIGGS
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Representative Charles C. Diggs, Jr., Democrat of Michigan said tonight he had been declared persona non grata by South Africa.

title: WATCHDOG IS URGED OVER JUSTICE DEPT.
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP)Attorney General William B. Saxbe urged Congress today to create a permanent watchdog committee to guard against Justice Department wrongdoing.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY IS REORGANIZED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The first major reorganization of the massive Social Security Administration was announced today. The reorganization was prompted in part by rising congressional criticism of the relatively new welfare program.

title: New Drugs on Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 That crowning tenet of AngloSaxon lawthat a person is innocent until proved guilty cannot and does not apply to drugs and medical devices. This fact has been brought sharply to public attention this week in connection with three important, quite disparate things: a class of drugs used by diabetics, two relatively new antibiotics, and one widely used birth control product of the group called intrauterine contraceptive devices IUD's.

title: The Detroit Symphony Capable And Efficient in Program Here
SENATE HEARING SET ON REACTOR SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Two Senate committees will hold a hearing next Wednesday on the Government's order that the emergency cooling systems of almost half the nation's reactors be closed down and inspected for cracks.

title: Turk Reports Agreement . To Open Nicosia Airport
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan 30 (UPI  Turkish and Greek Cypriotes have reached agreement to reopen the Nicosia airport to international traffic under joint Turkish and Greek control, Premier Sadi Irmak of Turkey said today.

title: Who Are the Friends of Israel?; WASHINGTON
description: Henry Kissinger is going back to the Middle East again amidst a plague of propaganda. The Arab extremists are blaming him for threatening war; the Israeli extremists are muttering that maybe he's going to sell them out. But oddly, both sides don't seem to know what they'd do without him. He has become the old kitchencrisis man of the thirties: Quic.k Henry, the Flit.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Iremite explosives that were used in recent bombings in Puerto Rico had been described by Robert Dwyer, of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as stolen from a factory in Manati, P. R.not in Manhattan, as an article said in The New York Times Tuesday.

title: Miriam Cans Gould, 85, Professor of Psychology
description: Miriam Caris Gould, professor of psychology at Smith and Vassar Colleges for a quarter of a century, died Wednesday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home here. Her age was 85.

title: Carey Budget Proposal Would Affect 20 State Panels
description: In what would represent a rare shrinkage of the state bureaucracy, Governor Carey recommended yesterday in his proposed budget the elimination or consolidation of 20 state boards, commissions and councils, many of which have been havens for seldom show political appointees.

title: DRIVE TO STEP UP WAR AID TO SAIGON OPENS IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Administration opened an uphill battle in Congress today for additional military aid for the Saigon Government with a claim that North Vietnam was moving one and perhaps two other combat divisions into South Vietnam.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (Millions of dollars)

title: PARLEY IS WARNED ON GAS SUPPLIES
description: Conflicts between East Coast householders and industries over shrinking supplies of natural gas could lead to chaos within a year, Dr. Philip Abelson, editor of Science magazine, told a session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science here yesterday.

title: Abram Names 4 to Panel On Nursing Home Inquiry
description: Morris B. Abram, chairman of the state commission set up to investigate conditions in nursing homes, announced the four other members of the commission yesterday and pledged that their work would not suffer the fate of the 1960 Kaplan report on alleged nursinghome frauds in New York City. That report apparently was ignored or pigeonholed by high city officials.

title: CANADA PLAN TO GET TARSAND OIL GAINS
description: OTTWA, Jan. 30 (AP)Projects to extract oil from a huge area of tar sands in the province of Alberta advanced somewhat today in Ottawa and in Calgary.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $727million, up 1 per cent from the year earlier $721million. Total retail store sales were about $10.43billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $9.74billion.

title: CAREY ASKING NEW TAXES, CUT IN AGENCIES TO MEET A $10 69BILL1ON BUDGET
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Citing a. massive and threatening gap". between revenues and expense's for the year ahead, Governor Carey today proposed $806million in new taxes and the elimination or merger of 20 state agencies to balance a record $10.69billion budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1.

title: Stock Market Ends SixSession Advance
description: Increased profit taking in the afternoon ended the stock market's six consecutive sessions of advances yesterday as prices ended lower in continued hectic trading.

title: Myopia on Africa
description: At a time of dramatic change in southern Africa, President Ford and Secretary Kissinger need an experienced handsensitive alike to the fears of white Africans and the longdelayed aspirations of black Africansto advise them on United States policy. They have had such an adviser in Donald Easum, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs since last March, a man of long experience in several countries of the new Africa, who has been inexplicably and abruptly replaced.

title: McKellen Leads Title Skating
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 30 Gordon McKellen Jr. of Lake Placid, N.Y., admits he's a come from behind guy and proved it today as he took the lead after opening competition in the senior men's event at the United States figure skating championships at the Oakland Coliseum.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Iremite explosives that were used in recent bombings in Puerto Rico had been described by Robert Dwyer, of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as stolen from a factory in Manati, P. R.not in Manhattan, as an article said in The New York Times Tuesday.

title: Jersey Reports 1 in 10 Persons Was Unemployed in December
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30At least one of every 10 persons in the labor force in New Jersey was unemployed last month, according to state figures released today. State labor officials said the figure signified an economic and social crisis of major proportions in the state.

title: Bonn Lists Million Jobless
description: BONN, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The number of unemployed rose to 1.15million in West Germany this month, the highest figure in 16 years, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: BORIS BLACHER DEAD, GERMAN COMPOSER
description: Boris Blacher, one of the leading German composers in the period after World War II, has died at the age of 72, it was announced yesterday in Berlin, where he had been living since 1922. The son of German and Estonian parents, he was born in Newchwang, China.

title: Dim Days of January
description: During January, the handwriting on the wall became very clear indeed.

title: State Police Swear In First Woman Trooper
description: SEA GIRT, Jan. 30  Gail Just stood with the graduating class of 80 men tonight and took an oath to serve faithfully in the ranks of the New Jersey state police.

title: CarOutput Cut Seen
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30Automobile production in February is expected to decline about 8 per cent from January, according to industry analysts, indicating that they do not see any major recall of indefinitely laidoff workers in the month ahead.

title: About New York
description: The art of walking in New York, like so many other arts, has undergone great change over the years and it is not always easy to take it in stride.

title: Article 1  No Title
Mr. Ford Acts Like a President
description: Gerald Ford is beginning to look more like a President, which is not necessarily a good thing. In dealing. with the energy crisis, he has acted unilaterally, challenged rather than consulted Congress, and proclaimed one true religion.

title: The Euphoric and Libidinous Art of Reuben Nakian
description: GREENWICH, Conn. Sculpture of a fullbodied obstreperous sort thrives on tragic involvement. When the bronze pours like molasses and the welded steel is all spikes and tatters. it helps if the subject matter is nearer to King Lear than to Much Ado About Nothing. Agitation and anxiety are one, in other words, and agitation is basic to abstract expressionism, whether in painting in sculpture.

title: Notes on People
description: In the latest convolution in the Boston University controversy over the invitation later rescindedto Ronald Ziegler to lecture Feb. 26, John R. Silber, the university's president, said yesterday that the original offer of $3,000 was wholly unauthorized, but he reinvited the former White House press secretary to appear at the school's standard maximum fee of $1,000. The offer was declined.

title: Bergman Is Asking That He Not Testify Before Senate Unit
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator, has asked the Senate subcommittee on longterm care to excuse him from testifying here next Tuesday on the ground that in the present atmosphere it would prejudice his rights in the light of grandjury Inquiries.

title: Money
description: DOMESTIC MARKET

title: Air Force Awards Contract To Alter F111 to Grumman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Air Force awarded Grumman Aerospace Corporation of Bethpage, L. I., an $85million contract today to modify two FUnder the contract, which 111 fighterbombers into electronic countermeasure planes.20;

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Dr. Stella Chess, an author, researcher and professor of child psychiatry at New York University, says that her early trainidg left her under the impression that if child had !'a certain set of experiences. he'd have a certain set of problems. But her daytoday clinical practice taught her It just wasn't so.

title: THE JOBLESS RATE IN JERSEY CLIMBS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30At least one of every 10 persons in the labor force in New Jersey was unemployed last month, according to state figures released today. State labor officials said the figure signified an economic and social crisis of major proportions in the state.

title: President Sends Congress Energy Independence Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  President Ford sent Congress today his proposed Energy Independence Act of 1975  a 182page program for energy conservation  and said prompt action on all these measures is essential.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 30The United States world championship team was in top gear this afternoon at the start of the semifinal match against France, the European champions.

title: About Real Estate
description: DALLASThe lapel buttons read HOW, and the people who were wearing them at the 31st annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders week ago were only too happy to tell you how.

title: Dr. William Daily, 79, Dies; A Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. William T. Daily, an attending physician at Long Island College Hospital, serving its obstetrics and gynecology department for 45 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived at 99 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.

title: How Carey's Sales Taxes Affect Everyday Affairs of Consumers
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30The full impact of Governor Carey's proposed $806million tax program, if it is enacted, would affect taxpayers across the state even as they drive from the gasoline pump to the beauty parlor, the bowling alley and the theater.

title: Feminist Predicts April Ratification For Equal Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Karen DeCrow, a feminist leader, predicted today that the Equal Rights Amendment would be ratified by April. However, Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national chairman, foresaw a full hard year's work ahead because it becomes part of the Constitution.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Inquiry Begun on Parkway Shooting

title: AIR RULES EASED FOR GLASS PLANTS
description: SALEM, N.J., Jan. 30 (AP)The State agreed today to relax pollution restrictions on glass factories in South Jersey.

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: U.S. Court Assigns Priority to Seniority Over Race on Jobs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan, 30 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled today that workers with seniority have priority proteciton against layoffs over minoritygroup and female emnloves.

title: LASTING TAX CUTS OPPOSED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Saying that inflation was still a major problem, the Federal Reserve chairman, Arthur F. Burns, recommended today against any permanent tax cut and indicated that his agency would not quickly ease credit to bolster the economy.

title: Fred Lindstrom and the Hall of Fame
description: Fred Lindstrom, the youngest man ever to play in World Series, served for 12 blameless seasons with the Nev York Giants, the Pittsburgh Pirates and Chicago Cubs, and when the Cubs gave him his release after 1935 he signed with the Brooklyn. Dodgers. Casey Stengel, the Brooklyn manager, realized that Lindstrom was slowng down but reasoned that if he had anything left at all his presence would improve the team, which was distinguished chiefly by a talent for low comedy. Lindstrom himself had remarked on the Dodgers gift for slapstick years earlier when he was still a Giant. Sitting in a friendly game of fivecard stud one evening, he was raised by John Drebinger of The New York Times. Drebinger had just been assigned to the Giants after considerable exposure to the Brooklyn variety of baseball. When he tilted the pot, Lindstrom called.

title: An Anonymous Gift of $15,000 Highlights Neediest Donations
description: An anonymous gift of $15,000 yesterday highlighted the continuing stream of contributions to the 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Abram Names 4 to Panel On Nursing Home Inquiry
description: Morris B. Abram, chairman of the state commission set up to investigate conditions in nursing homes, announced the four other members of the commission yesterday and pledged that their work would not suffer the fate of the 1960 Kaplan report on alleged nursinghome frauds in New York City. That report apparently was ignored or pigeonholed by high city officials.

title: How Carey's Sales Taxes Affect Everyday Affairs of Consumers
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30 The full impact of Governor Carey's proposed $806million tax program, if it is enacted, would affect taxpayers across the state even as they drive from the gasoline pump to the beauty parlor, the bowling alley and the theater.

title: SAME JUDGE GETS CARTER'S APPEAL
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Lanier refused today to disqualify himself from hearing a new appeal in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case, as defense lawyers asserted that they had discovered additional evidence that could clear the former boxer and his codefendant, John Artis, of a triplehomicide conviction.

title: Agencies Facing Changes
description: Following are agency and staff changes recommended by Governor Carey in his budget message:

title: Tax Concession Set by Britain For North Sea Gas Production
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP)The British Government announced today a major tax concession to companies with gas fields in the British sector of the North Sea.

title: Simon Lowers Forecast On OPEC Cash BuildUp
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon, citing a detailed new Treasury analysis, told Congress today that the buildup of petrodollars in the oilexporting countries would be much less in the years ahead than was estimated last year after the sharp increase in the price of oil.

title: All 234,000 Cadillacs for 74 Are Recalled for Hood Latches
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30The Cadillac Division of General Motors announced today that it was recalling all 1974 model Cadillacs, about 234,000 cars, because some misaligned hood latches could cause hoods to fly open and obstruct a driver's vision.

title: New Items Would Fall Under Localities Levies
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30A $27million windfall for New York City is contained in Governor Carey's plan to expand the state sales tax, although that aspect is thought to be even more politically precarious than the rest of the Governor's tax and spending program.

title: BUOYANT FRIEDMAN HERE WITH SEXTET
description: To describe Kinky Friedman, the parodistic country rocker who was at the Bottom Line through last night, is to search for parallels. Mr. Friendman's peculiar persona can be found somewhere among those of Groucho Marx, Gene Autry, Frank Zappa and the stars of Hee Haw. But that's unfair, because Mr. Friedman and his zany band are complete originals.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Boston Eyes Navy Yard For Kennedy Library
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)Boston is considering the possibility of building the John F. Kennedy library complex at the Charlestown Navy Yard. Mark Older, a Boston Redevelopment Authority planner said yesterday that the authority was figuring out what the impact would be of establishing the library there.

title: Bayi to Make U.S. Debut In Mile at Garden Tonight
description: Filbert Bayi found some home cooking less than a 440yard dash from Madison Square Garden yesterday, which was all he needed to take his mind off Marty Liquori and his first indoor race in tonight's 50th Wanamaker Mile.

title: SALISBURY HEADS ARTS INSTITUTE
description: The National Institute of Arts and Letters, made up of artists, composers and writers eminent in their fields, has elected Harrison E. Salisbury, the newspaperman and author, as its president for a threeyear term. He succeeds Jacques Barzun, a university professor at Columbia.

title: Landmarks Unit Backs Hotel at Villard Houses
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday approved in principle the controversial plan of Harry Helmsley, the realestate developer, to erect a 52story hotel and office building joined to the historic Villard Houses on Madison Avenue, but withheld approval of specific design features.

title: Notes on People
description: In the latest convolution in the Boston University controversy over the invitation later rescindedto Ronald Ziegler to lecture Feb. 26, John R. Silber, the university's president, said yesterday that the original offer of $3,000 was wholly unauthorized, but he reinvited the former White House press secretary to appear at the school's standard maximum fee of $1,000. The offer was declined.

title: N.F.L. Draft Overlooks Some Stars
description: Echoes from the National Football League draft yesterday included hidden hurt feelings at Notre Dame; a wry comment out of Southern California; pride in West Liberty, W. Va., and a boast from Houston.

title: Construction Contracts Rose In December But Dipped in 74
description: Contracts for new construction, expanded by plans to build a huge new nuclear power plant, rose to $7.3billion in December, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems Company, reported yesterday.

title: Community Council Is Toasted At 50thAnniversary Reception
description: The Community Council of Greater New York is celebrating its 50th birthday this year, and Governor Carey and Mayor Beame last night toasted the agency's dedication to delivering social services at a golden anniversary reception at Gracie Mansion.

title: Ecology Issues Called Life's Meat, Potatoes
description: People should stop thinking of environmental protection as sort of dessert on the social menu and realize it is the meat and potatoes of man's existence, Russell W. Peterson, chairman of the Federal Council on Environmental Quality, said yesterday.

title: HOWARD WHITMAN OF NBCTV SERIES
description: Howard Whitman, a writer and syndicated radio and television commentator, died Wednesday of a stroke in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 60 years old.

title: Article 5  No Title
KISSINGER APPEAL ON TURKEY AID DUE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Secretary of State Kissinger is expected to inform key members of Congress Saturday that some progress is being made in the Cyprus negotiations, in the hope that this will lead to continued military aid to Turkey beyond next week's cutoff date for such aid.

title: Flash Fire in Camden Kills 4 Children While Their Mother Is Out for 10 Minutes
description: CAMDEN, Jan. 30While a young mother was out of her house for 10 minutes early this morning, a fire flashed through her home, killing four of her five children.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed mixed, yesterday as profit taking following a threeday gain exerted, a strong influence after an early rise.

title: BOGGS SAYS FATHER LEFT F.B.I. DOSSIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  The son of the late Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that his father had given him dossiers that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had compiled on critics of the Warren Commission in an attempt to discredit them. They weren't basically sex files, said Tom H. Boggs, of Washington, a lawyer. They had some of that element but most of the material dealt with leftwing organizations these neoole belonged to.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ALOHA SCARSDALE One of the real theater joys in town, on or off Broadway. Is a delicious serving of Leonard Bernstein's 1952 oneact opera, Trouble in Tahiti, by the enterprising WPA Theater, in a batch of short American works at its downtown showcase, 333 Bowery.

title: 260 POLICE OUSTED AS P. A. REJECTS BEAME PROPOSAL
description: The dismissal of 260 city policemen, the first Civil Service workers to be laid off since the Depression years, was ordered by Mayor Beame yesterday after the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Ken McFeeley, rejected a city proposal for laborcontract concessions that would have forestalled the discharges.

title: Average is 7.95% At U.S. Refunding
description: The United States Treasury wound up its quarterly refunding operation yesterday by selling $750million of 25year bonds at an average yield of 7.95 per cent. At this rate, the average price was 99.191. The threeday sale, which amounts to a financing of $5.5billion, attracted surprisingly strong demand, in the opinion of some observers. Yesterday's Auction apparently attracted in part the same type of buyerpension funds, for example that has been an aggressive bidder lately for toprated corporate bonds.

title: Haitink, Conductor, in Debut With Philharmonic
description: It was Bernard Haitink's debut with the New York Philharmonic, though it cannot be said that the Dutch conductor is an unknown quantity in this city. He has conducted here before, and his numerous records alone would have sufficed to make him well known. Last night in Avery Fisher Hall he introduced himself to New York audiences with Wilhelm Friedemann Bach's Symphony in D and the Bruckner Seventh Symphony.

title: Peru Wants the U.S. Excluded Form New Dialogue by Latins
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 30 (AP)President Juan Velasco Alvarado suggested today that LatinAmerican nations show their disapproval of the new United States trade law by holding their own new dialogue, excluding the United States.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: BRITISH REVIEW LAWS IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 30A committee appointed by the British Government to review antiterrorist laws in Northern Ireland recommended in its report today that detention without trial should be retained, but not indefinitely.

title: Leading Millrose Games Entries
description: 7 P.M.Pole Vault: Kiell Isaksson, Bob Richards Jr., Casey Carrigan, Mike Cotton, Don Baird.

title: Skiers Are Finding Trip Uphill More Difficult Than Trip Down
description: LEBANON, N. H., Jan. 30 Skiers unhappy about standing on long lift lines should be glad to learn there is a growing movement among resort operators to cope with this problem. The remedy on peak days, many area managers feel, is to shut liftticket windows when it is apparent the demand for uphill transportation is about to outstrip the supply.

title: Slight Effect on Racing Seen in State Cutback
description: The abolition of five betting commissions recommended yesterday by Governor Carey in his budget message will have virtually no effect on the way New York horse racing is conducted.

title: Union Pacific's Net Cut by LIFO Shift And Fund for Loss
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, operator of the Union Pacific Railroad, the nation's most profitable line in 1973, reported yesterday a 45 per cent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1974, resulting primarily from the company's decision to switch accounting methods and put $31.2million into a special reserve fund to cover anticipated losses on an oil project.

title: 8 UTILITIES PLAN JOINT FUEL STUDY
description: A group of eight electric utilities announced yesterday plans for a joint feasibility study for a $250million plant that would reprocess spent fuel from their nuclear power plants. At the same time, in Minneapolis the Northern States Power Company announced an $80million to $90million coal gasification project as a joint venture with the Office of Coal Research and the Foster Wheeler Energy Corporation.

title: Judge in Carter Appeal Won't Disqualify Himself
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Lamer refused today to disqualify himself from hearing a new appeal in the Rubin [Hurricane] Carter murder case, as defense lawyers asserted that they had discovered additional evidence that could clear the former boxer and his codefendant, John Artis, of a triplehomicide conviction.

title: LASTING TAX CUTS OPPOSED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 30 Saying that inflation was still a major problem the Federal Reserve chairman, Arthur F. Burns, recommended today against any permanent ,tax cut and indicated that his agency would not quickly ease credit to bolster the economy.

title: Pirates Reach Final With Holy Cross
description: Surviving the loss of Glenn Mosley, who has been declared ineligible by the school, Seton Hall opened the Madison Square Garden Classic last night with an 8987 victory over Fairfield University.

title: The Cast
description: LA RUPTURE (The Breakup), directed bY Claude Chabrol; screenplay (French with English subtitles) be Chabrol, based on a novel by Charlotte Armstrong; produced by Andre Genoves; director of photography, Jean Rablier; editor, Jacques Gaillard; music, Piefre Jansen; a BelgianFrenchItalian coproduction by Les Films la Beetle, Furo international and Cinevog Film. Running time: 125 minutes.

title: Garden Scoring
description: FAIRFIELD (87)Balkun 8 02 16; Reha 4 23 10; Luechau 5 12 11; Kelly 11 910 31; Odums 4 01 8; Finn 0 12 1; Mahorn 5 00 10; Pletka 1 0 0. Total: 37 1219 87.

title: Jackie Onassis Fights for Cause
description: Jackie Onassis will save us.

title: Met Resumes Sunday Sales
description: Sunday boxoffice operations at the Metropolitan Opera, discontinued last fall in an economy move, will be resumed Sunday. Tickets through March 8 will be on sale from non until 6 P.M. The company said that its many patrons had found it difficult to get to the box office during the week.

title: National Distillers Profit Rose to 4thQuarter Peak
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation had record net income of $21.1million, or 85 cents a share, in the fourth quarter last year. In the 1973 final quarter, the net income, including an extraordinary gain of $25.9million, or 97 cents a share, from the exchange of stock, came to $41.2million, or $1.55 a share.

title: U.S. Ready to Propose Controls On Use of Valium and Librium
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30After almost nine years of controversy, the Drug Enforcement Administration once again is ready to propose formal controls over the tranquilizers Valium and Librium, two of the most widely prescribed drugs.

title: PILOTS DECLARE BAN ON PERILOUS CARGO
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 30 (UPI) The Air Line. Pilots Association today ordered its 32,000 members riot to fly passenger planes with, hazardous cargo aboard.

title: Israeli Study of 73 War Cites Command Failures
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30An official commission investigating the October, 1973, war between Israel and the Arabs said today that Israel's initial setbacks resulted from a series of command, control and communication failures in the face of unexpected assaults on two fronts.

title: Mirage Sale to Egypt Said to Pose Risk to Israel
description: United States analysts say that Israeli air superiority, key element in the last two Middle East wars, may be jeopardized by Egypt's acquisition of French Mirage fighterbombers and fighters.

title: South African Nominated
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 30 (UPI) South Africa's ruling National party today nominated Finance Minister Nicolass Diederrichs to the largely titular office of President. The nomination assures Dr. Diederrichs's election to succeed Jacobus Fouch, who will step down in April.

title: C. A. B. APPROVES AIRROUTE DEALS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines approval yesterday for a massive exchange of overseas routes that would save the financially ailing carriers up to $25million each per year.

title: Egypt Reported Order 44 Jets From France
description: PARIS, Jan 30  French sources said today that Egypt had ordered a total of 44 Mirage fighters from France. Half of them are to be the new F1 plane, which went into service with the French Air Force last year.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Baltimore Theater Getting New Home

title: Old Ways Survive on Brazilian Plantation Workers Heed the Call of the City
description: MUCAMBO PLANTATION BrazilThe air on this rambling cocoa plantation in the northeastern state of Bahia is sweet with the fragrance of fermented cocoa beans and the freshness of last night's tropical rain.

title: Fighting Birth Defects
description: Each year 250,000 infants in this country are born with some type of birth defect. Some die, but many live. Today, 15 million Americans have significant birth defects.

title: ConsumerFarmer Coalition Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Consumers and farmers were urged today to unite in a coalition against big business interests that have been charged with simultaneously shortchanging farmers and gouging consumers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Swallowing the Grenade
description: In discussing his budget proposals privately a few days ago, Governor Carey reportedly observed: I am not merely biting the bullet. I may be swallowing a hand grenade. He was hardly exaggerating. The 197576 budget message delivered by the Governor yesterday an explosive documenta grim elaboration on the harsh fiscal realities that Mr. Carey outlined in his State the State address three weeks ago.

title: U.S. RETAIL SALES MIXED IN JANUARY
description: The nation's retail sales faltered in January as many consumers became more cautious in buying clothing, home furnishings and other departmentstore merchandise, according to reports yesterday from number of the country's biggest retailers.

title: Step to Civic Salvation...
description: The crisisborn agreement of three powerful civil service unions to give up some benefits guaranteed under their contract with the city represents a historic start toward a turnaround in municipal labor relationsa turnaround vital to restoration of fiscal soundness to this metropolis.

title: Gerulaitis Gains Quarterfinals
description: ROANOKE, Va. Jan. 30 (UPI)  Fifthseeded Vitas Gerulaitis, who won $7,000 last week with a secondplace showing in the United States professional indoor championships in Philadelphia, beat Gene Mayer of Mendham, N. J., 62, 63, today to enter the quarterfinals of the Roanoke international tennis tournament.

title: Advertising
description: When a consumer gets an advertising message, what makes him remember it and remember it right? A number of researchers addressed themselves to that question yesterday at a conference sponsored at the Biltmore Ho tel by the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association.

title: City Council Panel Hear Tenants Argue Right to Have Dogs
description: In a somber session yesterday, the City Council's Housing and Buildings Committee heard tenants and public and private housingproject representatives debate proposed legislation to bar landlords from excluding tenants with dogs.

title: Gary Black Weds Verina M. Adams
description: Verina Mary Adams of London, daughter of Mrs. M. C. Layton of Danbury, England, and the late Maj. W. H. Berwick, British Army, was married yesterday to Gary Black of Glyndon, Md., chairman of the board of the A. S. Abell Company, publishers of the Sun papers in Baltimore.

title: Market Averages
description: THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: Mayors Call on Congress For Vast Emergency Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30A delegation of mayors, calling President Ford's economic program inadequate to meet the crisis afflicting the nation's cities, urged Congress today to enact a multibilliondollar program of emergency aid for city and state governments.

title: RANGE IS NARROW IN GRAIN TRADING
description: Wheat, corn and soybeans traded in a narrow price range yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting uncertainty about the effect of the Soviet cancellation of orders for 100,000 tons of American wheat.

title: F.E.A. CHALLENGED IN SUIT BY EXXON
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, yesterday filed suit in United States District Court in Newark, N. J., challenging the legality of the Federal Energy administration's controversial Federal program to equalize the costs of refiners.

title: Nassau Would Be 2d In Gas Tax Benefits
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  The biggest local government beneficiary  outside of New York City  of Governor Carey's proposed 10centagallontax increase would be Nassau County, with $25.5million out of an estimated annual statewide yield of $225million.

title: INDIA WELCOMES A CHINESE TEAM
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 30Chinese have come to India to play tabIe tennis, and the Indian Government, which has been seeking to normalize relations with Peking, is treating the games as more than a sporting event.

title: How Pact Was Reached To Avoid Many Layoffs
description: Monday night, shortly after 6 o'clock, five leaders of the largest municipal labor unions in the city were standing idly in front of Mayor Beame's desk.

title: Split in Oil Nations On Price Forecast By Energy Planner
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30A leading European energy planner suggested today that a conference between oilexporting and importing countries would lead to a split in the ranks of the exporters of the crucial question of price.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Greenwood Wins Pole Spot at Daytona

title: Thieu Says $300Million Is Minimum Saigon Needs
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Jan. 30  President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that the $300million in additional aid requested for his Government by the Ford Administration was the minimum that his forces needed to defend themselves from steppedup North Vietnamese and Vietcong attacks.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Waterfowl Aid
description: Nothing, perhaps, has better dramatized the growing anti  hunting sentiment in this nation than the suit filed late last year in the United States District Court in New Jersey against the Department of the Interior.

title: Market Place
description: When a Federal Appeals Court in Denver overturned last Friday an earlier ruling that the International Business Machines Corporation owed the Telex Corporation nearly $260million in antitrust damages, most of the attention fell on the fortunes of I.B.M. But what about Telex?

title: Suspect in Hospital Shooting Served Half a Jail Term
description: The 19yearold former convict accused of wounding a police officer and killing a man who came to his aid during a shootout at St. Vincent's Hospital Wednesday had been sentenced to a 10month prison term on Aug. 29, but for some reason that could not be learned yesterday had been released from jail less than five months later.

title: I.C.C. Rejects a Rate Rise Of 7% for Most Railroads
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected yesterday a request by most of the nation's railroads to increase freight rates by 7 per cent on Feb. 5.

title: DRIVE TO STEP UP WAR AID TO SAIGON OPENS IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Administration opened an uphill battle in Congress today for additional military aid for the Saigon Government with a claim that North Vietnam was moving one and perhaps two other combat divisions into South Vietnam.

title: 2 ARE ARRAIGNED IN HOLDUP KILLING
description: Two Brooklyn men were arraigned on murder charges yesterday in the fatal shooting of woman bookkeeper and the wounding of two coworkers in a Queens holdup on Wednesday,

title: DRUG DEALS LAID TO VINCENT PAPA
description: A key witness in Federal District Court here yesterday identified Vincent Papa as a major heroin supplier.

title: Goldin Plans Sale Of City Securities To Civil Employes
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday that he would set up a procedure to sell city securities to municipal employes through a voluntary payroll deduction program.

title: Saudi Fails in West Coast Bank Bid
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 30Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian financier, has been rebuffed in his attempt to buy a onethird interest in the First National Bank of San Jose.

title: Simon Lowers Forecast On OPEC Cash BuildUp
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon, citing a detailed new Treasury analysis, told Congress today that the buildup of petrodollars in the oilexporting countries would be much less in the years ahead than was estimated last year after the sharp increase in the mice of oil.

title: Proposed Tax Seen Adding $8Million to Cost of Gas
description: President Ford's proposed tax of $3 a barrel on crude oil and 37 cents a thousand cubic feet on natural gas would cost the nation's natural gas consumers $8billion a year, Louis R. Reif, president of the National Fuel Gas Company, told about 50 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

title: 2 ARE ARRAIGNED IN HOLDUP KILLING
description: Two Brooklyn men were arraigned on murder yesterday in the fatal shooting of a woman bookkeeper and the wounding of two coworkers in a Queens holdup on Wednesday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Commissar to Be Reckoned With
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 30The announcement this week in Peking that Teng Hsiaoping had been appointed chief of staff and Chang Chunchiao the chief political commissar of the armed forces was the second time this month that the two names have been linked. Earlier Mr. Teng's name, followed by that of Mr. Chang, led a list of 12 Deputy Premiers appointed by the the National People's Congress in its first session in a decade, which unveiled China's new leadership structure.

title: Excerpts From Governor Carey's Message to the Legislature on the 7576 Budget
description: Three weeks ago I told you that the Government of New York State is in need of strong action to avert financial crisis. Today I will detail the magnitude of that crisis and the steps I recommend to meet it.

title: E. Bruce Clark, 79, Dies; DentalCeramics Pioneer
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 Dr. E. Bruce Clark, Pittsburgh dentist, researcher and writer on dental subjects, died Monday in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Amnesty Deadline Extended to March 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Ford today extended until March 1 the deadline for Vietnamera draft evaders and military deserters to apply for clemency.

title: Jet With 41 Crashes in Sea At Istanbul During Blackout
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 30 (UPI)A Turkish Airlines twinengine jetliner crashed into the Sea of Marmra here today with 41 persons aboard when a power failure blacked out the runway during landing, airport officials said.

title: Bargaining May Erase Some Parts of Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30One immediate line of speculation about Governor Carey's budget proposal centered on which parts of it might be negotiating items to be surrendered in compromise with the two parties that control the Legislature.

title: Dress Union May Strike If Raise Is Withheld Here
description: The dress board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union warned yesterday of a possible strike if employers go through with plans to withhold payment of a 6 per cent wage increase due next month under the present threeyear contract.

title: WIRETAPPING LAW AT ISSUE IN STATE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30  Key state legislators today questioned the proposed sixyear extension of New Jersey's wiretapping law, voicing doubt especially about the use of consent recordings of one party to a conversation without court approval.

title: 9 Federal Offices In Washington Get Bombing Threats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 30 (UPI)  A flurry of bomb threats to at least nine Federal offices in Washington set guards searching today, but only two buildings were evacuated and no bombs were found. The warning telephone calls followed the explosion yesterday of a bomb causing $350,000 damage at the State Department.

title: Thoeni Wins Cup Slalom In France
description: CHAMONIX, France, Jan. 30 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni, Italy's 23yearold world and Olympic champion, showed his masterly form again today and won the World Cup slalom race of the Arlberg Kandahar ski tournament.

title: Indians Balk at a Role in Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Some of the people who run the bicentennial sat down with a group of Indian leaders here today to talk about their celebration of the country's 200th anniversary.

title: Open Interest
Mayors Call on Congress For Vast Emergency Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30A delegation of mayors, calling President Ford's economic program inadequate to meet the crisis afflicting the nation's cities, urged Congress today to enact a multibilliondollar program of emergency aid for city and state governments.

title: . . . and Away From It
description: By all odds the most dubious of the economies made by Governor Carey in his proposed state budget, discussed more fully below, is the elimination of $360,000a flyspeck in the total budgetto keep alive the Commission on Public Employe Pension and Retirement Systems.

title: Collision Halts River Traffic
description: CHALMETTE, La., Jan, 30 (UPI)Three oil barges and an empty freighter collided on the Mississippi River yesterday, creating a wall of fire that paralyzed 15 miles of the nation's longest inland waterway.

title: Police Here Open a Campaign For Stricter Controls on Guns
description: In an attempt to convince the public of the need for stricter gun controls in the city, the Police Department announced yesterday that it would issue a daily list of illegal guns recovered by the police, along with a summary of gunconnected crimes and arraignments.

title: 'Nothing by Chance' Casts Biplane as a Screen Hero
description: "Nothing by Chance," playing at the Fine Arts Theater, is a pretty documentary about flying that comes a cropper by trying too hard to flog too much nostalgia and significance out of what is essentially a summertime barnstorming jaunt in a pack of old planes. The group of dedicated pilots and parachutists is headed by Richard ("Jonathan Livingston Seagull") Bach.Filmed in color as the members of the self-proclaimed Great American Flying Circus, established 1922, hopscotched across middle America, landing in pastures and stubble fields to sell rides at $3 to small-town residents, it is at its best in the air.It is then that this film needs none of the forgettable narration written by Mr. Bach and delivered with furry smoothness by Hugh Downs to sell the romance of flying the brighly colored little 1929 biplanes or the equally impressive glories of the countryside below.But when the participants come to earth and labor, at times painfully, to wrench mystique and profundity out of flying, planes and the Grant Wood people its cameras favor, "Nothing by Chance" lapses into tedium.None of the talk can make it more than what it isa simple valentine to a bygone era, full of bright color and shallow sentiment.

title: 260 POLICE OUSTED AS P.B.A. REJECTS BEAME PROPOSAL
description: The dismissal of 260 city policemen, the first Civil Service workers to be laid off since the Depression years, was ordered by Mayor Beanie yesterday after the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Ken McFeeley, rejected a city proposal for laborcontract concessions that would have forestalled the discharges.

title: Lisbon's Socialists Are Set Back Again By the Communists
description: LISBON, Jan. 30The Socialist party has suffered its second defeat in eight days at the hands of the Communists with the banning by the armed forces of four street demonstrations scheduled for tomorrow.

title: The Pop Life
description: Looking at rock as a popular art as well as a business, one is sorely tempted to paraphrase the old saying about God and man: If rock music hadn't had to deal with a recession, it would have had to invent one.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: People and Business
description: We need to rebuild confidence in our economy and get it rolling again. That requires actionnot words, Cornell C. Maier, president and chief executive officer of the Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation, said yesterday. Backing up his words with action, Mr. Maier disclosed that Kaiser is changing its policy this year and replacing company vehicles one year earlier than normal. The change will result in the immediate purchase of over 100 new vehicles, the company reported.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Before you rush up down or across town to the corner of First Avenue and 74th Street to try a dinner at the Anastasia Restaurant, as I am about to advise you to do, bear the following in mind:

title: DOUGLAS ON MEND AND KEEPS BUSY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Associate Justice William 0. Douglas, who was partially paralyzed by a stroke New Year's Eve, is on the mend, but he will probably not be able to rejoin his colleagues on the United States Supreme Court before midMarch, at the earliest.

title: Books of The Times
description: Sooner or later, I'm going to have to tell you that this delightful little book is all about big ideas. So I may as well get over with at the start. Elting E. Morison's From KnowHow to Nowhere: The Development of American Technology asks how we developed from a society that in 1800 lacked the technical wherewithal to build even a 26mile canal between the Charles and Merrimack rivers, to one that less than two centuries later could put men on the moon without a serious hitch. It wonders what happened to us in the course of that miraculous metamorphosis, why we are suddenly in such trouble, and where we ought to go from here. It tries to locate the role of reason in our future, and of technology itself, and even human beings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Gillies, an Executive Of Castagna Construction
description: Harry W. Gillies, vice president and treasurer of Castagna & Son, a construction concern with headquarters in Manhasset, L.I., died Monday of cancer in a Boston nursing home. He was 59 years old and lived at 101 Witherbee Avenue, Pelham Manor. N.Y.

title: Copper Price Cuts Continue But Industry's Layoffs Up
description: Price cutting continued yesterday in the copper Industry, and there were several layoffs announced by copper producers.

title: For Those Who Dare Seek the Future, No Lack of Soothsayers
description: In these uncertain times, who knows what the future will bring? The answer may be somewhere out there, depending on which fortune teller, seer, clairvoyant or psychic you go to.

title: Mass for Mary Foote Moore
description: A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Wednesday at 10 A.M. by Cardinal Cooke for Mary Foote Moore, the wife of John D.J. Moore, the United States Ambassador to Ireland. Mrs. Moore died in Dublin on Jan. 23, at the age of 64.

title: Parties in Thailand Taking First Steps Toward a Coalition
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 30 Thailand's Democratic party received conditional agreement today from two conservative parties to form a coalition government, a spokesman for the Democrats said.

title: Of Lizards, Mites and Youngsters
description: What's that little red dot on the lizard, I asked the guy, and he said, Oh, that's its natural color. Well, I said, how come it's walking?

title: 10 Homes in Connecticut Are Linked to Bergman
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursing home operator who has been linked through family members, business associates and a public corporation to more than 60 homes in New York and New Jersey, also is disclosed to have links to at least 10 homes in Connecticut and possibly dozens elswhere.

title: Fuel vs. Education
description: A major Eastern university whose expenditure for oil, gas and electricity during the last year before the Arab embargo had been $660,000 is currently budgeting $1.3million for the same purposes. Despite stringent economies, resulting in a 20 per cent reduction in fuel consumption, that institution's energy bill will rise $1.8 million  nearly 300 per gent  in the 197576 academic year.

title: Hemingway Papers Open for Study In a Setting That Belies Their Vitality
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 30 an antiseptic setting that seems alien to the barrelchesfed, hard living novelist and adventurer, the literary remains of that towering but enigmatic figure known as Ernest Hemingway are being opened for research.

title: Carey's First Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30 With a greenclad budget proposal of 886 pages and some flinty challenges to legislators and other doubters, Governor Carey today began the task of adjusting to the legacy that Nelson A. Rockefeller left in moralobligation debt and a ganglia of services and agencies including a statewide system for higher education  that have made state government $10billionayear business. Mr. Carey finds himself seeking total tax increase of 8.6 per cent more than the state collected last year. At the same time, he is promising no new increase in school aid, and he is tying the promise of some additional localgovernment aid to his gasolinetax increases.

title: INDIA OPTIMISTIC ON NEXT HARVEST
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 30India's Food and Agriculture Minister expressed optimism today about the crucial spring harvest.

title: Mosley, Seton Hall Ace, Ineligible
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 30Glenn Mosley, Seton Hall University basketball star and the nation's leading rebounder, was ruled ineligible today. He was a victim of N.C.A.A. recruiting violations by three members of the university's athletic department who were suspended. The action was taken by Msgr. Thomas G. Fahy, the president of the university.

title: MORTGAGE RATES ARE CUT IN STATE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30Governor Byrne announced today that New Jersey's statutory ceiling for interest rates on convational mortgage loans would be reduced from 9 per cent to 9 per cent, effective immediately.
